HEADLINE: Administration Errs on Taxes, Kemp Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp said today that the Bush Administration was wrong in predicting that tax breaks for businesses that locate in poor areas would lose revenue for the Government.
"It is my opinion that enterprise zones will actually increase Government revenues by spawning new business and by putting unemployed people and resources back to work and back on the tax rolls," Mr. Kemp told the Senate Small Business Committee. 
 President Bush, like President Ronald Reagan, has urged creation of enterprise zones for a decade. Employers that locate in selected blighted areas would be forgiven capital-gains taxes and be allowed an immediate tax deduction of up to $50,000 a year for spending on equipment. Workers would get a tax credit on part of their wages.
The White House Office of Management and Budget, the Congressional Budget Office and the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation have forecast that creation of those enterprise zones would cost as much as $1.8 billion over five years.
Mr. Kemp also disagreed with many in the Administration who say the economy is already recovering from recession.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Higher; Gold Down $3 in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the major currencies yesterday in thin, uninspired trading.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery dropped $3 an ounce, to $367.60. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $367.35, off $3.05 from late Friday. 
 Currency dealers said the dollar traded in a narrow range and ended slightly higher as the market corrected itself from Friday's drop.
"It was very thin trading, very quiet, with just a little profit taking," said Karen Kluge, a corporate adviser for foreign-exchange trading at Credit Suisse in New York.
John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Algemene Banc Nederland in New York, said the market was being driven by technical considerations.
"I think we need another round of news positive about the U.S." economy before the dollar is pushed higher, he said.
Economic indicators due later this week include durable-goods orders for June, mid-July auto sales and the Government's first report on the gross national product for the second quarter. Reports indicating strength in the economy would prop up interest rates and make the dollar more valuable.
In New York, the dollar gained 1.25 Japanese yen to close at 137.65 yen. Mr. McCarthy said the yen remained weak in the face of the country's brokerage scandal.
Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar slipped 0.45 yen, to close at 136.65 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 137.43 yen.
In New York, the British pound fell to $1.6795, from $1.69425 late Friday. In London, it slipped to $1.681, from $1.69.
Against the German mark, the dollar rose in New York to 1.762 marks, from 1.748.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.5255 Swiss francs, up from 1.51125; 5.9805 French francs, up from 5.9360; 1,311.875 Italian lire, up from 1,303.75, and 1.15475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15975.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $369.90 an ounce, from $370.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold's closing bid was $369.85, down from $370 on Friday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 67 cents, to close at $370.52.
Silver for current delivery fell 6.1 cents on New York's Comex, to $4.325 a troy ounce. Silver also fell in London, to a late bid price of $4.39, from $4.40.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Late Premed Programs for Graduates

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
LIBERAL arts graduates unhappy in or out of the job market, nurses, engineers and others interested in midcareer changes can become doctors if they have the dedication, persistence and enthusiasm, plus a respectable scholastic average. Many are doing just that, as schools that have had programs in place for some time have noticed a large increase in applicants since the beginning of the recession.
For the last few years, Goucher College in Towson, Md., has had a premed program intended for such persons, and especially for liberal arts majors who decide they would like to become doctors after working at other jobs following college graduation. 
 "We have an 87 percent placement success in medical schools," Barbara Berkowitz, director of Goucher's post-baccalaureate premedical program, said recently.
She works closely with Dr. George Delahunty, associate professor of biology, in processing and selecting candidates for the program, which requires eight intensive semester courses in basic sciences starting in June and continuing for a year. Those who took basic sciences in their undergraduate programs can have some required courses waived, but they must then take more advanced science courses to make up the semester hours.
"We prefer liberal arts majors, art, English, psychology, music and others," she said, "although we have taken nurses, physicians' assistants and electrical engineers into the program who do offer some science courses."
Other premed programs are available for such career changes, most notably one at Bryn Mawr College, near Philadelphia, which this year has 55 students. Goucher has 26.
The Goucher program takes a liberal view of scores achieved on the Scholastic Aptitude Tests. Entry requirements for Bryn Mawr's program are more stringent. Goucher likes combined marks of 1,100 or more, along with a good scholastic record of around a B average. But it has accepted students offering combined marks of 950, considered quite low in terms of the aptitude tests, which measure verbal and mathematics skills.
"We use our intuition about accepting students for the program," Mrs. Berkowitz said. "Some talented people do have low S.A.T. marks, but maybe they have better sensitivity. As long as they can do the work, such as passing two semesters of organic chemistry, we don't object to the lower marks." In some instances, students do have good college marks but do not fare well in the exam-taking.
Sometimes she urges prospective students to "wait a year and do volunteer work in a medical setting" to be sure they are really interested.
This year's class, which began studies in June, consists mostly of women. "Sometimes the classes are 50-50," she said, "but this year we have 21 women and 5 men."
She does not know why so many women applied and were accepted this year, but she suggested that perhaps more women have become disenchanted with working for corporations or have had difficulty finding jobs because of the recession.
"We have no nurses this year, but we did last year," she said. "It's a relatively young class this year with ages ranging from 22 to 38 years, and we have taken some students in past years as old as 46." The program has no limit on age for entry.
About half a dozen of this year's students recently graduated from college, and another half a dozen have been out of college about a year. "We have majors in English, fine arts, Russian literature and language, mathematics and psychology in the current class, she said. "We have had a Ph.D. in anthropology, several computer science majors and some Peace Corps workers in past years, as well as many children or other relatives of doctors."
The current class started by taking "a very intense" summer course, which is the equivalent of two semesters of basic chemistry, called Principles of Chemistry. Then in the fall and spring semesters the students continue taking basic sciences -- two semesters of physics, two of biology and two of organic chemistry.
An advantage, Mrs. Berkowitz believes, is that all of the premed students take courses together as a cohesive group, and not with undergraduates. It makes for strong and enduring friendships among the group, she said, adding, "That is a good marketing point for us."
In January, she said, it is recommended that all the students get some "hands on" experience in a hospital. "We have a working arrangement with the University of Maryland Medical Health System to provide them with such experience," she explained.
In the spring, the students take review sessions for the medical college aptitude tests required for admission to medical school.
As for costs, she estimates the total for the year at somewhat more than $15,000. The tuition is $10,400, and Mrs. Berkowitz suggested that by sharing apartments and brown-bagging lunches a student could get along on another $5,000 for rent and food.

HEADLINE: Sandinistas Shed a Bit of Their Past

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 22

 BODY:
The Sandinista Front took the first tentative steps toward giving up its leftist guerrilla past to create the structure of a democratic political party during a congress that ended on Sunday night.
But the existing leadership retained control and fought off the demands of dissidents for profound changes, both in the internal structure of the party and in its ideology and world view. 
 While dropping references in the organizational documents to being a Marxist-Leninist party, the nearly 600 delegates decided to continue calling their party socialist, revolutionary and anti-imperialist.
After three days of debate, the delegates voted to retain in the nine-member National Directorate most of the former guerrilla commanders who dominated Nicaragua in the nearly 11 years the Sandinistas held power.
 
Ortega to Lead Party
 Daniel Ortega Saavedra, who served as President of Nicaragua until losing last year's elections to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and a broad opposition coalition, was elected to serve as secretary general in addition to continuing on the Directorate.
Two longtime members of the Sandinista inner circle who had not previously been on the Directorate -- Sergio Ramirez Mercado and Rene Nunez Tellez -- were elected to replace Gen. Humberto Ortega, who had resigned as a condition of his remaining army commander under the Chamorro Government, and Mr. Nunez's brother Carlos, who died of cancer last October.
Tomas Borge, the last surviving founder of the Sandinista Front, who was Interior Minister and head of the secret police during the years in power, argued that conditions in the party and the country were not right to replace the original leadership.
 
'Economic or Political Errors'
 Dismissing the demands of many party members to vote for members of the Directorate on an individual basis, Mr. Borge said that "if it is necessary to judge economic or political errors then the Directorate should be judged in its entirety."
The single slate for the Directorate emerged from congresses held earlier in the country's 17 departments. There was opposition to the single slate concept in some of the departmental congresses, especially in the capital, but it was always in the minority.
In the report of the National Directorate, the leadership recognized that many of its policies while in power had created the dissatisfaction among voters that led to the Sandinistas' defeat in 1990.
But Mr. Ortega asserted that the Sandinista Government had been forced to undertake land seizures, price controls and other unpopular economic measures in response to the guerrilla war mounted by United States-backed contras. The report closed with a continued rejection of capitalism and said the Sandinistas would continue to seek "a new economic-social model."
Rafael Solis, a longtime leader of the Sandinista parliamentary delegation and now a leading dissident, said in a long interview published in the newspaper El Nuevo Diario that blaming the contra war on foreign intervention had been "part of the rhetoric and our propaganda," adding that even though the contras received help from the United States the Sandinistas had been aided by the Soviet Union.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Sandinista Front decided to create a democratic political party during congress that ended Sunday. Tomas Borge, right, last surviving founder of the Sandinista Front, hugged Daniel Ortega Saavedra, who was elected to serve as secretary general. HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Banco de Santander C.D.'s Are Rated AA by S.& P.

 BODY:
Banco de Santander, the Spanish bank that recently purchased a large financial interest in New Jersey's largest bank, has been given an AA rating on its long-term certificates of deposit from the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the rating agency. The agency also affirmed the A-1+ rating on the bank's commercial paper.
At the same time, the subordinate debt of the bank's wholly owned subsidiary, Banco Santander Puerto Rico, has been raised to a AA- from an A+. The certificates of deposit of the Puerto Rican subsidiary also were raised to AA/A-1+ from AA-/ A-1+, affecting about $40 million of the subsidiary's debt. 
 In upgrading the ratings, S.& P. said that the loan quality remains strong and that a buoyant Spanish economy continues to benefit all Spanish banks.
In May, Banco de Santander of Spain bought a 13.3 percent interest in First Fidelity Bancorp of New Jersey for more than $220 million. The purchase involved 9.5 million shares of First Fidelity common. At the time, Emilio Boton, chairman of the Spanish bank, acknowledged the bank's interest in United States banks, saying, "We looked at some 80 banks in 38 states before deciding to invest in First Fidelity."

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
New Loss Is Reported By Cummins

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Losses continue unabated at the Cummins Engine Company as sluggish sales of big trucks have shrunk orders for the large engines that are its primary product and aggressive competitors have reduced its share of what market there is left.
Yesterday the company reported a second-quarter loss of $17.2 million, compared with a profit of $6.1 million, or 15 cents a share, in the 1990 period, and said it expected the losses to continue at least through the third quarter. Sales in the second quarter rose only slightly, to $877.6 million from $871.3 million. 
 The company's stock closed yesterday at $38, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
A Bitter Disappointment
 For Cummins, the loss came as a bitter disappointment after a decade of rebuilding plants, fending off Japanese manufacturers and gaining important investors and customers. "In this business, if you can't make money in the second quarter you have a problem," said Mitchell I. Quain, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder. "Spring is spare-parts shipment time, and parts are the most profitable part of their business."
Even the company conceded that the outlook was grim. Cummins, which is based in Columbus, Ind., said in a statement that it continued to see no sign of improvement in the North American heavy-truck market. In the first half of this year, 48,083 class 8 heavy trucks were sold in this country, according to the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. If the current trend continues that would produce annual sales of about 98,000 trucks. This represents a 34 percent drop from sales of 148,361 as recently as 1988.
 
Economy Seen as Issue
 "The issue here is the economy," said John E. McGinty, an analyst with First Boston. "If the economy improves, then trucks sales should improve as well."
But Cummins may not automatically benefit from an upturn in truck sales. After holding more than 50 percent of the market for heavy-duty truck engines for most of the 1980's, the share of Cummins has slipped sharply in the last few years. The company said its market share was 41 percent in the first half of this year.
Unlike buyers of automobiles, who can expect to get a Ford engine in a Ford car, buyers of heavy trucks specify which of a limited range of engines they want installed. Caterpilllar Inc. and a newly revived Detroit Diesel Corporation have both picked up sales at the expense of Cummins.
Roger Penske, the auto racer and business executive, bought 80 percent of Detroit Diesel from the General Motors Corporation and began aggressively marketing a new series of engines. Detroit Diesel's market share grew to more than 20 percent in the first quarter from 12.4 percent last year and 3.5 percent in 1988.
"Penske has been very successful in getting engines into the market," said Steven J. Colbert, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "That has impacted Cummins in both share and price levels."
 
Dividend Cut to 5 Cents
 Analysts are estimating that Cummins will lose between $70 million and $100 million this year, on top of a loss of $165 million last year. To conserve cash, the company slashed its dividend earlier this year to 5 cents from 55 cents a share.
One bright spot in an otherwise bleak picture, analysts said, was the company's smaller diesel engines, used in automotive and off-road vehicles, and its widening profit margins for these products.
But the continuing losses are eroding the $250 million in cash the company received last year from the Ford Motor Company, Tenneco Inc. and the Kubota Corporation. "If the market does not come back the way they hope, they could end up in a real tight cash position," Mr. Colbert of Prudential Securities said. He added that this might force the company to take financial actions that would dilute the value of its shares.

HEADLINE: Bush Returns to Prepare for Moscow

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
President Bush returned to Washington today to prepare for a summit meeting in Moscow next week. Officials say Mr. Bush wants the session to mark the start of an era in which economics and cooperation on regional issues dominate Soviet-American relations.
The formal purpose of the meeting is to sign the first treaty that would reduce long-range nuclear missiles, which Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded at their meeting in London last week after nine years of negotiations. 
 The two leaders will also talk about a new phase of arms control, including more possible reductions in nuclear arms, and about Soviet-American cooperation in halting the spread of nuclear weapons around the world, a senior Administration official said today.
But the official said: "The headline is clearly not going to be arms control. This has to be the summit where you begin defining the relationship for the 90's, when the dynamic is going to shift more to economic and political and regional issues. That, certainly, will be the bulk of the summit next week."
 
Tentative Outline
 According to tentative plans outlined by American officials today, Mr. Bush is to leave Washington for Moscow early on Monday morning for Moscow, where he will meet with Mr. Gorbachev the two next days. Administration officials here said today that Mr. Bush was expected to travel to Kiev on Thursday, Aug. 1, as part of his effort to foster relations with leaders of the individual Soviet republics.
Walking a fine line between encouraging opposition groups in the Soviet Union and supporting Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush is also expected to meet with a group of Soviet republic leaders, including representatives of the Baltic region, and to talk separately with Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian Federation.
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the President's travel plans were not final and that the White House was considering other side trips, including one possibly to Leningrad. The President is expected to return to the United States on Aug. 2.
The ceremony surrounding the signing of the strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start, will provide much of the pomp and the most evident historical moment of the Moscow meeting. Because the details of the treaty were ironed out by the two leaders in London last week, the signing is likely to be overshadowed by other issues at the core of the new Soviet-American relationship.
 
New Cooperation
 Testing the new cooperation between Moscow and Washington that was demonstrated by the Persian Gulf war, the two leaders will talk about joint efforts to resolve the Arab-Israeli dispute, officials said.
To that end, they said the White House announcement today that Mr. Bush wanted an answer from Israel about an American proposal for a Middle East peace conference before he gets to Moscow was in part an effort to make as much progress as possible before the summit begins.
Economic and trade issues will also dominate the agenda for the Moscow talks, although officials said Mr. Bush was no more prepared to offer Mr. Gorbachev major financial assistance than he was when the Soviet leader met with the heads of the seven largest industrial democracies in London last week.
"Gorbachev went away from London saying he was satisfied enough, but clearly he wanted more," a senior official said today. "Our job is to convince him the things he wanted, like a stablization fund or debt restructuring, are putting the cart before the horse and that what he needs is first of all a program that is accepted by the international and business community."
With Mr. Bush under pressure from some allies to accelerate financial aid to the Soviets, American officials said they expected Mr. Gorbachev to press for a more concrete program than Mr. Bush was willing to offer.
 
I.M.F. Program Sought
 "Gorbachev's view, understandably, is something like, 'I've got to convince the political leadership and all the rest falls into place,' " an official said. "What Bush has to convince him of is that it isn't he, President Bush, that Gorbachev needs to talk to, but the bankers and businessmen. That means going to the International Monetary Fund and coming up with with a specific program."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev plan to touch on regional issues apart from the Middle East, officials said, including Afghanistan and Cuba. Administration officials said planning for the session demonstrates how closely the United States is being drawn into Soviet affairs, including the elaborate arrangements for Mr. Bush's meetings with republic leaders.
Mr. Yeltsin, who has already been received in the White House, will be given a private meeting with Mr. Bush, officials said. But other republic leaders will meet the American President in a group in a more social setting, perhaps a dinner at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence in Moscow, officials said.
"We don't want to become part of the problem, but when you're dealing with the Soviet Union these days you're flirting almost by definition with internal problems," a senior official said.
"Take the Kiev trip," he said. "We want to show our interest and respect but we don't want to leave the city having made more difficult a solution to the problems they have with Moscow."
This delicate equation also will come into play when the two leaders talk about the civil strife in Yugoslavia.
Although the Soviet Union has been generally cooperative, a senior official said, the two countries have clear differences over Yugoslavia. The Soviet Union has stressed the country's "territorial integrity," while Washington could accept some partitioning as long as it is done peacefully and democratically, the official said.

HEADLINE: New Head of Nuclear Commission Seeks Change

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Declaring that he was not content to "watch industry stagnate as it has for the last dozen years," the new chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that he wanted to lay the groundwork for resuming construction of nuclear power plants, with safer and more economical plants.
But the chairman, Ivan Selin, an engineer and management expert who took office at the beginning of this month, said in his first extended meeting with reporters that much, including the industry's public image, would have to change before a utility could order a new reactor. 
 "There isn't any real future for the industry unless power plants are safe and unless the public understands how they're safe," he said, echoing remarks he made to the commission staff last week. The industry's needs are changing, he said then, and while "strong public support was not needed to maintain the status quo" it would be needed for new plants.
All the nuclear plants ordered since 1974 have been canceled, but two manufacturers are seeking approval for new designs, which they say would be cheaper to build and easier to operate than the current plants.
 
Making Waves in First Weeks
 Mr. Selin has made waves in his first three weeks in office by his interest in the safety of a Massachusetts nuclear plant that a watchdog group wants closed and by slowing development of a new rule allowing plants to renew their operating licenses. His actions have drawn praise from some members of Congress and caused concern in the industry.
He acknowledged today, "My tenure has started off with a little more momentum than I had intended."
A week after taking office, Mr. Selin visited the Massachusetts plant, Yankee Rowe, with a group of Congressmen, including Representative Peter H. Kostmayer, the Pennsylvania Democrat who is chairman of the House Interior Subcommittee on Energy and the Environment.
The last commission chairman, Kenneth Carr, had "become an advocate for the industry," Mr. Kostmayer said in an interview, adding that he felt that was "entirely inappropriate" for a regulator. Mr. Kostmayer said Mr. Selin appeared to be taking a more open view.
But a nuclear watchdog group has already taken issue with the way Mr. Selin handled his tour of Yankee Rowe. Robert Pollard, a safety engineer with the Union of Concerned Scientists, pleaded unsuccessfully with the commission to be allowed on the tour. He gained access only by persuading Mr. Kostmayer that it was unfair for Mr. Selin to meet privately with Yankee Rowe's operators while the commission was hearing his group's case against the plant. Afterward, Mr. Pollard expressed little hope that Mr. Selin would enforce commission regulations any more vigorously than his predecessors.
Yankee Rowe, at 31 years old, is the oldest operating nuclear power plant in the country, and critical steel parts have become brittle because of radiation. Mr. Pollard's group maintains that the reactor's owners have failed to complete safety analyses to demonstrate that the plant is safe, and that commission rules stipulate that it must close.
Mr. Selin has tentatively scheduled a vote of the four commissioners on that subject on July 31.
The industry is also somewhat apprehensive about the new chairman, a former Under Secretary of State for Management. Plant owners were concerned about Mr. Selin's decision to slow the process of developing regulations to extend plant licenses. As Mr. Carr's term ended in June, the commission voted to adopt ground rules for extending the licenses of power plants but left the details to be worked out by its staff. Mr. Selin has decided the commission must review the final language. He said the earlier approval "looked like unseemly haste."
 
A Different Background
 Mr. Selin's background is markedly different from that of the last two chairmen, both of whom were retired admirals. Although Mr. Selin has a Ph.D. in electrical engineering fro Yale University, he is stressing management.
For example, he said today that the nuclear industry was not only inefficient to run but also difficult to regulate. He noted that there were 111 operating plants, with 80 designs. And even "the ones that are the same are different," he said. Applying regulations consistently is therefore difficult, he said.
He has also approached complex issues with a touch of humor. At a recent briefing on Yankee Rowe, he interrupted a commission staff engineer whose presentation was particularly thick with acronyms and technical language. Mr. Selin, who speaks six languages, said, "At the risk of setting a standard we can't live up to in the future, could you repeat that in English?"
In his session with reporters today, he said one problem facing the industry was the bad public image of everything nuclear since the collapse of the Energy Department's nuclear weapons complex. Civilian radioactive waste can be safely stored for decades in casks outside reactor buildings, he said, but the bomb makers have had trouble containing their wastes.
"High-level waste is high-level waste, and if the Government doesn't handle the waste properly, we're going to have a serious problem in both safety and perception," he said.
He listed the priorities of his five-year term as establishing a procedure for extending the licenses of older plants, developing a small number of standardized reactor designs that would be licensed generically and establishing a streamlined process for licensing new plants. This last point is already the center of intense debate, with some citizen groups saying that the leading proposals would eliminate public input.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Former BMC Chairman Assumes Posts at Case

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Since April, when James K. Ashford resigned unexpectedly as chairman of the J. I. Case Company, the heavy-equipment unit of Tenneco Inc., analysts have wondered who would replace him. And since last week, when Robert J. Carlson, 61, resigned as chairman of BMC Industries, analysts have wondered where he was going.
Yesterday, both mysteries were solved. Tenneco named Mr. Carlson as Case's new president and chief executive officer, effective immediately. Election to the board is scheduled for the near future. 
 "Sure, we had plenty of good young managers in place, but we needed someone with strong industry background, and Carlson fit the bill," said Christine LeLaurin, a Tenneco spokeswoman. Apparently, Case fit the bill for Mr. Carlson, too. As he put it: "I like jumping into alligator ponds."
That may be an apt description of Case right now. A combination of the recession and mismanagement of inventories resulted in a loss of $147 million in the first quarter. Rick James, a Case spokesman, conceded that the company would probably report a loss for the year.
Analysts, too, predict losses. "Case has been a problem child for decades, and Tenneco finally realized it had to bring someone in with a strong personality and real industry knowledge to run it," said Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc.
Mr. Carlson's last 12 years have been evenly split between the United Technologies Corporation and BMC, a manufacturer of electronic and optical products. He spent the first 29 years of his career at Deere & Company, Case's much larger, and consistently profitable, competitor.
Case currently is less concerned with losses than with clearing out its high inventory. The company has been furiously discounting, a practice that has depressed prices but, Mr. Carlson said, is "finally cleaning up the balance sheet."
Since Tenneco has mandatory retirement at 65, Mr. Carlson has four years to turn Case around and groom his successor. He speaks of "bringing some discipline to procedures" and focusing on "new philosophies in dealer and distributor relationships."
Mr. Carlson has a bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of Minnesota. He and his wife, Joann, who have four children, recently moved to Racine, Wisc., six minutes from Case's office.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Amoco, ARCO and Ashland Report Declines in Earnings

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 22

 BODY:
Two large oil companies operating mainly in the United States, the Amoco Corporation and ARCO, said profits fell sharply in the second quarter. Net income fell by 37.2 percent at Amoco and by 37.1 percent at ARCO.
Ashland Oil Inc., the nation's second-largest refiner after the Sun Company, said net income declined 33.3 percent in the quarter. 
 Amoco and ARCO said their refining and chemical units were hurt by the weak economy, which reduced demand and pushed prices lower, and by tumbling natural gas prices. Amoco has the largest natural gas reserves in North America and is one of the largest gas producers.
ARCO, another big supplier of natural gas, posted lower profit in gasoline marketing because of a pricing war on the West Coast, where it is the market leader. Amoco does not sell gasoline west of the Rocky Mountains.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Amoco
Net income dropped to $238 million, or 48 cents a share, from $379 million, or 75 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. Revenues for the nation's fifth-largest oil company fell 9.4 percent, to $6.74 billion from $7.44 billion. The Chicago-based company said its profits were reduced by $68 million in special charges in the recent quarter, which included $43 million to close a filament plant in Bainbridge, Ga.
Costs for paring the work force in its Canadian operations, to 3,055 employees from 4,550 by the end of 1993, accounted for another $25 million.
Unlike many large gas producers, Amoco increased output in the quarter, by 10 percent in the United States, to 2.3 billion cubic feet a day. Natural-gas prices during the quarter fell to an average of $1.21 for 1,000 cubic feet, from $1.42 in the comparable quarter a year ago, according to Natural Gas Intelligence, a trade publication. Amoco did not disclose its average gas price.
Amoco's share price rose 37.5 cents today, to $53.375, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
ARCO
Net income declined to $246 million, or $1.51 a share, from $391 million, or $2.36 a share, in the second quarter of 1990. Revenues rose 5 percent, to $4.24 billion from $4.04 billion.
Profits in oil-and-gas production rose sharply in the quarter, to $163 million from $96 million. ARCO's average crude price, which reflects an average transportation cost of $6 a barrel, rose to $12.66 a barrel, from $10.61 in the period last year.
Natural-gas output fell 15.5 percent in the United States, the location of most ARCO gas reserves, while worldwide production of crude and natural-gas liquids rose 4.8 percent.
In refining and marketing, however, profits fell by more than half, to $85 million from $175 million, largely because of a bitter pricing war with the Chevron Corporation and the Unocal Corporation in the West. The 1991 profit would have been much lower without $37 million added from a favorable tax adjustment in Brazil. ARCO, based in Los Angeles, had posted its biggest profit in refining and marketing in the 1990 second quarter.
ARCO's share price fell by $1.50 today, to $123.125, in trading on the Big Board.
 
Ashland Oil
Net income declined to $66.7 million, or $1.19 a share, from a company record of $100.0 million, or $1.79 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. The Ashland, Ky.-based company said revenues rose 4 percent, to $2.33 billion from $2.24 billion.
Refining profits fell to $79.5 million, from $127.1 million, but the Valvoline oil marketing unit posted a sharp gain, to $15.5 million, from $7.0 million a year ago, as sales rose by 28.6 percent, to $235.5 million. Chemical profits rose to $26.6 million from $22.8 million.
Ashland Oil's share price rose 25 cents today, to $30.875, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: PLAN WOULD LET BAGHDAD SELL OIL

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is drawing up a plan to allow the Security Council to remove some sanctions against Iraq to allow Baghdad to sell petroleum, senior Administration officials said today. The profits would be used to pay for food and medicine, war reparations and the destruction of weapons.
The plan, which was drafted by the State Department, is being circulated for review within the department and at the Pentagon, the White House and the Central Intelligence Agency. Officials said that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was expected to approve it. It would also need President Bush's approval before it could be presented to the United Nations Security Council as the basis for a resolution. 
If the Bush Administration puts the plan forward, as many officials expect, it will represent a major shift in policy. Currently, Iraq is not allowed to sell its oil because of stringent United Nations sanctions imposed after the invasion of Kuwait, and until now the Administration has argued that Iraq had hidden assets in its Central Bank as well as gold reserves that should be used to buy food and medicine, which are not covered by sanctions.
Administration officials said the examination of a new approach reflects a growing realization that the postwar economic strangulation was hurting the Iraqi people rather than weakening President Saddam Hussein's grip on power. The plan is a response to reports by independent medical teams, United Nations officials and the news media of widespread malnutrition and disease in Iraq, as well as an attempt to counter calls for a more sweeping removal of economic sanctions on humanitarian grounds, the officials said.
"We don't want to see more reports about massive starvation and disease in Iraq," said one senior Administration official who is working on the plan. "We know we will eventually have to go this way. We're not there yet, but we'll have to get there." Another senior official described the plan as "a good way to maintain the bulk of sanctions and not be on the wrong side of a potentially emotional issue."
The sanctions review comes at an uncomfortable time for the Administration, which charged again today that Iraq has not disclosed all the details of its secret nuclear program. "We are still very skeptical about their disclosures and believe they have more to tell us," the State Department's deputy spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said at the State Department briefing today.
Several days ago the five permanent Security Council members -- the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China -- gave Iraq until July 25 to declare a final inventory of its nuclear sites. But one senior Administration official today described the date as "an artificial deadline, not necessarily a turning point." The United States had threatened to resume bombing if Iraq did not comply.
 
'Absurd and Indefensible'
 The move to ease sanctions against Iraq was pressed at the United Nations today by Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the head of a United Nations Commission that is assessing Iraq's humanitarian needs. The Prince told the Security Council's sanctions committee about a worsening crisis for Iraq's civilian population and suggested that the country be allowed to sell oil to import food, medicine, and some agricultural and industrial materials.
Prince Sadruddin later told reporters that it was "absurd and indefensible" for the United Nations to pay for Iraq's humanitarian needs, "when numerous other urgent crises and disasters, from Bangladesh to the Horn of Africa, cry out for our attention." He added, "Iraq has considerable oil reserves and should pay to meet these needs herself."
The United States has found itself increasingly isolated in the Security Council as other members and officials have made a two-pronged argument: first, that the only way to force Iraq to pay for war reparations and for the elimination of its weapons of mass destruction, both mandated by Security Council resolutions,is with its own oil revenues; and second, that the Security Council should force Iraq to buy much-needed food and medicine with oil profits that could be monitored or even disbursed inside the country through the United Nations.
 
Special Account Suggested
 The first hint of a change in United States policy came in testimony last Thursday by John R. Bolton, the assistant Secretary of State for Interational Organizations, before a House foreign affairs subcommittee. Mr. Bolton described a new mechanism to provide humanitarian assistance "under a regime of tight controls and strict monitoring." He said that the United States was consulting with members of the Security Council and its coaltion partners "on the appropriate operational ways to do this."
One likely scenario would be for the United Nations to control Iraq's oil revenues through a special account or accounts. Thirty percent of the revenues would pay for reparations for Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last August, a formula worked out by the Security Council's sanctions committee, and the rest would pay other bills.
Administration officials stressed that oil sales would go forward only if strict conditions were met, and that the details of the plan still have to be worked out and discussed with coalition partners. Because an international body would control the funds, the officials argued that the plan does not reflect a weakening of international sanctions or of the Administration's resolve to continue to exert maximum pressure on Baghdad.
 
Policy About-Face
 But the plan is a significant departure from public statements by Mr. Bush and some senior officials in recent months that Mr. Hussein had to be punished. On May 7, Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser and the nominee for Director for Central Intelligence, said in a speech that "Iraqis will pay the price while he is in power." Mr. Gates added: "All possible sanctions will be maintained until he is gone." On May 20, Mr. Bush acknowledged to reporters that while there are some instances in which Iraq must sell its oil to comply with United Nations resolutions, "my view is we don't want to lift these sanctions as long as Saddam Hussein is in power."
But Administration officials have said, albeit quietly and reluctantly, that Mr. Hussein has successfully consolidated power since the end of the Persian Gulf war and may remain President of Iraq for years.

HEADLINE: Delta Insists That Its Bid Is Better

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 22

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines confronted the joint bid by T.W.A. and American for much of Pan Am by standing pat and calling its own $260 million offer a better one.
Delta executives said that if Pam Am accepted a separate United Airlines offer of $190 million for its South American and Caribbean operations, the total price with Delta's bid works out to the same $450 million that T.W.A. and American would pay for virtually the same assets. 
 "We think we have a deal that will be in the best interest of Pan Am's creditors," said Neil Monroe, a Delta spokesman. Pan American World Airways has accepted Delta's offer, but the ultimate decision will be made by a Federal bankruptcy court. Delta has also offered to invest $60 million in Pan Am to enable it to continue its Latin American operations.
 
Says It Has the Cash
 Despite three straight losing quarters, Delta says it has cash on hand to finance the purchase of Pan Am's European, African and Asian routes, plus the Northeastern shuttle. Delta completed a $476 million stock offering this year. Delta will not announce its results for the fiscal year that ended on June 30 until later this week, but Mr. Monroe said the airline was "well beyond" its war-related losses.
But some airline analysts still question the airline's financial strength. "Delta is healthy compared to the rest of the industry," said Daniel A. Hersh, an analyst in Denver with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards. "But they are not particularly healthy compared to other corporations."
Delta's efforts to capture Pan Am's routes come after years of such cautious expansion abroad that many in the industry wondered whether Delta was losing out to its rivals. The airline's executives say they are merely understated, not under-motivated.
 
'We Can Move Fast'
 "We don't make a lot of noise about what we're doing," said W. Whitley Hawkins, president and chief financial officer of Delta. "That probably gives us a reputation for being somewhat slower than we really are. When we need to, we can move fast."
Mr. Hawkins said the pace of events had left some of Delta's top executives a bit dizzy. Last week, a few of them could not even name all of the cities that the Pan Am deal would add to Delta's route map. "I'll bet there are some Pan Am executives who can't name all those cities either," Mr. Hawkins said with a laugh.
Three destinations that every Delta executive can name are Washington, New York and Boston. Mr. Hawkins said Delta had wanted a Northeast shuttle for years, but sat on the sidelines as the former Eastern Shuttle changed hands.
Ronald W. Allen, Delta's chairman and chief executive, said Delta's interest in a Northeast shuttle increased last year after the airline began New York-Los Angeles flights. "If some of those transcontinental travelers are going on to Boston or Washington, we don't want to lose them to another carrier," he said.
 
Started in Crop Dusting
 Delta, based in Atlanta, may extend its reach as far as Bombay and Moscow with the Pan Am deal, but it still boasts of never straying too far from its roots. The company always holds its annual meeting in Monroe, La., the town where the company was born in 1924 as a crop-dusting operation.
Virtually all of the company's top executives are home grown. Mr. Allen has been with Delta 27 years, joining even before he received his undergraduate degree at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta.
Mr. Hawkins began with Delta in 1955 as a transportation agent in Lexington, Ky. He insists that the company retains something of its small-town culture, despite growing to 66,000 employees, from fewer than 5,000, during his years there. "I don't think our corporate culture has changed in all that time," he said.
 
Avoided Labor Troubles
 With few unionized workers except pilots, Delta has avoided the kind of labor strife that contributed to the demise of Eastern Airlines this year. Several years ago, employees chipped in to buy the airline a $40 million Boeing 767-200 in gratitude for being spared layoffs during a recession.
Adding Pan Am employees would help Delta improve its international service, said Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst with Morgan Stanley in New York. "Pan Am's in-flight service has heaps of tradition," he said. "Their pilots' average age is 51. They've got flight attendants with a tremendous amount of international experience. There is a lot Delta can learn from them."
Delta has won respect for the quality of its domestic service. It tied for second place in a recent Consumer Reports magazine rating of domestic airlines, the only one of the largest airlines in the top five.
At home, Delta is moving to cement its dominance of Atlanta, buying the Eastern gates closest to the main terminal and seeking to buy Eastern's abandoned maintenance hangar. The hangar purchase would make it still more difficult for a rival to establish an Atlanta hub.
But ask Delta executives about these moves, and they say their aims are friendly. "We've always said we welcome another carrier to establish a hub here in Atlanta," Mr. Hawkins said. "We've told the city we would be glad to help them attract another airline."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With its offer to buy a large part of Pan Am's overseas operations, Delta Air Lines hopes to extend its reach from its busy hub at Atlanta's Hartsfield Airport, shown above last week, to as far as Bombay and Moscow. (Ken Hawkins for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American Express Says Profit Falls 20%; Revenue Is Up

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit fell 20 percent, to $256 million, or 53 cents a share, from $320 million, or 73 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenues rose nearly 5 percent, to $6.36 billion, from $6.06 billion in the 1990 period. 
 Profits at the company's charge-card business fell only slightly and two other units, IDS Financial Services and the Information Services Corporation, performed strongly.
After an unexpectedly troubled first quarter, in which American Express's charge-card business fell 25 percent, the latest overall performance was better than Wall Street expectations. Some analysts had expected profits to fall to 40 cents or less a share. The stock nevertheless slipped 75 cents yesterday, to close at $23.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The second-quarter results reflect a large write-off related to the stake Shearson Lehman Brothers held in a Los Angeles insurance company that invested heavily in "junk bonds." Shearson, American Express's troubled Wall Street investment house and its largest subsidiary, is taking a previously announced $144 million pretax write-off for its investment in the insurer, the First Capital Holdings Corporation.
 
$41 Million Tax Benefit
 Alison A. Deans, who follows American Express for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the second-quarter performance was helped, however, by an unexpected $41 million tax benefit from Shearson writing down the value of its First Capital investment. "I had expected it to be zero," she added, referring to the tax benefit.
Shearson posted an overall loss of $48.8 millon, compared with a gain of $26.5 million a year earlier. Second-quarter revenues rose more than 7 percent, to $2.81 billion, from $2.62 billion the year before.
Travel Related Services, the charge-card business that is the heart of American Express and its biggest profit contributor, reported a net income of $241 million, down 3 percent from $249 million a year ago. Revenues rose more than 2 percent, to $2.41 billion, from $2.35 billion.
Last April, when American Express reported first-quarter earnings, it surprised analysts and investors with the extent of the downturn at Travel Related Services. The first-quarter profit for the unit dropped 25 percent, to $162 million.
Ms. Deans of Smith Barney cautioned that the charge-card business in the second quarter was performing about as expected, but that the seeming improvement was mainly because of a first-quarter provision for bad-credit losses.
What surprised Ms. Deans, however, was an actual shrinkage in the number of American Express cardholders. Cards in force in the second quarter totaled 36.6 million, or 100,000 fewer than in the first quarter. But the figure was nearly 2 percent larger than the 35.9 million in the second quarter a year ago.
Charge-card volume, the total of goods and services purchased with American Express cards, was flat at $27.7 billion. The number of cards in customers' wallets and purses rose 1 percent in the United States, to 25.9 million, and 4.2 percent abroad, to 10.7 million.
This means, however, that actual purchases per card, an important measure of American Express's business, declined nearly 2 percent worldwide, to $756.83 from $771.58 last year.
 
Gain for IDS Financial
 IDS Financial Services, which mainly provides financial planning counseling, posted a 19 percent increase in profits, to $61.4 million. Revenues rose more than 12 percent, to $630.2 million.
The Information Services Corporation, which processes credit-card transactions and provides other computerized financial services, had a 16 percent rise, to $25.3 million. But revenues rose only 3 percent, to $219.9 million, reflecting some growth in new accounts despite the recession, American Express said.
At American Express Bank, the company's international commercial bank aimed at wealthy customers, profits fell nearly 20 percent, to $25.5 million, because of $155 million in nonperforming loans. That compared with a $37 million profit a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Hawaii Shows It Can Offer Health Insurance for All

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU

 BODY:
Residents of the Hawaiian Islands, more than 2,400 miles from the American mainland, have long complained that they are left out of major debates that ripple across the nation.
But on at least one big issue -- how to provide adequate medical care to all citizens -- health policy analysts say Hawaiians are well ahead of the rest of the country, and their state is being studied in Congress and by other state governments as a potential national model. 
 The 50th state is the only one that can boast of near-universal health care. Under a 17-year-old program that requires employers to pick up the cost of insurance premiums for any person working more than 20 hours a week, most of Hawaii's 1.1 million people have some kind of medical insurance. The unemployed, seasonal workers and those whose job does not include insurance are taken care of by state medical subsidies.
 
Some Special Circumstances
 In all, 98 percent of Hawaiians have some kind of medical insurance. By contrast, in the country as a whole, 14 percent of the population, or 34 million people, lack medical insurance and get no government subsidy. Most are wage earners who work for small or low-paying businesses.
Perhaps most surprising to many experts, the near-universal access to health care here has not led to soaring costs. While Hawaii ranks near the top of the states in cost of living, its average health insurance premium is near the bottom. For example, a family in Hawaii pays a premium of $263 a month, nearly half that of other states.
To be sure, Hawaii differs from the other 49 states in many important ways. The population is small, the climate is healthful, and the state has a long tradition of providing generous benefits to workers, most of whom belong to unions.
Even during the current recession in tourism, Hawaii has the lowest unemployment rate of any state, 2.8 percent; its insurance companies have to pay little compared to other states for hospital care for the unemployed. Its insurance industry is dominated by a few big companies, which can exercise strong bargaining power to keep doctors' and hospitals' fees down.
It is in the middle of an ocean, so businesses that might object to paying health care costs -- up to $1,000 a year per employee -- cannot simply move across a state line.
But while these oddities help explain Hawaii's success in keeping rates low while providing care to nearly everyone, advocates here and experts on the mainland say the state has much to contribute to the current national debate.
"One criticism I hear is that we are different, as if we're all sipping mai tais on the beach and dancing in coconut shell bras," said Dr. John Lewin, Hawaii's director of health. "We have a lot of poor people in Hawaii. We have all the health problems of the rest of the states. But what makes us different is that we decided to do something about it."
Dr. Lewin, energetic and outspoken, has become a sort of evangelist for universal health care, which he calls a basic human right. He has spoken to numerous Congressional officials and to leaders in states like California and Washington, where similar plans are under discussion. The thrust of his argument is that the states can provide health insurance for all citizens and keep costs down if preventive care is emphasized, and if there is competition among the major insurance companies to go after the uninsured.
Dr. Karen Davis, a professor of health policy at Johns Hopkins University, agrees. "What Hawaii has demonstrated, to a lot of people's astonishment," she said, "is that they have covered all their people while minimizing economic disruption."
By contrast, Massachusetts's plan for universal health insurance, also considered a pioneer of sorts, has stalled amid concern over the state's soured economy. Small-business owners, who starting in January would be required to offer employees insurance or pay the state to do it, are lobbying for a delay or outright repeal of the plan.
 
A 'Cost of Doing Business Here'
 The Hawaii plan took effect in 1974, when much of the country was in a severe recession. The world of health care was much different then. For one thing, mandatory insurance coverage by employers was not considered particularly radical; one of its leading advocates was the Nixon Administration. For another, no one had heard of AIDS, crack addiction or the host of high-technology advances that have driven up the cost of medicine. Before Hawaii's plan went into effect, 17 percent of its residents were without medical insurance -- a greater percentage than that represented by the 34 million Americans who now lack coverage.
In the Hawaii plan, the employee pays a portion of the insurance: no more than 1.5 percent of a person's gross wages, or half the premium, whichever is less. For someone making $2,000 a month, the fee can work out to around $30 a month. The requirement applies even to people who hire domestic workers for 20 hours a week or more, and any business that does not comply can be fined or shut down. State officials say they have had few problems with compliance.
Some business groups still complain about the cost. "For the smaller businesses, it's somewhat of a problem," said Mary Jane Van Buren, a spokeswoman for the Hawaii Chamber of Commerce. "It can make a difference, for some people, between going under and staying profitable." But she added, "People accept it, like everything else, as the cost of doing business here."
 
A State of Small Businesses
 As Congress debates a Democratic-sponsored bill to require employers who do not provide health coverage to pay premiums for uninsured workers, the main argument used against the measure is that it puts too much of the burden for national health care on small businesses. It could lead to higher inflation, the critics say, and create still more bureaucracy to bedevil small businesses that are already snagged in Government-generated red tape.
But Hawaii's example, experts here say, belies the argument.
The state's economy is run by small businesses; more than 90 percent of Hawaii's 27,271 individual enterprises employ 50 people or less, according to the state labor department.
Jean Pinc, who runs the B & L Bike and Sport Shop in Kona-Kailua, on the Big Island of Hawaii, says the additional cost of paying health insurance for three full-time employees has not been a drag on the business. "We want to keep our good people, and one way to keep somebody loyal is to give them good benefits," she said. "Everybody who runs a small business is pretty much in the same situation."
Not everyone is covered by the Hawaii requirements. In the most important exception, employers do not have to pay for care of dependents. But business people here say the competition for workers is so strong that most dependents are covered.
There are ways to get around paying insurance premiums. Some businesses hire only part-time workers, avoiding the 20-hour threshold.
"We could do that if we wanted to, and I know some people do," Ms. Pinc said. "But again, it comes down to trying to run a business with people who will stay loyal and do a good job for you."
The fact that Hawaii has virtually full employment means that companies have to compete, with various benefit packages, to keep good workers. As it is, "some employers are desperate for workers," said Rich Budnick, a spokesman for the Labor Department in Honolulu.
Last year, a second part of the Hawaiian health plan, intended to cover the 5 percent of the population that falls between the cracks, went into effect. People who otherwise have no insurance pay a small fee for each doctor visit and a portion of the insurance premium. The rest is picked up by the state. The poor are covered by Medicaid, the state-Federal program, as in other states.
The 1990 plan, called the State Health Insurance Program, is runnning below its projected budget cost -- insuring slightly more than 10,000 people at an annual cost of under $1,000 per person. But it provides only basic benefits, covering no more than five days in a hospital per year and limiting care in other ways.
 
A Pound of Prevention
 The question most frequently asked about Hawaii's system is how the state has managed to control costs. With Hawaii's isolation and expensive real estate, the cost of living is about 30 percent above the national average. But its health insurance premiums, for a single person per month, average about $94 a month -- well below the $154 average cost for a similiar policy in New York, California's $141 premium and the $282 average for Kansas.
The infant mortality rate, down 50 percent from its high of 16 per 1,000 in 1974, is among the nation's lowest. Life expectancy, at 78 years, is near the top.
"The secret of our success, the secret that many in the American medical establishment do not want to hear, is prevention," Dr. Lewin said. "We have twice as many outpatient visits, that is, people see their doctors several times a year, and half as many hospital stays, as the national average."
People are encouraged to go to the doctor early and often, he said, thus minimizing the chance of costly operations for maladies that could have been prevented. "The emergency room is not the place to get prenatal care," Dr. Lewin said.
Another cost-saving aspect is that the pool of workers covered by a given insurance plan is not drawn from a single workplace but from the entire population. If the premiums were based on the health of 10 people at one office, and 2 of those people had life-threatening diseases, the costs for everyone else at that office would skyrocket. But because the risk pool comprises all state residents, the costs are much lower.
"This has reduced the administrative expenses for insurers, and together with the spreading of risk, made insurance premiums affordable for all but a handful of small employers," wrote Molly Joel Coye, the head of California's Department of Health Services, in the Summer, 1991 edition of Issues in Science and Technology.
But just as Hawaii is being studied by people outside the state, Dr. Lewin fears that a new Federal system proposed by Senate Democrats, a "mega-Medicaid," as he calls it, will be imposed on Hawaii. The proposal would eventually require all employers to provide health insurance for their employees or to or pay into a health-care fund. Although Dr. Lewin likes aspects of the bill, he worries that the additional Federal bureaucracy would set Hawaii back.
The Federal Government should establish a minimum set of benefits, Dr. Lewin says, then step aside and let the states craft their own programs.

HEADLINE: Israel Tells U.S. It Will Consider Mideast Conference;
Shamir Says He Will Consider Mideast Conference

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 22

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that because of Syria's agreement to attend a peace conference and negotiate with Israel, his Government would reconsider its opposition to the meeting and give Washington an answer soon.
After a second round of talks with Mr. Baker, Mr. Shamir told his Cabinet that judging from what the Secretary of State brought from Damascus, there appeared to be a "revolutionary change" in Syria's position, even if it was for only tactical reasons, Yossi Ahimeir, an important adviser, said. 
 Later tonight, when asked if he believed that a peace conference could start within the next few months, Mr. Shamir told a reporter for Israeli television that "it's very possible that talks could be held in the framework of peace negotiations between us and the Arab world."
 
Reconsideration in Israel
 As a result of the recent Syrian, Lebanese and Jordanian commitments to attend talks with Israel, Mr. Baker said that Mr. Shamir, who only six weeks ago wrote President Bush rejecting American terms for the conference, was now rethinking that position.
"The Prime Minister indicated that he would respond shortly to our proposals," Mr. Baker said, adding:
"I think that this is a moment of historic opportunity. For 43 years, Israel has sought direct negotiations with its neighbors, and it has been right to do so.
"Direct negotiations are the only way to solve problems and the only way to secure peace, and now there is a real opportunity to get to these face-to-face negotiations."
A senior Israeli official said it was quite possible that Mr. Shamir would find a way to drop his earlier procedural objections to the conference.
 
U.N. Role Opposed
 These were his opposition both to the attendance of a United Nations observer and to the provision that the conference could occasionally reconvene after Israel and the Arab countries had begun direct negotiations.
The Israelis have opposed reconvening the full peace conference because they prefer direct talks with individual Arab countries, the kind of forum in which they think it less likely that the superpowers or Arab nations would be able to press them to accept unwanted compromises. Israeli leaders are also uncomfortable with a continuing United Nations role, recalling resolutions adopted in the past at the world organization that Israelis considered unfavorable.
Mr. Baker did not appear to get anywhere with Mr. Shamir on another issue -- a proposal endorsed by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to exchange an end to the Arab economic boycott of Israel for suspension of the building of Jewish settlements in the West Bank.
"He's not enthusiastic about that approach," Mr. Baker said. "That may be an understatement. We have a disagreement on that issue which is quite separate and apart from the peace process."
Before deciding on the peace conference question, Mr. Shamir is seeking clarification on the role the United Nations observer will play at the conference. The Israeli leader also wants to know which Palestinians will attend the conference. And he wants to more firmly establish the sincerity of Syria's commitment to peace.
Until Israel receives those clarifications, it will not respond, officials said. In light of that, Mr. Baker left his top Mideast adviser, Dennis Ross, chairman of the State Department Policy Planning Staff, in Jerusalem while he went to Malaysia to meet Southeast Asian foreign ministers.
President Bush, flying back to Washington from Turkey, spoke by telephone with Mr. Baker. Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, told reporters on Air Force One that "I think the President is encouraged that there wasn't a rejection." He also said that Mr. Bush would like Israel's response by the time of his summit meeting in Moscow on July 30 and 31. That would allow him and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to announce the conference and issue invitations.
Senior Israeli officials said that of all the outstanding issues, Mr. Shamir plans to take the hardest line on the question of which Palestinians can take part in the talks.
In particular, the official said, Mr. Shamir will hold to his insistence that no Palestinians from East Jerusalem be allowed to take part on the ground that this would imply that the eastern part of the city, captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 war and since annexed, is subject to negotiations.
He will also continue to insist that the Palestine Liberation Organization have no direct involvement with the Palestinian delegation.
The Israeli Government's insistence on maintaining the unity of Jerusalem is an emotional one in Israel and among Jews worldwide. Thus, if Israel is to hold out on one issue, that would be the strongest one for Mr. Shamir.
He would also enjoy considerable support for adopting a tough line at eventual negotiations with the Syrians.
 
Golan Compromise Opposed
 The Jerusalem Post today published a poll by the Smith Research Center, conducted a month ago, which found that only 7 percent of Israelis were ready to give up all of the strategic Golan Heights in return for "real peace and security guarantees."
A former Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, in an interview with Israel radio today, said that the Golan Heights are "ours and will remain so."
Geula Cohen, a leader of the far-right Tehiya Party and an important member of Mr. Shamir's coalition, warned the Prime Minister today that the moment he signals Washington that Israel is prepared to take part in the conference on America's terms, her party will bolt the Cabinet. So would the other far-right parties, she predicted.
If all seven far-right members of Mr. Shamir's coalition left, that would leave him with only 59 seats in Parliament -- two shy of a majority. But Parliament adjourned for the summer today and will not reconvene until the first week of October.
As a result, it is now impossible to bring a motion of no confidence against the Government for the next two and a half months, which means that Mr. Shamir cannot be ousted from office, even if some coalition members quit.
Mr. Shamir was quoted by Israel Radio today as saying that Mr. Baker told him the conference would likely convene in October, with each country represented by its foreign minister. Israel wants the conference in Washington; the Arabs want it in Cairo.
 
Palestinians Staying Flexible
 As objectionable as the Palestinians find some of Mr. Shamir's conditions, they are refraining from stating categorically that they will not take part in the conference unless people from East Jerusalem are in the delegation and unless the P.L.O. has a role.
Their strategy, according to prominent Palestinians in the territories, is to wait and see what Mr. Shamir does. They want him to move first.
If he spurns Mr. Baker, they think, the blame will fall on him and they will have given away nothing. If Mr. Shamir agrees to drop all his procedural objections and focuses on the Palestinian representation issue, however, then the Palestinians will likely try to find a way to swallow his conditions and go to the conference. They will be able to argue to their people that while they are making concessions, they will be get peace talks in return.
Hanan Ashrawi and Faisal al-Husseini, two of the West Bank Palestinian leaders who have met with Mr. Baker six times in the last three months, said at a news conference today that they believe that no talks should start without a Palestinian delegation including people from East Jerusalem. But when repeatedly pressed as to whether this was a condition for participation, they would not go that far.
They also declared that while the Palestinians believe that they are entitled their own delegation at the conference, they might consider attending as part of a joint Palestinian-Jordanian delegation, as Mr. Baker prefers, if the United States would declare that "the Palestinians are a people with a right to self-determination."
 
Opposition to Talks in Jordan
AMMAN, Jordan, July 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Jordanian Parliament has issued a tough statement condemning American peace efforts in the Mideast. The action on Sunday came just hours after King Hussein told Secretary of State Baker that Jordan was ready to attend a peace conference and that it supported Egypt's proposal to end the boycott of Israel.
The statement rejected peace talks "that would enhance Israel's occupation of Palestine and bring to an end its enmity with surrounding Arab states."
It also rejected the proposal for an end to the Arab boycott in exchange for a suspension of the building of new settlements in the occupied territories.
Several members of Parliament, in telephone interviews today, said they did not expect Parliament's action to affect the policies of the King or Prime Minister Taher Masri, whose Government won a vote of confidence in Parliament last week despite stiff oppostion from members of the Muslim Brotherhood, who form the largest parliamentary grouping.

LENGTH: 599 words

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

Hot Times
A subtropical shroud covered the city like a dirty old coat, turning fashionable people into human puddles. These are the horse latitudes of fashion, when it's O.K. not to think about clothes, if only for 15 minutes. 
 Several of the chic small stores on Madison Avenue have closed for vacation. Others, particularly luxury retailers with a clientele that summers by the sea, are closed on Saturdays till Labor Day.
In the department stores, there is a general atmosphere of not much business being done, although they are excellent places to sample air-conditioning. The coolest places to see clothes are action movies. In the future, as Arnold Schwarzenegger has demonstrated, robots will have a great sense of style.
The heat does gives rise to a certain fashionable languor, especially among the legions going to work. Among working women, one summer trend has been readily apparent: the return of the sleeveless shift dress. More and more women go to work in such easy styles: cool, crisp and unfettered.
By contrast, the men slogging toward the subway in their stifling suits seem a trifle absurd. If design is still vaguely related to function, their uniform is the inferior one. Note that after 5, the first thing the men do when they go home is slip into a long, loose tank tops, worn over a pair of extra-baggy Bermuda shorts, just above the knee.
If you squint your eyes and look at this outfit, regarding it purely as a silhouette, it resembles nothing so much as, well, a sleeveless shift dress. Don't tell anyone, but this may be the secret desire.
 
Boston Fashion
 While New York fashion has been mired in the hot season, Boston is in the midst of trying to kick-start its own garment industry. On Thursday, the Boston Designer's Collective, an industry group formed in February, is putting on a group show of about 30 designers at the Marine Industrial Park on the South Boston waterfront.
The show is part of a joint city-state effort of the kind that New York fashion designers have been lobbying for, unsuccessfully, for years. The Boston Designer's Collective Press Expo, as the event is called, is being underwritten with the help of the City of Boston's Economic Development and Industrial Corporation and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
The aim is to develop Boston into an internationl fashion center for tailored and specialty apparel, said Geoffrey B. Small, a Boston designer who helped found the Boston Designer's Collective. It is modeled on the strategic industrial plan used in Antwerp, Belgium; Barcelona, Spain, and Milan, Italy, to promote those cities' fashion businesses, Mr. Small said.
As in New York, the number of people employed by Boston's once-vibrant garment industry has declined sharply, to 1,200 from 3,000 in the last 10 years, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union said.
 
Hopalong Hip-Hop
 "The jean is dead," said Francois Girbaud, which is a funny thing coming from half of the French design team that makes some of the most popular jeans in America.
The Y-back and suspendered overalls with the Marithe and Francois Girbaud label are now the rage on city streets. But they are jeans with a different attitude, not so much James Dean as hip-hop. While many traditional jeans styles have faltered in the market, Marithe and Francois Girbaud jeans have soared, with sales of $120 million in 1990, up from about $70 million in 1989.
Mr. Girbaud, who learned about jeans in the 1960's by shopping Paris flea markets, regards his work as similar to couture. "I'm a cowboy in my mind," he said.

HEADLINE: Global Investors -- a special report: EMERGING MARKETS;
Big Profits, Large Risks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Outside the world's developed economies, a host of stock markets in developing countries from Mexico to Malaysia, Thailand to Taiwan and India to Indonesia offer the opportunity for substantial profits. But the price of those profits is increased risk, for these markets are volatile and generally lag far behind in the rudimentary measures required to protect investors.
In terms of basic accounting standards, the International Finance Corporation of Washington, which has established regulatory criteria for 20 of these emerging stock markets, found in a recent survey that only 7 nations -- Brazil, Chile, Mexico, India, South Korea, Malaysia and the Philippines -- have accounting standards that are acceptable by international standards. Nine nations have standards that are merely "adequate," the I.F.C. found, and Greece, Jordan, Taiwan and Indonesia have poor accounting standards that are in need of reform, it said. 
In terms of investor-protection regulations, Taiwan, Greece and Turkey got poor ratings, while 11 other nations -- Argentina, Columbia, Venezuela, Indonesia, Pakistan, the Philippines, Thailand, Jordan, Nigeria, Portugal and Zimbabwe -- were rated "adequate."
Only Brazil, Chile, Mexico, India, South Korea and Malaysia were given good ratings.
Some of those highly rated markets -- notably, India, where Bombay is the dominant stock exchange -- limit the ways foreign investors can participate, restricting them to a few mutual funds. These country funds, even in weakly regulated markets like Taiwan, have proved extremely popular with Americans.
But even in countries with the highest ratings, the markets still have a long way to go. "Over all, Mexico has probably the strictest laws and enforcement power of any emerging market but still lags far behind industrial country standards," said Gary Kleiman, an adviser on emerging markets who runs Kleiman International Consultants of New York.
 
Better Informed Than Others
 Insider trading can still be a problem because of concentrated family holdings or cross-ownership between banks and corporations. "One has got to fear that some people acting in the market are better informed than the minority shareholders," said Josiane Pain, director of the Greece Fund, which invests in Greek stocks.
In general, even if a country has a structure and rules that seem to provide the framework for adequate protection, the markets may not work that way in real life.
"These markets have little of the tradition of supervisory independence, which enables S.E.C.-type agencies to perform their duties free of ministry interference," Mr. Kleiman said. "Even when autonomous structures exist in legal form, practice has not yet evolved to reflect their mandate. You cannot look at the legal framework on paper. It is much more complicated than that."
Recent scandals in some countries, like Indonesia and Thailand, have prompted calls for more independent enforcement. Some rules on disclosure and listing of stocks have been tightened. But the new laws do not always help. Mr. Kleiman said that in Indonesia companies often kept three sets of books, trotting out the one best in a given situation. In Thailand, where supervision is split between the Securities Exchange of Thailand, the central bank and the Ministry of Finance, market scandals have prompted legislators to consider establishing a separate agency like the S.E.C.
A broker in Mexico, who asked not to be identified, said: "We are quite far down the road in terms of regulations and laws. But the problem is that when it comes to the supervision of the regulations it is not consistent, which is typical when it comes to a developing country."

GRAPHIC: Photo: BOMBAY: Stock markets in developing countries offer opportunity for substantial profits -- at the price of increased risk. Above, the Bombay stock exchange floor. (Reuters)
