SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk

LENGTH: 2132 words

HEADLINE: Children Of Divorce: Steps to Help Can Hurt

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
WITH two children in five now growing up in divorced families, researchers who have studied the long-term effects of marital dissolution are raising serious questions about the value of popular measures that are widely believed to ease the burden of divorce on children.
In fact, some steps long thought to be helpful, including no-fault divorce, delaying divorce until the children are older and court-ordered joint custody, may actually add to the already severe trauma many children suffer in the wake of divorce and sometimes for a decade or more after their parents' marriage ends, the studies suggest. 
 These concerns are emerging from research in this country and in Europe, including studies that follow families for years, starting well before signs of marital discord appear.
The commonness of divorce -- half of marriages contracted in the 1970's will not last -- may have reduced societal scorn and parental shame, but shows no signs of alleviating the anguish of children. In families split by divorce, the findings suggest, children do best if both parents are consistent in their upbringing and remain physically and emotionally involved in the youngsters' development. But the commitment and cooperation that facilitates such involvement is often lacking among divorced parents, the research indicates.
When both parents fail to maintain close parental relationships with their children after divorce, the children often do better if the father drops out of the picture altogether, a national survey of 1,423 children indicated. Among those surveyed by Dr. Frank F. Furstenberg Jr. and colleagues at the University of Pennsylvania, children from divorced families who had not seen their fathers in five years were doing better behaviorally and academically than those who had more frequent or recent paternal contacts.
With time, many divorced fathers become increasingly detached from their children. In the national survey, for example, the researchers were startled to discover that 23 percent of fathers had had no contact with their children in the last five years and another 20 percent had not seen their children during the preceding year. When fathers fail to play an active role in the children's upbringing, the best predictor of their healthy adjustment after divorce is a good relationship with the custodial mother, researchers have found.
A father's financial contribution to his divorced family can also have a major effect on the children. Many children felt abandoned by their fathers when the divorced family's finances suffered, when child support payments stopped on their 18th birthday and when fathers -- often themselves professionals with advanced degrees -- failed to contribute to the children's college education.
"The lack of adequate economic support has a devastating effect on the children's self-esteem and aspirations," said Dr. Judith S. Wallerstein, a California psychologist who has been studying divorce since 1971. "The children are enormously angry at being lost in the shuffle. They feel they are paying for their parents' mistakes."
Dr. Wallerstein's review of seven major studies and more than a dozen smaller ones of the long-term effects of divorce on children was published in May in The Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry.
 
Repercussions in Adulthood
 "The good news," she said, "is that by the third decade of life, a lot of kids do manage to pull their lives together, albeit after much blood, sweat and tears and often therapy." But for about half the children of divorce, the unhappy baggage of their parents' battles remains a lasting legacy.
 Dr. Wallerstein said her in-depth study of 60 middle-class families for up to 15 years after divorce revealed that since parental conflicts often center on the children, many youngsters mistakenly assume they caused their parents to split. Others maintain a fantasy for years of bringing their parents back together, even when they know rationally that the two are ill suited or do not get along.
Furthermore, she said, the frequency of divorce has raised anxieties among children in intact families. Occasional disagreements between otherwise happily married parents often lead to fears of divorce among their children.
Dr. Wallerstein summarized her findings in "Second Chances: Men, Women and Children a Decade after Divorce," written with Sandra Blakeslee and published in 1989 by Ticknor & Fields ($19.95). The book concludes, "We are allowing our children to bear the psychological, economic and moral brunt of divorce."
No-fault divorce, which has eased the way for couples who decide to end their marriage, does not necessarily reduce the ongoing conflicts between parents that can be highly destructive to children whether or not the marriage continues. Instead, by helping to make divorce more common, no-fault divorce may place more children at risk, Dr. Wallerstein said in an interview.
 
'A Disaster for Children'
 "Divorce on demand has turned out to be a disaster for children," she said, especially since "parents have no idea how to alleviate their children's anxieties when they divorce."
Although it has long been assumed that older children have an easier time understanding and accepting divorce, the findings suggest that parents who postpone divorce for the sake of the children may make it harder for children to adjust to the eventual split.
Younger children, especially young boys, often seem most distressed in the immediate aftermath of divorce, several studies have shown, but they generally recover faster and show fewer long-lasting effects than do children who are older when their parents separate.
Divorce has been found to be most traumatic in the long run to children who are pre-adolescents or teen-agers at the time of the split. From the ages 8 to 16, Dr. Wallerstein noted, children normally go through stages of identification with and separation from parents that can be seriously complicated by divorce. In addition, she said, delaying divorce exposes children longer to a model of an unhappy marriage and may make it more difficult for them to later establish a healthy, committed relationship of their own.
Furthermore, a new study of 17,000 British families and an ongoing study of 110 American families have shown that for years before their parents' divorce, many children show the same developmental disturbances typical of children of divorce.
These studies suggest that parental conflict during the marriage as well as after it ends is a major cause of youngsters' behavioral and academic problems. To the extent that divorce limits children's exposure to such conflict, it may reduce stresses that foster abnormal development.
"The notion that divorce will probably be devastating for children has influenced many couples to remain unhappily married until their children are grown," said Dr. Jack Block, his wife, Jeanne H. Block, who has since died, and Per F. Gjerde, the authors of the American study.
"Yet many of the behavioral problems boys especially exhibit at the time of divorce or subsequently are in fact present years before parental separation actually occurs," the psychologists from the University of California at Berkeley wrote in the journal Child Development.
The Berkeley team was among several research groups to note that parental conflict and divorce seem to have a more devastating, or at least more obvious, adverse effect on boys than girls, who generally are more resistant to environmental stresses.
But in her in-depth study over the years, Dr. Wallerstein found that while girls from divorced families at first adjusted about as well as girls from intact families, they encountered far more difficulties as older teen-agers and young adults. Depression commonly marred the teen-age years of girls from divorced families. Fearing rejection or betrayal by men, many became involved at an early age in short-lived sexual relationships, sometimes with older men.
 
Harmful Effects on Girls
 The British study found that girls from divorced families were more likely to become unwed mothers, to marry and have children at a young age and to get divorced than were comparable girls from intact families. Among white American women whose childhoods were marred by divorce, the divorce rate is 60 percent higher than for the general population.
In an interview, Dr. Wallerstein, who directs the Center for the Family in Transition in Corte Madera, Calif., cautioned divorcing parents against assuming their daughters were taking the split in stride. Her studies suggest that many need professional help as teen-agers or young adults if they are to be able to form meaningful and lasting relationships with men.
When divorcing parents battle over custody of the children, court-ordered settlements that require hostile parents to share custody can place children in the middle of continuing conflicts that are ultimately detrimental to their development.
According to Dr. Wallerstein's review of the literature, "there is evidence from many studies that intense parental conflict poses severe threats to the psychological health of children, whether the family is divorced or remains married."
In a study of 100 children and their families who were involved in custody disputes, Dr. Janet Johnston and colleagues at the Center for the Family in Transition found that fewer than 5 percent of the children were shielded from verbal or physical abuse between their parents.
The study found many instances in which parents displayed an "extraordinary disregard for the children's safety." These children were often exploited, enlisted by parents as battle allies, or even kidnapped by a parent. Several mothers even rammed their cars into the autos of former husbands while children were in the cars.
The children in the Johnston study were highly distressed, frightened, anxious and inhibited. Younger children and those who had witnessed physical violence between their parents were especially disturbed.
Major changes in behavior, including "zombie-like behavior and severe withdrawal," occurred when the children had to switch from one parental home to the other. The children seemed even more disturbed when they were interviewed again two and a half years later.
Four and a half years after their parents separated, children from these high-conflict families who lived in both parental homes because of court orders or mediation decisions "were significantly more depressed and more withdrawn" than children living with only one parent.
A Stanford University study of adolescents who were caught in the middle between divorcing parents found that even four years later, both boys and girls were more likely to suffer depression and anxiety and to engage in deviant behavior like drinking, smoking or skipping school.
The researchers, directed by Dr. Christie M. Buchanan, concluded that dual-residence arrangements were harmful when there was a lot of conflict between divorced parents.
Still, Dr. Wallerstein noted, there was considerable variation in the youngsters' response to parental conflict. "A good 40 percent of the youngsters whose parents showed high levels of discord had been able to maintain their emotional distance from the ongoing parental fray," she said.
In her own study, Dr. Wallerstein found that when the agreed-upon custody arrangement was not working well for the children, many parents seemed unwilling or unable to change it.
She concluded that this lack of flexibility could inhibit a child's development, particularly in adolescence when activities with peers take on primary importance and are sometimes disrupted when the child moves from one parental home to the other. Very young children also had difficulty adapting to frequent switching of households.
 
Strains From Remarriage
 When divorced parents remarry, yet another stress is introduced into the lives of their children.
In a six-year study of 180 families by Dr. E. Mavis Hetherington of the University of Virginia, when parents remarried their relationships with their children underwent a radical shift. Mothers and daughters, who got along best after divorce, often began fighting with one another when the mother remarried, while boys, who typically were most disturbed after the divorce, tended to settle down soon after acquiring a stepfather.
Dr. Hetherington reported that girls were hostile to their stepfathers no matter how hard the stepfathers tried to establish a good relationship. But stepfathers did better with boys, especially when the stepfathers supported the mothers' child-rearing efforts by acting as friends and confidants rather than disciplinarians of their stepsons.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Industry's Earnings Running in Circles

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
New York ran its 612th and final race of the summer season at Belmont Park yesterday and headed for five weeks of racing at Saratoga with the gnawing news that attendance at Belmont had slipped 6.2 percent and betting 6.5 percent during the 68-day meeting.
The racing scene will switch to Saratoga tomorrow afternoon for a five-week run before returning to Belmont on Aug. 28. But the horses will be accompanied by the hard facts of racing life: fewer people betting fewer dollars at the track and placing their bets instead at offtrack locations. 
 In Belmont's spring and summer meeting, which opened on May 8, attendance declined to an average of 12,431 customers from 13,259 the year before, continuing a slide of recent years. Betting at the track declined to an average $2.7 million a day, from $2.9 million a day the year before.
Even away from the track, the betting business generally retreated from last year's levels. Offtrack betting offices in New York City reported that betting had slipped slightly to $2.6 million a day from $2.7 million a day a year before, a drop of 2.6 percent. On Long Island, the decline measured 2.8 percent; at upstate OTB offices, 2.7 percent.
 
Yonkers Thrives
 But one betting location thrived: Yonkers Raceway handled bets on races televised from Belmont Park for its full meeting, and reported a rise of 237 percent in bets, to an average $446,562 a day this year from $132,619 a day last year.
Since Belmont receives a share of offtrack bets, the bottom line for its 66-day season managed a slender gain. Last year, $7.41 million a day was bet on the average; this year, $7.42 million.
"We are happy to see business reach this level," Gerard J. McKeon, president of the New York Racing Association, said in a statement focusing largely on some of the season's memorable races. "The thrilling finishes in the Belmont Stakes and the Mother Goose gave racing fans everywhere a weekend to remember. The rematch between Lite Light and Meadow Star in the Coaching Club American Oaks was icing on the cake.
"The slippage on track can be directly attributed to the resumption of the Yonkers simulcast. With Yonkers in operation for the full meet this year, it figured that ontrack business would suffer somewhat. We now look forward to what promises to be a memorable Saratoga meeting, including hopefully a rematch between Strike the Gold and Hansel in the Travers Stakes."
 
Extra Factor
 But his deputy, Gerald Lawrence, the executive vice president of New York racing, said that the extra week at Saratoga might dilute any immediate gains.
"We are moving into uncharted waters," Lawrence said. "We've never run a five-week meet upstate before. We aren't sure what effect the poor state of the economy will have on vacationers, and we certainly don't know the type of weather we will have. All of those will have a significant impact on attendance and handle for the meet."
Saratoga usually draws more people and money than Belmont. Last year, after Belmont had averaged $7.41 million in bets during its spring and summer season, Saratoga averaged $10.1 million during its four-week season.
Bets on the races at Saratoga also can be placed at the otherwise empty Aqueduct track in Queens, which will open each afternoon just to handle wagering on races televised from upstate. Parking and admission are free, and concession stands will be open. But the horses will be racing 200 miles to the north.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Course for Israel

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The Bush Administration and its Arab allies have strewn the field with traps. Just the same, the best available course for Israel seems to be to move toward direct talks with the Arab states, walking with exquisite care every step of the way and ready to cut out at the first sign of betrayal.
Israel, deliberately and outrageously being isolated and squeezed by Washington, faces one of the most difficult decisions in its lifetime of difficult decisions. Those who wish Israel well owe it to her and themselves to separate out the ingredients of the Middle Eastern stew -- hope from hypocrisy, truth from lie, opportunity from suicide. 
 The assumption that every Israeli or friend of Israel should make is that Hafez al-Assad of Syria, that clone of Saddam Hussein in aggression and terrorism, has not suddenly surrendered his goal: the eventual destruction of Israel. The assumptions must also be that King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has not overnight moved from political medievalism into the age of enlightenment and that King Hussein of Jordan remains available to the highest bidder, never for sale but always for lease.
Sadly, it also remains true that the Bush Administration still has a spiritual affinity for Arab rulers and oil men but bares its teeth when Jerusalem shows independence of mind, otherwise known as intransigence.
So Israel is asked to enter talks with its sworn enemies, under the sponsorship of the U.S., which never has been less friendly, and of Moscow, which never was friendly, and with the attendance of the U.N., which is rancid with anti-Israel passions.
What's worst, the present U.S. Administration would prefer Israel pushed back to its pre-1967 borders. From those borders, Syrians fired down incessantly from the Golan Heights -- and Jordanian troops took pot shots at Israelis from across the street in East Jerusalem.
So why even suggest that Israel now accept the American plan for a quick conference, to be followed by direct negotiations? The reasons are at least four:
l. Because Israel has always said that the only way to reach peace is through direct negotiations with the Arab countries. To refuse outright now would wither something Israel has cherished that is almost unknown in the Mideast: trust in its word.
2. Because there is the possibility, however meager, that direct talks with Palestinians would give some of them the courage to break from the murderous Palestine Liberation Organization and lead Palestinian Arabs to the solution of self-government. (That in itself would be a risk for Israel, which would have to make sure that it did not turn into the independence that could be the launch for Arab attacks.)
3. Because someday Mr. Assad will outsmart himself. The Syrian President, who murdered thousands of his own subjects in the city of Hama, will wind up dispensed with by his countrymen. Then it would be easier for his successors to deal directly with the Israelis if the precedent had already been set by Mr. Assad himself. That could be the beginning of the real Mideast turning point.
4. Because accepting the American plan might prevent Israeli-haters in the U.S. Government and the weeping-crocodile "friends" of Israel among American Jews from crippling Israel economically and forcing it to turn away Jews fleeing Communism, or African and Arab dictators.
Those are my own opinions. But it is important to me that when I called him I found they were also the conclusions of the man whose thoughts probably mean most to foreign supporters of Israel, Jew and non-Jew -- Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Laureate and a friend.
While on friendship: It may be that Prime Minister Shamir thinks differently and turns down the U.S. plan, or later sniffs the air and walks out. Most of the American press, plus the hate-Israel mob and the crocodiles, will howl for the U.S. to put the boot to Israel. Then it will be the duty of the friends of Israel and of political democracy to oppose them.
No, that is not because we support Israel right or wrong. It is because Israel will still be the only democracy in the Middle East, because it has political and ethical ties with America that the hero of Hama could never understand, and because it is better to trust a democracy even at times of disagreement than a mass murderer -- anytime.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Of Three Unlikely Allies and Their Conflicts

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The Big Three
Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin in Peace and War
By Robin Edmonds
608 pages. Illustrated. W. W. Norton. $27.95.
 
The Juggler
Franklin Roosevelt as Wartime Statesman
By Warren F. Kimball
304 pages. Illustrated. Princeton University Press. $19.95. 
 For the generation that came of age during the cold war, it must be hard to imagine that there was once a grand alliance between Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union. During World War II, people in these countries mourned one another's military losses and cheered one another's victories against Nazi Germany. The Iron Curtain had not yet descended over Europe, and Stalin was sometimes referred to (half-jocularly and half-ironically) as Uncle Joe.
The event that forged the alliance was Germany's invasion of Russia in June 1941. Before then, the cynical Soviet-German nonagression pact of August 1939 had been greeted with fear and dismay by Britain and the United States. After that pact, the attitude toward Hitler and Stalin, the two dictators, was best summed up in David Low's brilliant cartoon of Sept. 20, 1939, titled "Rendezvous." It showed Hitler, standing on corpses, bowing to Stalin, saying, "The scum of the earth, I believe," and Stalin, bowing in return, replying, "The bloody assassin of the workers, I presume?"
In "The Big Three," a well-documented history, Robin Edmonds had the bright idea of explaining the war through the personalities and activities of Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin. Mr. Edmonds, who fought with the British Army in the African and Italian campaigns and later held high posts in the British Foreign Service, including Assistant Under Secretary of State for American affairs, uses his strong background to good effect. The book deserves praise for its readability as well as for its usefulness as a reference work.
To illustrate the opposition that Churchill had to overcome in Britain even while it was being bombed by the Luftwaffe, Mr. Edmonds recalls some of his own personal experiences. Just before Churchill became Prime Minister in 1940, he was present at a dinner given by a prominent Tory, Charles Londonderry, who was an open admirer of Hitler's Third Reich. Londonderry presented Mr. Edmonds with a copy of a book he had written in defense of appeasement; it expressed his gratitude to Hitler, Hermann Goring and Joachim von Ribbentrop "for their repeated kindnesses and hospitality." The story makes the point that members of the appeasing aristocracy tried to undermine Churchill.
Mr. Edmonds assesses the three wartime leaders. Stalin remains a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma. Nevertheless, the three worked together, despite their occasional clashing views about military operations and, especially, about the shape and colors of the map after the war: a New World Order for their time.
The political differences between Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin were not confined to the obvious gulf over Marxist ideology. Mr. Edmonds says that had Roosevelt lived, he and Churchill would hardly have seen eye to eye about the postwar role of the British Empire. Roosevelt regarded Churchill's view of colonial matters as "mid-Victorian."
The American President's attitude toward Stalin was laced with pragmatism. Optimistically, he thought the United States and the Soviet Union could work out their political and economic differences. As for Stalin, his attitude about the military aspect of the alliance was best expressed a few days after the Second Front had finally been opened by the Anglo-American invasion of Normandy in June 1944. Of D-Day, Stalin said, "History will record this event as an achievement of the highest order." But as postwar events proved, political dominance on Russia's borders was another matter to Stalin.
Taking the long view, Mr. Edmonds says the Big Three's two main achievements should not be overlooked: Hitler's Germany was defeated and a world body was created, the United Nations, that the author sees growing in influence and respect today.
President Roosevelt receives high marks for his wartime statesmanship from Warren F. Kimball in "The Juggler." In a bold analysis, Professor Kimball, who teaches history at Rutgers University, advances the notion that while Roosevelt often seemed to be inconsistent, he was actually a Wilsonian idealist with a fixed vision for a more democratic world. He described himself as a juggler in 1942 to Henry Morgenthau Jr., his Secretary of the Treasury, but explained that even if he appeared inconsistent, he was willing to mislead and tell untruths to help win the war.
The author says that despite the efforts of some historians to turn Roosevelt into "a belated but convinced cold warrior," he, unlike Churchill, took a conciliatory approach to avoid an East-West confrontation. In a memorandum to Churchill shortly before he died, referring to conflicts over German surrender talks at Bern, Roosevelt said, "I would minimize the general Soviet problem as much as possible because these problems, in one form or another, seem to rise every day and most of them straighten out as in the case of the Bern meeting." In contrast, Mr. Kimball says, once Harry S. Truman succeeded Roosevelt, "there was a sharp reversal of Presidential policy" toward the Soviet Union.
The great might-have-been is whether postwar Soviet-American relations would have been different had Roosevelt lived. All through "The Juggler," Professor Kimball is unafraid to speculate -- and give President Roosevelt the benefit of any doubt. His lively history draws this conclusion:
"It is easy to mock and condemn Roosevelt for his attempts to create a cooperative relationship with the Soviet Union, particularly in the light of Stalin's crude brutality. Even if the cold war was inevitable because of Stalin's actions, which is by no means certain, F.D.R.'s attempt to work with the Soviet Union makes more sense than the belligerent, confrontational approach that was the alternative."

HEADLINE: Blacks Are Found to Be Still Scarce in Advertisements in Major
Magazines

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Two decades after the civil rights movement began prodding the communications media to increase and diversify their depictions of members of minorities, blacks remain nearly invisible in the advertising of major national magazines, a comprehensive study has found.
 Although blacks make up 12 percent of the United States population and more than 11 percent of all magazine readers, they appear in only 4.5 percent of all magazine advertisements and constitute a little more than 3 percent of the 
characters in those advertisements, according to a study by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.
 In some periodicals, including Time, Esquire and Vogue, the proportion of advertisements featuring blacks has actually declined over the past 20 years, and in most magazines, a large proportion of the blacks are depicted as athletes, musicians or objects of charity.
 Concluding that "stereotyping, under-representation and de facto segregation continues to exist" in advertising, the Department of Consumer Affairs said it would ask the nation's magazine publishing companies, the largest of which have their headquarters in New York, to establish goals for improved representation of blacks and other minority members.
 
Who Makes the Choices?
 The slippage in black representation in magazine advertising lends support to a theory heretofore cautiously advanced by marketing experts: Marketers' improving ability to reach specific consumer targets in specialized media is leading to the disappearance of minority images in many media with broader appeal.
 Publishing and advertising agency executives said that any responsibility for
changing minority representation in print advertising resided with the agencies, not the magazines.
 "Magazines don't create advertising," said Michael A. Clinton, the publisher of GQ, the men's magazine. "The creative choices fall in the hands of the ad agencies. They determine who the talent is, what the target is and what the image should be."
 Several publishing and advertising executives questioned why the city's Department of Consumer Affairs felt that a study of national magazines was within its jurisdiction.
 Mark Green, the commissioner of consumer affairs, responded that it was within his department's mandate to investigate the issue because "minority consumers are being hurt, and so many magazines and ad agencies are located in New York."
 "It affects the way whites and blacks see each other," he added. Mr. Green did an earlier study that found that people in poor neighborhoods in New York pay more for food in local groceries than do other consumers.

 
Resisting 'Police' Role
 Mr. Green said he would send letters this week to 17 magazine publishers in New York and ask them to take "a visual-image pledge to integrate their content."
 But several magazine executives interviewed said it was not their role to police advertising.
 "He will have a very receptive audience among magazines for the message of this study, but the hot button is with the agencies and the advertisers," said James R. Guthrie, the executive vice president of the Magazine Publishers Association. "What they're talking about here is the message -- do you have a fair, representative proportion? For that, you talk to the people who are manufacturing the message."
 The report, which is scheduled to be released today but was provided in advance to The New York Times, comes at a time of particular sensitivity over the portrayal of blacks in the media. In several cities, including New York,
Baltimore and Chicago, angry black inner-city residents have painted over billboards promoting cigarettes and alcoholic beverages to black consumers.
 
Ruling Is Appealed
 And last January, a Federal appeals court ruled that The New York Times could be sued for racial discrimination under provisions of the Federal Fair Housing Act because of the lack of minority members in its real estate advertisements. The ruling came in a case filed against The Times in 1989 by several advocates of open housing.
 The Times has appealed the ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, to the United States Supreme Court, said George Freeman, a senior attorney for the newspaper. A similar suit filed against The Cincinnati Enquirer was dismissed by the lower court but is under appeal to the Sixth Circuit.
 Advertising executives and marketing experts offered several explanations for the scarcity of minority faces. Some cited the continually improving ability to segment the consumer audience into small demographic slices and to direct
advertising at these niches through specialized publications and other media. Such "narrowcasting," as this targeting process is called, may allow marketers to ignore minority members in advertising designed for their broader market, which the advertisers tend to think of as white.
 "The argument is always on the side of going with the white images in the white media," said Caroline R. Jones, the president of Caroline Jones Advertising, a New York agency that specializes in marketing to black consumers. "People want to talk to the consumers they want rather than the consumers they have or the consumers they could have. And the consumers they want are 'people like me.' "
 
A 'Best Efforts' Clause
 In television, minority members are more prevalent in advertising. Blacks constituted 7.5 percent of all actors in television commercials in 1987, according to the Screen Actors Guild. The agreement between the guild and its sister union, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, and the American Association of Advertising Agencies contains a clause requiring that "best efforts" be made to cast minority members in commercials.
 John E. O'Toole, the president of the American Association of Advertising
Agencies, said that because most magazine ads were created for publication in many periodicals but use only a single character marketers tended "to choose the model that reflects the majority of their constituency, which for most consumer products is white."
 Still others said the low representation of blacks in magazine advertisements was due to the spirit of the times. Roy J. Bostock, the chief executive of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles advertising agency, which represents General Motors, Procter & Gamble and Burger King, said he believed that "sensitivity to the representation of minorities in advertising" existed in the early and mid-1970's, but "that sensitivity waned somewhat for some agencies and advertisers during the Reagan years."
 
Economic and Social Sense
 Mr. Bostock added that increased minority representation in advertising made economic as well as social sense for their clients.
 "The mythology of the American family being a white Mom and Dad and two kids living in the suburbs is just that -- mythology," he said. "The Hispanic population is growing. The Asian-American population is growing. Blacks are
becoming more significant economically. It's very important for marketers to track these population trends and reflect them in the advertising they create. It increases the persuasiveness of the advertising."
 To reach its conclusions, the Department of Consumer Affairs surveyed all the advertisements with photographs or drawings of people in 27 national magazines, randomly selecting nine issues of each published from July 1988 to July 1991. In cases where a given issue of a magazine contained a small number of advertisements, extra issues were added to the survey. A total of 11,391 advertisements, with 21,607 models, were reviewed.
 Only 674 of these models, or 3.15 percent, were black. One hundred ninety-five -- less than 1 percent -- were Asians, who constitute 3 percent of the American population. Of the 11,391 advertisements, 10,725 featured only white characters.
 
Lagging Behind the Readers
 The study found a similar dearth of black and Asian models in catalogues from mail-order companies. Of 22,685 models featured in 157 catalogues, 4.6 percent were black.
 For some magazines, the depiction of blacks lagged far behind their
representation among the readership. Almost one-quarter of the readers of GQ are black, according to the Simmons Market Research Bureau; yet only 2.9 percent of the models in the magazine's advertisements were black. In the women's fashion magazine Vogue, only 1.6 percent of the advertising models are black, compared to 14.6 percent of the readers.
 The study found a significant decline in some magazines in black advertising representation in the past decade. A review of 24 randomly selected issues of Time from 1988 to 1991 found that 7.6 percent of the advertisements featured blacks. A separate study, published in the research journal Public Opinion Quarterly in 1984, found that in 1980, 11.4 percent of Time's advertisements featured blacks.
 The magazines surveyed were Better Homes and Gardens, Business Week, Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Family Circle, Fortune, GQ, Good Housekeeping, House and Garden, Ladies' Home Journal, Lear's, Life, Mademoiselle, McCall's, Money, Newsweek, New York Magazine, The New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, New York Woman, People, Self, Seventeen, Sports Illustrated, Time, Vanity Fair and Vogue.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Goodyear Reports Fuel-Saving Tire

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, July 23

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it had developed a new automobile tire that would help the environment by reducing fuel consumption and related exhaust emissions. Goodyear said the new tire, called the "Invicta GFE," for greater fuel economy, employed a new rubber chemistry that allowed a 4 percent reduction in gasoline usage by cutting rolling resistance. 
 The company said it would introduce the tire in September in several large markets. Goodyear said the tire would be priced slightly higher than its most popular consumer tires. The tire will be produced at plants in Lawton, Okla.; Union City, Tenn., and Valleyfield, Calif. Goodyear's stock fell $1.25 a share, to $37, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Kinshasa Journal;
A Country Is Plucked Clean, and the Feathers Fly

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 19

 BODY:
Here in one of Africa's poorest countries, tens of thousands of people have suddenly found their pockets even emptier than usual. As it happened, they were tricked into practically giving their money away.
They were among those who placed their faith -- and the equivalent of millions of dollars in savings -- in an investment swindle that promised returns of up to eight times their original money. 
 A few won big, but far more were losers in what is being called the most spectacular financial debacle in this Central African nation's history.
The investment-swindle story in Zaire has everything -- big money, violence, a whiff of political scandal, reputations being made and unmade overnight. Above all, the scandal is expected to have an influence on whether Zaire's longtime President, Mobutu Sese Seko, remains in office.
 
Some Lose Their Homes
 "Everybody invested money, and I mean everybody," said Jerome Nelson, a longtime resident here who is president of the Zaire-America Chamber of Commerce. "I know people who lost their homes, their jewelry. "They sold their furniture and their cars. They would have even sold their souls if they could."
The swindle began in January when Michel Bindo Bolembe, a 32-year old small-time businesman, opened a shop in La Cite Indigene, the sprawling district where most of Kinshasa's nearly four million people live.
The lure was deceptively simple: people who deposited money in Bindo shops were promised a 100 percent return on their investment in four days, or 800 percent in 45 days.
And at first it worked.
"I played it and won three times, but lost the fourth time," Mr. Nelson said, "and the truth is, a lot of other people won a lot of money."
In fact, according to charges recently brought against Mr. Bolembe, it was a classic pyramid scheme, with money from new investors used to pay off old ones.
In Zaire, as in most countries, such "Ponzi schemes," as they are commonly known, are illegal. But here as elsewhere the gullible find the lure of easy money difficult to resist. This time, it seems that a substantial part of a nation was fooled.
"In a country as poor as we are, someone who promises something for nothing is irresistible. " said Buana Kabwe, chairman of the Zaire League of Human Rights. "A lot of people invested their life's savings."
 
More Money Pours In
 Before long, as news spread that some people were indeed being paid huge sums, more money poured in. At its height, the swindle's popularity was so great that people reportedly slept outside Bindo shops to keep their place in line.
In his dizzying rise, Mr. Bolembe, at first a rather mysterious figure, became something of a folk hero. The Government-controlled news organizations gave his scheme fawning coverage, and his credibility was enormously enhanced when he became a regular guest of Mr. Mobutu at the President's luxurious country estate in Gbadolite.
The fraud cascaded out of control on May 13 when the Bindo offices suddenly stopped paying. Within hours, the main office on the Avenue de la Victoire was burned down.
The next day, rioting broke out among students who feared -- with some justification -- that they might have thrown away their meager scholarships in hopes of easy riches.
At one point, the rioters seized and dragged Isalu Isanga, Zaire's Minister of State for Primary and Secondary Education, from her car. She was stripped beaten, reportedly raped and paraded through a campus. In addition, three students were reported to have been killed and two soldiers burned alive.
Western diplomats here say that the Bindo fraud has added fuel to an already overheated national economy. Inflation in Zaire, by some accounts, is running at 600 to 800 percent a year.
 
President May Be Loser
 A big loser may have been President Mobutu, who has ruled this country of 36 million since coming to power in a coup 26 years ago. The seizing of power by Mr. Mobutu, then a major general, followed five years of fratricidal fighting among post-independence leaders considered either pro-Soviet, pro-Western or even neo-colonial.
"There's no way this could have happened without Mobutu being involved, no way," said Nguza Karl-i-Bond, a former Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, who over time has become one of President Mobutu's severest critics.
It is a refrain increasingly heard here from those who complain that the Government never expressed concern about Mr. Bolembe's frantic activity or unusual behavior, even when he began buying time on the state-controlled radio and television stations. One jingle ran: "Take part in Bindo promotion and solve all your problems!"
 
Mobutu Denies Involvement
 Mr. Mobutu has adamantly denied any involvement in the scheme and spokesmen emphasize that the Government took swift action against Mr. Bolembe as soon as it had hard evidence that his business was a sham. Mr. Bolembe was arrested and is awaiting trial.
But the scandal could hardly have come at a worst time for the Mobutu Government. Here in Kinshasa, Zaire's capital, there have been rising protests in recent months against Mr. Mobutu, and the Bindo fiasco appears to have given critics added ammunition against his autocratic rule.
For now, the Government has sought to mute the rising criticism of its handling of the episode by promising to refund the money of all who invested in the swindle, a promise that skeptics highly doubt, given the parlous condition of Zaire's economy. Some investors have got their money back from Zaire's central bank, but by all accounts they are few in number.
"There's no way the Government can pay those people back," Mr. Kabwe said, "and a lot of people are going to be very angry when they find they've been duped again."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Truths About Welfare

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TO paraphrase Will Rogers, only one person in 1,000 knows how to untangle the welfare mess -- and you meet him every day.
Most Americans, it is safe to say, have strong views about the system that supports impoverished single parents and their children. But only in the last decade have social scientists generated hard evidence about what works in getting the poor off the dole, and what does not. 
 Now the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, the remarkable nonprofit organization behind most of this research, has summarized dozens of these studies involving tens of thousands of welfare recipients. And while the underlying message of "From Work to Welfare," to be published next month by the Russell Sage Foundation, is optimistic, it will not reassure those who want to believe that welfare dependence can be eliminated at little expense to taxpayers.
Social science research typically is not very scientific because it cannot be. Practitioners rarely have the luxury of comparing what is with what might have been -- the way, for example, cancer researchers test the effect of a new drug by comparing it with a placebo.
But the Manpower research corporation, created by the Ford Foundation in 1974, is anything but typical. Its research has been exclusively built on experiments in which programs are evaluated by comparing their effect on randomly selected participants with control groups. And the results of these experiments in the 1980's, analyzed by Judith Gueron, the president of the corporation, and Edward Pauly, a senior researcher, are striking.
A very modest public investment -- typically, help looking for a job, combined with a little work experience -- pays off handsomely. Arkansas's WORKnot an acronym, peter sez program, for example, spent an average of only $118 for each participant. But the public's savings in reduced welfare outlays averaged $503 a person over the first three years.
The catch is that welfare recipients themselves did not gain much: their average increase in earnings barely offset their loss in welfare payments. Indeed, Ms. Gueron notes, it is remarkable how many welfare recipients are eager to take jobs that leave them little better off.
Equally sobering, most of the beneficiaries were short-termers with just one foot in the welfare camp. Chronic welfare recipients, who absorb 60 percent of the total welfare budget, were largely unaffected.
The Manpower group evaluated the more ambitious Saturation Work Initiative Model, known as SWIM, in San Diego, in which a mandatory basic education and job training program was added to the simpler job search approach. At $919 a person, SWIM was relatively expensive. But it saved that much in welfare payments in just two years. And it cut a little more deeply into the welfare population, increasing people's earnings by $658 in the second year of the program alone.
Ms. Gueron suggests that SWIM was very well managed and that it is not yet clear whether its success can be matched elsewhere. But even if SWIM can be duplicated, there are obvious limits to the potential impact on poverty.
At best, SWIM-style programs gear up people to find and keep full-time unskilled jobs -- minimum-wage jobs that do not come close to raising out of poverty a mother with a child or two. Thus, if work is to be the primary answer to poverty, welfare-to-work programs are going to have to do more than teach people to read, write and punch a time clock.
The Welfare Reform Act passed in 1988 allotted about $1 billion a year for state-run experiments with programs likely to have a greater impact on chronic welfare recipients. Some of that money will be spent on variations of SWIM, to see if it works as well outside San Diego and if the payoff can be enhanced by tinkering with the components. Some will go toward even more ambitious efforts, in which states try to give welfare recipients the skills and motivation to fight their way into the middle class.
But these efforts are bound to require far greater public investments up front, and will take longer to pay off. The immediate worry is that state legislatures, pressed by budget deficits and record welfare caseloads, will not come up with the matching funds for expensive long-term experiments. Roughly a third of the Federal grant money available, Ms. Gueron notes, is not being used.
A longer-term worry -- for the moment, hypothetical -- is that taxpayers will balk. Expensive welfare-to-work programs may pay big social dividends. But unlike bare-bones job-search programs, much of the benefit may go to the poor rather than to taxpayers. And it is unclear whether Americans would support successful antipoverty programs that raise the cost of government. Finding out may prove the biggest experiment of all.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower After Day of Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most major currencies yesterday in a second day of light, uneventful trading.
Gold prices rose domestically after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery gained 50 cents, to $368.10 an ounce. Republic Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $367.50, up 15 cents. 
 Dealers said the dollar closed lower as traders sought direction on the state of the United States economy and the prospect for lower interest rates. Lower rates would tend to drive down the value of the dollar.
"There's been no incentive to either buy the dollar or sell the dollar or kick it out of this range we've been in for the past day or so," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston's New York office.
He said some movement could come today with the release of durable-goods figures for June and auto sales for mid-July.
Some dealers sold dollars after remarks by Michael Boskin, the chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, about the prospect for lower interest rates. Mr. Boskin told a Congressional committee that the Federal Reserve would feel pressure to push rates lower if credit remains tight.
"I don't think there's anything immediate that could be taken from his statement," Mr. Lawrie said. "But I think the dollar started to look at the downside of the range."
Traders overseas said the dollar was hurt in European dealings by the release of higher German inflation figures. The report renewed speculation that the German central bank would raise interest rates to curb inflation. That would weaken the dollar against the mark.
In New York, the dollar slipped to 1.7575 marks from 1.7620 marks late Monday. In London, the dollar slid to 1.7555 marks from 1.7587.
The British pound strengthened to $1.6825 from late Monday's $1.6795. In London, sterling was quoted at $1.6845, up from Monday's $1.6810.
The dollar also dropped against the Japanese yen in New York, to a closing 137.25 yen from Monday's 137.65. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 137.52 yen from Monday's 136.65 yen, while in London, it was quoted at 136.95 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.5255 Swiss francs, unchanged.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
4 Big Agencies Will Share Work for Northwest Airlines

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
NORTHWEST AIRLINES joined the ranks of giant marketers using more than one large advertising agency when it announced yesterday that it would create a four-way "communications partnership" for worldwide advertising, marketing and promotional campaigns.
Northwest is hiring this shop quartet: the J. Walter Thompson Company, New York; Ogilvy & Mather, New York; FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York, and McElligott Wright Morrison White, Minneapolis. 
 Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest airline, would not discuss billings, but it is estimated that they could reach $90 million in the next year. Northwest's spending has fluctuated between $20 million and $60 million in the last three years, varying with the economy's ups and downs and the Persian Gulf war.
"It became obvious to us we needed to present a face, and communicate, on a global basis," Christopher E. Clouser, senior vice president of communications and advertising, said in a telephone interview from Northwest's offices in Minneapolis. The joint task of the four agencies, he added, will be "to produce the operating and communication strategy for a global brand."
While specific assignments for each agency are still to be determined, Mr. Clouser described this general lineup: domestic and international advertising aimed at consumers, to Thompson; the Trump Shuttle, assuming Northwest's deal to manage it goes through, and a second, undisclosed project, to Ogilvy; direct-marketing campaigns aimed at business travelers and frequent flyers, to FCB/Leber Katz, and corporate identity, to McElligott Wright.
Hiring two or more agencies to work on huge accounts has become popular in the last couple of years. Among those doing so are McDonald's, which splits its account between the Leo Burnett Company and DDB Needham Worldwide; I.B.M., which employs Wells Rich Greene BDDP and Lintas New York, and Burger King, which has on its roster Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.
"This is a pretty bold experiment," said Tony Wright, president of McElligott Wright, "to choose four agencies to work together to come up with big global ideas." Mr. Wright, who worked on the British Airways campaigns in Britain, said he would welcome the partnership because it was "tough to do great advertising that crosses borders."
 At Ogilvy, Bill Hamilton, executive vice president and creative head, said, "We're going into this with the idea we're going to work together to leverage the entire Northwest brand." It can work, he added, "if you have your head screwed on right and don't play N.I.H. games" -- meaning accepting the others' ideas instead of resisting them as "not invented here."
To help make the partnership work, top executives of the agencies will meet quarterly with Northwest officials. All will become members of a new communications board the airline will create. Mr. Clouser hopes new ads can appear in the next 90 days.
Northwest's decision ends a seven-year relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, which handled Northwest's consumer account. "We're very proud of what we did," said Ed Wax, president and chief executive of Saatchi. "But this is a business where change is inevitable." The ad community had been speculating about an agency change since April, when Mr. Clouser and Peter Hoult, senior vice president of marketing and sales, joined the airline. Indeed, the company acknowledged in May that it was reviewing the status of its account.
Once Northwest decided to rethink its marketing communications in worldwide terms, Mr. Clouser said, that presented a conflict for Saatchi. Its British parent, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., represents British Airways internationally.
 For Ogilvy, the assignment means "we're back in the airline business," Mr. Hamilton said. Its relationship with Eastern Airlines ended when Eastern went out of business this year. The Trump Shuttle account, which billed as much as $7 million to $9 million under Donald J. Trump, had been handled by Scali, McCabe, Sloves, New York.
Northwest's decision also puts Thompson back in the airline business for the first time since it handled USAir's account from 1978 to 1986. "It's exactly what we've been looking for," said Donald Sullivan, executive vice president of Thompson. The agency is known for its Pan Am campaigns from 1942 to 1978, including "Pan Am makes the going great."

HEADLINE: Yields on Short-Term C.D.'s Show a Mild Drop in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on short-term certificates of deposit took another mild decline for the week ended yesterday. This followed a drop the week before.
The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., said the decline came despite an uptick in the rates on the Treasury's three-month bills. 
 "There is definitely a flat picture ahead for the nation's savers," Robert K. Heady, the publisher, said yesterday.
 
Yields on Treasury Bills
 The yields on the three-month Treasury bills were 5.6 percent yesterday, up from 5.57 on Monday, while the six-month bills held almost steady, at 5.74, a basis point below the 5.75 yield on Monday.
The largest change among banks in the New York area was made by Marine Midland, which raised the yields on its six-month C.D. by 15 basis points, to a yield of 5.6 percent. A basis point is one hundredth of 1 percent.
In additiion, Marine Midland cut 10 basis points from its yields on money market accounts, dropping them to 5.12 percent.
Dollar Dry Dock, a large savings bank in New York, lowered its three-month certficates by 6 basis points, to 5.81 percent.
Among commercial banks, the average money market account fell by a basis point, to 5.14 percent, while six-month certificates on average were up by a basis point, to 5.65.
Depositors at savings institutions saw the average yield on six-months certificates of deposit fall by 2 basis points, to 5.99, and the yield on three-month certificates of deposit dropped by a basis point, to 5.73 percent.
Yields on money market accounts tended not to change from the recent 5.54 percent level.
By comparison, at the 20 large regional banks around the country outside of New York, the average yields on money market accounts were down by 2 basis points, to 5.21 percent. For the six-month certificates of the 20 banks, the average was 5.71 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESSES AVOID SOUTH AFRICA TIES

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Despite President Bush's recent decision to lift economic sanctions against South Africa, most American companies that once owned businesses there say they have no plans to return soon, if at all.
Some companies that sold their businesses in South Africa, like the Coca-Cola Company, moved important operations to neighboring countries like Swaziland, and say they can serve the South African market from there. 
 Other companies, like the International Business Machines Corporation, sold their operations to local groups and signed agreements promising not to return and compete against their former operations.
"We have restrictions on whom they can sell to that we monitor closely, but we have no buyback arrangement and no right to compete with them," said Thomas Belz, an I.B.M. spokesman.
 
More Attractive Markets
 Many corporate executives also say that with the opening of Eastern Europe and markets elsewhere in the developing world, they find more promising opportunities for investment than in South Africa.
And many executives expect the 75 American city and state governments that have policies against doing business with companies that have ties to South Africa to keep those restrictions in place until South Africa extends equal voting rights to all citizens.
Indeed, on the day President Bush ended the sanctions, Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York announced broad new rules that would limit city business with banks that have ties to South Africa. And Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, among others, said the President had acted too soon.
Groups opposing apartheid are also continuing to keep pressure on businesses to adopt a wait-and-see stance.
"If pressure at the state and local level continues, it just won't be worth it for a lot of companies to go back to South Africa," said Richard Knight, a researcher at the American Committee on Africa in New York. "And Bush's action angered some groups enough that there could be more pressure to pass local laws against involvement in South Africa, not less."
 
Move by Big Banks
 Against this backdrop, Citibank and other major banks immediately responded to Mr. Bush's move by restating their policies against making new loans to South Africa. And J. P. Morgan & Company, which only two months ago yielded to anti-apartheid pressures in deciding to halt trading in American depository receipts that represent shares of South African stocks, said it was not ready to resume normal relations.
In similar fashion, Coca-Cola said it would continually review its options but had no plans to return to South Africa. It withdrew from the country in 1986, selling a number of assets, including 30 percent of a large bottler and an 80 percent interest in a canning plant. It also closed a sales and marketing office.
Today, Coke continues to supply beverage concentrates to bottlers in South Africa and eight other African countries from the plant it built in Swaziland, a tiny nation surrounded by South Africa.
 
Agreements With Buyers
 I.B.M. and the Mobil Corporation said they have agreements with the buyers of the businesses they formerly owned in South Africa not to return and compete against them. Mobil's non-compete agreement with Gencor Ltd., a South African conglomerate that bought its 1,200 service stations and other assets, runs through 1995.
In general, the poor economic outlook for the near term and fears of violence are likely to discourage reinvestment by the companies that left and to curb investments by newcomers.
The Ford Motor Company, which had a 42 percent stake in Samcor, a company that employed 6,500 workers at a Port Elizabeth assembly plant, gave more than half its investment to a worker-owned trust and sold the rest to the Anglo-American Corporation in 1987.
At the time Ford pulled out, its operations had been only marginally profitable at best for more than a decade, and the company has no plans to go back, a company spokesman said.
 
'A Long Way to Go'
 That stance is shared by many other companies. "We enthusiastically welcome President Bush's action, but there is a long way to go before we get what everyone wants," said Sal G. Marzullo, administrator of the Industrial Support Unit Inc., a coalition of 57 American companies that have maintained operations in South Africa and 22 others that pulled out but still support American investment there.
The lifting of sanctions provides one immediate benefit for American companies in South Africa: the restoration of their right to receive Federal tax credits for taxes paid to the South African Government.
Under legislation introduced by Represenative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, the South African subsidiaries of American companies had been limited in taking deductions for such payments since sanctions began in 1986. That tax penalty was cited by companies like Mobil as a major factor in their decisions to pull out.
 
Expanding Relationships
 The end of sanctions might also encourage companies that had been developing trading relationships with South African companies to expand their activities.
"We had already been seeing a steady increase in the number of companies with licensing, distribution and franchising agreements," said Alison Cooper, senior analyst with the South Africa Research Service at the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington. "Some of that was from companies selling their operations, but it includes a number of computer companies that had never had operations there."
Most companies that stayed, like Johnson & Johnson, say their current investments are sufficient to serve the local market.
Another disincentive to investing in South Africa is the better opportunities elsewhere. Eastern Europe and many developing countries are competing for the same investment dollars. And some companies are heavily indebted or under severe competitive pressures in markets that are far more important to them than South Africa.

HEADLINE: Soviets, in Surprise, Apply for Full World Bank Status

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
In a move that surprised the White House and put new pressure on Western Governments to help the Soviet Union, the Soviet Government has applied for full membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
The Soviet action, which was taken late Monday and announced today by both lending agencies, came less than a week after the leaders of seven industrial democracies endorsed in London a more limited "special association" with the I.M.F. and the World Bank for the Soviet Union. 
 Full membership would allow the Soviet Union, which is struggling to cope with a sharply shrinking economy and a growing foreign debt, to borrow from both institutions. Associate status would only permit the I.M.F. and the World Bank to offer technical assistance, such as the training of Soviet officials and advice on how to rebuild industries and create free-market institutions such as a modern banking sytem.
An Administration official said today that it was not clear to the United States why Moscow took the action at this point.
 
A Week in the Mail
 The letter, an I.M.F. official said, was dated July 15 -- the day before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived in London. The Administration official said that the United States does not know why it took the Soviets a week to deliver the letter.
The United States opposes the Soviet move and still agrees with the views of Britain's Prime Minister, officials said. "Our position is as John Major outlined it in London -- that we would favor associate membership status and that full membership is premature," one official said.
The Soviet application has been sent for review by the 22-member executive boards of each institution. If they approve it, the application would then be considered by all of the 155 member countries of each agency.
A series of technical details concerning the size of the Soviet contribution to each agency would still need to be settled if membership is approved. The United States, which provides a fifth of the I.M.F.'s money and a little more than a sixth of the World Bank's money and has corresponding votes at each institution, could not block the Soviet application by itself.
 
Procedure for Associate Status
 By contrast, associate status for the Soviet Union could be approved by a majority vote of the executive board alone.
An I.M.F. official said a Soviet application to join that institution as a full member did not conflict with plans to offer associate status. Applications for full membership take one or two years to process even for small countries, he pointed out, and the I.M.F. could grant associate status in the meantime.
The timing of the Soviet application could not be worse from the Administration's perspective, coming as it does just a few days before the scheduled summit meeting between Mr. Gorbachev and President Bush and at a time when the United States is interested in giving the Soviet Union things, not denying them. "This letter raises the ante a bit more than we're comfortable with," an official said. "It's a bit awkward for us. The last thing we want to be doing at this point is denying something to the Soviets."
 
U.S.-Soviet Trade Treaty
 At the same time, the United States and the Soviet Union were redoubling their efforts to broaden their commercial ties by removing the last obstacle to ratifying a trade agreement that was signed here last year giving the Soviet Union favorable tariff treatment. Mr. Bush has not yet sent the treaty to the Senate for its approval.
After the agreement was signed, the Soviet Union passed laws on copyright protection that were stricter than those envisioned in the trade pact. But American officials said today that the two countries were working on a document in which the Soviet Union would guarantee that those provisions never take effect and promise to revise them with future legislation. If that commitment is given in the next few days, Mr. Bush is prepared to send the trade pact to the Senate before heading to Moscow, officials said.
In another issue of concern to the Bush Administration, the United States is insisting that the Soviet Union account for all of its intermediate range nuclear missiles in Europe. The White House said today that the Soviet Union misled the United States about how many of these missiles it had deployed in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria before it signed the 1988 treaty that banned them. "This is not a new issue, but it is a real outstanding issue and we continue to press it," said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.
 
How Many Soviet Members?
 Full membership poses a major policy issue for the I.M.F. This is whether the Soviet Union would join as a single country with one central bank or whether special deals would be struck with one or more of the Soviet Union's increasingly fractious 15 republics, some of which are trying to assert control over monetary and economic policies within their borders.
Another issue is the convertibility of the Soviet ruble. Although the I.M.F. does not require that a country's currency be convertible for the counry to join, it then makes convertibility one of its first goals.
Soviet membership in either institution would pose several thorny bureaucratic issues that could take months or years to resolve, I.M.F. and World Bank officials have said.
The World Bank, for example, has a fixed number of shares, and the Soviet Union would have to find a nation willing to part with some of its shares in order to join the organization. Industrialized nations own most of the shares and have traditionally been reluctant to give them up because their representatives on the World Bank's executive board carry votes in proportion to their countries' holdings.
 
U.S. Blocked Loans
 The United States controls 18 percent of the votes on the board now, and has used its resulting influence to block World Bank loans to unfriendly countries and to push for changes in the World Bank's environmental and other policies.
The I.M.F. does not have a limited number of shares. Instead, new members are simply asked to contribute a sum of money corresponding to the size of their economy, so that the total capital base of the I.M.F. is increased. New members also gain votes on the I.M.F.'s 22-member executive board in direct proportion to their contributions.
But the size of the Soviet economy is unclear, because Soviet statistics are unreliable and because much of the Soviet Union's output is of such poor quality that it cannot be traded internationally.
In addition to the size of a Soviet contribution to the I.M.F., it is also unclear what currencies the Soviet Union would use and how it would raise the money. The I.M.F. has traditionally required that new members pay a portion of their contribution in an internationally traded currency such as the American dollar or the Japanese yen.
The Soviet Union's reserves of gold and foreign exchange are not known in the West, but the country has been borrowing large sums abroad while Soviet enterprises have encountered increasing difficulty this year in raising money to pay the interest on their foreign debts.
The Soviet economy needs technical and humanitarian aid, a senior I.M.F. official who insisted on anonymity told reporters in April, because it had performed worse than the Fund's worst-case scenario in a major study completed only a few months before.

HEADLINE: Pepsico Earnings Up 8.8% in the 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Pepsico Inc., the soft-drink, restaurant and snack-food giant, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 8.8 percent over the quarter last year.
Earnings were $318.3 million, or 39 cents a share, compared with the net income of $292.5 million, or 36 cents, in the comparable quarter last year. 
 The earnings were roughly in line with analysts' expectations but investors seemed worried about the recession's effects on Pepsico's varied businesses. On the New York Stock Exchange, Pepsi's stock closed at $29 a share, unchanged.
Sales in the quarter ended June 15 rose 11 percent, to $4.68 billion from the year-earlier $4.2 billion.
Hugh S. Zurkuhlen of Salomon Brothers, one of the most bearish of analysts covering Pepsico, described the company's performance as being helped by lower borrowing costs because of lower interest rates. Its net interest expense totaled $101 million in the latest quarter compared with $120 million the year before. But unforeseen factors hurt, as well, including a potato shortage that raised ingredient costs and thus hurt snack-food profitability by about $16 million in the quarter.
 
Restaurants Are Strong
 The strongest-performing sector of Pepsico's business was its restaurants, with the exception of Kentucky Fried Chicken, which reported a profit decline on an increase in sales. Soft-drink earnings performed well, although sales rose weakly in the United States market.
The worst-performing sector once was snack foods, which accounts for a third of operating profits. Pepsico's Frito-Lay products dominate the market with such brands as Doritos tortilla chips and Ruffles potato chips, but price discounting by smaller but growing rivals like Borden, Anheuser-Busch's Eagle snacks unit and Keebler have forced Frito-Lay to cut prices, too, thus hurting earnings.
Worldwide profit for the Pepsico's snack foods declined 7 percent in the quarter, to $206.3 million, with a 9 percent decline in the United States, to $158.2 million. Snack-food sales rose 12 percent, to $1.32 billion, with much of that rise attributed to strong growth -- 20 percent -- in the smaller foreign business; foreign profit, however, rose only about 1 percent.
 
Discounting Troubles
 Mr. Zurkuhlen of Salomon said that despite Frito-Lay's dominance of snack foods, the unit will find it difficult to maintain profits because of heavy discounting in supermarkets.
"Unless you've got them addicted in some way," Mr. Zurkuhlen said, "you can't continue to charge customers high prices, which is something McDonald's and Procter & Gamble are finding in the markets they dominate."
Restaurants performed well, led by Pizza Hut. Profit for the restaurant business grew 14 percent to $154.8 million, but Pizza Hut's earnings grew 22 percent, to $78.4 million. Taco Bell's increase was close behind at a 19 percent increase, but Kentucky Fried Chicken's sales declined 5 percent, despite a 17 percent rise in sales. Pepsico cited heavy price discounting in fast-food restaurants that sliced profit margins at Kentucky Fried Chicken.
 
Change at Pizza Hut
 Pizza Hut prospered despite the fact that company-owned stores open for at least a year had a sales increase of only 1 percent for the quarter and only 2 percent for the six months.
One factor is the growing Pizza Hut delivery business, which now accounts for an estimated $400 million in the second quarter out of perhaps $1.8 billion in sales at company-owned and franchised stores. Pizza Hut typically earns more money from a delivered pizza than a pizza in a restaurant.
While there are heavy start-up costs to buy automobiles and train drivers, the cost of a Pizza Hut delivery outlet, with smaller square footage and capital costs, is perhaps $300,000, compared with $600,000 to $800,000 for a sit-down restaurant, Mr. Zurkuhlen said. Labor costs are lower, too.
Soft-drink earnings, still accounting for more than 40 percent of profits, rose 10 percent to $256.3 million, on an 8 percent rise in sales to $1.72 billion.
The American soft-drink business performed fairly well, but second-quarter earnings rose 12 percent to $214.6 million, partly because year-earlier earnings were hurt by a $4.5 million bad-debt charge, principally for the troubled Circle K convenience-store chain, which filed for bankruptcy protection last year .
