HEADLINE: Soviets Plan to Sell 30% Interest In Big State-Owned Auto Maker

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
In a step toward capitalist reform, the Soviet Union is planning to sell a large stake in a big industrial corporation to a foreign investor, advisers to the Soviet Government said yesterday.
The state-owned company, the Volga Automotive Plant Association, is the country's dominant producer of passenger cars. Its no-frills Lada sedans, sold throughout Europe and Canada but not in the United States, are the Soviet Union's leading manufactured export. The Government intends to sell at least 30 percent of the company, a holding that recent Soviet press reports have speculated may be worth more than $1 billion. 
 Joint ventures involving foreign partners are numerous in the Soviet Union. But the sprawling Volga plant in the industrial heartland of Russia, where 120,000 workers turn out more than 700,000 cars a year, has been singled out to become the first big Soviet industrial company with large direct investment by a foreigner.
The planned privatization stems from talks between the Soviet Government and Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, which helped build the Volga plant in 1967; those talks have been reported in the Soviet and European press. And Fiat remains the front-runner to buy the stake of 30 percent or more of VAZ, the Russian abbreviation for the Volga auto works.
 
Help From Wall Street
 Yet the Soviet Government last month hired Bear, Stearns & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, to assist with the sale of the VAZ stake. The move is seen not as a rebuff to Fiat, but as a bit of capitalist savvy on the part of Soviet bureaucrats eager to obtain the highest possible price.
"The Soviets just want to make sure there is a free-market process for getting an industrial partner," said Brian Murray, a senior managing director of Bear, Stearns.
To date, privatization in the Soviet Union has been confined mainly to small, typically family-run establishments like restaurants, shops and trading firms. Proposals have circulated in the Soviet Parliament calling for the sweeping privatization of as much as two-thirds of the economy, but these are mostly just grist for debate.
Moscow trails Eastern European neighbors like Poland and Czechoslovakia in selling state-owned companies, largely because it lacks a popular mandate for bold reforms. To many Soviet citizens, a free-market economy is still associated with black marketeers and price gouging.
Accordingly, analysts say they doubt that the Volga deal will soon pave the way for a flood of similar transactions. Instead, they view the Volga works as an extraordinary property -- at least by the humble standards of Soviet industry -- that can attract a foreign investor despite the political and economic uncertainties in the country.
"It's unlikely that broad-scale privatization with foreign partners is going to take place in the environment in the Soviet Union today," said David Lipton, an economist for the World Institute for Development Economics Research in Helsinki.
Fiat recently hired Morgan Grenfell & Company, a London merchant bank, to help it place a value on VAZ. "It's all part of the game," said Gualberto Ranieri, a vice president of Fiat U.S.A. Inc., referring to the introduction of investment bankers in the negotiations. "But, clearly, Fiat is on the front line for this deal."
In April, Paolo Cantarella, president of Fiat's automobile operations, signed an agreement with the Soviet Government laying out guidelines for negotiations on the sale of the VAZ stake. But the Soviets are not prevented from talking with other interested companies, Government advisers said.
 
Close Ties to Fiat
 Fiat's links with the Volga works are deep and longstanding. The factory at Togliatti, 700 miles southeast of Moscow, was largely designed by Italian engineers and its first product, built in 1970, was a Soviet version of the Fiat 124, a small economy car. The city of Togliatti, which was formerly called Stavropol, is on a plain near the Volga River and was named for the Italian Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti, who died in 1964.
The relationship with Fiat remains a close one, including recent joint work on the development of new models. But with the thaw in cold war tensions, VAZ has broadened its links with Western auto companies.
Last year, VAZ selected the General Motors Corporation's A. C. Rochester division to supply emission-control systems for its export models. The five-year supply agreement, running from 1992 to 1997, is expected to be worth about $1 billion. VAZ needs the upgraded emissions-control technology to meet tighter pollution standards in the European Community, an important export market for the Lada. The new standards take effect next year.
The interest of Western auto companies besides Fiat in bidding for the VAZ stake is unclear, and Bear, Stearns said it had not yet approached other companies.
"We're always interested in opportunities, but we have not looked at other investments or projects in the Soviet Union other than supplying the emission systems," said John Pekarek, a spokesman for G.M.'s international operations.
 
Trying to Set a Value
 The sale of the VAZ stake will probably take place sometime next year. The delay will allow time for the lengthy legal and financial work needed to place a value on a big company in a nation where the concepts of pricing and private ownership are unsophisticated by Western standards.
Bear, Stearns must first work on valuing the automotive operations of VAZ, separating those from the workers' housing, hospitals and schools that VAZ provides for its employees in the company town. And the American investment bankers regard the estimates of the likely price on the VAZ stake that have appeared in the Soviet press as "sheer speculation at this stage."
Several layers of government must be consulted on the deal, including ministries of both the central Government and the newly vigorous Russian republic. And the uncertain political environment in the Soviet Union will be an additional risk for any Western company, whose hard-currency investment will go to VAZ for building new assembly operations and developing new models.
Still, for a patient company willing to bet that the Soviet economy will improve -- raising the living standards of its vast population -- and that the Government will make its currency convertible, the investment in VAZ could turn out to be lucrative indeed.
VAZ exports more than a third of its production, with most models selling for $8,000 to $10,000 in their foreign markets. By Soviet standards, it has been a pioneer, being one of the first factories, for example, to experiment with self-financing under which enterprises pay most of their own expenses and investment costs from the profits they generate.
But it badly needs foreign investment and know-how to catch up with Western auto companies and stay even with new competition in its export markets. Those rivals include the Proton automobile from Malaysia, designed with help from Mitsubishi of Japan. The Proton has been taking sales from Lada in some European export markets.
In the Soviet Union, by contrast, consumers wait for years for delivery of a Zhiguli, as the Lada is known in the domestic market.

HEADLINE: Democrats Use a Hearing To Berate Bush Economist

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
Sounding what is sure to be a campaign theme next year, Democratic lawmakers today berated Michael J. Boskin, the Bush Administration's chief economist, accusing the Administration of ignoring the nation's economic problems and of being callous to the plight of the unemployed.
While Mr. Boskin sat mostly silent before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, looking somewhat like a teen-ager being dressed down by the high school principal, one prominent Democrat after another criticized especially the Administration's policy of opposing unemployment benefits for people out of work more than six months. 
 "I hope you'll take the message back to the President," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, the committee chairman. "I mean, these people are hurting. These are Americans. The President reacted when he saw people abroad hurting. We ought not to do any less for our own people in this circumstance."
Some of the Democrats, demanding lower interest rates, also provided a preview of the Senate's hearings on the confirmation of Alan Greenspan for another four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
But Mr. Boskin, who like others in the Bush Administration has at times criticized the Fed's tight money policy, did not jump at the bait this time. He said the Fed should adopt a "wait-and-see attitude" on interest rates for the time being but should be "prepared to move" if the recovery proved more sluggish than expected.
Although Mr. Greenspan's current term expires Aug. 11, the Senate will not vote until after Labor Day to confirm him for another term.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Banking Committee, said in an interview today that his panel was so preoccupied with banking legislation that it would not have time to consider the Greenspan confirmation until Congress returned from its August recess.
Mr. Riegle said that while some witnesses representing organized labor would testify against Mr. Greenspan, and some Senators would criticize the Fed's policies, he did not know of any Senators who planned to vote against confirmation.
Mr. Greenspan will serve as acting chairman between the time his term expires and he is confirmed for another term, and the operations of the Federal Reserve are expected to proceed without change.
 
Rates Discussed in Passing
 Interest rates and the Federal Reserve were discussed in passing at today's hearing. Most of it dealt with the Administration's economic policy in general and unemployment benefits in particular.
The Joint Economic Committee, comprised of senior Senators and Representatives, does not have the authority to propose legislation itself, and its Democrats are thus freer than those on most other committees to criticize the Administration without accepting responsibility for specific alternatives.
Today, with Mr. Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, as their foil, the Democrats came prepared to challenge the Administration's argument that the recession was short, shallow and now over.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the end of the recession was news to the tens of thousands still out of work in New England and accused the Administration of "standing by while the economy has been staggering."
Representative Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland, declared, "Oppression, deprivation, denial and disprivilege still remain very real impediments to millions of people in this country who, again, don't feel buoyed by the rosy forecast that you've painted."
The Democrats repeatedly pressed Mr. Boskin on the plight of about three million workers whose unemployment compensation has been exhausted. Normally, workers who lose their jobs get benefits for 26 weeks. In every other recent recession, Congress and the Administration have approved another 26 weeks of benefits for those who are still jobless, but the Bush Administration opposes an extension of benefits.
Congress may to vote this fall to extend Federal unemployment payments for an additional six months, but Mr. Boskin said he would recommend that President Bush veto the measure unless the spending was offset with cuts elsewhere.
"Are you prepared to offer any suggestions as to programs that might be cut in order to provide an offset?" asked Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn.
Mr. Boskin replied: "I think that's Congress's responsibility. You know, the priorities setting, et cetera. I wouldn't presume on that."
Mr. Solarz then said, "It's absurd to say that this is solely the responsibility of Congress. The President submits a budget every year in which his priorities are established."
 
Distinct Disadvantage
 Mr. Boskin was at a distinct disadvantage in such exchanges. On the one hand, while his advice on economic matters is highly regarded within the Administration, the policy is mostly set by others. On the other hand, he is savvy enough to know that it does no good to argue with lawmakers out to score political points.
In addition, the Republicans on the committee by and large did not come to Mr. Boskin's defense, although at one point, Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire said that "there's enough blame to go around" and that "to come down as hard as you have this morning, gentlemen, on Mr. Boskin is a little bit out of line."

HEADLINE: A Women's Chain Beckons to Men

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
When Sara Lee bought the Coach Leatherware Company in 1985, there were 6 company-owned stores selling mostly traditional sturdy handbags. The company has opened 48 more stores and stocked them with added luxuries like silk scarves and leather luggage.
Now, with some gentle prodding from its parent, which knows a thing or two about building brand names, Coach is moving to conquer the market for expensive accessories and extend the Coach appeal to younger consumers. At the same time, it has opened its first stores intended specifically to woo the affections of men. 
 True to its reputation for fastidious understatement, Coach is avoiding flashy advertisements and celebrity endorsements. Instead the company is hoping its boutiques will work as its main marketing tools and laboratories for new products like more shapely handbags in peacock blue, golden yellow and coral.
In May, the flagship Coach for Business store opened on the corner of Madison Avenue and 44th Street in Manhattan, and became the company's calling card to men. Regular Coach stores have long carried leather wallets and other small items for men, but the new store and another in Boston are the company's first with mostly men's goods. The store has sturdy leather attaches, briefcases, appointment books and desk accessories at $16 to more than $600.
Trying to expand a prestigious brand's market share is always risky, as companies like Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent can attest. But corporate image consultants said that adding products and stores was a good if somewhat limited way to capitalize on the Coach name.
"Although it's not terribly well known, it's tremendously admired by those who do know it," said Stewart Owen, executive vice president of Landor Associates, a San Francisco marketing consulting firm. "That would certainly suggest to us that making the brand name better known is a good strategy."
The Madison Avenue store, with its stark neoclassic storefront and intimate interior lined with dark mahogany display cases is a discreet "Ahem!" aimed at the bankers, lawyers, journalists and business people who frequent Brooks Brothers, Paul Stuart and J. Press, the staid and starchy men's stores that are its neighbors.
At lunch hour, customers fill the slate-and-marble floor of the tiny shop. Many are fingering the silk ties, peering into the pockets and recesses of briefcases and surreptitiously sniffing the scent of new leather.
At least half the shoppers are women, perhaps not surprising since the company is betting that Coach for Business will both introduce more men to its products and increase sales to women.
 
The Numbers Are Good
 The company said the store has rung up sales of $3,000 to $4,000 a square foot since it opened, numbers retail sales experts say are impressive even by pre-recession standards.
Even so, Coach executives maintain that sales are not really the store's raison d'etre.
"Of course we're interested in strong sales there, but we're more interested in sending a message," said Lew Frankfort, who is Coach's decidedly unstarchy chief executive, despite his navy blue braces. "Coach for Business is a showcase that says while we're still a handbag business, we are now a full-range accessories company for men and women."
For those who want some visible sign of status, a tiny, detachable leather label stamped with the Coach logo does dangle from the straps or handles of many bags. But for true Coach aficionados, leaving the tag on is, well, gauche.
Although Coach probably contributed only $150 million to $200 million to Sara Lee's estimated $12.5 billion in sales for the year ended June 30, the parent company is grooming Coach's name in much the same way it cultivated Hanes, once a small hosiery company that analysts say is now probably Sara Lee's single biggest source of income.
Mr. Owen, the marketing consultant, said companies gained more control over the exclusivity of their brand name by opening shops that market their products. He noted that Hermes and Dunhill, two of Coach's competitors, used similar strategies.
By contrast, Gucci, with its interlocking G's, and Yves Saint Laurent, widely known by its YSL logo, gave licenses to too many products and outside manufacturers, shattering their cachet, Mr. Owen said.
"When YSL was on $2,000 and $3,000 dresses at the same time it was on a $19.95 men's polyester dress shirt, it destroyed the exclusivity of the brand," he said.
Mr. Frankfort views the mail order catalogue that the company started in 1980 as another good way to spread the name into the nation's most affluent homes.
"We'd continue the direct marketing even if it wasn't profitable because it gives us great access to the homes of those predisposed to buying Coach," Mr. Frankfort said.
Analysts say the hallmarks of Sara Lee can be seen in the new stores, the foray into the accessories business and Coach's recent switch to Kirshenbaum & Bond, the New York advertising agency that signed Donna Rice to endorse No Excuses jeans and has a reputation for innovative, offbeat concepts. Sara Lee bought Coach from its founder, Miles Cahn, in 1985.
 
Global Growth Potential
 "Coach clearly fits Sara Lee's strategy as a branded consumer product with international growth potential," said Paul Fulton, president of Sara Lee.
Coach's sales are expected to grow by 20 percent this year, but the company is not likely to challenge Hanes's leading position within Sara Lee. "The opportunity to make it enormous like Hanes is probably limited because of the high-priced, high-quality positioning of the product," said Nomi Ghez, who follows Sara Lee for Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But it's still a very nice, fast-growing, prestigious business for them to be in, and they still have plenty of room to expand overseas."
Coach already has two stores in London and one in Stuttgart, Germany. Mitsukoshi, the prestigious Japanese retailer, has Coach boutiques in 19 of its stores in Japan, where Coach is the fourth most popular brand of handbag, after Louis Vuitton, Chanel and Hunting World.
Coach sales in department stores increased by 5 percent last year, and now account for more than 60 percent of the company's total sales, Mr. Frankfort said.
Karen Katz, vice president and divisional manager for leather accessories at Neiman Marcus, said sales of Coach handbags had increased steadily over the years, although higher-priced purses by Chanel and Bottega Veneta are the stores' best sellers.
"Although it's basically the lowest-priced bag we carry," she said of Coach, "it offers the customer a powerful price-value relationship. It delivers a very high quality at a lower price."
 
Attention to Detail
 That quality is guaranteed by excruciating attention to detail. The cattle whose skin is used in Coach luggage, introduced in some stores last spring, are deticked daily and dine from special feeding troughs that keep them from bending their necks lest their leather be marred by wrinkles.
But even high quality is no guarantee that every new line will work out. One collection of understated men's ties and suspenders and ladies' scarves had to be sent back to the drawing board after Coach started selling them in 1987. Emblazoned with bridles and stirrups and other horsey paraphernalia, they too closely resembled Hermes scarves.
"We don't think imitation is the best form of flattery," said Mr. Frankfort, perhaps recalling the lawsuit Coach brought against Ann Taylor for producing a bag remarkably similar to a Coach. "But it was a compliment to know our American-made Coach products are good enough to be mistaken for a very fine European luxury."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lew Frankfort, the president of Coach Leatherware, straightened up a display of men's accessories during a recent visit to the company's new Coach for Business store on Madison Avenue and 44th Street. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Anti-Japan Din in France Softens a Bit

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 23

 BODY:
Having upset Japan with repeated gibes and alarmed French fashion houses that sell to Japan, Prime Minister Edith Cresson made a point of asking to sit next to the wife of Japan's Ambassador to France at the first haute couture show of the season here this week.
As a public relations gimmick, it was a bit obvious. As a political insight, it was more telling. For the first time since taking office nine weeks ago, Mrs. Cresson seemed to recognize that her penchant for speaking her mind was the source of her growing troubles. 
 Strained relations with Japan is just one result of what has become known as her "langue crue" -- her "raw tongue." She has also questioned the sexuality of Anglo-Saxon men, sniped at her predecessor and provoked protests from stockbrokers and human rights groups with her choice of words.
 
Conservatives Drink It In
 The conservative opposition is delighted. But President Francois Mitterrand, her worried friend, mentor and boss, has dispatched a team of image-makers to advise her, while her own colleagues in the Socialist Party cringe every time she speaks in public.
Polls show that her popularity stands lower than any Prime Minister's in a generation; in the latest survey, just 18 percent said they were satisfied with her performance. Many women who welcomed the appointment of the first woman to serve as France's Prime Minister now express disappointment.
But by all accounts her problems stem less from what she has done. Even her political foes concede that she inherited an economic recession, labor unrest, an explosive immigration issue and no easy answers. Rather, the political issue of the day has become what she says and how she says it.
An elegant, strong-willed 57-year-old, she has never minced her words. And after she took over on May 15, her past frankness came back to haunt her. In a 1987 interview that was published only in June, for example, she proclaimed that 25 percent of English, American and German men were gay.
Complaints that it was unfair to dredge up old statements were soon forgotten. Her opening statement to Parliament disappointed her Socialist colleagues, but television viewers were more taken aback to hear her describing her male critics in the National Assembly as "machos and hyenas."
In a television interview, she also said she "didn't give a damn" about the Paris Stock Exchange, while she stirred a political storm in her own party and among human rights groups by using the word "charter" to describe special flights to be used to deport illegal immigrants.
Even her predecessor and fellow Socialist, Michel Rocard, did not escape her tongue. She said repeatedly that she was bequeathed problems that his Government had chosen to ignore; on one occasion, she raised eyebrows by indirectly questioning his patriotism.
Her views on homosexuality also got a fresh airing on the ABC News program "Prime Time Live" on July 18, when she noted in perfect English that "it exists more in the Anglo-Saxon tradition than in the Latin one." She added, "Well, it's a fact of civilization."
But nothing has caused more controversy than her attacks on what she describes as Japan's strategy of expanding its economic power to embrace Europe. "They are in a position to destroy any industrial target that they decide to destroy," she said last month.
On "Prime Time Live," offering an opinion more often thought than voiced in the West, she said Japan believed that "the Japanese market is ours and the rest of the world is for us also." She denied calling the Japanese "ants," but added, "I say they work like ants."
And she went on: "But we don't want to live like that. I mean, in the small flats, with two hours to go to your job and -- we want to keep our social security, our holidays, and we want to live as human beings in the way that we've been always used to live."
In Japan, her remarks prompted demonstrations outside the French Embassy, and on Bastille Day, July 14, rightist protesters decapitated her in effigy. Now, fearful of a backlash against their products, French fashion, perfume and liquor exporters are also complaining about her bluntness.
 
As for You Men . . .
 Until she sat next to Yukiko Kiuchi, the wife of Japan's Ambassador to France, at the Torrente fashion show on Sunday, Mrs. Cresson has given no hint that she is having second thoughts about the effectiveness of her style.
Rather, she has preferred to fault France's male-dominated society. "It has always been more difficult for a woman to do anything in France," she said. Asked if she believed that France was ready for a woman as President, she responded, "No, I don't think so, not for another 100 years."
One man, however, has been quick to jump to her defense. In a television interview on July 14, President Mitterrand said, "It is healthy to have a Prime Minister who speaks clearly, who faces up to problems and has the courage to deal with them."
Asked whether her appointment was not "a bad good idea," Mr. Mitterrand insisted that he was relieved to hear someone speaking the language of the people "after 15 years of technocratic language." He added, "There are plenty of people who are against her, but I am for her."
Increasingly, though, the question being asked here is, for how long? With legislative elections due before 1993, Mrs. Cresson was named to replace Mr. Rocard in the hope that her energetic approach would revive the Socialists' flagging fortunes. So far, Mr. Mitterrand has seen his own popularity slip to its lowest level in years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edith Cresson, left, the outspoken Prime Minister of France, made a point of sitting next to Yukiko Kiuchi, the wife of Japan's Ambassador to France, during a recent fashion show. She had strained relations with Japan as a result of what has become known as her "raw tongue." (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
3 Media Companies Report Lower Profits in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Three big media companies, the Washington Post Company, Knight-Ridder Inc. and McClatchy Newspapers, reported lower second-quarter earnings yesterday, partly because of the soft advertising market.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 

Washington Post
The company said its profit tumbled 37 percent in the quarter, also reflecting one-time expenses for staff reductions at the flagship newspaper.
It earned $35.1 million, or $2.95 a share, for the quarter, down from $55.9 million, or $4.60 a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 6 percent to $356.6 million, from $379.6 million.
The newspaper division's revenue dropped 10 percent. Advertising volume at The Washington Post declined 16.3 percent. Revenue fell 6 percent at Newsweek magazine and 9 percent in broadcasting, but rose 11.5 percent in the cable television division.
Earnings were also cut by a one-time $6 million charge for severance pay and related costs from the reduction of about 80 jobs at The Post.
The company's class B shares fell 50 cents each yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $223.50.
 
Knight-Ridder
Knight-Ridder, a newspaper and information services company based in Miami, reported a drop of nearly 7 percent in its second-quarter profit and said it might be unable to post a 16th straight year of growth in earnings per share.
Earnings were $41.6 million, or 82 cents a share, in the quarter, down from $44.6 million, or 88 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell nearly 4 percent to $569 million, from $592 million.
"The outlook for 1991 as a whole is clouded," said Robert Singleton, the company's chief financial officer. "We had hoped to have better results from our newspaper operations by now."
Newspapers in large markets are still struggling with advertising cuts resulting from the recession. Mr. Singleton said the company's performance for the year would depend on signs of an economic recovery.
"Unless the economy begins to show real vigor reasonably soon, the fourth-quarter improvement will not be sufficient to give us another year of earnings-per-share growth," he said.
The newspaper division's revenue was down 5.3 percent, to $486 million. Advertising revenue was down 9 percent, to $369 million, but the decline was partly offset by an 8.6 percent increase in circulation revenue, to $109 million.
Knight-Ridder publishes 29 daily newspapers, including The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer. Its shares rose 75 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $51.875.
 
McClatchy Newspapers
The newspaper and newsprint company said its profit fell 19.2 percent, mostly because of a fire at rental property it owns in Sacramento, Calif., where the company is based. McClatchy said the weak economy and a new California tax on newspaper circulation could hold its earnings for the year below the 1990 level.
Earnings fell to $6.3 million, or 22 cents a share, in the second quarter from $7.8 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. But revenue edged up 1.7 percent to $109.4 million, from $107.6 million.
Erwin Potts, the chief executive, said advertising volume continued to be soft in most markets.
The company, which publishes 11 daily and 8 nondaily newspapers, said 60 percent of the decline in earnings per share stemmed from a $1.3 million nonoperating loss before taxes resulting from a fire and cleanup at the rental property next to The Sacramento Bee's office.
McClatchy's stock fell 12.5 cents a share yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $21.625.

HEADLINE: Killing of 4-Year-Old Is Linked to Dispute at Pool

BYLINE: By JOSH KURTZ

 BODY:
A 4-year-old girl who was shot to death in a blaze of gunfire that left three others injured was the innocent victim of a feud that may have started at a swimming pool, the police said yesterday.
The child's pregnant mother, Eva Cade, and two other people were wounded in the drive-by shooting Monday night at 154th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem. The shooting came the same day that Mayor David N. Dinkins announced plans to deploy extra police officers in neighborhoods plagued by shootings of children. 
 Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said one of the three people wounded in the dispute, Kevin Thompson, 17 years old, may have been the target in the shooting, which apparently stemmed from a dispute at a swimming pool. Mr. Thompson, who was shot in the head, was listed in stable condition but had not regained consciousness last night so police were unable to question him.
The third person wounded in the shooting, Sandra Page, 36, was treated for a minor gunshot wound to the leg and was released yesterday from Harlem Hospital Center.
Neighbors and relatives said the mother of the slain 4-year-old was particularly devoted to the child, whose name was Jameeka but was often called Meeka
"She wouldn't go anywhere without Meeka," Ms. Cade's sister, Ethel Frazier, said yesterday in the lobby of Harlem Hospital Center, where Ms. Cade, 36, of 2900 Eighth Avenue, was listed in stable condition with two gunshot wounds to the leg.
Ms. Cade was going to the grocery store to buy some medicine when she and her daughter were shot, her sister said. Ms. Cade, a widow, was unemployed, and her life revolved around her five children, who range in age from 1 to 19.
"I would always see her walking around with the little girl," said Mary Jones, a 15-year resident of the block where the Cades live. "She would take her to school, take her shopping, everywhere." Neighbors said Jameeka seemed to enjoy her special status as her mother's constant companion.

HEADLINE: Weicker Veto Withstands Vote in House

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 23

 BODY:
The Connecticut legislature failed tonight to override Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s veto and pass a budget for the fiscal year that began 23 days ago, shattering the two-party coalition that had backed the plan.
With no new budget plans in the wings, the outcome of the vote also pushed the state toward what some lawmakers described as a degree of chaos and turmoil that had not yet been seen in the state's budget struggles. 
 "It seems to me it's this or shut the state down," said Representative Robert Farr, a Republican from West Hartford, in an anguished speech on the House floor urging members to override the Governor's July 1 veto.
"Without an override of the veto today, I personally see little resolution of the problem," said the Deputy Speaker, Dean P. Markham, Democrat of East Hampton.
 
14 Votes Short
 The budget plan, which was originally passed on June 30 by simple majorities in the House and Senate, needed 101 votes in the House, or two-thirds of the 151 members, to override Mr. Weicker's veto. But only 87 lawmakers voted for it.
By sustaining the veto, the House, which is led by Democrats, killed the budget, which had been formulated mainly by the Republican minority. The Republican leader in the House, Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., said after the vote that many of his party members had said they would now walk away from the process and the idea of a bipartisan solution.
Mr. Weicker praised the vote sustaining his veto, saying that the House had done its job and that the key to the solution now rested entirely in the hands of the Senate, which has blocked every attempt at passing an income tax. Mr. Weicker proposed a wage tax for the state in February and has vetoed two budgets that lacked the income tax. "We've seen 'No! No! No!' in terms of the ideas or the action being taken," Mr. Weicker said in a news conference in his office after the 9:30 P.M. vote. "My hand is extended."
The Speaker of the House, Richard J. Balducci, Democrat of Newington, said he was not sure what kind of budget might be considered next, or even whether another two-week budget could be passed by the House to keep the state running.
The Senate earlier tonight approved a two-week resolution that would maintain state spending commitments through Aug. 11, and the House is to take up the measure on Wednesday. Many lawmakers said tonight that they would vote against another temporary spending plan, to exert pressure to find a solution by the time the current resolution expires on Sunday.
Mr. Weicker also said he was hopeful. "There is no reason under the sun why the State of Connecticut and the legislative branch cannot produce a budget," he said.
The day leading up to the vote was filled with last-minute warnings from Mr. Weicker's budget office about the "flaws" in the legislative budget and anxious appeals by income-tax opponents trying to gather the last crucial votes needed to build the necessary two-thirds majority.
Mr. Weicker's office, in pushing to sustain the Governor's veto, issued a four-page critique to lawmakers outlining what it called the "bad balancing," "bad policy," "bad planning" and "bad business" elements of the plan.
The critique said that unspecified and overly optimistic spending cuts, increased borrowing and additional business taxes would all work to give the state a worsened economy and a budget that would be out of balance from the first day of passage.

HEADLINE: Manor Offers Lessons On the Lives of Slave

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
For the fifth graders, it was an eye-opening discovery to learn how slaves lived and labored in New York's colonial era.
"Slaves were not treated like humans, even though they worked hard and were skilled in many ways," said 10-year-old Jeanne Marie Vinchiarello, after a visit to Philipsburg Manor, a restored 18th-century farm here. "They prepared all the food but were not permitted to sit down and eat." 
 Other students were impressed that 23 African slaves virtually ran the farm and gristmill for the often absent Dutch owner -- precisely the type of lesson that an organization called Historic Hudson Valley wants to teach as it reinterprets early American history to focus more on the contributions of African slaves, Indians and Caribbean traders.
"We've always used the Hudson Valley properties as a way of presenting 250 years of history, but the perspective was too narrowly focused on the industrious Dutch and English colonists," said John H. Dobkin, president of the organization, which has restored four landmark sites. "Now we have corrected the balance, based on years of research and created a more inclusive 'living history' of our region."
In fact, a state-appointed panel of teachers and scholars recently recommended sweeping changes in the teaching of American history in public schools to give more emphasis on the roles of nonwhite cultures.
Acting long before the report, Historic Hudson had adopted its new approach. The organization, Mr. Dobkin said, was expanding research, rewriting brochures and sending staff members into local schools like St. Joseph's in Millbrook, where Jeanne Marie and the other fifth graders are students. The group also arranges for students to visit the properties and learn about early American customs from the organization's interpreters, 60 men and women in period dress.
 
Major Gifts Pledged
 These activities coincide with another goal, to increase Historic Hudson Valley's endowment by $20 million to $42 million, said Nancy Gold, the organization's marketing director. The money will help support Philipsburg Manor, Van Cortlandt Manor at Croton-on-Hudson, Montgomery Place at Annandale-on-Hudson and Sunnyside, the Tarrytown home of Washington Irving.
Two major gifts have been pledged, $7 million from the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest fund managed by New York Community Trust, and an additonal $5 million from Laurance S. Rockefeller, chairman emeritus of Historic Hudson Valley. Mr. Rockefeller has sought to broaden the group's financial base in much the same way as the support of Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia was expanded from a Rockefeller family activity to a more widely financed undertaking. Both the New York and Williamsburg restorations were begun by Mr. Rockefeller's father, John D. Rockefeller Jr.
Williamsburg also served as a model for the Hudson Valley preservation. Historians and staff members from Virginia helped the New Yorkers restore the properties, plan tours for visitors and set up an education program for schools.
The focus at Philipsburg is the interaction of Africans and Europeans, which has been largely ignored in history studies, said Radiah Harper Sumler, director of education for Historic Hudson Valley.
"Few people know trading ships from the Caribbean regularly sailed upriver with spices and cloth," she said. "Eighteen languages were spoken on the wharf. We had the seeds of New York City's multiethnic society long before we had an Ellis Island."
She is insistent on getting across that lesson to students, saying, "We owe it to the children we serve, African-American as well as white, to provide them with a sense of their heritage, so they can stand next to a buddy and know with pride they have a history and a proud past."
When Lee Hart, a 66-year-old interpreter, leads students through the barn where wheat is threshed and winnowed, Mrs. Sumler points out how the process resembles traditional African methods.
From Peter Curtis, a 41-year-old interpreter dressed as an 18th-century grist miller, students learned that some slaves were brought to the Hudson Valley because they were skilled in making farm tools.
"I can tell from the eye contact, they are surprised to learn slaves were not just field hands," Mr. Curtis said, "but they go home with an understanding that slaves had an important role here and, after the Emancipation, many likely gravitated toward work in the cities."
Historic Hudson wants to investigate further the history of the Philipsburg slaves with the help of scholars, including A. J. Williams-Meyers, executive director of the New York African American Institute at the State Univer sity of New York at Albany.
"Historians tend to focus on slavery in the South and glide over New York even though slavery existed here 40 years after the American Revolution," Professor Williams-Meyers said. A Federal census in 1790 found 21,324 slaves in New York, only 8,000 fewer than in Georgia, he said. The New York Legislature banned slavery in 1827, but some owners like the Van Cortlandts freed their slaves years earlier.
"Records at Philipsburg Manor give us a comprehensive look at their involvement -- they were carpenters and ship builders, millers and tool-makers -- and they helped New York develop one of the most prosperous economies of the time," Professor Williams-Meyers said. "It is important we recognize the interrelatedness of these people who shaped and developed our democratic society."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Students from Cathedral School in Manhattan touring Philipsburg Manor, a restored 18th-century farm in North Tarrytown, N.Y., in a program run by Historic Hudson Valley. The organization is focusing attention on the contributions of nonwhite cultures to early American history. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Oregon to Stress Job Training In Restructuring High School

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Oregon has approved an education plan that would be the first in the nation to establish a statewide apprenticeship program and would make students choose between job training or a college preparatory curriculum after 10th grade.
The plan for Oregon's high schools, the most radical component in an extensive state effort to overhaul public education, grew out of increasing concern among legislators and some educators that public schools have done a poor job of serving students who do not go to college. 
 The plan was also intended to attack the state's dropout rate of 25 percent in high school (the national rate is 28 percent, according to the United States Department of Education) by giving all students more options. State legislators and business leaders also hope the plan will improve the quality of Oregon's work force.
"We don't have serious technical programs to prepare students for a high-performance work world in the 1990's," said Ira Magaziner, a consultant in the development of the Oregon plan and co-author of a study last year for the National Center on Education and the Economy that offered a model for professional and technical curriculums. "In our view, this is a significant step forward."
The legislation also provides for Oregon's primary schools to be ungraded, with students from kindergarten through third grade grouped by their abilities rather than by age; for expansion of early childhood education programs, and for allowing parents to choose to send their children to any public school in the state.
 
Introduction in Stages
 The education package, which was approved last month by the Legislature and is scheduled to be signed next Wednesday by Gov. Barbara Roberts, is to be installed in stages through the year 2010.
Despite its passage by the Legislature and the Governor's enthusiastic support, the plan has drawn much criticism, particularly for the dual-track idea for high schools.
Many educators express concern that it has the potential to stigmatize students who are guided into the job-training track or to discourage young people from pushing themselves to attempt the academic track.
But Vera Katz, a state representative who was the legislation's chief sponsor, said the bill carried an provision calling for the creation of a state monitoring committee to insure that students were not steered to various curriculums because of social or economic factors.
"The last thing we want to do is perpetuate tracking," said Ms. Katz, a Democrat from Portland.
Under the Oregon plan, loosely based on western European models, high school students would be required to demonstrate competency by the 10th grade in math, science, reading and other academic courses, using new assessment tools being designed by the state, not the usual standardized tests.
 
Movement Between Tracks
 After demonstrating competency, the students would receive a certificate of initial mastery. They would then proceed, with advice from parents and school guidance counselors, into either a college preparatory curriculum or one of several vocational, business or professional curriculums in health, computer operations and other fields.
Students who do not demonstrate competency in the academic subjects would receive extra attention and continue to work until they are able to demonstrate it, education officials said.
Once students enrolled in their chosen curriculum as 11th graders, they would be free to move between the academic and the job-training curriculums if they are unhappy with their initial decisions.
In the revamped high school, students would then receive a certificate of advanced mastery upon completing the 12th grade, although state education officials said it might take some students longer to receive their final certificates depending on the rigor of their selected curriculums.
"It's quite innovative, and there is much to be said for this approach," Bob Palaich, director of policy studies at the Education Commission of the States, an education research and policy organization based in Denver, said of the apprenticeship component.
"We have been fighting the dropout problem, and this approach essentially says, 'Let's try to get kids up to speed by the 10th grade and then give them options,' " he said.
 
Similarities With Bush Plan
 The Oregon education package has many features similar to the "Education 2000" plan of the Bush Administration, such as allowing parental choice rather than zoning children into neighborhood schools.
But the state's plan for high schools "goes a little further and is a little more expansive than the Bush plan," said Joyce Reinke, director of personnel development for the Oregon Department of Education who will oversee implementation of the plan.
Although educators generally support the idea of overhauling education, they and other critics have maligned the legislation's pay-as-you-go provision, under which the financing of each stage depends on future legislatures. That, critics assert, would allow officials to abandon aspects of the plan, such as early-child programs that are needed but may also prove unpopular among voters because they are expensive.
Critics have also opposed the bill's school-choice component. They maintain that choice programs require heavy spending to accommodate students whose parents cannot afford transportation costs to other schools without aid.
Given the pay-as-you-go feature, critics question the future resolve to pay transportation costs.
But the high school plan has triggered the most debate among residents, educators, legislators and the business community. The Oregon plan, supporters said, will better prepare students for life after high school, particularly those who plan to move into the workplace immediately rather than attend college.
"Our current system isn't working very well, so we might as well give this a shot," said Gary Carlson, vice president of Associated Oregon Industries in Salem, which represents the state's 14,000 to 15,000 businesses. "It sounds like a realistic approach."
Companies have become increasingly alarmed by the growing gap between the quality of high school graduates and the skills needed for a variety of positions that do not necessarily require a college degree but require more skills than current high school graduates have.
Indeed, a study last year by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics projected a healthy growth rate in jobs in the technical, professional and health areas, but many high school counselors say and students themselves acknowledge they lack the background to step into those positions.
 
Work in Both Tracks Envisioned
 State education officials and business leaders are still discussing how to set up the apprenticeship part of the plan, but they said they envisioned students in the business and professional track continuing to take academic courses while also enrolling in courses that include work-site training.
It is not the state's responsibility to guarantee jobs after graduation for students in the vocational track, said Julie Brandis, a legislative assistant for Associated Oregon Industries, the state's largest business group, which will help in writing the business and professional curriculums.
But, she added, "once business owners can see that these students can do the job that student is going to be hired."
The law allows participating businesses to take part in setting the curriculum for students who take their training from the businesses, state education officials said. Although it is likely that companies will have to spend some money for vocational courses, the education officials said many companies would welcome the opportunity to help tailor training programs.
 
Skepticism About Training
 But some educators and state officials said the business and professional component places unrealistic expectations on public schools.
"It is impossible for a public school to be an apprenticeship program for a particular profession," said William Liebert, special assistant to the superintendent of Salem Public Schools who oversees the district's vocational curriculum. Partly because of the expense, "we have not been able to keep up with the technological and changing workforce," he said. "That's a tremendous problem."
The Salem school district, with 28,000 students and the state's second- largest school system after Portland, currently has 15 vocational offerings, from woodworking crafts to health professions to office management skills, which cost an average of about $1 million a year.
Mr. Liebert could not estimate how much more money might be needed to expand and improve the program, but other educators and state officials say the sum will be significant.
Mr. Liebert is also among those who are concerned about the idea of two tracks in high school.
"I have a huge concern about kids being sterotyped as plumbers," he said. "Our school system is very concerned that our kids don't get stigmatized."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
REMEMBER the last time you picked up a numbingly expensive bottle of French, or Italian, or German wine and asked yourself: "How can they get away with this?"
The answer is, they don't always. Impact, a respected newsletter for people in the wine and spirits business, recently came out with figures that, it says, explain why. 
 They show that imports of table wines -- the kind drunk with meals -- were off 12.4 percent in 1990, better than three times the decline the same category of wines suffered in 1989. It was a bad year for the wine importers. And, to a lesser degree, for the people who made the wine they imported. Lesser because they do have other markets, some perhaps, more affluent then Americans are.
The figures for total imports are dramatic. In 1970 they came to 8.6 million cases. By 1980 they were up to 37 million. Five years later, in 1985, 47 million cases were imported. Then, in 1990, they plummeted to 21.3 million.
As usual, figures don't lie, but they don't tell the whole story, either. According to Impact and the United States Commerce Department, Italian wine imports were off 9 percent last year with shipments of almost 9.3 million cases of table wine. A lot of wine, you say. Yes, but bear in mind: the United States imported almost 25 million cases of Italian wine in 1985.
From 1970 to 1980, imports of Italian wines rocketed from 1.6 million to just under 23 million cases. Imports didn't stop going up until 1986, at which point they began to drop rapidly. In fact the decline was so precipitous that it averaged out to almost 9 percent a year for the decade. In a brief four years, Impact calculates that Italian wine imports to this country plunged well over 50 percent, to about 10.2 million cases.
What went wrong? The figures would seem to indicate some major disillusionment with Italian wines, a lemminglike flight to French wines, perhaps, or Californian. In fact, many good Italian wines did well all through the debacle and have continued to do so. What suffered so badly was one single type of wine: lambrusco, a semisweet, slightly fizzy concoction that is consumed cold, like beer and soft drinks.
The biggest name in lambrusco is Banfi Vintners ' Riunite. Last year, Banfi imported 2.5 million cases of Riunite into the United States, down 16.5 percent from 1989's 3 million. But in 1984, Riunite's apogee, Banfi brought in 11.3 million cases of lambrusco, almost as much as all the table wine imported that year from France. And Riunite was only one of several lambruscos with annual sales in the millions of cases during those golden years for the importers.
And where did all those lambrusco lovers go? Did they take the pledge, or switch to Perrier? No. They switched to white zinfandel, a California product best described as a semi-sweet, slightly fizzy concoction that is consumed cold, like -- but you already know the rest of the line.
 Wine enthusiasts, people who drink traditional dry table wines and sparkling wines, are only marginally affected by the marketplace tribulations of lambrusco, white zinfandel, apple wine, wine coolers, cold duck and other similar amusements. Often, in years when the overall picture for imported wines looked particularly dark, premium wines, including the most expensive, did well. People who buy rare Burgundies and famous Bordeaux may complain about prices, but they buy.
French imports were off 19 percent in 1990, dropping in one year from 7.5 million cases to 6.1 million. German imports were off 20.7 percent, Portugal 29.4 percent and Spain, which never shared in the boom of the early 1980's, was off 16.6 percent last year. In 1970, 876,500 cases of Spanish wine were imported. The figure was down to 687,000 in 1980 and 631,000 in 1985. Last year it was only 407,000 cases.
The winners were Australia and Chile. Australia's meteoric rise in the early 1980's has slowed considerably, but a 15.8 percent increase last year over 1989 was certainly respectable. Total cases: 491,000.
Chilean imports posted a whopping 57.1 percent increase last year over 1989, with 921,000 cases, making it the fourth largest table wine exporter to the United States after Italy, France and Germany. Almost a third of all the Chilean wine, 315,000 cases, came from one company, Concha y Toro .
It will be interesting to watch these wines over the next few years. They are good wines, some of them excellent, but their chief attraction is price. Wine enthusiasts have been snapping up good Chilean cabernets and sauvignon blancs for $5 and $6. But some Chilean producers are growing restive; they want to see retail prices at $10 and more.
In that range, competition is fierce. California, France, Italy and Spain all produce excellent wines in that price category and, as the Australians discovered when they pushed their wine prices up 30 percent and more, American wine consumers are very price conscious.
Importers acknowledge the flight to white zinfandel, but they also blame the slump on the weak dollar, the recession and the war in the Persian Gulf.
If high prices are at all a factor in the drop in imported wine sales. we may take some comfort in what might be called a retaliatory strike. Recently, Manfred Esser, the president of Cuvaison Winery in California, noted that the Restaurant Girardet, near Lausanne, in Switzerland, had his 1987 chardonnay on its wine list for $88. (Cuvaison is owned by a Swiss family.)
Mr. Esser was obviously pleased that Girardet, which is touted by some as the world's best restaurant, had chosen to add his and half a dozen other California wines to its list. We can all share in his pride and perhaps take some comfort in what Girardet's clients will be set back for these bottles: 1986 Grgich Hills chardonnay, $120; 1984 Grgich Hills cabernet sauvignon, $92; Robert Mondavi 1987 Opus One, $264.
 
TASTINGS
Landmark Vineyards Chardonnay, Alexander Valley 1989, Demaris Vineyard; about $17.
Landmark Vineyards was the first commercial California winery to make only chardonnay. Landmark was founded in 1975 by William Mabry in Windsor, in northern Sonoma County. In 1989, with once-rural Windsor turning into a split-level heaven, Landmark left. Because of money from the new principal owner, Demaris Etheridge, Landmark has a magnificent new winery in Kenwood, central Sonoma, not far from Chateau St. Jean. Landmark Vineyards Cardonnay, a single-vineyard wine from a 56-acre vineyard in the Alexander Valley, was one of the last wines made at the old winery. It presages good things for the new $5 million plant. The wine was fermented in oak barrels rather than large steel tanks. It's concentrated without being heavy-bodied. There is plenty of fruit, a minimum of oakiness and a variety of subtle flavors, none of which mar the overall impression of an exceptionally well-made wine. If your name is going to be identified with only one type of wine, it had better be good. If this wine is any example of what's to come, Bill Mabry is on the right track.

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Single Portions
There are a number of new sources for prepared foods in and around the city. And what is striking about them is their emphasis on serving sizes for singles. One shop sells salads and such in small containers only by the portion, not the pound. 
 The Washington Market, 162 Duane Street (at Hudson Street), could be called the Washington Market Redux because it occupies the same space as a market of the same name that closed a few years ago. The new market opened last week.
Among the prepared dishes, some standouts are torta rustica of pastry filled with spinach, peppers, ham and cheese ($3.50 a portion), roasted peppers ($9.50 a pound), "Surprise" meatloaf with a hard-cooked egg inside ($5.95 each) and bacon, lettuce and tomato pasta salad ($9.50 a pound). Chicken salad with fennel and artichokes ($11.50 a pound) was light and summery, but needed seasoning.
In Chelsea, Food for All Seasons, 132 Ninth Avenue (18th Street), is a pleasantly rustic shop and cafe that sells everything in single portion sizes and does not post prices. The grilled vegetables ($2.75 a portion) are excellent, as is a cold puree of Swiss chard soup ($2.50 for a 12-ounce cup). Lentil salad ($2.75 a portion) needed seasoning and the lentils, like so many of the legumes used in salads around town, were undercooked.
Cucina and Company, specializing in prepared Italian food in the lobby of the Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue (45th Street), sells hot dishes cafeteria style, large or small portions of salads, sandwiches and pastry.
The sandwiches are the best, among them a New Orleans-style muffuletta with meats, cheese and marinated vegetables ($5.75); a roast beef sandwich with garlic puree and horseradish mayonnaise on peasant bread ($5.75) and an escalivada made with grilled vegetables and goat cheese on onion ficelle ($5.95).
And in Southampton, the Market at 75 Main, 75 Main Street, sells imaginative sandwiches and appealing salads like orzo with sun-dried tomatoes and pine nuts ($7.50 a pound), a delicate cole slaw ($6 a pound) and a black-bean salad that tastes better than the coating of creamy dressing makes it look ($9 a pound). Excellent brownies are $1.75 each, a peanut butter and jelly muffin that needs nothing spread on it is $1.10 and superb fruit tarts are $1.75 to $3.50.
 
City Cakes
Breads baked by E.A.T. have been available in the Hamptons for a couple of years. Now William Greenberg Jr. Desserts is providing another taste of Manhattan with its cakes and pastries.
Trucks make weekly deliveries on Thursdays to Barefoot Contessa, 46 Newtown Lane, East Hampton; Wainscott Produce Company, Montauk Highway, Wainscott, and, occasionally, to Hampton Epicure, 103 Main Street, Westhampton Beach. These shops will accept special orders for the weekend if they are placed by Wednesday morning.
 
Coyote Food Shop
Mark Miller, the chef and owner of Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M., has opened a food shop adjacent to his restaurant. The Coyote Cafe General Store specializes in ingredients for Southwestern cooking. Gift baskets and kits for making fajitas or cornbread are also sold.
The store takes mail orders. For a catalogue, write to the store at 132 West Water, Santa Fe, N.M. 87501, or call (505) 982-2454.
 
Blueberries for the Picking
Blueberries are the easiest berries to pick. No stooping, no thorns. At Blueberry Park, Route 21, Wingdale, N.Y., in Dutchess County, Ed and Anna Thomkins have 50 acres of blueberry bushes for picking.
Their wild, high bush variety yields smaller but more intensely flavored berries than the cultivated kind. Mr. and Mrs. Thomkins say the bushes have not been sprayed or treated with chemicals. They provide buckets for picking but urge visitors to bring containers to take the berries home. The fee is 80 cents a pound for the berries on a pick-your-own basis.
The farm is open every day from sunrise to sunset and Mr. Thomkins expects that the berries will be available through the first week in August. For directions and picking conditions, call (914) 724-5776.
 
Kitchen Closeouts
Williams-Sonoma has just opened an outlet store selling closeouts and overstocked items from its stores and from catalogues including Pottery Barn, Hold Everything, Gardener's Eden and Chambers. Discounts of 30 to 70 percent are offered.
The 15,000-square-foot store, which takes up three floors, is at 231 Tenth Avenue (23d Street).
The Chefs Catalogue is offering 10 percent off every item in its catalogue through Aug. 9. Customers must mention the discount to operators taking telephone orders or use the order forms in the catalogue. To obtain a catalogue or place an order, call (800) 338-3232.
 
Suffolk Party
 Twenty-six restaurants and five wineries are participating in a party Aug. 3 from 5 to 8 P.M. to benefit the Family Service League of Suffolk County, a group that provides services for families and individuals with emotional and economic problems. The event, a Taste of the Hamptons, is being held at a private estate in Southampton. Craig Claiborne is the honorary chairman.
Tickets are $75 each and will not be sold at the door. Send checks payable to Family Service League of Suffolk County in care of Jane Iselin, Cat's Cradle, Box 449, Bridgehampton, N.Y. 11932. Reservations cannot be guaranteed for checks received after July 30. For information, call (516) 427-1768.
 
Freshly Bottled Milk
OLD-FASHIONED whole milk in bottles, with an inch or so of cream on top, is being sold in the Union Square green market on Saturdays. On July 1, Ronny Brook Farms in Ancramdale, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley, a farm that was started 50 years ago, began bottling its pasteurized but unhomogenized milk instead of selling it to a cooperative. The milk is $1.50 a quart, plus $1 deposit for the bottle.
The farm also sells a particularly rich-tasting skimmed milk, also $1.50 plus the deposit, and has started selling half liters of heavy cream for $3.75 plus the deposit.
It sells for $9 a special canvas bottle tote made for the milk bottles by a group of mentally retarded adults in Columbia County. The tote has inner pockets that make it good for transporting wine as well as milk.
The milk also sells in Poughkeepsie at Adams Fairacre Market, in Kingston at Mohican Market, in Pine Plains at Teck's Market and in Millerton at Protta's.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Saratoga Extends Offer to Spend An Extra Week in the Country

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 23

 BODY:
The 124th season of racing in the countryside will open on Wednesday at the Saratoga Race Course and will continue for five weeks in an experiment to test the curative powers of this famous old spa for the ailments troubling thoroughbred racing.
The Saratoga season normally runs four weeks, but was extended by a week to lengthen the most successful part of the racing year in New York State in the continuing search for answers to the recession that has stalked the sport in recent years. 
 More than 27,000 people went to the Saratoga track every day on the average last year, which is double the attendance this season at Belmont Park. And the thoroughbred business would like to know whether they were drawn here by the charms of the countryside, the summer seasons of the ballet and the Philadelphia Orchestra or the quality of the racing itself.
 
Burst of Youth
 Whatever the reason, the racing will start with the customary burst of young talent in the opening-day fixture, the Schuylerville Stakes for 2-year-old fillies, a race that can launch careers.
The race is a Grade II stakes with 13 fillies racing six furlongs over a track they have never tested, and it is the first of five stakes races scheduled for the opening week alone.
The cast will be headed by Celeste Cielo, a daughter of Conquistador Cielo, the star colt of a decade ago. The filly made a splashy debut at Belmont Park in June when she set a track record by zipping five furlongs in 56 4/5 seconds.
But she got a dose of racing reality in her next start on July 3 when she struggled over a muddy track and lost by two lengths. So, whether she is a good filly or a great filly has not yet been established. But a solid clue may surface in the Schuylerville, when she runs with Angel Cordero Jr. in the saddle.
The same question confronts Ms. Copelan, who has raced twice and won twice. Her trainer, Alan Seewald, agreed with the general feeling that she was special, and said: "She schools well and ships well. She's a sensible filly. She acts like a 10-year-old mare."
But, taking no chances, he signed a senior jockey, Jerry Bailey, one of the stars of the Belmont Park meeting of the last two and a half months, to try to keep his filly's winning streak alive.
Once the Saratoga season is started, the quaint old track will trot as many stars across its stage as the nearby Performing Arts Center. The summertime meeting at Saratoga forms the ideal bridge between the Triple Crown races for 3-year-old horses and the autumn stakes leading to the year's ultimate prize, the Breeders' Cup series of championships and million-dollar purses.
In the first week alone, D. Wayne Lukas has nominated 29 horses to compete in stakes races. They won't all go to the post, but he can select carefully from his large stable and call his shots.
But Lukas is likely to run his precocious 2-year-old colt Salt Lake in the Saratoga Special on Friday and his star 3-year-old filly Withallprobability in the Test stakes on Saturday.
But the highlight of the opening week figures to be run on Sunday, when a pair of old rivals stage a return match at a mile and an eighth in the Jim Dandy Stakes, the steppingstone to the $1 million Travers, the dramatic high of the season on Aug. 17.
They are Fly So Free, last year's champion juvenile colt and last winter's favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, and Strike the Gold, who outran him in both the Bluegrass Stakes and the Kentucky Derby.
Scotty Schulhofer, who trains Fly So Free for the music publisher Tommy Valando, said that he also was disappointed in the colt's third-place finish in the Dwyer Stakes two weeks ago.
But Fly So Free still had a long list of credentials, including three consecutive victories in Florida in three months earlier this year and another in the Riva Ridge at Belmont in June.
Nick Zito, who trains Strike the Gold for Giles Brophy and his partners, Bill Condren and Joe Cornacchia, pointed toward his star colt and said with the proper mix of pride and caution:
"The 3-year-old picture will be clearer as the summer goes along. But this one is the champ, there's no question, if he stays together. Knock on wood."

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
The Three O'Reillys Walk Alike, Talk Alike

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y., July 23

 BODY:
Terri O'Reilly had her turn on the court today, and she did more than her one-third share. She pinned Chanda Rubin to the baseline with an aggressive topspin game, drubbing her 15-year-old opponent in the first round of the Westchester Ladies Cup at Manhattanville College, 6-2, 6-0.
 O'Reilly walked off the court and met two more of herself, Patty and Christine. Together again. Identical triplets, Team O'Reilly, making their way in this very individual sport. 
 "We are just as good as anyone up there," Terri O'Reilly said. "And we have a lot of marketing possibilities."
 With each victory, the O'Reilly triplets of Ridgewood, N.J., become more than a small-tournament sideshow novelty. That is the goal, anyway. Terri's ranking has zoomed 350 places since January, when the three sisters turned professional, to No. 423 in the world. After today's success, she is assured of reaching at least the low 300's. Patty is ranked 387. As doubles players, Patty and Terri have a shot at making the United States Open draw. Christine will have to wait her turn, because three into two does not go.
 
Three of a Kind
 "We're all in this together," said Christine, who is expected to get her first singles ranking after this tournament. "We share the winnings. And we're sure that if one of us makes it, the other two are going to be close behind."
 The three women, 23 years old, all played for Duke University and graduated in May with majors in economics. They all suffered injuries to their knees and backs during rigorous college careers, which is one way to tell them apart: Terri, a right-hander, wears two knee braces. Patty, the only left-hander, wears one. Christine does not wear any.
 "We haven't pulled any tricks yet, no switching," Terri said. "But we always say, 'Not yet.' We want to keep the umps alert."
 They travel the tour together, share the same hotel room to cut down on expenses. Sometimes they must face each other on the court. In fact, Terri upset Patty in the qualifiers of the Ladies Cup to earn a spot in the main draw.
 They don't often fight, although Terri was getting impatient today at Patty's emphatic courtside cheers. "Come on, T.," Patty screamed. Terri waved her off. "I didn't need her then," Terri said, later. "I was doing fine."
 Patty is the oldest, born in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, to Dee and Gene O'Reilly 15 minutes before Terri, who was born 14 minutes before Christine. When they needed coaching tips this spring, they went to a twin, Tim Gullickson, because he understood their mindset.
 Today, against Rubin, Terri O'Reilly's mindset was where it belonged: on the court, focused on the ball and on Rubin's backhand.
 "I didn't want to hit it to her power zone, I wanted to mix up my shots," Terri O'Reilly said. "I figured she had a lot of tournament experience, despite her age, because she has sponsorship from the United States Tennis Association."
 There is no such sponsorship for the O'Reillys, who are far too old to be considered hot prospects by any tennis federation. But after Terri O'Reilly's victory today, a tournament official made a point of asking all three sisters to come by and try to qualify for his event.
 Sorry, the O'Reillys said, in unison. Previous commitment.
 
 
MATCH POINTS
 JOHN KORFF, tournament director for the recently completed Pathmark Classic exhibition event at Mahwah, N.J., paid a visit Tuesday to the rival Ladies Cup tournament. He said the Women's Tennis Association is expected to levy fines totaling $92,000 against all the players who competed in his unsanctioned tournament. . . . MONICA SELES's fine has been announced at $20,000. Korff said he would help the players appeal the fines to the Women's International Professional Tennis Council and would pay whatever penalties were upheld.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 583 words

HEADLINE: Don't Ease the Squeeze on Iraq

 BODY:
Should Iraq be allowed to resume limited oil exports in order to pay war reparations and finance compelling humanitarian needs at home? Not as long as Saddam Hussein continues to flout the U.N. cease-fire resolution that requires him to disclose all details of Iraq's secret nuclear, biological and chemical weapons programs.
To accept human suffering as a diplomatic lever is tormenting -- but preferable to leaving the Persian Gulf allies with no credible way to compel Iraqi compliance except resuming military attacks. 
 There are other ways to address Iraq's emergency humanitarian needs. With the July 25 allied deadline for full Iraqi nuclear disclosure now at hand, it's exactly the wrong time to be hinting at partial lifting of the oil embargo.
 Making Baghdad come clean on nuclear supplies won't be easy. The embargo was originally designed for the less ambitious task of containing Iraq's arms buildup. Rolling back existing programs requires greater pressure.
Nor is the alternative of renewed air strikes fully satisfactory. The massive, unopposed air raids of the gulf war apparently failed to destroy Baghdad's nuclear hoard. With allied force levels now reduced, new air raids could involve far greater risk to pilots, with no more success.
The best available course is to maintain maximum economic and political pressure on Baghdad while holding the threat of renewed military action in reserve.
The human suffering Baghdad cites in seeking permission to resume oil sales is real and wrenching. Yet Saddam Hussein's regime showed scant concern for the suffering it caused its own people through eight grueling years of aggressive war against Iran and the devastating defeat in Kuwait.
Honorable arguments can be made for easing the oil embargo. Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the U.N. official in charge of monitoring Iraq's humanitarian needs, argues that precious international relief funds needed for Africa and Bangladesh should not be diverted to help oil-rich Iraq.
U.N. diplomats also point out that for Kuwait to receive the reparations it is entitled to, Iraq needs some way to raise funds. And a long series of U.N. resolutions anticipated humanitarian exceptions to the embargo. Limited relief now could help prevent a total erosion of sanctions later on.
The Bush Administration, which long resisted any easing of sanctions, seems to be shifting. The President, declaring that innocent women and children should not suffer, hinted yesterday at possible approval for a U.N. move to allow limited oil sales.
We, too, were once moved by these arguments, but this is the wrong time to relax the embargo. Once Iraqi oil is allowed back on the international market, even if the revenues remain under U.N. control, it will be difficult to make distinctions. How can the immediate needs of food and medicine be distinguished from the longer-term rebuilding of distribution networks and power plants that serve humanitarian needs and the Iraqi economy?
Easing the embargo now would give Baghdad a psychological lift, possibly reinforcing its defiance. A more straightforward way to provide humanitarian relief is to do just that, through an internationally financed effort limited to milk, food and medicine. A bill for the assistance could be presented to Iraq for later payment from oil revenues.
Easing sanctions prematurely could one day leave no choice except winking at Saddam Hussein's defiance or going back to war. There's a wiser course.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Saudis Won't Ditch OPEC for Our Sake

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The suggestion by Edward L. Morse, publisher of Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, in "How to Make OPEC Obsolete" (Op-Ed, July 1) that the United States enter into a bilateral agreement with Saudi Arabia on oil for "reciprocal security" is highly unlikely, to say the least. 
 We should not forget that in 1960 Saudi Arabia was the main architect of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which brought unprecedented wealth and power to that kingdom. Saudi Arabia, with its huge overhang of crude oil supply and proven reserves, still polices OPEC's price and production quotas, and works as the glue that holds the cartel together. To expect the Saudis to give away that lever in the name of some amorphous benefits is unrealistic.
Also, history belies this optimism. It was Saudi Arabia, under the guise of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries, that imposed the oil embargo against the United States and its allies in October 1973. The embargo was deadly in hardships put on the people and economy of the United States. Who could forget the long lines in front of gasoline stations, with the rationing of two gallons at a time, an odd-even plate-number system to buy gas on alternate days, flags flying at gas stations to indicate whether or not they had some gas for desperate motorists?
Even in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, Saudi Arabia has not lurched toward anything close to an open society and is trying very hard to maintain the status quo. Today OPEC is weak because of its action in raising the benchmark crude oil price from $12.70 a barrel in 1979 to $34 a barrel in 1981. At that price, demand for oil was not so inelastic, and production from non-OPEC areas increased considerably. Now OPEC has a hard time holding the price of benchmark crude even at $18 to $20 a barrel, with the spot price sometimes plunging much below that and baring the softness of the world oil market.
OPEC will be obsolete only when production from non-OPEC regions works as a deterrent, when Saudi Arabia as a producing country is effectively marginalized, when price cheating and volume discounts among the member nations will be virtually impossible to control and when alternative energy sources make a substantial dent in the world energy market.
Only then will OPEC declare itself dissolved. We may not live to see it, but we foresee it.
 
ARABINDA GHOSH
Assoc. Prof., Economics and Finance
William Paterson College
Wayne, N.J., July 8, 1991

HEADLINE: To Reagan We Owe A Catastrophic Debt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Edwin Meese 3d credits President Reagan with producing "the longest peacetime economic expansion in modern history" (letter, July 9). 
 President Reagan's tax and defense policies produced an eight-year increase in the national debt of $1.9 trillion (up 186 percent), the foundation for this false prosperity. While blaming Democrats for "tax and spend" politics, Mr. Reagan directed a "borrow and spend" spree, stealing from America's future well-being to promote a shortsighted agenda.
Every household in the United States went $20,000 more in debt, and interest payments on that debt tripled to $240.9 billion a year in 1989. To call Mr. Reagan "a successful President" for this fiscal disaster is like claiming a Cabinet officer who can leave office without being indicted is a success.
 
EUGENE J. CARROLL JR.
Washington, July 10, 1991
 
The writer, a retired rear admiral, is deputy director of the Center for Defense Information.
