HEADLINE: Majority Rejects Race Preference

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To Tom Wicker's question in "Riding the Quota Wave" (column, July 4) -- "in the face of a history of discrimination, is rigid evenhandedness to be the test of a candidate's or party's devotion to American values?" -- the answer from the overwhelming majority of the American public seems a resounding yes. 
 The Gallup organization has polled on preferences five times since March 1977 and has consistently found that more than 80 percent of respondents favor a strict meritocratic system in employment and university admissions over a system in which "women and members of minorities" are given preference "to make up for past discrimination." On no occasion (the last poll was December 1989) has support for preferential treatment exceeded 11 percent of the general population.
Similar results have been obtained in other polls, the most instructive perhaps being a Newsweek poll last April in which 72 percent of white respondents rejected racial preference even in a toss-up situation between equally qualified people ("Do you believe that because of past discrimination against black people, qualified blacks should receive preference over equally qualified whites in such matters as getting into college or getting jobs, or not?").
The public, I believe, understands something about justice and fairness that Mr. Wicker and other supporters of compensatory preferences based on race and ethnicity have not understood: such preferences in employment involve outrageously unfair systems of benefit allocation and burden sharing. Since ethnic groups as a whole cannot apply for jobs, but only individuals, those who may themselves not have been heavily victimized may (and often do) receive benefits at the expense of others who were neither beneficiaries nor perpetrators of past wrongdoing.
Affirmative action programs do not work like the scheme devised to compensate the unjustly interned Japanese-Americans of World War II. There, monetary compensation was victim-specific, and the burden of paying for the scheme was widely diffused throughout the tax-paying public. Affirmative action programs, rather, often benefit those who do not deserve benefits (the sons of Jamaican physicians or wealthy Cuban businessmen, for instance) and require that an arbitrarily selected subset of the population pay the cost.
I think it no accident that virtually all supporters of preferential employment policies who are not themselves in the beneficiary categories are people who enjoy comfortable middle- or upper-middle-class status (or the academic credentials and family resources to enable them to obtain such status). The opposition to race- and ethnicity-based preferences by poor and lower-middle class white people (non-Hispanic) is virtually unanimous, and it would seem they have something very important to tell us on this matter.
 
RUSSELL NIELI
Princeton, N.J., July 12, 1991
 
The writer is a lecturer at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School.

HEADLINE: Money Funds Keep Too Much Cash Idle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A market economy requires customers with money to buy its products. Too many potential customers have reduced spending and investing, and are putting their surplus income into money funds. A money fund is like an idle checking account or demand deposit in a bank. It buys no goods and provides no employment. 
 The excessive growth of money funds takes money out of circulation, reduces demand and is a cause of recession. It should be discouraged, but instead is rewarded by as much as 4 percent tax-exempt interest, derived mostly from short-term lending in competition with banks.
Although money funds don't appreciate or provide a hedge against inflation, they have grown to more than $500 billion! Five hundred billion idle dollars! No wonder our economy is in recession.
So what should we do? I am a capitalist myself and own shares in a money fund. But I realize that to restore prosperity we will have to make it unprofitable to hold money idle in banks or money funds. We know that what keeps a capitalist economy going is the steady spending and investment of money by individuals, business and government.
This means that private savings that can't find profitable investment must be taxed and spent by the government. The alternative is recession.
 
GEORGE R. WALKER
Bedford, Mass., July 11, 1991
 
The writer is a retired real estate executive, economist and writer.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 29.74 in Heavy Program Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Heavy waves of program selling by professional traders toppled stock prices yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average slid 29.74 points, or just a little less than 1 percent, to 2,983.23. 
 Smaller stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq composite index, sank a little more than 1 percent.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 160.2 million shares, from 149.1 million on Monday.
Only 180,000 shares of the Big Board's total volume came in the extra hour of trading that was added by the exchanges in June in a move to keep business from drifting to other markets.
The exchanges were also planning to add an additional half-hour of trading in the morning, opening at 9 A.M. instead of 9:30 A.M.. But officials from the over-the-counter market said yesterday that they would oppose the earlier start, noting that the plan would make it more difficult to talk to clients at that time of the day. The officials said, however, that they would comply if other exchanges opened earlier.
 
6 Waves of Selling
 Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said it spotted six waves of selling -- particularly between 9:48 and 10:03, and between 10:43 and 10:57. It said the heavy selling sliced almost 32 points off the Dow, meaning that the professionals accounted for the entire decline in the blue chips. If not for a small amount of buying, the Dow might have fallen even more.
Jack Solomon, market technician for Bear, Stearns & Company, said the stock market's weakness was a result of the soft bond market, program selling and the heavy flood of Treasury refinancings coming to market.
"When the market didn't succeed in attacking and surpassing the old high -- 3,035.33 -- in the last three days, disappointed sellers came in," he explained. "This drove the market down, with very few buyers around because of the lack of economic news."
Slightly more than half of the decline in the blue chips came from five stocks -- Minnesota Mining, off 3 3/8, to 89 5/8; Procter & Gamble, off 1 5/8, to 78 3/8; International Paper, off 1 3/4, to 69 1/2; Goodyear Tire, off 1 1/4, to 37, and I.B.M., off 1 3/8, to 100 5/8.
Among the most-active Big Board stocks, American Express rose 1 5/8, to 24 3/4, with a little more than three million shares changing hands. It reported that second-quarter profits fell 20 percent, but analysts said results were better than expected.
3M reported that second-quarter profits fell 12.6 percent.
 
Estimate Is Cut
 Alex Henderson, photography analyst at Prudential Securities, said he cut his 3M earnings estimate yesterday, and after talking with the company, might cut it a bit more. He said 3M's revenue patterns going into the third quarter "look flat at best."
Quaker Oats, another big mover, reported yesterday that second-quarter profits more than doubled, but its stock price tumbled 4 1/8, to 59. There did not appear to be any news to account for the drop.
Kimberly-Clark, the paper company, reported a sharp rise in second-quarter earnings, but its stock fell 3 3/4, to 100.
Monsanto, a standout in a weak chemicals group, rose 2 3/8, to 72 1/2, in heavy trading, after reporting higher-than-expected second-quarter profits. Reuters reported that Nicholas Filippello, Monsanto's chief economist, said the company might buy back more of its stock.
Along with a rise in gold prices, gold shares advanced, with Newmont Mining up 1 5/8, to 41, and Newmont Gold up 1 3/8, to 39 7/8.
High-technology stocks fell sharply, with Aldus, a computer software company, down 2 3/4, to 37 1/2, and Chiron, the biotechnology company, down 3 1/4, to 51 1/2, in heavy trading.
Aldus fell after it told analysts that earnings estimates might be too high.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 25, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about stock trading on Tuesday referred incorrectly to the earnings and stock price of Quaker Oats. The company did not report second-quarter earnings yesterday; it will do so in early August. The company's stock on Tuesday rose 50 cents, to $59 a share; it did not fall $4.125. Tuesday was the first day of trading for Quaker Oats without its Fisher Price unit, which was spun off.

HEADLINE: ITT Earnings Down by 20%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The ITT Corporation said on Tuesday that its second-quarter earnings were only about half the level of a year ago, when a one-time gain increased its earnings.
Even without the gain, ITT's profits were 20 percent below those in last year's second quarter. 
 The New York-based conglomerate said it had earned $206 million, or $1.62 a share, in the three months that ended on June 30, compared with $397 million, or $3 a share.
Its revenues totaled $5.1 billion, down slightly from $5.2 billion in the 1990 period.
The results from the second quarter of last year were increased by $139 million after taxes from ITT's sale of 7 percent of Alcatel N.V., a European telecommunications company, to Alcatel Alsthom. ITT retains a 30 percent stake in Alcatel.
Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman, said the lower profit resulted from the recession, which he said had hurt results in the automotive, forest products, financial services and hospitality businesses in which the company operates.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, ITT's stock was unchanged, closing at $55.50.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
2 State Offerings Raise $400 Million

 BODY:
Two states have issued tax-exempt bonds in a buoyant market where good investor demand, a shortage of supply and improving economic news have combined to bring more favorable rates for issuers.
The Florida Board of Education's $200 million issue yesterday was won by Merrill Lynch & Company with a bid of 6.8331 percent. 
 The general-obligation bonds have been priced to yield 4.7 percent for the 1992 maturity, and 6.828 percent for the 2012 maturity. A longer maturity of 2021 yields 6.888 percent, at a price of 98.25.
The State of Connecticut, which is having budget problems, has issued $200 million in general-obligation temporary notes. Goldman, Sachs & Company, the lead underwriter, said yesterday that the notes would bear a 5 percent coupon and be priced at about 100.042 to yield 4.75 percent.
The bonds have not yet been rated by Moody's Investors Service Inc. or the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Edward Bodman, 69, An Investment Banker

 BODY:
Edward Dunham Bodman, an investment banker who worked earlier in his career for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Agency in China, died yesterday at his home in Stonington, Conn. He was 69 years old and also lived in Manhattan.
He died of intestinal cancer, a spokesman for the family said. 
 He was a graduate of Harvard College and later attended the Columbia University School of Business Administration. After graduating from college, he worked in Beijing for the United Nations relief agency from 1945 to 1947. He returned to work for the Economic Cooperation Administration, traeling extensively in China. After the fall of the Nationalist Government in China, he went into investment banking.
From 1951 to 1958, he worked for Milmine, Bodman & Company in Manhattan in investment management and export-import financing, and from 1958 to 1966, he was with the Crocker National Bank in San Francisco. From 1966 until he retired in 1982, he was with the Empire Trust Company, now the Bank of New York, in Manhattan.
He was a member of the boards of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Associaton and of the American Bureau of Medical Assistance to China and in retirement was a recruiter for the International Executive Service Corps.
He is survived by his wife, the former Rosamund Reed Veit; a daughter, Beaufort Butler of Concord, Mass.; a sister, Violet Coffin of Stratford, Vt.; a brother, Herbert Bodman of Chapel Hill, N.C., and three grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: HONG KONG BUOYED BY AIRPORT ACCORD

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 24

 BODY:
After two bleak years in which it has lurched from one crisis to the next, exhaling confidence the way a punctured tire loses air, Hong Kong finally seems to be feeling good about itself again.
A new agreement was reached at the beginning of this month between Britain and China about a new airport to be built here -- and more broadly about how the territory will be governed until the hand-over to China in 1997 -- and it has elicited an enormous sigh of relief. 
 Spirits also rose today after the United States Senate vote Tuesday on trade benefits to China. Because Hong Kong depends a great deal on China for its economic livelihood, the vote, which makes likely the prospect of unconditional extension of the benefits, touched off even greater business optimism.
 
Stock Market at a High
 For two straight days now, the Hang Seng stock market index has hit a new high, closing today at 4,028.77, up nearly 19 points from Tuesday's record. Housing prices are also estimated to have risen at least 10 percent since the airport agreement was announced on July 4. And for the first time since the Army crackdown in Beijing two years ago, there seems to be a measure of hope in the air here.
Hong Kong's confidence has been shaken not only by the political repression and ideological orthodoxy on the home turf of its future landlord, but also by the arrests of Hong Kong visitors on the mainland and a rising number of mainlanders sneaking into the territory and committing robberies. Emigrants continue to flee the territory at a pace of over 1,100 a week.
Now, with major uncertainties removed, politicians, business executives and bureaucrats here are turning to the nuts and bolts of the airport and port project, which is expected to dominate the economy until 1997 and cost more than $16 billion.
 
Caution and Foreboding
 As with all bouts of optimism in Hong Kong in the last decade, however, this one is mixed with caution and a foreboding that China's verbal assaults may once again cloud the skies.
The agreement provides that China will support the construction of the airport in Hong Kong and will honor Hong Kong's debts after 1997. In exchange, Britain agrees to consult Beijing on all matters relating to the airport that will have an impact after 1997. Academics and politicians say the document is a crucial annex to the original joint declaration in 1984, which provides the basis for the handover of power. Some say it could set a precedent for power-sharing on all matters straddling 1997.
"China got what it wanted -- it got a formal acknowledgment of their role prior to 1997," said a diplomat in Hong Kong. The Chinese, he added, are believed to have suggested registering the memorandum as a treaty with the United Nations, as was the case with the 1984 Joint Declaration, but the British said no.
 
Risk of Imported Labor
 As companies enter the contract bidding in the next few months for certain parts of the airport project, the Government is suggesting that the construction activity will add more than a full percentage point to Hong Kong's economic growth estimates in the near future. Costs for the airport and rail and bridge links will be $12.7 billion and billions more for the port development.
Although the political uncertainty may be removed for the moment, some economists and analysts say the endeavor will still stumble. For instance, a construction boom could be inflationary, unless the Government allows the import of labor. Another major risk that investors and bankers must consider is that all the connecting parts, such as the rail link, the suspension bridge and the airport, must be completed before any one can be used.
For the moment, the general public is busy with Hong Kong's favorite pastime: making money. Last week, the first Government land sale since the memorandum brought a price that was more than double the one reached for a similar plot in the same area last November. And there are some indications that the small investor also wants to keep investing in Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: Baker Asks Asians to Move Warily on New Pacts

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 24

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urged major Southeast Asian countries today to move cautiously on proposals to create new trade and security alliances that would replace "tried and tested frameworks" involving the United States.
Speaking at the annual meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Mr. Baker appeared to react warily to proposals made at the meeting to create an East Asian trading bloc that did not include the United States, and to begin regular regional meetings on military issues. 
 He was also apprehensive about a suggestion that Soviet and Chinese representatives be included in future meetings of Asean, which is made up of Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Brunei.
"We have had a remarkable degree of stability in this region," said Mr. Baker, referring specifically to security cooperation in Southeast Asia.
"We ought to be careful about changing those arrangements and discarding them for something else unless we're absolutely certain that the something else is better and will work," he said at a news conference.While Mr. Baker received a warm reception this week from the Asean foreign ministers, a central theme of the Kuala Lumpur meeting was that the non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia must integrate their economic and security planning, even if that means asserting more independence from their old ally in Washington.
Asian diplomats said there was general agreement on the need for closer economic ties within Asean in response to trading blocs being created in Western Europe and in North America, and on the need for new cooperation on military issues in light of the reduced American presence in the region. Not one of the proposals that had most worried American officials was adopted by the Asean foreign ministers at the meeting this week, although all remain under consideration.
Among them is a Japanese plan for formal regional meetings on defense issues. American officials say they are wary of the proposal because it might weaken a string of bilateral military agreements between the United States and nations in Asia and the Pacific.
Like the United States, Japan is invited as a "dialogue partner."
The most serious disagreement between the United States and its Southeast Asian allies at the gathering appeared to center on Myanmar, formerly Burma, and whether economic sanctions should be imposed on that nation to end human rights abuses.
American and other Western nations have for some time been urging Asean members to use their influence to persuade the Burmese to hand over power to civilians leaders elected last year.
"We would like to see Asean use whatever influence they have, individually or collectively, in order to move the Burmese Government toward greater respect for human rights, greater respect for political process, freedom for political prisoners," Mr. Baker said.
Southeast Asian nations have been wary of Western attempts to impose human rights standards on Myanmar, if only because many of their own governments are also subject to criticism about human rights abuses.
Asean officials said today that the Philippine Foreign Secretary, Raul Manglapus, would soon travel to Myanmar on behalf of the association to discuss human rights. But Asian diplomats at the Kuala Lumpur meeting insisted that Mr. Manglapus's trip was not a response to Western pressure.
"This will be a cordial meeting between Manglapus and the Burmese," said one diplomat. "We believe that friendly, constructive persuasion -- not bullying -- will be most effective in bringing about change in Burma."
Several Asean officials drew comparisons this week between the association's policy on Burma and the Bush Administration's policy on China -- continued contact despite concern over human rights violations.
At the news conference, Mr. Baker said the United States continued to hope for better relations with Vietnam, but that normal relations were not possible until Hanoi helped bring about a settlement in the Cambodian civil war.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Report Of Weak Factory Orders

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday after the Government released an unexpectedly weak report on factory orders to the nation's manufacturers.
The Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods slipped 1.6 percent in June after three months of gains. Some analysts said the report could rekindle talk of a double-dip recession. That could put further pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates in an attempt to help the economy. 
 Lower interest rates weaken the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities less valuable.
"The market was already pushing down" before the durable-goods report, said Andrew Hodge, chief corporate trader at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York. But the report extended the decline even further, he said.
Mr. Hodge said the dollar had been trying to correct itself after lengthy efforts by foreign central banks this year that served to strengthen the United States currency against the German mark.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7375 marks, from 1.7575 marks late Tuesday. In London, the dollar slipped to 1.7365 marks, from 1.7555.
The dollar rose against the yen on a belief that weakness in the Japanese economy could lead to interest rate cuts in Japan, Mr. Hodge said.
The dollar gained 0.25 yen, to close at 137.50 yen in New York. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.65 yen, to close at 136.87 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 137.35 yen.
The dollar fell against the British pound. The pound strengthened to $1.6920 in New York, from $1.6825 on Tuesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.6935, from $1.6845.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.5125 Swiss francs, down from 1.5255; 5.9059 French francs, down from 5.9665; 1,294.75 Italian lire, down from 1,310.50, and 1.15325 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15445.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Fund Yields Unchanged in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds showed virtually no change in the week ended yesterday, according to IBC/Donoghue's, which regularly monitors the leading funds.
Yields on bank money-market accounts that compete for the public's interest in short-term investing were 5.23 percent, compared with 5.25 percent the week before, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index. 
 Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's, said the Federal Reserve had shown little intention of lowering rates further, "and it is the short-term rates that affect money market yields."
 
Few Municipal Issues
 "I suspect yields were dropping quite sharply until this week because of a lack of supply of new municipals," he continued. "States have been having budgetary problems and postponing some issues, and there has been seasonal factors like the June fiscal-year end, which for many states led to juggling times of issuing new tax-exempts."
This week, he said, some yields increased slightly because of an increased supply of municipal securities.
Recent improvement in economic indicators has raised the possibility of another Federal Reserve move to lower interest rates, he explained. "I think it is premature to think about now," he said. "The recovery is alive and well," he said, adding he thought the decline in money market yields had essentaiially ended.
The seven-day simple yield for taxable funds dropped a basis point, to 5.46 percent, and the seven-day compound yield dropped to 5.61 percent from 5.62, according to Donoghue's. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. The 30-day simple yield was 5.47, down from 5.48, and the 30-day compound yield was 5.62, down from 5.63.
Assets of the taxable funds were virtually unchanged, rising slightly by a net of $145 million, to $451.4 billion. Institutions accounted for a rise of $800 million, to $111.3 billion, which means an outflow of money belonging to small investors. "The public is still looking for higher yields elsewhere," Mr. Frank said.
Total assets of the tax-exempt funds declined by $605 million, to $88.5 billion, continuing a slide in the previous week. "I think that was due mostly to the lower yields," Mr. Frank said. Days to maturity of holdings by the funds averaged 58, down from 59 the previous week.
Thirty-day simple yields were 3.66 percent, off 2 basis points, and the 30-day compound yield was also down by 2 points, to 3.73.
But the seven-day simple average yield for the tax-exempt funds was 3.71 percent, up 25 basis points from the previous week. The seven-day compound yield was 3.77 percent, also an increase of 25 basis points.
 
Fund on Top Again
 For the 13th week in a row the top- yielding tax-exempt fund was the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee. On the seven-day basis it yielded 4.84 percent, up 13 basis points from the previous week. Some of its investments are in securities that might be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax for some investors.
The top-yielding tax-exempt fund in New York for the week was Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market fund, with a seven-day compound return of 4.28 percent.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Cuomo Seeking the Presidency? Yes, He Isn't, Maybe He Is

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 24

 BODY:
Since putting the state budget to rest three weeks ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has appeared on national television to belittle the Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas and has told a convention of black Baptists that the national debate on quotas reflects a Republican strategy to make an issue of race.
He has issued a news release saying that President Bush's economic policy "lacks any formula for sustainable, long-term growth" and has told reporters that the Republican economic agenda "is zero." 
 He has invited photographers from Life magazine to document a day in his life and has directed his staff to find places for him to deliver speeches attacking the White House, including one at the American Stock Exchange on Thursday morning.
But please do not ask the Governor whether he is acting like a Presidential candidate. Such suggestions generate an expression of boredom and contempt usually reserved for Republican foes in the State Senate.
 
'No Plans to Make Plans'
 "Why should it be," he snapped at a forum of the New York State Broadcasters Association in Saratoga Springs on Monday, "that if you happen to have eight and a half years as Governor, having all that background, having a platform to discuss national issues, if you do it in any plausible way then it follows you should be running for President?
"And if you're not, then there's something wrong with you. Either you've got a Mafia uncle hidden away in a closet or you've got some serious illness or you've got some psychic indisposition. Why should that be?"
Such is the curse of being Mario Cuomo, a burden that has not been lifted by his poor showing at the polls last November, his state's dire fiscal troubles or his unbending insistence that he has "no plans and no plans to make plans" to run.
Those closest to the Governor take him at his word. Of 13 current and former Cuomo aides surveyed in the last week, none said they believed that Mr. Cuomo would run for President. But many also believe there is a method to his high-profile approach to national politics.
"My gut tells me he's not going to do it, but I don't think it hurts for people to think he might," said one top Cuomo aide. "With the Legislature, it's certainly better than them thinking that this will be his last term and that he's a lame duck."
Mr. Cuomo's popularity is lagging after a budget fight that ended with a record delay, severe spending cuts and a broken pledge against raising income taxes. He is caught in the middle of a dangerous political impasse with Mayor David N. Dinkins over how to rescue New York City from severe service reductions and projections of mounting deficits.
Against that political backdrop, the Governor has set out to use New York's fiscal crisis to illustrate the Federal Government's abandonment of its obligations to the states and cities. Mr. Cuomo does not mind if the perception of him as a potential candidate adds power to his message.
His message may also help mend fences with constituents who are stewing about this year's combination of deep cuts and higher taxes.
Mr. Cuomo's speeches on Federal economic policy effectively shift the blame for the state's budget travails from Albany to Washington. He received a standing ovation last week at Union Baptist Church in Hempstead, L.I., when he told a black audience that Republicans were raising the quota issue to divide the electorate along racial lines.
The Governor's practice of leading the intellectual charge against the Republicans while avoiding the hand-to-hand combat of a campaign has become a familiar one since 1984, when his speech to the Democratic National Convention made him an instant celebrity within his party.
He has been consistent -- at least since announcing in February 1987 that he would not run in 1988 -- in maintaining that he is not considering the 1992 race.
But he has allowed speculation to continue by not veering from his carefully crafted "no plans" disavowal and by announcing last year that he would not promise to serve out his third four-year term, which began in January. Late last year the Governor rejected the advice of a top aide that he use his 1991 State of the State speech to declare that he would not be a candidate.
Knowing that there is skepticism about his intent, Mr. Cuomo has even started arguing the case against a Cuomo candidacy. This week he advised the Democrats to find a "nonthreatening" candidate, and said that "distinct ethic types," like himself, did not always fit that category.
He also said in an interview that if he were going to run, he would have had to establish a campaign structure by now.
The Governor has expressed increasing irritation at the notion that he, like all politicians, must want to be President.
"The American idea is you have to be the star, you have to be the leader, you have to keep going up even if you don't feel like it, even if you're satisfied, even if you think you've arrived at a level where you think you can make an intelligent contribution," he said on Monday. "God forbid you want to be a member of the chorus and not a quarterback."

HEADLINE: Bush to Meet With Soviet Opposition

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 24

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Bush would address the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine and meet with members of the emerging democratic movement in Moscow as part of a diplomatically tricky effort to foster contacts with the Soviet Union's emerging opposition.
Because of its political sensitivity and symbolic importance, this foray by Mr. Bush into the volatile world of Soviet politics could end up overshadowing the formal centerpiece of his trip to the Soviet Union next week: the signing of a treaty reducing nuclear weapons and a two-day summit conference with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
 In a further departure from the historic tenor of Soviet-American summit meetings, with their heavy emphasis on arms control and military competition, a major focus of Mr. Bush's trip will be the expansion of commercial ties between the nuclear powers.
A senior Administration official said today that a trade treaty with the Soviet Union that will include favorable tariff treatment is essentially ready to be sent to Congress and that Mr. Bush would discuss a Soviet role in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank while in Moscow.
 
Criticism From Brady
 But Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady sharply criticized the Soviet Union's application for full membership in the I.M.F. and World Bank, a sign that the two countries have yet to work out some of the most basic principles of their changing relationship.
Saying he was "completely surprised" by the Soviet move, which came late Monday, Mr. Brady told reporters that it was "counterproductive," and added, "We have advised them to the point of boredom not to apply for membership."
In London last week, the United States and the six other leading industrial democracies offered Moscow a limited "special association" with those two financial institutions, while the Soviet Union drafts the specific plan for economic reform that the United States is demanding as a condition for full membership and any big increase in economic assistance.
While in Moscow, Mr. Bush will meet with a group of democratic opposition leaders that the senior official said is likely to include Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Foreign Minister, who resigned last year with warnings of a Kremlin dictatorship and then became a founding member of the Democratic Reform Movement, created to challenge the Communist Party orthodoxy.
The President will also meet privately with Boris N. Yeltsin, the combative and politically powerful President of the Russian federation, and deliver a second major address in the Soviet capital, a senior Administration official told reporters today.
 
Yeltsin and Protocol
 The Moscow speech will focus on Soviet-American relations in a more traditional sense. The speech in Kiev will be devoted to the changing relationship between the United States and the Soviet republics, the official said.
The senior official, whose remarks were part of a series of pre-summit briefings at the White House, said Mr. Bush would meet with Mr. Yeltsin on Wednesday. He said it was not clear whether he would go to see Mr. Yeltsin at his offices, which in protocol terms would represent a more significant recognition of the Russian President than inviting him to meet with Mr. Bush at the American Embassy or the Ambassador's residence, Spaso House.
Asked if Mr. Bush would meet with Mr. Shevardnadze, the official said: "The President will be seeing a broad range of people, in Moscow and Kiev. I imagine we'll see Mr. Shevardnadze."
That session is expected to be less formal than the one with Mr. Yeltsin, perhaps a dinner at Spaso House, and is expected to include representatives of the Baltic region and of the Soviet Union's other fractious republics.
These meetings and the President's plan to visit Kiev represent the most dramatic moves in an effort by the Bush Administration to foster relations with Soviet political figures outside the traditional center of Kremlin power.
 
Complex Pressures
 In taking these steps, the United States has been trying to strike a balance to avoid antagonizing national leaders in Moscow, undermining Mr. Gorbachev's power, violating diplomatic niceties or encouraging opposition groups to take action toward greater autonomy that the United States might not be willing to support.
In his briefing today, the senior official alluded to these complex pressures, saying the choice of Kiev over any other republic's capital was not a sign of American approval of the relation between the Ukraine and Moscow.
But it was significant that Mr. Bush chose not to visit the Baltic republics -- Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia -- which have been the most vocal in their demands for independence. The United States has never recognized their incorporation into the Soviet Union.
"We're not issuing seals of approval on internal affairs," the official said. "We think that as this society opens up, we're going to need contacts with the republics as well as the center. We want to do it in a way that doesn't affect relations with the center, but expands relations to the republics."
In Kiev, for example, the official acknowledged that Mr. Bush was likely to encounter members of the Ukrainian independence movement who are members of the republic's legislature. But he said the President will not have a "stand-alone meeting" with them.
In Moscow, the Bush Administration is inviting a broad range of opposition figures to dinner with the President but is screening out members of the more right-wing radical groups, like Pamyat, the Russian nationalist movement that is sometimes accused of espousing racist doctrines.

HEADLINE: RJR Nabisco Posts Second Profit in Row

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
RJR Nabisco Inc., whose products include Winston cigarettes and Oreo cookies, said yesterday that it had posted a profit for the second quarter in a row and further improved its balance sheet, significant achievments for history's largest leveraged buyout.
But analysts regarded the performance as being at the low end of their expectations, and some said the stock was overvalued. 
 RJR Nabisco said net income in the second quarter totaled $79 million, in contrast to a loss of $108 million a year earlier. After paying preferred-stock dividends of $56 million, the net income is equivalent to 3 cents a share. In the first quarter, it reported a profit of $5 million after more than two years of losses.
 
Bondholders vs. Shareholders
 The tobacco business improved considerably, aided by stronger international sales, especially to Europe and the Russian republic, but domestic unit sales continued to decline. Food sales improved as well.
"From the bondholder's point of view, RJR Nabisco is doing just fine," said Charles S. Lemonides, a high-yield bond analyst at Gruntal & Company. "I just need for RJR to not go broke and I still get paid. But from a shareholder's point of view, it's not doing as well. Somebody owning stock has got to see more growth to sustain this valuation."
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, RJR Nabisco's stock closed at $11, down 50 cents, on heavy trading of 3.8 million shares.
Mr. Lemonides said RJR stock was trading at the "high end" of a fair valuation of $8 to $12 a share. And he noted that operating cash flow rose only slightly, to $1.06 billion, from $1.01 billion a year earlier.
 
9.3 Percent Rise in Sales
 Sales in the quarter rose 9.3 percent, to $3.78 billion, from $3.46 billion a year earlier, a relatively strong performance at a time when many packaged-goods companies are having trouble selling their products during the recession.
Tobacco sales in dollars rose nearly 10 percent, to $2.21 billion, and operating profit rose 1.4 percent, to $728 million. Food sales in dollars rose nearly 9 percent, to $1.57 billion, and operating profit rose nearly 14 percent, to $226 million.
But tobacco unit sales, the actual number of packages of cigarettes, continued to be weak in the United States, where the bulk of business is, and strong overseas. American cigarette unit sales declined 6.8 percent, while foreign sales rose 27 percent, RJR Nabisco said. Without sales to Russia, foreign sales rose 21 percent.
Debt to equity, the ratio of what the company owes to how much it is worth, has improved sharply. RJR Nabisco owed about $2.70 for every $1 of net worth on June 30, compared with $4.40 for every $1 of net worth a year earlier.
Lower interest costs, an important factor in any company but critical to one deep in debt, helped RJR Nabisco considerably. RJR has been replacing its high-interest long-term debt, some $9 billion, mostly with publicly owned common stock that pays no cash dividends. Moreover, short-term interest rates have dropped sharply, mainly because of the recession.
As a result, total interest expense in the quarter dropped by nearly a third, or some $229 million, to $541 million.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Hits 11-Week Low As Recession Fears Grow

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver prices fell yesterday to their lowest level in more than 11 weeks, as renewed recession fears and a lack of inflation prompted heavy selling of futures contracts on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Silver futures settled 27.6 cents to 32 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in July down 27.6 cents at $3.984 an ounce, the lowest settlement of a near-term silver contract since May 3. 
 Gold futures finished $3.80 to $4.20 lower on the Commodity Exchange, with August at $364.70 an ounce. Platinum futures plunged $12.30 to $12.80 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the July contract settling at $364.50 an ounce.
Silver had slipped about 6 cents an ounce in each of the two previous sessions. It lost its footing completely Wednesday after the Commerce Department reported an unexpected 1.6 percent decline in orders for durable goods in June.
It was the first pause in three months in the manufacturing economy's recovery and suggested that "the possibility of a double-dip recession is upon us," said Peter Cardillo, research director with Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York.
"People are wondering if we are going to wind up again in a recession," Mr. Cardillo said.
He said silver and platinum were hit harder than gold because they have more industrial uses, making them more sensitive to economic data.
 
Soybeans Drop Sharply
 On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain futures prices fell, led by a sharp drop in soybean values as cooler weather in the Midwest tempered fears of crop damage.
Wheat futures settled 2 3/4 cents to 5 3/4 cents lower, with September at $2.83 1/2 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 6 1/2 cents lower, with September at $2.44 3/4 a bushel; oats were 3 3/4 cents to 4 1/4 cents lower, with September at $1.33 1/4 a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 12 1/2 cents lower, with August at $5.49 a bushel.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, most livestock futures rose, while pork bellies fell sharply.
Live cattle finished 0.05 cent lower to 0.60 cent higher, with August at 73.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.38 cent to 1 cent higher, with August at 89.77 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to 0.63 cent higher, with July at 57.10 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were down 0.12 cent to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents, with July at 43.70 cents a pound.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light crude oil futures finished 12 cents to 20 cents higher, with September at $21.52 a barrel; heating oil was 0.13 cent to 0.44 cent higher, with August at 58.09 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.05 cent lower to 0.95 cent higher, with August at 66.17 cents a gallon, and natural gas was 1.8 cents lower to 1 cent higher, with September at $1.216 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: 2d-Quarter Earnings Drop For 2 Subsidiaries of G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 24

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation, whose automotive earnings have been hit hard by the recession, saw the second-quarter profits of two important non-automotive subsidiaries decline. G.M.'s finance subsidiary and electronics and aerospace units both posted lower profit yesterday, in large measure because they are dependent on automotive sales.
A third unit, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, showed a strong increase in profits. 
 G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, is expected to announce lower second-quarter profits over all tomorrow. Following are the details of the subsidiaries earnings:
 
G.M.A.C.
 The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, one of the nation's largest financial institutions, posted a second-quarter net profit of $283 million, a 6.3 percent drop, from $302 million during the 1990 period.
G.M.A.C. said the lower earnings were mostly attributable to lower receivables, but were partially offset by lower borrowing costs. The lower level of receivables was caused by soft automotive sales, and the maturing of automotive financing contracts from 1986 and 1987, which were popular because of 2.9 percent and 1.9 percent subsidized finance rates.
As of June 30, G.M.A.C.'s earning assets totaled $96.6 billion, down from $103 billion a year ago. The average interest rate on borrowed funds was 7.73 percent in the second quarter, compared with 8.6 percent a year ago. During the quarter G.M.A.C. financed or leased 458,000 new vehicles in the United States, compared with 541,000 a year ago. Leasing grew to 59,000 vehicles in the quarter, compared with 22,000 last year.
 
E.D.S.
 The Electronic Data Systems Corporation unit posted a 12 percent increase in second-quarter profit on a 15 percent revenue increase.
Profit for the quarter reached $139.8 million, compared with $125.3 million last year. Revenue rose to $1.68 billion, from $1.46 billion last year. The earnings of G.M. class E shares, which represent an interest in E.D.S.'s dividend payout, were 58 cents a share, up from 52 cents a share last year.
The data processing company said revenue related to work at G.M. amounted to $833.2 million, or about 49.6 percent of total revenue, compared with $799.3 million, or 54.7 percent of revenue last year.
 
GM Hughes Electronics
 Second-quarter profit for the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation dropped 39.6 percent, to $114.3 million, from $189.5 million last year. Revenue was $2.9 billion, compared with $3 billion last year. The earnings of GM class H shares, which represent an interest in the unit's dividend payout, were 29 cents a share, compared with 47 cents last year.
Robert J. Schultz, chairman, said the lower revenue and profit reflected a 16 percent drop in G.M. vehicle production. The company's Delco Electronics business manufactures radios and other electronic components.
The company's Hughes Aircraft Company unit received several important contracts during the quarter, including a $585 million contract to supply air-to-air missiles.

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TO BUILD NO NEW SHUTTLES

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it planned to build no more space shuttles, concentrating instead on creating new family of rockets to succeed the 30-year-old designs now being used.
A plan was announced by Vice President Dan Quayle in a speech at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. "In all probability, we have purchased the last space shuttle," he said. 
 The policy also includes converting some military missiles to launch satellites and developing unmanned vehicles that can be modified later to carry astronauts.
"The space launch policy proposes to extend the life span of the shuttle fleet; to maintain the capacity to produce spare parts, and to operate the system conservatively," Mr. Quayle said. "But the policy does not envision acquiring new orbiters."
Mr. Quayle, who is the head of the National Space Council, which sets national space policy, added: "It is time for a new phase in space launch. I am here to announce that as of today, we have entered that new phase."
 
Making Actions Official
 The announcement puts into effect some recommendations made last December by a 12-member committee that studied future of the nation's space program.
The announcement also made official some actions already in progress. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Department of Defense have been working together to design a new national launching system; NASA had asked to buy a new orbiter in the next fiscal year and was turned down, and the Air Force has been studying whether to release surplus ballistic missiles for civilian use.
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union are to sign a treaty in Moscow next week to reduce their nations' long-range nuclear weapons by approximately 30 percent.
The number of missiles that will be available for conversion to civilian use is potentially in the hundreds, but the new policy specifies that "due regard to economic impact on the commercial space sector" will also be considered. Three rocket builders now form the core of America's commercial industry.
The cost of developing a new family of launching vehicles able to carry medium and heavy payloads into orbit has been estimated to be as high as $11.5 billion. The goal is to reduce current launching costs from $3,600 a pound to about $300.
 
Commercial Role Considered
 The technology effort, Mr. Quayle said, will go into all phases of a launching system, from engines, structures and materials to exotic concepts like the National Aerospace Plane and a single-stage rocket that could reach orbit.
The space launching strategy will actively consider commercial space launching needs, and the directive said the space agency and the Defense Department "should actively explore having private industry take part in the new rocket plans." The two agencies and the Department of Energy are to submit a 10-year plan by Dec. 1.
Mr. Quayle told his audience at Vandenberg that the strategy would lead to a new commercial launch vehicle "as good or better than those of our foreign competitors."
 
Shuttles to Stay in Service
 The Administration said it did not intend to phase out the shuttle fleet, which will have four vehicles when Endeavour begins flying next year.
"The production of spare parts should continue in the near term to support the existing shuttle fleet and to preserve an option to acquire a replacement orbiter in the event of an orbiter loss or other demonstrable need," the policy says.

HEADLINE: Exxon Net Up Slight 2.7%, Bucking Oil's Downtrend

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 24

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation, the nation's biggest oil company, said today that net income in the second quarter rose 2.7 percent, as profits from oil and gas production and foreign operations barely offset downturns in other parts of its business.
Exxon was unusual among major oil companies in posting higher income for the quarter. Yet its profit was half its first-quarter total of $2.2 billion -- the highest of any quarter in Exxon's history. 
 The surge was tied to the Persian Gulf war, which caused demand and prices to soar for refined products in the Middle East and Europe. Profit margins in those regions fell sharply after the war.
Texaco Inc., in an earnings report more typical of current industry trends, said today that its profit fell 23.8 percent in the second quarter.
Analysts said that the Exxon and Texaco reports had few special gains or losses and that the companies' operating profits were in line with Wall Street forecasts.
Exxon's stock rose 37.5 cents, to $58.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, while Texaco shares slipped 50 cents, to $63.75.
Weak demand for gasoline and other refined products, as well as for natural gas and chemicals, depressed operating income for most diversified oil companies in the quarter, even though oil prices were generally a few dollars a barrel higher than in the spring of 1990.
Mobil, Amoco, ARCO and Phillips Petroleum posted lower quarterly earnings earlier this week. Analysts expect Chevron to announce sharply lower earnings on Friday.
"There really isn't much developing to boost income in the second half of the year" at most major oil companies, said George F. Friesen, senior oil analyst at the Deutsche Bank Group in New York. "Comparisons will be the most negative for the fourth quarter."
 
Exxon
 Net income was $1.13 billion, or 90 cents a share, compared with $1.1 billion, or 87 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Revenue rose 4.6 percent, to $27.3 billion, from $26.1 billion.
Lawrence G. Rawl, chairman and chief executive, said lower interest rates and debt totals helped Exxon to increase profits. Exxon has the lowest amount of debt as a percentage of total capital among major oil companies.
The company, based in Irving, Tex., increased output of refined products, with global output of gasoline, jet fuel and other products rising slightly to 4.8 million barrels a day. Natural gas sales rose in Europe, where spring weather was unusually cool, and declined in the United States.
Profits from oil and gas production in the United States more than doubled because of higher crude prices, to $179 million, from $81 million, but were flat at $463 million in foreign drilling activities. Spending for exploration, plant expansions and other projects rose to $2 billion, from $1.9 billion in the period a year ago.
 
Texaco
 Net income fell to $269 million, or 94 cents a share, from $353 million, or $1.26 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Revenues increased 3.4 percent, to $9.03 billion, from $8.72 billion.
In a statement, James W. Kinnear, Texaco's president and chief executive, confirmed Wall Street views that market demand for refined products remained weak and that profit margins had narrowed further in the United States.
He said Texaco, based in White Plains, was seeking to control costs to maintain its rising capital spending program.
Profits from oil-and-gas production in the United States rose to $111 million, from $66 million, with oil prices averaging more than $2 a barrel higher in the quarter, at $16.48 a barrel, than in the spring quarter of 1990. Production products abroad rose to $78 million, from $67 million.
Results in global refining, marketing and transportation plunged to $194 million, from $328 million, and global chemical profits fell by 73.3 percent, to $8 million. Capital spending rose to $831 million, from $654 million.

HEADLINE: Troubled Workers Transport Urban Woes to the Catskills

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

DATELINE: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Bill W. left New York in the spring last year because trouble was following him. It can be that way in the city, he said. Men roam the streets looking for or waiting for something bad to happen, and the tension from this can make you tired and old. When the bus from the Concord Resort Hotel came to his homeless shelter to recruit workers, he slipped on. "Drugs got me," he said. "I needed a place where no one could find me. My own escape."
His first day in the Catskills, working in the kitchen of the Concord Hotel, he washed close to 500 dishes. Then, he said, he walked down the road to his small room in a falling-down bungalow, closed the door and removed a small pipe and some crack from a pouch. Outside, he heard two men arguing. Someone was throwing stones against the side of the bungalow. It sounded like Jerome Avenue in the Bronx when he was homeless. Nothing was happening. Just drugs and drink and the idle feeling that in a flash, something could turn wrong.
 
No. 3 in Per Capita Crime
 Hundreds of people like Bill, homeless and penniless or in trouble have come to the Catskills either on their own or as recruits of the big hotels to fill minimum-wage jobs. Some have come to escape the strife of urban life but others have brought with them some of its grimmest symptoms, chiefly drugs and violence. 
 The presence of the transient workers is a large reason that the county ranks behind only Manhattan and Erie County in the state for crimes per capita, said the Sullivan County District Attorney, Stephen F. Lungen. Records indicate that the county's felony rate nearly doubles during the summer months, he said.
The issue has stoked a complicated debate in a region that is only now beginning to climb out of a deep economic slump that saw many of its old-time hotels go bankrupt. Minimum-wage jobs may well be a necessity, and besides, the hotel owners say they cannot attract any workers to do the "non-glamour" labor left over after they hire college students to do the "front" jobs, waiting tables, working as lifeguards and the like.
So sometimes working with employment agencies and homeless shelters, the hotels bring the men up, generally to have them work in the kitchen or as porters.
There was a time when the transient employees were part of the Catskills lore, bringing with them a kind of roguish charm that fit in with the borscht belt sensibility that liked its edges rough. They would shoot dice in the stairwells and play all-night poker games and no one minded.
But over the last few years, romantic ideas about these employees have vanished. Many of them, Mr. Lungen said, are working by day and then using or selling drugs by night.
Their desperate need for money for crack has led to more burglaries and violent crimes. But, Mr. Lungen said, the hotels, accustomed to hiring as if it were 30 years ago, have been slow to respond to the change. Instead of sending buses to the Bowery as they did years ago, the hotels now send buses to homeless shelters. They do not follow up, Mr. Lungen said, by screening the men, who are simply put to work.
The owners of the Pines and Kutsher's said that because their staffs are relatively small and a high percentage of their employees work the year round, they generally do not have a problem with transient workers. Brown's recently hired Sgt. G. W. King of the Sullivan County Sheriff's Department to screen applicants.
"You don't see card games between the workers anymore," he said. "You see drugs. They want it cleaned up."
The Concord, by contrast, expands its summer payroll by about 400 jobs to serve the guests who fill its 1,225 rooms.
Some local officials as well as advocates for the homeless say that the Concord may have logistical problems that the other hotels do not, but that the hotel's managers have created an underclass by recruiting workers from homeless shelters with fliers and phone calls. The officials said the Concord put them in rundown quarters and took too much money for room and board.
 
Ethical Questions
 "We are only allowed to do so much by law," said George N. Parker, an owner and the general manager of the Concord. "Every resort community in the world has this problem. We can't fingerprint people, and the college kids don't want to work in the kitchen.
"And besides, where do you think some of these people would be if it were not for their jobs here? Some of them have made a life out of this."
The executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless for Westchester, Anthony Wynne, said the Concord had recruited from the men's shelter in New Rochelle and elsewhere, often in emergencies, like the day after payday, when many of the transients leave without notice.
"I have some very strong ethical questions about importing poor people, paying them minimum wage and then taking more money out," Mr. Wynne said. "How can anyone move on from there? How can they purchase any goods, besides drugs and alcohol? More than anything else, this is slave labor."
The debate, Mr. Lungen said, has remained a quiet one because the drugs and violence have "never affected guests" and because most people in the community know that they depend on the survival of the hotels. Some officials who were interviewed called the issue too "politically hot" to talk about.
"The hotels are up against it, but there is no question that the transients make my job tougher," Mr. Lungen said. "It's not that we don't have local people committing crimes. We do. But because of the transients, our jails are more crowded and the feel is closer to that of a big city."
Three employees have been killed in the staff quarters of the Concord in the last 16 months, one in a stabbing by another worker in May and two in March 1990 in a fire set by another employee. Mr. Lungen said these incidents had received little attention "because as usual they happened amongst the employees."
But on a recent hot afternoon, state police investigators trudged from one door to another in a group of disheveled bungalows that house much of the Concord's staff. Their mission: handing out notices of a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrests and convictions of the killers of Miriam and Lazar Papier, an elderly Hasidic couple slain earlier this month in their own summer bungalow only a mile away. Investigators believe the slayings started as a burglary.
While Mr. Lungen and Capt. Michael F. Cahill of the state police have said they are not ruling out any possibility, both have also said that the Concord staff bungalows are a focus of the investigation, if only for their proximity to the scene of the slayings.
Bill W., who is 47 years old, sat in his room under a sign that said "Drugs won't work here." He said he did not want to give his full name out of fear of losing his job. A slight figure with a gaunt face, he held up his pay stub for two weeks' work. Though he had worked 80 hours at $4.25 an hour, he was left with $206, once room and board and union dues were taken out. He said he spends nearly all of his pay on crack, marijuana and alcohol.
He said he had come to the Concord because he was in trouble and homeless. He found out about the job through the La Guardia Men's Shelter in Chester, N.Y. He said he was concerned about the hotel's "loose hiring practices" because the "drugs keep pulling me down." But over all, he said, he was satisfied with the arrangement.
"This is good to get back on my feet," he said. "I don't have a lot of money, but then I don't have a lot to spend it on. I have no electric bills, no extra food bills. They give me my uniform for work. And it's very beautiful here."
He added one more note. "The violence doesn't bother me," he said. "People are upset with three or four murders in two years. But where I come from that happens before nightfall."

HEADLINE: Japan, to Rescue Bank, Will Tap Deposit Fund

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 24

 BODY:
Shedding new light on how they intend to consolidate the Japanese banking industry, Government officials said today that that they planned to tap the deposit insurance fund to help a healthy bank acquire a dying mutual savings bank.
With its paternalistic style of regulating banks and coercive but quiet methods for managing financial problems when they crop up, Japan has never before touched its bank deposit insurance fund. 
 But the regulators have now decided that the country has too many banks -- there are currently about 150 banks in all of Japan, compared with some 12,000 banking institutions in the United States -- and that the weaker and smaller must merge to survive in the tough financial environment of the 1990's.
"With financial deregulation and other pressures the financial environment is sure to worsen," one banking regulator said.
 
Sums Involved Are Modest
 The sums involved in the current case are modest. The deposit insurance fund is expected to make low-interest loans of some $80 million to encourage the Iyo Bank to acquire the Toho Sogo Bank, both modest-sized institutions on the largely rural island of Shikoku, in southwest Japan.
The Government officials said that the money would probably be provided in the form of loans at rates well below market levels, perhaps around 3 percent.
But the policy implications of the deal are more significant, as Government officials conceded that the highly publicized arrangement was intended to signal that the Government was now carrying through on its efforts to weed out weak banks and force them into combinations.
Robert Zielinski, a banking analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities here, said the move had sent a message "that all the fun is over and that there are going to be serious bankruptcies."
There have been two mergers of major city banks in the last two years and more are expected.
The deal has also illuminated the principal policy followed by the regulators in dealing with major financial problems at certain institutions -- it lets them slide.
The United States and many European countries have tough rules on when a bank must write off or make provisions for bad debts. In Japan there is a great deal of flexibility, giving banks years to try to work out problems.
A debacle like the collapse of the American savings and loan system may never happen in Japan, if only because the Government has shown no inclination to force sick institutions to face up to their problems quickly if speedy action would hurt public confidence or the public Treasury.
The Toho Sogo Bank is a good example. Toshio Tsubouchi, a wealthy industrialist, bought control of the bank in the early 1970's. It was used then to lend heavily to Kurushima Dock, a major shipowner with which he was affiliated.
With the depression in the shipping industry around 1980, Toho Sogo's loans to the company turned sour. But the bank has not had to face the problem head on until now, about 10 years later.
Toho Sogo must sell off about 20 of its 44 branch offices, according to news reports.
 
Committee Will Decide
 After that, the deposit insurance fund will form a committee of 10 composed of officials from the Bank of Japan, the Finance Ministry and the financial industry. These executives will then have several months to determine precisely how much aid Iyo Bank will receive for acquiring what remains of Toho Sogo.
In the past, mergers of ailing banks were generally supported by other banks under the guidance of the Government regulators.
The new approach shows that the Government is taking a more active role in eliminating the sick and leaving Japan with fewer, but presumably healthier, banks.

HEADLINE: President Out At Selectronics

 BODY:
Selectronics Inc., a developer and manufacturer of hand-held electronic Bibles and other reference products, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, James Finke, had resigned.
Mr. Finke was hired last year to expand the company's retail business, but Selectronics has since been restructured to focus on contracts with a few big distributors. 
 Because of this change, "it seemed timely for him to pursue other interests," Michael L. Weiner, the chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
During the recession, the Minneapolis-based company has seen many of its retail customers go bankrupt or fall behind in their payments. Selectronics said its fiscal-year results, to be reported later this month, would show "a significant loss."
To focus on big distributors, Selectronics has expanded in Europe in a venture with a large French distributor, Euro Direct Marketing. Selectronics said it was seeking a similar opportunity in Japan.

HEADLINE: Orders for Durables Drop 1.6%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
New orders for long-lived factory goods fell 1.6 percent in June and were not as strong in May as previously estimated, the Commerce Department reported today.
The unexpected decline in June's orders fanned doubts about economic recovery and caused bond prices to rise, but it did not force analysts into a fundamental reappraisal of the outlook. They noted that the report on orders for durable goods is one of the most erratic of the Government's statistical series. 
 "We were disappointed," said Paul W. Boltz, economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, when asked about the report, which had been expected to show a modest increase. Yet Mr. Boltz said he continued to expect the economy to grow at a 2.5 to 3 percent pace during the second half of the year.
 
Confidence Remains
 Nor did the June decline, which was four-tenths of 1 percent when the military sector is excluded, shake the confidence of Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economic at ASB Capital Management in Washington. Although some analysts worry that the economy may have pulled out of recession only to soon slip back again, Mr. Carpenter said this remained unlikely.
"I'm not in the double-dip camp," he said, adding that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to be stampeded into a resumption of interest-rate cuts by a few weak economic reports.
Today's report, moreover, included some bright spots, including a 3.6 percent rise in new orders for primary-metals goods and a 3.7 percent rise for transportation equipment that was the second straight increase after four declines.
 
Shipments Advancing
 Shipments of durable goods -- which are products, from desks to destroyers, that are expected to last at least three years -- posted their third straight monthly advance after falling from November through March.
Shipments are considered a gauge of current economic conditions, while new orders and unfilled orders, or backlogs, are predictive indicators. Unfilled orders fell 1.1 percent in June, the fourth straight decline.
Orders for all types of durable goods totaled $116.5 billion last month, 1.6 percent below May's $118.4 billion and 7.7 percent below the level of June 1990.
The bulk of the new-orders decline last month was in two categories -- electronic and other equipment, which fell 10.1 percent, to $15.2 billion, and industrial machinery and equipment, which fell 4.7 percent, to $20 billion.
The rise in transportation equipment orders resulted from a jump in orders for aircraft that more than offset a decline for ships and tanks, the Commerce Department stated.
Excluding transportation, orders for durable goods fell 3.3 percent,after rising 1.1 percent in May and 5.9 percent in April.
Over all, the May increase for orders for durable goods is now put at 2 percent, down from 3.8 percent initially reported and from 3.4 percent after an early revision.
 
Behind the Revision
 The downward adjustment reflected a smaller gain for transportation equipment, which a month ago was put at $30.6 billion but is now put at $28.8 billion.
Within the capital-goods industries, new orders for nonmilitary products rose 4.2 percent, to $29.2 billion -- the first increase in six months -- but much of this consisted of aircraft that for the most part will not be built for years. If aircraft and parts are not counted, new orders for nonmilitary goods dropped 5 percent in June, while shipments rose eight-tenths of 1 percent and backlogs fell 2.4 percent.

HEADLINE: GORBACHEV'S PLAN ON POWER SHARING WINS WIDE ASSENT

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 24

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced today that he had reached agreement with most of the country's republics on a draft treaty for a drastically decentralized system of power sharing in the Soviet Union.
By achieving a draft accord with nine of the 15 Soviet republics, Mr. Gorbachev has achieved a signficant political success on the eve of an important Communist Party central committee meeting, and next week's meeting in Moscow with President Bush. 
 Given Mr. Gorbachev's urgent efforts to encourage Western and Japanese investment and economic aid, the unity treaty will make it easier for Mr. Bush and other leaders to discuss such help more concretely. One problem in the past has been uncertainty by foreign governments and companies whether such funds should be given to the central Government or the separate republics.
The Soviet leader said the proposed treaty, one of the keys to his hopes for the political and economic reconstruction of this battered nation, would settle all major differences between his central Government and the republics except the precise system of tax sharing.
 
Gorbachev Delighted
 The taxation formula is supposed to be worked out in special negotiations within the next day, said Mr. Gorbachev, who was obviously delighted to announce progress toward liberalizing the nation as he faced a week of Communist Party intrigues and superpower summitry.
The White House said today in Washington that on his trip to the Soviet Union next week President Bush would address the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine and meet with members of the emerging democratic movement in Moscow. [Page A10.]
The party hierarchy gathers in private session on Thursday to again vent their frustration at how the Gorbachev strategy is undoing their power monopoly. On Tuesday, President Bush arrives to seal the strategic nuclear weapons treaty as the latest success in the Soviet leader's disarmament compromises.
For all his optimism, Mr. Gorbachev still faces a series of obstacles to his hope for fast final approval of a new union treaty. There is the insistence by some republics such as the Ukraine to put off republic parliamentary debate until September, and there is the thorny taxation issue as well.
Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federation republic and a key figure in the attempted compromise, stressed in remarks that the tax dispute -- how much the central Government coffers would yield to the republics' desire to control the revenue flow -- was a critical issue that had not been worked out.
Speaking on the eve of a Communist Party central committee meeting that is expected to again criticize his courting of Western economic alliances, President Gorbachev nevertheless pronounced the negotiations a success. In particular he hailed the decision of Armenia, one of the six republics that originally boycotted the treaty talks, to rejoin the discussions this week.
Mr. Gorbachev emerged early this morning with the announcement after a final 12-hour burst of negotiations that capped a three-month process of seeking compromise with the restless, sovereignty-hungry republics on a blueprint for a new Soviet Union.
 
Gorbachev Hails Treaty
 He hailed the treaty as "a very deep reforming of our federation and a serious redistribution of powers in favor of the republics."
"The most important thing is that we have finally reached agreement," the Soviet leader declared this morning. He said the next phase in the process is that the treaty would be open for signing after additional consideration by the nine republics that negotiated it with him.
In addition to Russia, the keystone republic with most of the the country's population and wealth, the republics involved in the original negotiations in April were the Ukraine, Byelorussia, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Khirghizistan, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenistan. Not taking part were the three Baltic republics demanding outright independence -- Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia -- plus Georgia, Moldavia and Armenia, which have been vowing independence at a slower pace.
The Armenian President, Levon Ter-Petrosian, who has scheduled a fall referendum in his republic on eventual independence, appeared at the discussions on Tuesday and has not yet commented on how attractive the proposed draft treaty might have become in the negotiating process of give and take.
President Gorbachev said he hoped the treaty would prove inviting to all the republics. "I am for the deep sovereignty of the republics within a framework of a new union," he said.
 
Fresh Problems and Doubts
 Fresh problems and doubts have arisen regularly across the three-month negotiating process, a pattern likely to continue into the next phase. But President Gorbachev was obviously pleased to be able to claim progress as he moved midway between last week's economic summit meeting, with its concern for the failing Soviet economy, and the summit meeting here next week with President Bush to sign the strategic arms reduction treaty.
The decentralization of political power and economic life has been the main goal of the republics in the treaty negotiations. Mr. Gorbachev at first resisted their pressure but then yielded last spring when the national economy approached a state of breakdown and he turned from the traditional reliance on the centralized monolith of state Communism to try and spark economic life.
With his strategy now cast more with the republics, President Gorbachev has won greater support from the world's free-market democracies, whose leaders, the Group of Seven nations, promised him technical aid and an ongoing subsidiary role last week at their London summit meeting.
 
New Political Force
 His closer alliance with the republics also clearly appeals to Mr. Gorbachev as a new political force to buttress him against the complaints and threats of Communist Party hard-liners. They have been thrashing about more lately as they see their role shrinking under the strategy of President Gorbachev, their own party leader.
After announcing the draft agreement, Mr. Gorbachev turned to the coming full gathering of the party central committee on Thursday and Friday, saying he wanted to liberalize the old party platform and "help the party get its second wind."
The meeting is expected to be interesting mainly as a measure of the resistance, or the atrophying, of the party elite in the face of Mr. Gorbachev's accelerating strategy of trying to democratize life and to build a Soviet role in the world's free economic market.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic, center left, and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, center right, during a meeting of Soviet republic delegations on Tuesday. (Associated Press)
