HEADLINE: Strong Overseas Sales Lift McDonald's Profits

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest restaurant chain, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 8 percent, to $232 million, or 63 cents a share. That compared with profits of $215.8 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier.
McDonald's is embroiled in a domestic price war with competitors, and much of the rise in the second quarter came from strong foreign sales. But analysts said the earnings were more sluggish than they had expected. 
 In the second quarter, sales for the company were nearly flat. Quarterly revenue rose less than 1 percent to $1.67 billion, from $1.66 billion in the 1990 period.
Systemwide sales, which includes nearly 8,400 franchised restaurants, rose 6 percent to $4.96 billion, from $4.66 billion a year earlier.
On the New York Stock Exchange, McDonald's stock closed at $33.125 yesterday, down 12.5 cents a share.
 
'Far Weaker' Than Expected
 Michael G. Mueller of Montgomery Securities, one of the more bearish restaurant analysts who follow McDonald's, said, "I was anticipating a weak quarter, but this is far weaker than I think anyone expected."
He said that while McDonald's lower-priced entrees, known as its "value menu," had succeeded in attracting new customers, it was disappointing in view of McDonald's large advertising and marketing expenses in the last six months.
Operating income from restaurants within the United States actually declined 1 percent in the first six months to $490.2 million, from $494.2 million. And revenue in the United States declined 5 percent in the period, to $1.83 billion, from $1.92 billion.
But Mr. Mueller noted that some of the revenue decline was actually a healthy sign because it was a result of McDonald's selling poorly performing company-owned restaurants.
 
Growth Abroad
 Strong growth at foreign restaurants helped. Operating income outside of the United States in the first six months rose 21 percent, to $303.1 million, from $250.9 million. Six-month foreign sales rose 12 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.25 billion.
In a statement, Michael R. Quinlan, McDonald's chairman and chief executive, said that despite the weak sales the company was convinced that its "value menu" had improved customer perceptions of McDonald's. Mr. Quinlan said the number of orders at restaurants had risen, although he was not specific.
"There is no clear sign," he said, "of economic recovery impacting consumer spending levels in several major markets, including the United States, and yet our top-line sales and transactions are improving, slowly but steadily, in economic environments which are not."
A spokesman declined to say how well the McLean Deluxe, the low-fat burger introduced this year, was doing. He said, however, that it was selling better than the McDLT, the poorly received lettuce-and-tomato burger that McLean replaced.

HEADLINE: Brazil Wins Skirmish With I.M.F.

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 24

 BODY:
President Fernando Collor de Mello has scored a populist victory here in a shouting match with the International Monetary Fund, which acceded to his demand yesterday that Jose Fajgenbaum, an Argentine economist, be removed as head of the fund's negotiating team in Brasilia. He is to be replaced Thursday by Sterie Baza, an American.
In the morning, demonstrators greeted the President, waving signs reading, "Long live Collor! I.M.F., Respect our people!" and "Brazil is not a colony!" Headlines proclaimed "I.M.F. backs down," and "I.M.F. heeds Collor."
 
Debate Over Motives
 In more sophisticated circles, analysts were debating today whether Brazil's shouting match with the fund actually represented a new, populist turn in economic policy, or a clever piece of political theater. Some suggested that Mr. Collor might have stage-managed it to make an eventual accord with the fund more palatable at home. Debt-rescheduling talks with the fund resumed today after a three-day suspension. 
 The confrontation between Brazil, the third world's largest debtor, and the fund started last Thursday when the Jornal do Brasil, a newspaper, reported that Mr. Fajgenbaum had said Brazil could straighten out its finances only when it changed clauses in its Constitution that mandate generous federal revenue sharing with states and muncipalities.
"He's the one who should get his own house in order," President Collor snapped in response, demanding Sunday that the Washington-based organization recall him. "For someone from outside to come and give us tips is inadmissible."
 
Statements Are Denied
 Mr. Fajgenbaum denied that he had made the statements, but his denial had no effect.
Many analysts here suggest Mr. Collor's highly confrontational stand was intended to defuse future left-wing opposition to constitutional changes of the kind the Fund representative was advocating.
"He is playing up a basically insignificant thing to show the domestic audience how tough he is," one Brazilian businessman said, noting that by law Mr. Collor needs the Senate's approval for debt-rescheduling agreements.
But other analysts feared the verbal sparring could signal a new phase of Brazilian intransigence that could slow Brazil's return to the good graces of the international banking community.
An agreement to reschedule $8.5 billion in overdue interest has been reached with representatives of foreign commercial banks, but must be endorsed by 95 percent of the creditors before it takes effect. The pact, which is the only debt rescheduling of Mr. Collor's 16-month-old Government, has been ratified by 280 banks, or about half the total.
"People here are very concerned; they don't want the arrears deal to fall through," Riordan A. Roett, a Brazil expert, said today from New York where he is a bank consultant.
Brazil's left views the fund as a meddling policeman for capitalist banks. Now, Mr. Collor, a free market conservative, is taking the same view, giving rise to such anxieties.
"The Government should reject this inadmissable interference and send this technician out of the country on the first plane," said Roberto Freire, a Congressman for the Brazilian Communist Party.
Brazil has not had an agreement with the fund since early 1989. A new accord could involve the disbursement of up to $2 billion in low-interest loans to Brazil over 18 months. But the true significance of an accord is that it signals private bankers that Brazil's finances are in order.
 
Talks on $52 Billion in Debt
 Next month, talks are to start in New York over rescheduling Brazil's $52 billion medium- and long-term foreign debt. Without an I.M.F. accord, there is little chance that the bankers will sign an agreement.
In constrast, Argentina's Central Bank president, Roque Fernandez, announced today that the fund is to approve a $1 billion standby loan to Argentina on Monday.
Brazil's progress on debt talks -- and Mr. Collor's position -- will no doubt be of considerable interest to an American business mission scheduled to arrive in Brasilia in two weeks, led by Vice President Dan Quayle and by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher.
In recent days, Mr. Collor has openly expressed frustration with a perceived lack of support from the developed world.
 
Plan for Rain Forests
 During last week's summit meeting in London, Brazil expected that the Western powers would give Brazil $1.5 billion for a three-year rain-forest protection plan. Instead, they gave $50 million.

HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS ASSESS ARAB-ISRAEL MOVE

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
If Arabs and Israelis decide to make deals, not war, how much does the Israeli economy stand to gain?
Nobody has a remotely reliable estimate, said Michael Bruno, governor of Israel's central bank. Nobody is suggesting, said Dan Halperin, an Israeli consultant in Tel Aviv, that "lifting the boycott today will have a major impact tomorrow." 
 And while an Israeli business group said this week that the boycott has cost Israel more than $36 billion since 1948, some Government officials, like Amnon Neubach, the Israeli economic counselor in Washington, say they are not sure that the Arab ban has hurt Israel measurably.
Egypt and Saudi Arabia had proposed ending the 43-year-old economic boycott of Israel if Israel freezes further settlements in the West Bank. Israel has rejected that proposal, but if the talk about peace produces any agreements with Syria and Jordan, the boycott could start to come down.
The Arab ban covers all direct trade with Israel, dealings with most companies that do business with Israel, as well as with firms that buy or sell to, or invest in, companies that do business with Israel.
 
Boom Not Expected
 Economists, investment experts and executives, including Mr. Bruno and Mr. Halperin, argue that, in time, ending the boycott could lift confidence among foreign investors, stimulate more service ventures, and improve the prospects for Palestinian exporters in the West Bank and in Gaza.
To be sure, economists are not predicting an Israeli export boom in the region. Most Israeli exports -- diamonds, electronics, pharmaceuticals -- are geared to upscale markets in Europe and the United States, not to neighbors like Jordan or Syria whose living standards are roughly one-tenth of Israel's.
Trade between Israel and Egypt, except for oil, remains negligable more than a decade after Egypt broke ranks with other Arab nations and dropped out of the boycott. Besides, the most eager buyers and sellers on either side of the Israeli-Arab divide are already finding ways to make hundreds of millions of dollars worth of transactions regardless.
The biggest benefit for the Israeli economy, said Walter P. Stern, a New York investment adviser, is likely to be an intangible one, greater investor confidence. The end of the boycott would be "a long term signal of Israel's re-entry into the world as a legitimate place to trade and invest."
 
'Psychological Barriers'
 Jean Abi Nader of the United States Arab Chamber of Commerce said, "It would lift psychological barriers to companies that want to do business in both markets."
Multinationals that have refrained from making investments in Israel -- especially Japanese, Korean and French firms -- may take a second look, Israeli economists say. With a few exceptions like I.B.M. and Motorola, foreign direct investment is small.
"You would see the involvement in Israel of more multinational companies, especially in industries where you don't see them at all," said Dan Halperin an Israeli consultant in Tel Aviv. "It will also become easier for Israeli firms to buy knowhow from international companies."
What is more, Israel's credit rating could get a welcome boost, Mr. Bruno said. Lenders, he said, would likely be less reluctant to risk their funds. Israel is struggling to create jobs for hundreds of thousands of new Soviet immigrants and is looking to the rest of the world to supply some of the needed investment.
 
High-Skilled Labor Advantage
 Consumers in Saudi Arabia or Syria may not be about to start stocking up on Israeli brands for which there are easy substitutes, economists say. But, Israeli services, from computer programming and insurance to medical services and tourism and agricultural may find a more ready reception.
"Israel has a comparative advantage in services because of its high skilled labor," said Leonardo Liederman, an economist at Tel Aviv University. With the influx of Soviet doctors, engineers and scientists, such services are apt to become even more affordable and abundant.
The total volume of imports and exports could swell by $1 billion if the boycott ends, said Haim Ben-Shahar, professor of economist at Tel Aviv University. Total trade last year was about $37 billion.
Surprisingly, some of the biggest winners of a cease-fire in the Arab economic war against Israel could be Palestinians in the Gaza and West Bank. Small businesses there produce things that Arab neighbors can afford to buy -- fruit, vegetables, olive oil, cut stone, clothing and shoes.
"These are natural traders," said Howard Rosen, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The boycott hurt Palestinian trade much more than Israel's."
Palestininas now find their exports to Arab countries blocked for a variety of reasons related to the boycott, like relying on Israeli ports, using inputs made in Israel or being required by the Israeli Government to sell produce through Israeli cooperatives.
"I could imagine an export boom," said Peter Gubser, president of Near East Refugee Aid. "You'd see a lot of products with some Israeli inputs going out under a West Bank label."
A spurt in export-related production on the West Bank and in Gaza would be blessing because, due to the Palestinian uprising as well as the Soviet immigrant wave, unemployment among Palestinians is rising.

HEADLINE: Peru's Ex-Leader Enmeshed In Scandal Over Failed Bank

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, July 20

 BODY:
This month's closing of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International has diverted the attention of Peru from its poverty, malnutrition and terrorism to a bizarre drama involving former President Alan Garcia, the mysterious financial network of the bank, and allegations that Mr. Garcia looted the country with the bank's help.
Investigations led by a commission of the Peruvian Congress and involving two American private investigative companies have turned up preliminary evidence -- which Mr. Garcia has rebutted -- that during his presidency he siphoned away as much as $50 million from the country and used B.C.C.I.'s Panama branch as a conduit for the funds. 
 One report said Mr. Garcia was introduced to B.C.C.I. Panama by Manuel Noriega, the deposed Panamian dictator, who was a close friend and ally of Mr. Garcia's and an important customer of the bank.
The congressional commission has also found that for two years during Mr. Garcia's presidency -- for reasons no one here can fully explain -- B.C.C.I. Panama was Peru's private banker, even though the bank paid a lower interest rate on deposits than other banks.
Early in Mr. Garcia's five-year term, which spanned the period from mid-1985 to mid-1990, the Peruvian central bank kept more than half of the country's cash in B.C.C.I. Panama, at a time when officials within the central bank were warning that B.C.C.I. was losing huge sums. In effect, Peru's deposits were propping up the bank.
In the aftermath of the bank's closing in nearly 70 countries, there are investigations -- both formal and informal -- as regulators, depositors and politicians try to resolve questions about the bank's dealings.
In Peru and elsewhere, those who are sifting through the bank's past are finding that its penchant for privacy and its unwieldy international structure make it difficult to reach any conclusions quickly.
The United States has long had a distaste for Mr. Garcia's politics because of his nationalization of an American oil company and because he led a movement in Latin America to resist paying foreign debts. It is intensely interested in the fate of the investigation and has encouraged the effort, which is being led by an ambitious, 32-year-old member of the Peruvian Congress, Fernando Olivera, who ran on an anti-corruption, anti-Garcia platform.
American diplomats have told the commission that information exists that could shed light on Mr. Garcia's dealings, yet they cannot share it with Peruvian authorities until the Peruvian Government votes to lift the immunity from prosecution that is bestowed on all former presidents.
 
Public Theater
The Investigator Becomes a Hero
 The theater for this investigation has been Peruvian television, which has broadcast the allegations and the denials in detail. That kind of visibility has fueled debate throughout the country and made Mr. Olivera a temporary hero.
This week, for instance, as hundreds marched through a dusty, narrow street here following a religious procession led by two life-sized silver images of the Virgin of Carmen, a peasant woman approached Mr. Olivera to cheer him on.
"We're praying to the Blessed Virgin that you'll get our money back for us," she said. She squeezed his hand and then disappeared into the crowd.
Most of the Peruvian people are puzzled, however. Recent polls found that 70 percent believe Mr. Garcia profited illegally while in office, but only 40 percent believe the charges by Mr. Olivera's commission. One reason for their confusion is that it does not seem plausible that a former president can afford two luxurious homes here, expensive travel and other luxuries on his modest income of $2,500 a month from a charitable foundation and as a member of the Senate.
"There is just no doubt among anyone you talk to that his salary could not have supported such a life style," said a very senior Western diplomat. "That's a given."
 
Letters From Banks
 Mr. Garcia, who left Peru after the bank was seized and is traveling, has denied allegations including that he had secret bank accounts in the United States. He says he has no savings and never had such accounts overseas. Appearing on national television, he has produced letters from B.C.C.I. offices and other banks where he allegedly had deposits saying no Garcia accounts ever existed.
Since one of the detective companies hired by the commission was based in Florida, Mr. Garcia filed a complaint with Florida officials seeking to examine the company, Larc Investigative Services. The state acted quickly, bringing charges of malpractice against Larc.
The counteroffensive seems to have worked. A Congress that two months ago seemed ready for the first time in modern history to lift immunity from a former president, is now in retreat. The House is scheduled to vote in August, and politicians say there is at least a 50 percent chance it will end the inquiry into Mr. Garcia's personal finances.
"What you have here is a cultural assumption that a Latin American head of state must be corrupt, but when you check out the allegations, there is nothing there," said Jerome I. Levinson, Mr. Garcia's lawyer at Arnold & Porter in Washington. "The hostility in this town towards Alan Garcia is palpable. I have a certain sympathy for the guy."
Mr. Levinson said he asked Mr. Garcia in their first conversation if he had any bank accounts abroad, even ones that might have not been named by the Olivera commission.
"He said he had no accounts, either direct or indirect, and that he had nothing to hide," Mr. Levinson said.
Mr. Olivera admits his commission has suffered a big credibility setback and is casting about for new evidence. And Mr. Garcia's supporters are quietly claiming victory and talking about a possible Garcia presidency in the next elections in 1995.
"I think the investigation has been very poorly managed," said Felipe Ortiz de Zevallos, an economist and one of the country's leading pollsters. "The accusations were premature, not conclusive, so Garcia could shoot holes in them. He's done a superb public relations job. He can now say that it is the bankers and foreigners who are trying to get back at him."
 
Tallying the Expenses
Houses and Trips On $1,500 a Month
 A year ago, it did not seem this grim to Mr. Olivera. As Mr. Garcia left office, the country was in shambles. Inflation had been two million percent. Peru was an outcast in the financial community. Foreign investment was nonexistent and terrorism on the rise.
What bothered many members of Congress was Mr. Garcia's life style -- the new house he bought in the fashionable section of Chacarilla, the beachhouse he built to the south, the restaurants he visited and the trips and vacations he took. After all, as President, Mr. Garcia's salary was only $1,500 a month.
And some are now wondering how he can afford such expensive legal defense.
After the investigation was begun, the commission tallied every known expenditure and source of income for Mr. Garcia, relying heavily on income tax statements. By November, it found that from 1977 through June 1991, Mr. Garcia's spending exceeded his income by $500,000.
"That in and of itself should be enough to prosecute him," said Lourdes Flores, another member of the investigative commission.
 
Americans Are Hired
 But the commission, tipped off that Mr. Garcia might have had foreign bank accounts, hired American investigators -- Kroll Associates of New York, famous for finding the secret bank accounts of Saddam Hussein, Ferdinand Marcos and the Duvalliers, and the little-known Larc, headed by Rafael N. Garcia (no relation to President Garcia).
By April, Mr. Olivera thought he had the evidence. A letter from Kroll describing "interim findings" said that in the failed Western Federal Savings and Loan Association of Dallas, which was folded into Sunbelt Federal Savings by regulators in 1988, there had been an account under the name of Alan Garcia Perez, but that it was closed by the end of 1989.
In reference to B.C.C.I., Kroll wrote, "We have been informed by sources we consider reliable that they believe it probable that Mr. Garcia had a personal account or accounts at B.C.C.I. and Mr. Garcia had accumulated substantial monies while in office."
 
Transfers Abroad
 A five-page Larc memorandum said Mr. Garcia had been introduced to B.C.C.I.'s Panama office by Mr. Noriega, Larc also said Mr. Garcia probably had diverted $50 million through the B.C.C.I. Panama bank into British, Belgian, Spanish and American institutions. Some of the accounts were in his wife's name, Maria N. Bodereau, and transfers were made from a Belgian bank to the defunct Bank of New England to an account held by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the bankrupt Wall Street investment firm, the report said. Calls to Larc seeking more information were not returned.
Account numbers were provided, information similar to the Kroll report was given about accounts at Western Federal, and a report was made of an account at the Centrust Savings Bank in Miami, another failed institution whose largest individual shareholder was Gaith Pharaon, a Middle Eastern businessman and a suspected connection for B.C.C.I. investments in the United States.
With great fanfare, Mr. Olivera announced the results before the Peruvian Congress last April. The country gasped. Mr. Garcia's powerful American Popular Revolutionary Alliance party shook at its foundation.
 
The Counteroffensive
Mustering Support From Old Allies
 Mr. Garcia struck back by hiring Arnold & Porter and calling into service Jorge del Castillo, former mayor of Lima and an old political ally. He also solicited letters from all the banks named by Larc and Kroll as to whether he held accounts there.
The rebuttal arrived: A letter signed by Ajmal Afzal and Khalid Zaidi, managers of B.C.C.I.'s Luxembourg branch, said no account existed. Likewise, B.C.C.I.'s branches in the Cayman Islands and Panama also denied existence of Garcia accounts. Sunbelt Federal Savings wrote that no Garcia account could be found, and the Bank of New England said no Drexel account with the number 092074392 existed.
These were presented on national television news shows as proof of Mr. Garcia's veracity.
Mr. del Castillo paid a visit to Florida, where he met with state officials and asked them to investigate Larc.
Within a month, the state had accused Rafael Garcia, Larc's president, and a former official of the Drug Enforcement Agency, of refusing to cooperate with their investigation, giving conflicting statements about the investigation to state officials, and not having a proper license to operate a branch office.
It also found that Mr. Garcia had been warned that the information he had received had not been verified. And state officials told the sources involved in gathering information for the Larc report not to talk to the press.
John M. Russi, director of Florida's division of licensing, also permitted two Peruvian television stations to tape an explanation of the charges against Larc given by Florida officials to Mr. del Castillo. The tape was widely broadcast on national television in Peru.
 
Claiming Victory
 The impact was significant; Mr. Garcia's allies began claiming victory. "We have showed that these accusations are lies, falsehoods and vicious statements with no basis," Mr. del Castillo said in an interview. "It should be absolutely clear that the former President has done nothing wrong."
Not everyone agrees. What they do agree on is that time is running out for Mr. Olivera and his commission.
In early August, the Peruvian House will vote on whether there is enough indication that Mr. Garcia was involved in wrongdoing to justify lifting his immunity.
If it does, then the Senate, of which Mr. Garcia is a permanent member because he is a former President, must take similar action. Only then, will the Peruvian Supreme Court consider lifting the immunity and begin prosecution.
One hope for the investigators had been the banking regulators in the United States. Since both the Larc and Kroll reports cited reports of a Garcia account at Western Federal Savings, they hoped regulators could find evidence of it.
Officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation, who examined the records of Sunbelt and Western Federal, say they found one suspicious $2 million transfer, but they could not link it to Mr. Garcia. They also checked the books of Centrust, but found nothing. Just last week, they closed the case.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Home Desk

LENGTH: 1367 words

HEADLINE: Siblings: Growing Up And Closer

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE

 BODY:
ADULT siblings inhabit a twilight zone of family relationships. They have no roles, no rituals, no clear-cut patterns of behavior, a few proscribed but no prescribed ways of relating -- no relationship at all, sometimes, since as freewheeling adults theirs is a voluntary association.
"Sometimes it seems like little more than that -- an association," said Janice A. Cummings, publisher of Memory Lane Magazine for radio station KXAM in Scottsdale, Ariz., and the eldest of five siblings age 22 to 35. "I mean, sometimes I can't believe that we were all raised under the same roof. I look at my brothers and sisters as adults and think, 'Who the hell are you?' " 
 Now, it seems, Mrs. Cummings and tens of millions of other American adults are going to have to find out. Demographic trends show the emergence of a generation of grownups with more siblings than children.
Steve W. Rawlings, a family demographer for the United States Census Bureau, projects that as many as 10 percent of the adult population may not marry during their lifetime, up from 5 percent in recent years. Of women born in the early 1950's, he said, 17 percent are remaining childless in their lifetime, up from 9 percent of women born in the 1930's. Mr. Rawlings also noted that overall family size has been steadily declining.
With Americans living longer, the importance of siblings as potential care-givers looms large. Their role is further underscored by the economic downturn and the AIDS pandemic, which are sending many adults to family members for support. That makes siblings "the ultimate insurance policy," says Deborah T. Gold, a medical sociologist at Duke University Medical Center.
"They are the only people with the potential to know us from birth to death," she said. "They can meet us on an equal footing not possible in a parent-child relationship. And they are the only ones who can help us look over the chaos of our lives and make it make sense."
More often than not, the summons for help is likely to be answered. Researchers say and siblings agree that there is a deep-seated sense of obligation for brothers and sisters lurking between the biblical mandate that they are one another's keepers and the hope that if worst came to worst, they would come to one another's aid. And there is a shared family history.
These ties, however, can often be buried by adulthood.
"The adult sibling relationship is a revocable detachment, a kind of dormant emotional tie that we can mobilize when we choose," said Ingrid Arnet Connidis, an associate professor in the sociology department of the University of Western Ontario.
The tie seems to operate independently of the relationship at times. "After our father died, it seemed that she was the grieving widow, not my mother," Donald G. Bauchner said of his sister. Mr. Bauchner, 50 years old, who is president of the Perfumer's Workshop in New York, said, "We had a major breakup over this."
But he said he always knew she was there if needed. "I just didn't want to put our bond to the test."
That bond is begun in childhood, with parents writing the script. "Many years ago, after her divorce, Mom selected my sister as the one who would help raise us -- a mini-mom," said Dana Wood, associate beauty editor for W magazine and Mrs. Cummings's 28-year-old sister. "I always felt like I could never be as good as her."
Psychologists say many parents inadvertently place children in comparative categories. "One is 'the smart one,' another 'the responsible one' in a unidimensional labeling that can stunt sibling growth," said Renee A. Cohen, a clinical psychologist in West Los Angeles.
Issues of rivalry and favoritism during childhood can be played out later in grownup terms, says Matti K. Gershenfeld, president of the Couples Learning Center in Jenkintown, Pa. Popular avenues, Dr. Gershenfeld says, are money -- who has more and how that largess is given and received among siblings -- and the comparative success of children.
But these childhood roles can be tossed aside, as Dr. Gershenfeld knows. Born six years after the accidental deaths of the first children in the family, she was the "miracle child" in her family. "I was 10 before I realized that breathing wasn't special," Dr. Gershenfeld said. "Two years after me, my sister was born. She has had to live with that."
So the sisters "intentionally took separate paths to outgrow our parents' definition of me," Dr. Gershenfeld said. "We did not attend the same college. We don't even belong to the same synagogue."
Not all such sibling baggage is as easily disposed of. Dr. Gold says she and her colleagues see about 80 percent of siblings age 65 and older in varying degrees of closeness, 10 percent more in neutral relationships and the remaining 10 percent in negative relationships.
Research, mostly among older adults, suggests, for example, the importance of family size, with larger families producing closer sibling ties, and the relative insignificance of birth order.
A family's race and ethnicity, even its gender composition, help shape the nature of the sibling bond throughout its life cycle. And sibling relationships do have a life cycle.
"In some ways my younger brother, Jerry, and I led a Beaver and Wally existence as kids, if you consider that normal -- sometimes best friends and sometimes worst enemies," said David Zucker, a director whose latest film is "Naked Gun 2 1/2." Jerry Zucker is also a film director.
Adolescence, however, created a break. "We didn't even have a rivalry," Mr. Zucker said. "We just had . . . nothing."
The turnaround, he said, came in college: "The first time I came home during freshman year, we had a long talk. I remember that conversation because it signaled the end of one period and the beginning of another, when we began to be equal."
Adulthood, says Victor G. Cicirelli, a professor of developmental and aging psychology at Purdue University, reduces emotional distances after a period of individual family and career building; a collapsing of age differences under the weight of events that all adults can experience: marriage, divorce, children, jobs.
"Today, my younger brother and I can greet each other as adults in our 40's, with respect for the separate tracks we took in life," said Barbara G. Nye, vice president of strategic planning and development for Jostens Inc., a maker of education and training products in Minneapolis.
But the same adulthood events that can strengthen the sibling bond can readily weaken it.
Their mother's death, which could have come between Mrs. Cummings and Ms. Wood, led to reunion. "We can have some fun with each other when we see each other, now that we no longer have to please someone who was hard to please," Ms. Wood said.
 But for Mr. Bauchner, his sister's marriage pushed them apart. "I never cared for any of her husbands," he said.
But the need to care for elderly parents has become a shared concern for Ms. Nye and her brother. "We've talked about him doing the bulk of the work," she said. "But I see him more clearly now as an adult, and I appreciate the fact that he is more patient with them than I would be."
Seeing siblings as adults and renegotiating roles, psychologists say, are tools with which even damaged relationships can be improved.
The starting point is a continued tie to shared memories, even painful memories, said Stephen P. Bank, an adjunct professor of psychology at Wesleyan University, and an author of "The Sibling Bond" (Basic Books, 1982).
 The search for common ground, Dr. Cicirelli says, can be a challenge. "Siblings are brought up to share certain similarities, values and interests, but life circumstances can weaken that glue," he said. "Operating counter to that, however, is what I believe to be a basic drive to preserve the relationship."
 It is that drive that Mrs. Cummings sees in many adult sibling relationships.
"As adults, we've all been undergoing a renegotiation of roles," she said. "Some of us have been successful, and some of us not. We all have the capacity to have incredible arguments, and then get in touch. In the end, we all seem to come back to each other."

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 720 words

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
A Feint or a Force?

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
At the London economic summit meeting, George Bush was impressed by the commitment of other leaders to aggressive action on environmental issues -- a commitment that appears to have been considerably stronger than the President's own.
His Administration, with the major exception of its support for a new and innovative clean air bill, has not been an active environmental advocate, either at home or abroad. Yet the U.S., with its uncounted automobiles, its near-universal refrigeration and air-conditioning and its vast accumulations of toxic wastes, is one of the world's great polluters. 
 During a 45-minute White House meeting with his new Commission on Environmental Quality, the President remarked that he had been surprised by his summit associates' interest in the subject. He specifically mentioned Chancellor Helmut Kohl's concern for preservation of the threatened Brazilian rain forest.
Mr. Bush also confessed that he had found himself under pressure from other summit leaders to attend a global environment conference to be held under United Nations auspices at Rio de Janeiro in June 1992.
Whether his experience with other leaders will push him to a more aggressive environmental policy remains to be seen. He has not yet agreed to go to Rio, for example, but is holding open the dates. Somewhat similarly, it's not clear whether his Environmental Commission, which met for the first time this week, is a feint or will become a force.
Appointing such commissions is a well-known, time-honored tactic by which many Presidents have appeared to be doing something about problems they didn't actually intend to tackle. At first glance, the large number of industrialists and businessmen in the new environmental group appears to put it in this "for show" category. So does Mr. Bush's stated hope to use the commission to help develop environmental responses other than "regulatory solutions," at reduced expense.
That sounds suspiciously like an effort to back away from enforcement of environmental regulation, which can be both costly and unpopular with industry and unions. The Bush White House often has been charged with seeking relief from, rather than firmly enforcing, rules and regulation -- blocking, for example, proposals by the Environmental Protection Agency that municipal incinerators be required to set up recycling programs.
On the other hand, a number of executives named to the commission have taken an active interest in environmental protection -- for example, William D. Ruckelshaus, twice a director of the E.P.A. and now chairman of Browning-Ferris Industries; Allen F. Jacobsen of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which has established a program to stop pollution from its plants; and Frank P. Popoff of Dow Chemical, a leader in the industry's environmental efforts.
The panel also includes prominent environmental advocates like Patrick F. Noonan of the Conservation Fund, Kathryn Fuller of the World Wildlife Fund and Fred Krupp of the Environmental Defense Fund.
Some in the environmental community believe, moreover, that the group's formation was engineered by Michael Deland, chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, in an effort to strengthen White House policy. Mr. Deland also will serve as commission chairman.
Thus it's at least possible that Mr. Bush's appointees may push him further than he expects, or wants, to go. At its organizational meeting, for example, Richard A. Clarke, the head of Pacific Gas and Electric Company, proposed that "concrete goals" be established for the reduction of pollutants in the atmosphere -- carbon dioxide, in particular.
Coming from an executive of the largest utility in the U.S., which would be directly affected by such a goal, this was a strong proposal. If adopted, moreover, a goal of restricting carbon dioxide emissions would be a direct challenge to John Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
High levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere are believed to be the major cause of the so-called "greenhouse effect," which results in global warming. Mr. Sununu has been highly skeptical of evidence that the earth is heating up, and has used his considerable authority to limit Administration action against a problem he has not been willing to acknowledge.

HEADLINE: Protect Consumers, Not Dairy Farmers

 BODY:
Milo Minderbinder, the famous wheeler-dealer in Joseph Heller's antiwar novel "Catch-22," "enriches" himself by buying high and selling low. With a similar spit-in-your-eye logic, the House Agriculture Committee proposes to protect American consumers -- by cutting back production of milk, thereby driving up its price by as much as 50 cents per gallon. Get it? Put plenty of milk on every breakfast table by cutting back production and raising prices.
That's a proposition that only Milo, or one of 200,000 dairy farmers contributing a total of $2 million a year in campaign contributions, could love. But it's a punishing proposition for millions of poor parents struggling to feed their children. Ordinary logic and fairness dictate a no vote when it comes to the House floor, as early as this week.
The bill would raise next year's milk price supports, the minimum price the Government guarantees dairy farmers, by 25 percent. That would reverse the 30 percent slide in milk prices during the past year. To prevent higher prices from leading to oversized surpluses, which the Government would be required to buy, the bill would penalize farmers who expand production. The idea is to drive up prices without driving up the deficit.
That's clever, but wrongheaded. It isn't Congress's responsibility to guarantee dairy farmers -- or house painters, taxi drivers or locksmiths -- a decent living. If the milk market is glutted, some farmers will have to exit. Indeed, the movement off the farms will intensify as technological advances allow fewer farmers to meet the nation's needs.
Congress could help distressed dairy farmers the same way it helps other displaced workers: job relocation and retraining. It could provide more unemployment compensation, even welfare. But forcing poor parents to skimp on milk purchases to bail out well-off farmers makes sense only in "Catch-22."

HEADLINE: Not Too Late to Keep From Making the Fare-Card Blunder

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Before New York's straphangers allow the subway to switch from tokens to magnetic fare cards (news article, July 2), learn from Washington. I have lived in Queens and in the District of Columbia, and I'm not surprised that magnetic cards are popular with municipal governments -- they let subway systems squeeze more money from riders.
For more than a century a New Yorker has been able to go to the farthest reaches of the subway system for one fare, and every increase in the fare has been made only with considerable deliberation. With the magnetic card system, each rider's fare depends on where the trip begins and ends -- it will no longer be so economical to live in or visit the outermost parts of the boroughs.
It will also be painfully easy to raise the fares, needing only a slight modification in the computer program that deducts values from the magnetic cards at the turnstiles. There is also a Big Brother aspect to the magnetic card system: the card you carry shows your (or, more precisely, its) travel history of where trips began and ended.
People who persist in using private cars should defray the expenses for those who use the more environmentally considerate mass transit system. Don't raise the price for bus and subway, but raise parking rates, gasoline taxes, tolls, license plate fees and the other expenses associated with clogging the streets and polluting the air. And offer a lower fare for rush hour as an additional incentive to ride mass transit to and from work.
 
BERNARD J. SUSSMAN
Washington, July 2, 1991

HEADLINE: Poles Teach U.S. on Employee Ownership

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Poland Outcapitalisms America" (editorial, July 8) puts the American attitude toward capitalism in perfect perspective. We seem to say that capitalism works for everyone else, but not in our backyard.
As Poland casts aside Communism, employee stock ownership plans have emerged as the most effective tool to promote economic freedom. Expanding employee ownership offers an ideological alternative to Marxist-Leninism by advancing a democratic capitalist platform of expanding ownership and democracy.
Marx and Engels stated that you could sum up the entire philosophy of Communism in a single sentence: Abolish private property. The democratic alternative offers an open system that promises working people everywhere what Communism could never provide: political freedom and control over their economic destinies. In many emerging democracies, employee co-ownership of the companies for which they work lends substance to the rhetoric of freedom and opportunity for all.
While most Americans hail the advances toward capitalism in Eastern Europe, they fail to support similar opportunities and measures in the United States. Representatives Beryl Anthony, Cass Ballenger and I have introduced H.R. 2410, a bill promoting employee stock ownership plans. It provides incentives for expanding employee ownership that will give Americans a stake in the company for which they work.
Historians, economists and philosophers alike attribute the economic strength and stability of the United States to our commitment to individual rights, private property and free enterprise. While we have widespread property ownership, the average citizen has not fully participated in ownership of our country's corporations. Our tax structure facilitates corporate enterprise but not the widespread ownership of capital. As a result many American workers feel detached from their workplace and at times disenchanted with free enterprise. Expanding employee stock plans would make participation in the system possible for those who have lacked access to capital and credit.
As the United States searches to promote productivity and improve national competitiveness, we should look to the almost 9,000 privately owned companies that have transferred stock to employees. Most of these -- a few brought back from the brink of bankruptcy -- are successful money makers. If Poland and other Eastern European countries can take bold entrepreneurial steps to expand democratic capitalism, shouldn't the United States be willing to take similar steps to expand ownership to all Americans?
 
DANA ROHRABACHER
Member of Congress, 42d Dist., Calif.
Washington, July 11, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: U.N. Council Opens Discussion of Iraq Sanctions

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 25

 BODY:
The Security Council began informal discussions today on a plan to remove sanctions against Iraq, enabling it to sell oil to buy food and medical supplies, which United Nations officials say are desperately needed by the Iraqi people.
But diplomats cautioned against expecting any quick response to Iraq's needs. They cited the complex problems in creating and monitoring a program to feed millions of people, as well as the efforts of some Council members, notably the United States and Britain, to link the question of sanctions with other components of the cease-fire agreement ending the Persian Gulf War. 
 These include full disclosure of Iraq's nuclear program and of its currency and gold reserves, its contributions to a compensation fund to cover the costs of the war, payments to cover the cost of destroying weapons of mass destruction, payments to Kuwait for property stolen during the war, and its share of the cost of a commission determining the Iraq-Kuwait border.
But the Americans and the British, other diplomats said, are not convinced that Iraq really needs a lifting of the sanctions, believing that it has sufficient foreign currency and gold reserves to cover its food and medical requirements for some time.
"How much money they need will, of course, be determined by how much they have," said Sir David Hannay, the British representative to the United Nations. So far, he said, the Iraqis have provided "an incredibly low figure for currency reserves and no figure at all for gold."
 
A Work in Progress
 Thomas R. Pickering, the American representative, added, "I think it's early to talk about a resolution, but people are looking into all the various components that might go into any action by the Council."
Sir David said, however, that "yes, the Council is working on a resolution," and insisted that "the other aspects of 687" -- the cease-fire resolution -- must be taken into consideration.
Asked about the propriety of linking other aspects of the cease-fire resolution to aid, Sir David replied: "The suffering of the Iraqi people over the sanctions is the fault of Saddam Hussein, and that has been clear from the beginning. There is no question of culpability on the part of the international community, which has been trying to restore international law. The culpability rests quite firmly on the Government of Iraq."
He noted that Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, who headed a team investigating shortages of food and medicine in Iraq, reported earlier this week that there is not a crisis in Iraq now, but rather an impending one, "and that we need to take action now in order to avert it."
Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who attended the Council's informal meeting, said he would soon set up a commission to work out the details of a program to provide help to Iraq.
This could be highly complex and expensive, other diplomats said. It would involve monitoring the sale of the precise amount of oil permitted, setting up an escrow fund to accept foreign-currency payments, overseeing expenditures for food and medical supplies, and then monitoring the distribution of those supplies to insure that they go to the people who need them most.
Still to be decided is the question of whether any profits from oil sales should be used to satisfy other requirements in the cease-fire resolution. These would include payments for the expenses of the special commission charged with destroying Iraq's nuclear and biological weapons.
 
Deadline Passes Uneventfully
 The Security Council meeting today came on the deadline set by the five permanent members -- the United States, the Soviet Union. Britain, France and China -- for Iraq to disclose all facets of its nuclear program.
For several weeks, there have been threats of new military action against unspecified Iraqi installations if the deadline was not met.
But the deadline came and went, with the inspection teams of the International Atomic Energy Agency still dissatisfied with the information supplied.
Diplomats here today evaded questions on the deadline without acknowledging that it seemed unenforceable through diplomacy alone.
Mr. Pickering, the United States representative, took shelter behind a statement released by the White House that noted that the deadline had passed.

HEADLINE: McDonnell Earnings Rise by 35%

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 25

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation today reported a 35 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter, led by a sharp improvement in its commercial aircraft business.
McDonnell Douglas, based in St. Louis, said it earned $77 million, or $2.01 a share, compared with $57 million, or $1.49 a share, in last year's second quarter. Revenues increased 22 percent for the period, to $5.04 billion. 
 The earnings report came one day after a Congressional subcommittee disclosed that McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor, had asked the Pentagon in January for a $1 billion loan to help it through a cash squeeze.
McDonnell Douglas withdrew the request several months later, saying its financial prospects had improved. But even making the highly unusual request suggested that McDonnell Douglas had come closer to a financial crisis than it had previously admitted.
 
Some Major Problems Remain
 McDonnell Douglas still faces major problems, including the possibility of huge cost overruns on its contract to build the Air Force's C-17 transport plane. It also faces the termination of several important combat aircraft programs in the next few years, including the F-15 fighter.
But today's earnings report indicated that the immediate crisis may be behind the company. Not only did it benefit from increased deliveries of commercial aircraft, it managed to pare its debt to $2.9 billion, from $3.3 billion at the end of the first quarter. The debt, which excludes borrowing by the company's financial services subsidiary, now stands at its lowest level in a year and a half.
The company's stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $51.50 a share.
In a letter to employees, John F. McDonnell, the company's chairman, attributed much of the improvement to cost cutting over the last year that included slashing its work force and reducing its dividend.
 
Higher Aerospace Earnings
 McDonnell Douglas said operating earnings increased in all three of its aerospace segments.
The transport aircraft segment earned $34 million, compared with a loss in last year's second quarter of $33 million. It was the third consecutive quarter of profitability for the division, which had been plagued by losses from the high costs of developing a new commercial jetliner, the MD-11, and from cost overruns on the Air Force's C-17 transport plane.
McDonnell Douglas began delivering MD-11's to airlines at the end of last year, and delivered nine in the second quarter. The company said the transport aircraft division, based in Long Beach, Calif., also benefited from lower costs.
The combat aircraft segment earned $125 million, compared with $77 million in the second quarter last year. Revenue for the segment was flat, the company said, but the division benefited from cost savings, which presumably included a lack of development expenses for two big aircraft projects -- a new Air Force fighter plane and an attack plane for the Navy. McDonnell Douglas lost a competition to build the new Air Force fighter, and the Navy canceled its contract to build the attack plane, the A12.
The missiles, space and electronic systems segment earned $59 million in the quarter, compared with $42 million last year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in Broad Advance; Gold Prices Remain Flat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday in a largely technical session that saw the currency recover some of its losses from the previous day.
Gold prices were basically flat, down slightly in New York, after small declines in Europe. Bullion was quoted at $364.25 an ounce late yesterday at Republic National Bank, down 10 cents from late Wednesday. 
 Analysts said the dollar was correcting itself after Wednesday's drop, which followed a weaker-than-expected report on June durable-goods orders.
 
Worry Overseas Aids Dollar
 Some traders bought dollars to cover exposed positions, while others were prompted by speculation about Germany's economic problems and their effect on the German mark, said Curtis Perkins, a vice president of foreign exchange at Chemical Bank.
He said trading also may have been influenced by concerns about the recent stock brokerage scandal in Japan, as well as by growing questions about the Bank of Credit and Commerce International S.A., the big Luxembourg-based bank that was shuttered recently amid fraud allegations.
"You have a lot of stories flying around, and it sort of interferes with what was a technical market," Mr. Perkins said.
Analysts said some dealers also may have bid up dollars ahead of the Government report, due today, on the second-quarter gross national product. Many analysts are expecting growth of between eight-tenths of 1 percent and 1 percent, although the durable-goods report has cast some doubt about the strength of the economy's recovery from recession.
General weakness could step up the pressure for lower interest rates, which would reduce the dollar's attractiveness.
 
Dollar Gains Against Yen
 In New York, the dollar rose to 138.85 Japanese yen from 137.50 yen. Earlier in Tokyo, it rose to a closing 137.60 Japanese yen, from 136.87 yen, and in London, it rose to 138.90 yen.
The dollar gained against the British pound. Sterling in New York fetched $1.6730, down from Wednesday's $1.6920. In London, the pound fell to $1.6750, from $1.6935 late Wednesday.

LENGTH: 2519 words

HEADLINE: Step Right Up to a County Fair!

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
THE county fair. The one and only. The smoky, seductive pall of frying sausage, wafting across the fairground and mingling with the sweet country perfume of fresh hay. The self-satisfied gaze of blue-ribbon Holsteins in the livestock barn. The urgency of barkers. The distant shriek of humanity on thrill machines being rocked and shaken, bumped and thumped, tossed into the air and whooshed back down. The county fair, where the soda always seems fizzier, the beer beerier and the hot dogs, arguably, hot-doggier.
These are the mature days of July, just about hot enough for the county fair to assume its traditional role as the summer's dominant amusement, still holding its own quite nicely, thank you very much, in this era of cable readiness. 
 From the Fourth of July weekend through Labor Day, you can find a county fair roistering at a fairground near you. This weekend, one of the stars of the bill is the 151-year-old Orange County Fair in Mechanics town, N.Y., on the outskirts of Middletown, about an hour-and-a-half drive from New York City. The 12-day fair, which had more than 300,000 visitors last year, ends Sunday night.
The best county fairs are not cute; they are reveling, sweating, mooing, neighing, high-fat bucolic festivals that flaunt their own rinky-dink charm. Last year, more than 100 million people across the United States attended county fairs, 4.5 million in New York State alone, according to the New York State Association of Agricultural Fairs. That compares with a New York attendance of 3 million in 1980.
For many, in a year of recession and tentative economic recovery, the local county fair, with its weekend admission fee of $7 or so -- half-price or less for children -- may be the cheapest, roaringest family fun this side of Disney World.
The most successful find a way to mix four popular elements: agriculture, vendors with products to sell, food and entertainment. These days, real county fairs work hard to be more than carnivals-on-a-fairground. "All the surveys we've done show that the reason most people go to county fairs is for the agricultural component and for the exhibit areas," said Peggy Lipinski, who will become president of the New York agricultural fair association in 1993. "People say the next most popular reason is for the fair food, and after that it's the entertainment. The carnival element ranks below that in popularity."
Increasingly, the trend at the best fairs is to present agriculture as both curriculum and entertainment, transforming somnolent, fly-specked exhibition barns into educational centers chock full of participatory events like calf feeding and goat milking, and demonstrations like sheep shearing, wool spinning and horseshoeing. "These things outpull anything in the midway," said Mrs. Lipinski.
At the Orange County Fair, as at every respectable fairground, the symphony of sounds, sights and scents is worth the price of admission alone. The aroma of frying onions and peppers blends with the sound of sizzling sausage and the spatter of frying dough. In the distance, a chorus of carnival barkers, bleating sheep, and clanging arcade bells harmonizes with the basso profundo of drag-racing at the fairground speedway. Every once in a while a disembodied voice essays a public-address-system solo, burbling a fairground announcement.
Though the basic elements of fairs are the same -- how different can Jersey cows, Tilt-a-Whirls and Slice-o-Matic demonstrations be? -- each fair has its own character. For example, the ingratiating honky-tonk bustle of the Orange County Fair creates its own distinctive personality. In comparison, there is the lovable agricultural ambiance of the Ulster County fair in New Paltz, N.Y. (Wednesday through the following Sunday), and the sprawling rustic beauty of that glorious megafestival near the Hudson, the Dutchess County Fair in Rhinebeck, N.Y. (Aug. 20 to 25).
Fair food can also be highly variable. If nothing tastes worse than sticky, stale cotton candy in the noonday sun, it is also true that nothing on the planet can compare to the taste of fresh-squeezed county-fair lemonade on a hot day, even if it costs $1.50 a cup.
Fair food could not accurately be described as low-cal. But even Weight Watchers group leaders might be ravished by the smell of simmering kielbasa. One of the best inexpensive feasts at the Orange County Fair is the home-cooked meal prepared in the 4-H barn; for $6.50, fairgoers get honey-barbecued spare ribs, a baked potato, salad, bread pudding and a soda. For post-dessert gorging, you might stroll over to one of the distinctive octagonal kiosks to purchase the classic, sinfully gooey, Bob Maxwell's Walk-Away Sundae ("Dipped in Chocolate -- Rolled in Nuts").
 
Meet the Animals
 To work off the calories, head with aerobic briskness toward the Grange building. There, if you're lucky, a friendly young 4-H-er will adopt you and take you around the neighboring buildings on a tour of the animal sheds -- and then sell you a ticket to the Bossy Bingo Raffle.
Also on display there are prize kohlrabi, corn, squash, beans, cauliflower and beets; winning floral arrangements; prize quilts, dresses and dolls, and blue-ribbon fudge, breads, jams, jellies and coffee cakes. Each of the last group has a little piece cut out of it, of course, where the judges took a taste.
There is no charge for any of these homestead exhibits, and, characteristically, the best fairs offer a lot of other free entertainment. At the Orange County Fair, a star free attraction is the raucous performance of Hale's Racing Pigs. The 15-week-old porkers -- racing under names like Elvis Pigsley, Michael Jordham, Soo-ee Jesse Raphael and Roseanne Boar -- scramble and squeal around a 100-foot-long wood-chip track, heading to their food trough at the finish line.
Animal-rights protesters have been picketing another free act -- Tim Rivers's High Diving Mules -- but so far seem to have generated publicity, and larger crowds, for Mr. Rivers, whose mules have been jumping 18 feet into a 6-foot-deep trough of water at fairs since 1957. Another of the free entertainments at the Orange County Fair is that decidedly noncontroversial perennial, the lumberjack show, in which brawny woodsmen in plaid shirts generate a lot of noise and sawdust while engaging in displays of chain-saw carving, ax-tossing and log-rolling. In other surroundings the urban sophisticate might find such entertainments primitive at best, but at a county fair it is great fun to see acts that are not slick, sophisticated or even scripted.
Some of the attractions at county fairs in 1991 are so basic that they recall the roots of fairground tradition. For example, at the Orange County Fair last week, there was an exhibition of Belted Galloways, brawny beef cattle from Scotland. This entrepreneurial display was a throwback to the first moments of the American county fair when, early in the 19th century, Elkanah Watson, a wealthy farmer, tethered a few imported merino sheep to a tree near his barn in Pittsfield, Mass. The locals came over to oh and ah over the superior merino wool, thus creating, some historians say, the first county fair.
 
Rural Celebration
 The Orange County Fair was founded in 1841, in an era when the county fair became a highlight of the farming year. It was a community celebration, a time when farmers showed off their prize animals to improve the breed; soon, farm families were also showing off their crafts and needlepoint and Sunday pies to improve the evolution of domestic arts. The best-of-breed animals, and the blue-ribbon recipes, went on to competitions at the state fair.
After rampant suburbification, the agricultural component has declined at many fairs. Nevertheless, there is an active attempt to keep it flourishing. "Across the nation, fairs are returning to their agricultural roots," said Mrs. Lipinski, "'because people say that's what makes a county fair a county fair."
Outside the precincts of the agricultural-exhibit buildings, the county fair takes on a shape that shifts with the time of day. There is the daytime fair, with its livestock judging and English and Western horse shows and family ambiance. And then there is the neon-lit night-time fair, an alternate world of loud noise and brilliant light and lurking fun. After sundown, the fair is the place where people go to be scared in the spook house and to be thrust topsy-turvy on glittering machines under the garish lights of the midway. They buy tickets to watch bands like Huey Lewis and the News, or sit in the grandstand to see stock-car racing, their bodies shaking with the elemental thrum of the engines as the cars skid around the dirt track.
At night, families sit with their exhausted children at free entertainments, or savor ice cream cones sitting at picnic tables under the stars. At the Orange County Fair, many know that night is the best time to visit the high-ceilinged, 27,000-foot commercial exhibit building where barkers hawk Golden Touch Jewelry Cleaner, Instant Heat Gel, Naturally Beautiful Nails, Worley's Wonder Cleaner and yes, a free, absolutely free, five-minute mini-lesson at the Wurlitzer organ.
Also on display: more karats of cubic zirconium than at any other location this side of the Home Shopping Channel studios. In fact, to tour this building is to realize that the Home Shopping Channel has aped the American county fair exhibit building in its roster of products, its high-decibel volume and its frenzied presentation.
What else can you do, day or night, at the Orange County Fair? You can swing the hammer like a he-man to hit the bell; you can have your choice of merry-go-rounds, scooter cars and Ferris wheels; you can try your luck at skee-ball, ring-toss and softball-throw, and you can hurl darts at balloons. And yes, you can aim a compressed-air cannon that splatters paint pellets on the dodging form of a carnival worker in a Saddam Hussein costume.
And last but not least, when you're truly exhausted, you can sit on the foot-rejuvenating Footsie-Wootsie machine ("The Ultimate Foot Massage, Still 25 Cents").

Pack Sun Block And a Hat
Here are some tips for getting the most out of a county fair:
Hell is only marginally hotter than a fairground parking lot. If you arrive in full sun and you'll be leaving before dark, deploy a sunscreen to shade your car windows, or your fingers will sizzle when they touch the steering wheel.
If you favor the organized approach to county fairs rather than the lightning-fast slash-and-burn strategy, phone a few weeks in advance (fairground offices are listed in the phone book). Ask about the event schedule; some fairs will mail a brochure to your home. If you're traveling a long distance to the fair, ask about reduced-rate arrangements at local inns and motels.
Unless you're truly mad about the roar of the crowd (the smell of the greasepaint isn't often a problem at the fairground), visit county fairs on a weekday. Then, fair admission fees are cheaper, crowds are thinner, petting-zoo lines are shorter and parking lots are emptier.
Since a respectable fair takes a whole day and night to enjoy, visit the agricultural judging and exhibits, the horse contests, and the free shows during the day; save the midway rides, the T-shirt browsing and the vendor exhibits for the evening. Then, the buildings are cooler, the vendor-area crowds are smaller and the salesmen have lost their pit-bull edge.
Pack up the sun block, sun glasses and sun hat. Leave home your pets, your rigid schedule, your cares, your woes.
 
Where and When
To get to the Orange County Fair in Mechanicstown, N.Y., from New York City, find your way upstate to Route 17 North. Take Exit 122 and follow the signs to the fair. Weekday admission is $5 for adults and $2.50 for children; weekend admission is $7 for adults and $2.50 for children over 6; under 6, free. The fair runs through Sunday, noon to midnight. Information: (914) 343-4826.

HEADLINE: Democrats Move to Seize Jobless Benefits as Issue

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Democrats on both sides of Capitol Hill moved today to extend unemployment insurance payments to people who have been out of work for more than half a year, and Republicans raised questions but not much opposition.
Administration officials have threatened a Presidential veto of any move to extend jobless benefits, saying it is not needed because the recession is ending. 
 But when the Senate Finance Committee voted this morning, 5 of 9 Republicans on the committee joined all 11 Democrats in supporting temporary legislation, costing $5.8 billion. That vote suggested that the bill would carry by a wide margin when it comes before the full Senate on Monday or Tuesday.
 
Political Soft Shoe
 Today's developments seemed to show clearly that the Democrats, after months of political tiptoeing, had seized on a central political issue that might unite them and embarrass Republicans.
Under current law, the basic 26 weeks of benefits can be extended for 13 weeks when unemployment among insured workers in a state reaches 6 percent or when it exceeds average state levels by 20 percent. Only three states are now eligible.
The proposal by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat who heads the committee, would make workers eligible for 20 more weeks of coverage when total unemployment in a state exceeds 8 percent, 13 more weeks when the level exceeds 7 percent and at least an extra 4 weeks in all states.
Also today, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who head the House Ways and Means Committee, bowed to pressure, from Democratic leaders as well as members, and introduced a similar bill. His committee is expected to act early in the week, with the full House voting before Congress goes on vacation next Friday.
That would enable Democrats to leave town having made a case against President Bush's handling of the recession, although for several months they have been reluctant to make any case on unemployment, their fundamental issue since the Great Depression.
Slightly less than nine million Americans are unemployed. Experts in Congress say that without the legislation, as many as three million will have exhausted their unemployment compensation by the end of September.
 
New Direction on Recession
 The recession has had hardly any effect on Capitol Hill all year, as Democrats have shied away from criticizing President Bush or voting for more taxes to pay for more benefits. But in the last week or so, they have given an orchestrated series of speeches arguing that under current law benefits beyond the ordinary 26 weeks are too restricted. Moreover, they have criticized President Bush for supporting aid for foreigners while opposing help for Americans.
For example, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said in today's committee meeting that the Bush Administration this year had called for aid for the Kurds and for Eqypt, Turkey, Israel, the Sudan, Ethiopia, Angola and Bangladesh. "The Administration is quite prepared to find these emergencies all over the world," he said. "But they're not willing to see the emergency here at home and provide the money for our own people."
Today's Senate bill, instead, declares that Americans whose unemployment benefits have been exhausted face an emergency. This is a budget act category that allows for spending more without raising taxes or cutting spending.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, complained at the meeting that declaring the unemployment situation to be an emergency amounted to a repudiation of last year's budget act and was "trying to dismantle it piece by piece."
Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, today sent a letter to Congressional leaders saying it was not the time to "abandon pay-as-you-go discipline." He said Mr. Bush's senior advisers would recommend that the President reject such a declaration. The President could take such a step on his own without exercising a regular veto, which could be overridden by two-thirds majorities in both Houses.
 
Giving Bush a Choice
 The Rostenkowski measure would allow the President to choose between declaring an emergency and imposing higher taxes on employers to pay for the broadened benefits. Mr. Rostenkowski said he preferred the "pay-as-you-go" approach that includes higher taxes, but acknowledged that some colleagues thought this was not the time to raise taxes.
"That is why the bill offers the President a choice. When the time comes, the President can consult with his economic advisers and choose the prudent course," Mr. Rostenkowski said in a statement accompanying the introduction of his bill. He had 14 co-sponsors, including Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who in March pushed legislation for extended benefits, and one Republican, Representative Raymond J. McGrath, also of Long Island.
On the Senate Finance Committee, five Republicans voted for Senator Bentsen's proposed bill. They were Senators Bob Packwood of Oregon, John C. Danforth of Missouri, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa.
Mr. Dole was joined in opposing it by three Republican colleagues, Senators William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, Steve Symms of Idaho and Orrin G. Hatch of Utah.
Mr. Bentsen argued that his bill was simply proposing to tap a trust fund already established to finance extended benefits. He said the triggering mechanism of the current law did not work to allow those benefits where they were needed.
Under existing law, only in Alaska, Maine, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico are the unemployed eligible for extended benefits, lasting 13 weeks. Under the Bentsen and Rostenkowski proposals, workers in those four states as well as Mississippi, Massachusetts, Michigan and West Virginia would also become eligible for 20 additional weeks of benefits because the unemployment level in those states is at least 8 percent.
California, the nation's most populous state, would be among 10 others and the District of Columbia whose unemployment levels of at least 7 percent would make their long-term unemployed eligible for 13 additional weeks under Mr. Bentsen's bill and 15 under Mr. Rostenkowski's. New York, New Jersey and Texas would be among 19 more states with at least 6 percent unemployment and whose jobless would be eligible for seven extra weeks of benefits under Mr. Bentsen's bill and 10 under Mr. Rostenkowski's.

HEADLINE: On Wall St., Cuomo Lashes Out at White House

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo accused the White House yesterday of complacency in attacking the country's economic problems and then proposed a series of Federal tax changes that he said would hasten a recovery by spurring long-term capital investment.
The Governor's proposals, which he outlined in a breakfast speech to about 80 business executives at the American Stock Exchange, included a corporate tax credit for investments in newly bought equipment and machinery. He also said that a cut in capital gains taxes on long-term investments should be coupled with an increase in Federal income taxes for top earners. 
 He drew a distinction between his proposals and President Bush's plan to cut capital gains taxes for all payers. The Bush proposal, he said, "would provide an enormous windfall for a narrow band of Americans."
The Governor's speech was the first of several critiques of Republican fiscal policy that Mr. Cuomo plans to deliver in the next month or two. While he hopes the speeches will help formulate a Democratic message for the 1992 Presidential race, he maintains that he is not planning to be a candidate.
 
Attacks Bush Domestic Policy

Speaking to an attentive but unresponsive audience in the Stock Exchange's wood-paneled board room, Mr. Cuomo minced few words in arguing that the Bush Administration has ignored domestic policy.
"Washington appears content to believe that it doesn't have to act, that however hard life is now," he said, "the hardships felt by millions of Americans will dissipate as soon as the cyclical economic gods choose once again to smile upon us."
"I don't think you can wait. Not when nearly 10 million Americans are out of work. Not when the nation has had virtually zero economic growth since 1989. Not when living standards for most Americans have been declining for more than a decade."
He depicted the supply-side philosophy of the Reagan and Bush Administrations as a failure that generated wealth but not investment, and that inflated the national debt.
The tax credit proposed by Mr. Cuomo would grant a credit of perhaps 10 percent for investments in newly bought productive machinery and pollution-control equipment. Under the capital gains plan, Mr. Cuomo said tax rates would be increased on gains earned in less than a year -- perhaps from 28 percent to 33 percent -- and decreased on investments held for more than seven years -- perhaps from 28 percent to 10 percent.

HEADLINE: Marchers Seek Special Inquiry in Police Killing

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, July 25

 BODY:
About 300 people marched through downtown Jersey City tonight demanding the appointment of a special investigator in the fatal shooting of a 23-year-old man by a police officer last week.
"One of us was killed, a member of our community, a very nice guy," one marcher, Frank Rivera, 40 years old, said of the victim, Maximino Cintron. "We want this cop to pay for what he did." 
 After the crowd marched about 10 blocks from the scene of the shooting to City Hall, City Councilman Jaime Vazquez made a speech urging Gov. Jim Florio to appoint a special investigator.
Mr. Cintron, an unemployed meat packer, was shot to death by Officer John Chiusolo on July 16 after the policeman and his partner, Christopher Henne, gave Mr. Cintron a summons for applying tinted plastic sheeting to the windows of a car parked a half-block from his home.
 
Questions Being Asked
 Since the shooting, questions have arisen about the officers' decision to stop to give the ticket while they were transporting another man to jail and about whether applying the tint on the street is a violation of a city ordinance banning major vehicle repairs on the street.
Before the march, the New Jersey Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, said through a spokeswoman that he would not intervene to change the course of the investigation.
"The Attorney General has confidence in the prosecutor to conduct a fair and responsible investigation," said the spokeswoman, Ann Crawford. She said that Mr. Del Tufo's top aides had frequently been in touch with Paul M. DePascale, the Hudson County Prosecutor, and had offered him assistance over the course of his inquiry.
Under state regulations, police officers may fire their weapons in self-defense, "when they reasonably believe that deadly force is necessary to protect themselves against death or serious bodily harm."
In interviews, two witnesses contended that the shooting was unjustified.
One witness, Jose Quinones, who said he had been helping apply the plastic tinting, said Mr. Cintron had his arms outstretched at his sides and said, "What are you going to do, shoot me?" just before he was shot.
Jose Torres, the 28-year-old prisoner whom Officers Henne and Chiusolo were taking to night court, said three men tried to remove Officer Henne's forearm from Mr. Cintron's neck.
