HEADLINE: GORBACHEV OFFERS PARTY A CHARTER THAT DROPS ICONS

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 25

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed a new charter for the Communist Party that rejects some of its most hallowed principles, even the sanctity of Marxism-Leninism.
Speaking at the opening of a two-day session of the party's Central Committee, Mr. Gorbachev, who is both President of the Soviet Union and General Secretary of the party, criticized "fundamentalists" in the party and threw his lot in with reformers seeking to replace the militant utopianism of old with a broad Social Democratic platform. 
 Declaring that the Communist Party would "lose any claim to participate in political life if it stepped away from the course of reform," he also called a full party congress for November, at which both the new program and his leadership would be judged. The unexpected move seemed to pre-empt an expected assault on Mr. Gorbachev from party hard-liners, who have used past party meetings to demand his resignation and criticize his policies.
 
Bush Is Due Next Week
 The proposed program also stood to bolster Mr. Gorbachev's credentials as a reformer before the visit here by President Bush next week. Western leaders declared a readiness last week to help the Soviet Union, but have been looking for concrete evidence of progress before committing substantial funds.
Introducing the draft of a new "party program," Mr. Gorbachev declared that previous programs "set goals not so much in accordance with reality, but with the then-popular understanding of the Communist ideal." The result, he said, was "raw ideology" irrelevant to the concerns of society.
He noted that there had been proposals to drop the name Communist and rename the party as a Socialist or Social Democratic party. But he said any changes in the name should await the November congress.
 
Market Economy Promoted
 The new program, he said, bases the party's goals on the experience of perestroika, on transforming the Soviet Union into a democratic federation of sovereign republics, on introducing a market economy and on integrating the country into the global economy.
Reaching to the very heart of the old ideology, Mr. Gorbachev declared, "In the past the party recognized only Marxism-Leninism as the source of its inspiration, though the tenet was utterly distorted to suit the pragmatic needs of the day, becoming something of a collection of canonical texts."
"Now it has become necessary to include in our arsenal of ideas all the riches of our own and the world's socialist and democratic thought," he said.
It would have been inconceivable even just a few years ago for the head of the Soviet Communist Party to denigrate Marxism-Leninism and to suggest that the party could be run with competing ideologies. One of the frequent forms of denunciation in the past was to accuse someone of falling under the influence of "bourgeois ideology."
Mr. Gorbachev said many participants had probably noticed that the program barely mentioned the creation of a Communist society, once the central goal of Marxist ideology.
In the original thinking of Marx and Engels as modified by Lenin, a society would go through different transitions until it reached the state of Communism, which was the theoretical goal of the party. Its basic features were supposed to be the end of private property, of any social classes and of the state, and it would follow a system of "from each according to his ability, to each according to his needs."
"Our experience, and not only ours, does not give enough grounds for believing that this aim can be realistically achieved in the foreseeable future," Mr. Gorbachev said.
 
On Class Struggle and Religion
 He also made these points in outlining the new draft program:
*On a market economy, once considered incompatible with socialism, he said, "The entire world's experience of the past decades points to the conclusion that it is not possible to achieve the principle of each according to his work without a market economy."
*On class struggle, Mr. Gorbachev declared, "The time has long come to acknowledge that the epoch when the masses had no means of improving their lot except by storming the Bastille or the Winter Palace has gone into the past."
*On religion, he said a member of the party had the right "to freely profess his own views, to be an atheist or a believer." In the past it has been forbidden for any party member to be anything but an atheist.
*On party discipline, he said the party no longer required, as it did in the time of revolutionary struggle, "iron discipline, essentially on a militarized structure."
While jettisoning many of the dogmas of the past, however, the program offered only broad and general affirmations of perestroika and democracy for the future.
"This program cannot be called either Communist or Social Democratic," Boris Gidaspov, head of the Leningrad party organization, was quoted by the Interfax news agency as saying. "It's just liberal, and it would suit anyone from Social Democrats to those who hold Communism as a sort of social idea."
That, some participants said, may have explained why the program did not draw greater fire from hard-core ideologues. Participants at the session reported that the first day's proceedings proved surprisingly tame, with most of the 27 speakers supporting the basic lines of the draft program.
On the eve of the Central Committee meeting, many members had expected a bitter assault on Mr. Gorbachev from party leaders frustrated at the erosion of their power. At the last meeting three months ago, hard-liners had mounted a concerted attack to unseat Mr. Gorbachev.
The text of the party program presented today was made public earlier in the week. But Mr. Gorbachev's detailed support of the document signaled his intention to try to fashion the foundering Communist monolith into a party capable of competing in free national elections envisioned by the new union treaty drafted by Mr. Gorbachev and nine republican leaders, including Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic.
 
Treaty Almost Ready
 Two days ago, the Kremlin announced that the treaty was all but completed. Though the draft has not been made public yet, it is known to devolve primary governing authority to the republic governments in a federation of sovereign republics, with the central Government accountable to them. The pact calls for a new national constitution by next spring and new national elections next summer.
In expectation of the new order, various liberal forces have already begun shaping new political movements and parties, each hoping to attract defectors from the Communist Party.
There had been speculation that Mr. Gorbachev himself would leave the party. Instead, he has evidently chosen to try to reshape it into a broad Social Democratic force and to stem the tide of departures.
Underscoring the urgency of the effort, Mr. Gorbachev reported that party membership fell by 4.2 million in the last 18 months, and was now estimated at its 1973 level of 15 million.
Signaling his own renewed identification with liberal forces in the party, he harshly denounced hard-line factions in the party that are called the Bolshevik Platform and the Communist Initiative. By contrast, he noted without adverse comment the rise of the liberal Communists for Democracy movement.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies

HEADLINE: A Sharp Rise In Failures

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Fifty percent more businesses failed in the first six months of this year than in the first half of 1990, reflecting the impact of the recession, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation reported yesterday.
The biggest increase was among transportation and utility companies, where failures increased 54 percent, to 1,894. Failures in the service sector grew 51 percent, while the number of failing manufacturers rose 36.5 percent, the business information company said in a survey. 
 "Business failures continued to climb across the U.S. during the first half of the year, particularly along the East and West Coasts," said Joseph W. Duncan, the company's corporate economist. But he said the rate of increase has slowed, with failures in June up only 31 percent, compared with 52 percent in May.
Dun & Bradstreet said it defined failures as companies that went out of business owing money or sought bankruptcy court protection from creditors.
Over all, 43,014 businesses failed in the first six months, Dun & Bradstreet said, up about 50 percent from 28,669 in the first half of 1990.
The biggest increase was in New England, up 93.8 percent, to 2,675 failures. Bankruptcies in the Middle Atlantic states were up 79 percent, while failures in the Pacific states grew 75 percent.

HEADLINE: Cost Cutting by Goodyear Helps Return to Profitability

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which has in recent months sharply reduced its work force in an effort to regain profitability, yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $22.5 million, or 38 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $9.4 million in the year-earlier period.
 The earnings improvement was largely the result of cost cutting and came in the face of a 2.8 percent drop in tire sales, the company said. Sales for the quarter slipped 3 percent, to $2.79 billion, from $2.87 billion in the second quarter of last year. 
 On the New York Stock Exchange, Goodyear's stock was up $1.625 yesterday, closing at $38.
 
Improvement in Two Units
 Goodyear said that operating income in its tires and related business segment increased to $157.7 million, from $108.9 million in the year-earlier quarter, which had included $21.4 million in unusual charges. Operating income in the general products segment rose to $56.3 million, from $40.9 million in last year's comparable period, which included $15 million in charges.
Like other international tire producers, Goodyear has been bruised by a number of difficulties, including intense price competition, a sluggish automobile market and narrow margins.
Goodyear has also suffered from operating an unprofitable 1,750-mile crude oil pipeline between California and Texas, which it bought in 1985 as a way to diversify. The company reported an operating loss of $13 million in the quarter from its oil transportation segment, which includes the pipeline, compared with $12.8 million in the year-earlier quarter.
 
Cost Cuts Said To Be Working
 Harry W. Millis, an independent tire analyst in Cleveland, said the earnings indicated that "the cost cutting Goodyear has put in place in recent months is having an effect."
He added that he was surprised by the strength of the domestic market for replacement tires and that sales in Europe had been stronger than expected.
"After a drop in the first quarter, sales in Europe came back and improved in the second quarter," Mr. Millis said. "It looks like the European recession is going to be more shallow than ours was in the United States."
Stanley C. Gault, Goodyear's chairman and chief executive, said, "Our tire and general products businesses continued to reflect the severely depressed auto industry and the weak economy in the United States."
Mr. Gault added, however, that "we are extremely pleased that earnings in the latest three-month period were back on the positive side and that we were able to reduce selling, administrative and general expenses 5 percent, compared to the year-earlier period."

HEADLINE: June Home Resales Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes jumped 1.4 percent in June to the highest level in two and a half years, a real estate trade group said today. It was the fifth straight monthly advance.
All regions of the nation posted gains except the Midwest, which experienced a sales surge in May that analysts said could not be sustained. 
 The National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned single-family homes reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.59 million, up from a revised 3.54 million a month earlier. The May rate was first estimated to have been 3.51 million.
The association said the June rate was the highest since January 1989, when the rate reached 3.66 million. It also was 6.5 percent higher than that of June 1990.
"This is a good, solid sign of recovery," said Harley E. Rouda, the association president.
Most analysts believe the housing recession ended in January. Sales of both existing and new homes have risen since then.
Mr. Rouda also noted that sales increased despite a slight gain in interest rates.
"When rates go up, people often will go ahead with their purchases, rather than risk further increases," he said.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said 30-year conventional, fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.61 percent in June, up from 9.47 percent a month earlier.
The association said the median price of an existing home was $101,900, up 3 percent from the June 1990 price and eight-tenths of 1 percent above the median price in May. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less.
The South posted the biggest sales gain, up 6.4 percent, to 1.49 million units. The median price was $90,800, up 1.6 percent from June 1990 and 1 percent from May.
Sales in the Northeast jumped 3.6 percent, to 570,000 units. The median price was $142,800, down 3.7 percent from the previous June and 1.4 percent from May.

HEADLINE: Gasoline at Low Price, But Benefits May Fade

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A year after Saddam Hussein sent tanks into Kuwait and fear and anger into the hearts of American motorists, the price storm is over and the cost of gasoline is at historic lows, when inflation is taken into account.
A new study by Cambridge Energy Research Associates concluded that the pretax price at the pump is now the lowest since 1947, after adjusting for inflation. Even with a one-third increase in recent years in Federal and state taxes, which now average 36 cents a gallon, gasoline today is only about 8 cents a gallon higher than it was in 1988. 
 "The good old days, when it comes to gasoline prices, are now," said Daniel Yergin, the oil historian and author of the report.
 
56% Below Peak
 Adjusting the price at the pump to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index, the average price in the first five months of this year, $1.15, was 6 percent lower than it was in 1972, the year before the Arab oil embargo. The current price is 56 percent of the peak price in 1980, in the panic that followed the Iranian revolution. Stated in today's dollars, the average price in 1980 was $2.04 a gallon, Mr. Yergin said.
During the Kuwait crisis, gasoline prices rose to a peak about 30 percent above the prewar price. Now, despite an increase in Federal and state taxes, prices are within 10 percent of the year-ago level.
The low price may surprise the public but not specialists, said David L. Morehead, vice president of the Petroleum Marketers Association, a trade association in Washington.
"The oil industry, let's face it, is an industry that people love to hate," he said. "I'm sorry to say that people are not going out and hugging gasoline dealers. Everybody notices when prices go up, everyone talks about it and Congress calls hearings. But when they go down, not much is said about it."
 
'A Dream World'
 David L. Lewis, a professor of business history at the University of Michigan Business School, called the current price "a dream world," adding, "You just can't expect gasoline to stay this cheap indefinitely."
Professor Lewis suggested that while a low price is good news for consumers in the short run, it may set the country and the auto industry on a perilous course. Low prices in the 1970's led American auto makers to specialize in big cars, and when the gasoline crunch of 1979-80 came along, consumers wanted small, fuel-efficient models and only the Japanese manufacturers had them.
"That's the lesson which does not seem to have been learned," he said.
The low price misleads consumers, too, said Glenn P. Sugameli, a specialist in energy issues at the National Wildlife Federation. "If there was a consistent trend toward higher gasoline prices, the consumer and auto companies would have a clear signal that more efficient cars is where they should be going," he said. Because price will not provide that signal, a strong auto-mileage bill is more necessary than ever, he said.
Congress is now sifting through several proposals on what Detroit should be building as part of a debate over national energy policy. One would force the auto makers to improve the fuel economy of new cars to 40 miles a gallon by the turn of the century.
But at today's low gasoline prices, investments to make cars more efficient pay for themselves slowly if at all, and that means the economics alone do not now encourage spending large sums to save gasoline.
Another proposal, sponsored by the Bush Administration, would direct fleet vehicles to use fuels other than gasoline, in part to clean the air. But the cost penalty of this switch would rise as the price of gasoline fell.
Mr. Yergin, in a telephone interview, said, "With prices down, it takes a lot of the fuel out of all the energy debates."

HEADLINE: U.N. Has $500,000 Frozen in B.C.C.I. Banks in Africa

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretariat said today that about $500,000 of United Nations money was frozen in accounts in branches of the failed Bank of Credit and Commerce International in two African countries.
Francois Giuliani, the chief spokesman for Secretary General Xavier Perez de Cuellar, also said that Mr. Perez had twice taken trips on private planes owned by Gaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi billionaire and a major shareholder in B.C.C.I. who had numerous business dealings in the United States. 
 Mr. Pharaon is a longtime associate of Aga Hassan Abedi, who founded the bank 19 years ago and had numerous contacts at the United Nations with third world governments.
Among his contacts was Andrew Young, who represented the United States at the United Nations in the late 1970's. Mr. Young later had a retainer arrangement and a credit line with Mr. Abedi's bank.
Mr. Giuliani was responding to an inquiry from The New York Times.
The Economic Commission for Africa, part of the Economic and Social Council, and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees maintained accounts in B.C.C.I. branches in Cameroon, Mr. Giuliani said. The refugee commission's account contained $12,000, he said; the amount in the economic commission's account was not immediately available.
In Sierra Leona, Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, maintained an account with "less than $400,000," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Giuliani noted that the sums in the B.C.C.I. branches were small in terms of what the United Nations programs actually spend in those countries. He noted, too, that there is a serious dearth of operating banks in some African nations and that the United Nations must use those that are available. He said that the accounts had been frozen with the worldwide closing of the bank earlier this month and that the United Nations was making other arrangements to continue financing its operations in Cameroon and Sierra Leone.
Mr. Giuliani said the Secretary General first used a plane provided by Mr. Pharaon on a trip to Haiti in 1986 when he was accompanied by a group of journalists and needed a larger aircraft than what had originally been provided.
 
'A Helpful Gesture'
 The second trip was to Peru in 1987. Mr. Perez de Cuellar is from Peru, where a Government investigation is looking into whether former President Alan Garcia looted as much as $50 million of the country's funds while he was President from mid-1985 to mid-1990.
"The plane was accepted as a helpful gesture both for security reasons and because the United Nations was at the height of the U.S. financial crisis," Mr. Giuliani said. The financial crisis to which he referred was brought on, in large measure, by the United States' refusal to pay its share of the world body's budget.
"At that time, we were always fishing around for cost-cutting schemes," Mr. Giuliani said. "Somebody wanted to be supportive at that time of crisis." The United States resumed its contributions after the United Nations agreed to cut its staff and make other administrative changes.
 
U.N. Chief Has No Aircraft
 The United Nations does not have its own aircraft for the Secretary General. Generally, United Nations officials use commercial aircraft or planes supplied by governments. On rare occasions, chartered flights are used, the spokesman said.
In 1979, after he had left the United Nations, Mr. Young provided B.C.C.I. with contacts in more than a dozen third world countries. Mr. Young also had a modest trade business that had a credit line from the National Bank of Georgia, which Mr. Pharaon purchased from Bert Lance, the former budget director in the Carter Administration. The following year, the credit line was transferred to B.C.C.I.
Recently, the Federal Reserve Board charged that Mr. Pharaon was acting as a front for B.C.C.I.

HEADLINE: T.W.A. Forges a Deal To Elude a Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
T.W.A. survived another close brush with bankruptcy yesterday after its chairman, Carl C. Icahn, forged an eleventh-hour deal with bondholders that granted them new concessions.
The airline's secured creditors had threatened to go to court yesterday to seek immediate payment of overdue payments on bonds that are backed by spare parts and landing slots. If the creditors had done so, or if they had sought an injunction in court to seize the collateral behind the bonds, the airline would most likely have been forced to seek bankruptcy protection. 
 A hearing had been scheduled yesterday by the bondholders before Judge Gerard Goettel in Federal District Court in White Plains, where T.W.A. is based, but it was postponed until Tuesday after Mr. Icahn offered the new terms. The court must now review and approve the agreement.
 
Flirting With Bankruptcy
 Trans World Airlines has been flirting with bankruptcy for many months and Mr. Icahn's brinkmanship has repeatedly managed to snatch the carrier from that fate. The troubled airline, which recently made a surprise bid to acquire the remnants of the bankrupt Pan American World Airways in partnership with American Airlines, stopped making payments on its bonds in February.
The holders of about $236.4 million in secured bonds that pay 15 percent in interest are owed roughly $12 million in accrued interest.
As part of yesterday's rough outline of the new agreement between the two sides, Mr. Icahn agreed to give bondholders about 25 cents on the dollar in cash and improved collateral to back the bonds, and in exchange the interest rate on the bonds would be reduced from 15 percent to 7 to 8 percent.
On Monday, T.W.A. had canceled a tender offer it had previously made for most of its outstanding debt. That canceled offer, which would have paid out 65 cents on the dollar to the holders of the 15 percent secured bonds, came to be widely viewed by the bondholders as well as T.W.A. as untenable because it would have drained the company of so much cash that the airline would not have been able to continue operating.
"What I've been trying to do in these negotiations is to keep the cash in the company," Mr. Icahn said. "It's very hard for an airline to raise cash today."
But the adventure in revamping the airline's debt is far from over. It is expected to last all weekend as the holders of the senior unsecured notes and the subordinated unsecured notes wrangle over how much equity in the company they will each get. Mr. Icahn himself owns about a third of the subordinated notes, which pay 12 percent in interest.
The holders of about $334 million of senior unsecured bonds that pay 16 percent and 17 1/4 percent are expected to receive some debt as well as some equity, people close to the deal said. They will probably also seek to get some collateral as part of the final deal.
Holders of the subordinated 12 percent notes are expected to receive equity in the restructuring.
Much of T.W.A.'s troubles can be traced to the complex series of financial transactions surrounding Mr. Icahn's acquisition of the airline. The financier borrowed heavily to take the airline private in 1988, three years after he first took control of it, and in that transaction he ended up with about $469 million for himself, which was more than $440 million above what he had previously paid for his interest in the company. In addition to that, Mr. Icahn got control of 90 percent of the airline's stock.
The airline's operating results have been deteriorating for more than a year, in large part because of the recession and the Persian Gulf war. With the heavy debt load that Mr. Icahn put on the company in 1988, it was ill-prepared to weather a downturn in the industry and the war-related increases in fuel costs. A substantial portion of the debt that was issued in 1988 began requiring cash interest payments earlier this year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Profits Down 30.6% at Disney

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 25

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that its net income for its third fiscal quarter fell 30.6 percent as the recession cut attendance at its theme parks.
Disney said it earned $165.5 million, or $1.24 a share, in the quarter ended June 30, down from $238.4 million, or $1.75 a share, a year earlier. Revenues slipped 1.8 percent, to $1.51 billion, from $1.54 billion. 
 Disney's earnings were depressed in part by the weak performance of two films, "The Marrying Man" and "One Good Cop." But most of the company's problems were in the theme park business, which Disney said was hurt by the recession and a general decline in air travel.
Operating profits for the theme park and resorts segment fell 39 percent, to $176.4 million. Disney said the decline was a result of lower attendance at Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland in California. Revenues for the segment declined 12 percent, to $759 million.
In the film entertainment division, operating profits increased 8 percent, to $79.1 million. Earnings were bolstered by the release of the home video version of "The Jungle Book," the company said. Disney also released "The Rocketeer" and "What About Bob" during the quarter, helping to push the segment's revenues up 7 percent, to $597.1 million.
Disney's shares fell $1.50 yesterday, to $117.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Lost Work at G.E. Will Mean Layoffs

 BODY:
The loss of a $50.5 million Navy contract means more layoffs and additional cost-cutting measures for General Electric's Syracuse operations, a company spokeswoman said. G.E. lost the contract last week to the International Business Machines Corporation, the spokeswoman, Connie Grasso, said.

Earlier this year, G.E. announced it would close one of its three Syracuse area plants by 1992, a move that will eliminate 1,300 jobs. The company employs about 5,500 people in Syracuse.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Du Pont Plans to Trim Expenses by $1 Billion

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., July 25

 BODY:
The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it would cut costs by $1 billion over two years by reducing staff and trimming its chemicals and specialties businesses in the United States. The announcement comes a day after Du Pont reported a 21 percent drop in second-quarter earnings.
Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the company's chairman, said costs were hurting the chemical giant's ability to compete worldwide. The reductions will not affect Conoco, Du Pont's energy subsidiary, based in Houston. Net income for the quarter was $549 million, compared with $694 million for the corresponding quarter in 1990. The decline was attributed largely to the recession. 
 Mr. Woolard declined to be specific about how many jobs would be cut. "We don't have a specific goal," he said. "Our goal is to reduce $1 billion, and we have a number of ways to do that. We need to get going as soon as possible."
Mr. Woolard said the $1 billion reduction represented about 10 percent of the fixed costs in chemicals and specialties, like the fibers sector. Among the costs to get special attention are travel, entertainment, redundant computer systems, consulting and contractor expenses, he said.
Du Pont employs about 140,000 people worldwide, and about 26,000 in Delaware. The company is based in Wilmington, Del.
Mr. Woolard said the company could achieve its goal "by changing the way we work and by eliminating some of the things we do."
He said the company would reduce the work force mostly through enhanced pension payments or lump sum payments to employees. In cases where employees are laid off, Mr. Woolard said Du Pont would help workers find other jobs.
Mr. Woolard met for about two hours this morning with top managers in Wilmington, and the announcement was sent by satellite to other Du Pont locations.
Afterward, Howard Simmons, a vice president and senior science adviser for central research and development, said there would be some reduction in research, "but nothing grave."
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Du Pont shares rose $1.325, to $48.125.

HEADLINE: Agencies Reap Savings in Building Decline

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
When engineers planned the repair of Manhattan's West Side Highway from 59th to 72d Street, they estimated the cost at $85 million. But at the bid-opening in January, the winning contractor agreed to do the job for only $62 million -- a savings of 27 percent.
In a silver lining to the recession, surprises like that are being repeated across the New York region in a wide array of projects on roads, sewers, recycling plants, water lines, subways, schoolhouses, airports and bridges. 
 A decline in private construction, which has been much more severe in the New York metropolitan area than nationally, has thrust local contractors into intense competition for work, resulting in lower bids.
Many homeowners have also discovered savings on home-improvement projects. As in larger construction, shrinking business in the renovation market has sharpened competition and lowered prices, according to members of the National Association of the Remodeling Industry, a contractors' group. A Queens carpenter and remodeler, Gary Gray, said: "Things are very slow. Everybody is trying to cut your price down. Sometimes you can do it and sometimes you can't."
 
Savings of $300 Million
 The savings reaped by local, state and Federal agencies are mounting into hundreds of millions of dollars a year, as bids have dropped between 10 and 30 percent, according to officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who were interviewed. An informal survey of seven major government agencies in the region showed a savings of at least $300 million this year compared with the estimated costs of projects.
"We're getting more bang for our buck," said Charles E. Williams, president of New York City's School Construction Authority. John Beckman, a spokesman for the city's General Services Department, said: "It's clear the acute distress in construction has produced a benefit to the city."
But that benefit may be limited by cumbersome procedures that surround the letting of public works contracts: authorizing, planning, designing and financing projects and soliciting and awarding bids.
"While it behooves you very much to try to take advantage, it's difficult," said State General Services Commissioner John F. Hudacs. "Not only do projects need funding, they take time, especially in the design phase."
"We're making every effort to get contracts out the door at these advantageous prices," said Stanley Brezenoff, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "Actually, we anticipated it a bit. When we talked about the toll increase, we said it's a good time for the public sector to prime the pump, generating jobs and activity." Construction industry officials are also lobbying for speeding up projects. Not only will the public get more value for its money, they argue, but the expanded work will also help revive the battered economy.
"Quite frankly, we have encouraged the public sector to spend more," said Francis X. McArdle, director of the General Contractors Association, which represents 114 heavy-construction companies. "The public gains good prices, and the work stimulates business." The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital management director, William Goldstein, said: "In a down economy we like to look at ourselves as a counter-cyclical force. We're trying to move as many projects forward as we can."
 
Tens of Thousands Unemployed
 The slump in construction is especially dramatic in the New York region, because it was hit earlier and harder than others by the recession, experts say. In what should be peak construction season, tens of thousands of workers are unemployed. "They're lining up at hiring halls, waiting for jobs to come in," said Louis Coletti. He is president of the New York Building Congress, representing 500 contractors, unions and allied groups.
Nationally, the construction business was down 11 percent in 1990 from 1989, but in the New York area it declined a much steeper 28 percent, said Matthew P. Drennan, an economist at Cornell University, citing figures from surveys by F. W. Dodge, a consulting firm owned by McGraw-Hill.
When a contract is below budget the difference may be saved, reallocated for other projects or used to upgrade the project. For Riverbank Park in West Harlem, a $3.5 million savings in the bid allowed the addition of night lighting and a better ice rink.
 
No Immediate Budget Relief
 Another hurdle to speeding up contracts during the slump is the fiscal crisis in state and local government. Hit by drastic drops in revenues, some agencies are suffering cuts in the staffs that manage projects, and some are trimming capital spending.
"We wish we could take fuller advantage," said General Services Commissioner Kenneth J. Knuckles, "but the Mayor made the decision that we need to reduce our debt service."
Because public works construction is generally financed by long-term bonds, the savings offer no immediate relief to the operating deficits that many governments face. But they do offer the prospect of lower debt repayments in future budgets.
New York City, whose construction spending program ranks third nationally after the Federal Government's and California's, budgeted $4.9 billion for projects last year and $5.7 billion this year. The state budgeted $3.1 billion last year and $3.8 billion this year.
 
Savings in Road Contracts
 Examples of savings are abundant. The city's last five road contracts saved a total of $25 million. The biggest spread was on the rebuilding of Hudson Street, estimated at $34 million and bid at $24 million.
Work on the Whitestone Expressway, estimated by the state at $59 million, is being done for $44 million. Estimates on 320 state general services contracts totaled $243 million but the winning bids were $213 million.
Contracts were awarded this spring for a $276 million, 27-story Federal courthouse and a $240 million, 34-story office building in Foley Square. William Jenkins, an assistant regional administrator for the Federal General Services Administration, said the bids were well within predicted costs.
"The public works market is the only game in town," Mr. McArdle said. "There's a substantial increase in competition and a substantial decrease in prices. People are bidding very aggressively to keep work on the books and keep their work forces intact."

HEADLINE: Phone Companies Are Permitted To Provide Information Services

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
A Federal judge lifted a legal bar today that had prevented the seven regional Bell telephone companies from offering services like home banking and electronic shopping, known collectively as information services.
The decision was a victory for the so-called Baby Bells, which hope to raise profits by selling Americans many new high-technology services. But opponents, including the newspaper industry, some long-distance companies and consumer groups, vowed to fight the decision, contending the phone companies could abuse their positions as local monopolies. 
 "An alarmist would say that the implications are Orwellian," said David E. Easterly, president of Cox Newspapers, who added that he expected the newspaper industry to appeal the decision and then, if necessary, to carry the fight to Congress.
 
Call for Neutrality
 "If we are going to enter a world in which a great deal of information passes through telephone lines, then those providing the phone lines should be neutral; they shouldn't be one of the information providers," Mr. Easterly said.
The Consumer Federation of America has argued that removing the restriction on information services could prompt the local telephone companies to spend too much money on fiber-optic cables and other sophisticated equipment that is currently used most heavily by businesses. Households could then end up footing the bill because local telephone rates still depend in many states on how much money the local phone companies invest in their networks.
 
Year-Long Process
 Judge Harold H. Greene, who oversaw the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and issued today's decision, blocked his ruling from taking effect until all appeals have been exhausted.
That process could take more than a year. But Judge Green's ruling seemed to stand a good chance of being upheld because the initial appeal would be to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which has already considered the issue. The appellate court prompted today's ruling by directing Judge Greene last year to reconsider his position on ownership of information services.
Judge Greene indicated in his decision that while the appeals court's decision last year left him little choice about lifting the restriction, he remained doubtful about the wisdom of the move.
"It would hardly make sense or be in the public interest to cancel an important part of an antitrust decree forged after several decades of on-and-off litigation, and turn a key ingredient of the emerging information society over to corporations who not so long ago were involved in major violations of the antitrust laws, and who even now seem ready to engage in anticompetitive practices whenever the opportunity therefore presents itself," he wrote.
 
Need for Incentives
 The phone companies have contended that their enormous financial and technical resources make them the best qualified to offer information services like news, stock quotes and other data to home users. They contend that only by owning these services will they have adequate incentives to invest in advanced technologies and insure that the United States does not lag behind other countries in developing such services.
Mr. Easterly of Cox on the other hand, said that the most immediate self-interest impact on the newspaper industry was likely to be creation of electronic Yellow Pages that could hurt classified advertising. But he said that he expected the Baby Bells to try to expand into creating news, video programs and a wide array of electronic services that would compete with the companies who now use the phone lines to deliver such services.
His argument touches on part of the original terms of the antitrust consent decree between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department. The Bell companies were barred from three industries to prevent them from using their monopoly control over local telephone service to subsidize new services unfairly or to bar other companies from the market. The three industries are long-distance telephone service, telephone equipment manufacturing and the creation -- but not transmission -- of information services.
 
Decision Is Praised
 Ronald F. Stowe, vice president of Washington operations for the Pacific Telesis Group, one of the seven Bell companies, praised today's decision in a statement as "a major step forward for American consumers, American business and the American economy."
But he expressed disappointment that the judge postponed the effect of his decision by issuing an immediate stay, and said that his company might ask the judge to cancel that part of his ruling.
The Bell companies own five-sixths of the nation's local telephone networks. For example, the Nynex Corporation, one of the seven Bell companies, is the parent of both the New York Telephone Company, which serves New York, and the New England Telephone Companies. The other regional Bells are Ameritech, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, Pacific Telesis, Southwestern Bell and U S West Inc.
Today's ruling did not change the restrictions that bar the Bell companies from entering the long-distance telephone industry or manufacturing telephone equipment. But the appeals court ruling that prompted today's decision also recommended that Judge Greene apply more flexible legal standards in considering these restrictions.
The original consent decree provided that Judge Greene review the restrictions every three years. The appeals court ruled on April 3, 1990, that Judge Greene had applied the wrong section of the consent decree when, in his first review of the restrictions in 1987, he denied the companies' request that they be allowed to enter the information services industry.
The panel said that Judge Greene should have used a section calling for the aproval of attempts by the phone companies to move into new industries if the effort were "within the reaches of the public interest."
Judge Greene had relied on a section of the consent decree that allowed such moves only if they were in society's best interest.
Herb Linnen, a spokesman for A.T.& T., said the telecommunications giant had never objected to the Bell companies' entry into the information services market, provided that they remained excluded from the equipment manufacturing and long-distance industries. Smaller long-distance carriers, led by the MCI Communications Corporation, opposed allowing the local phone companies into the information-services business.
 
Some in Favor
 Some state regulators have favored lifting the information- services restriction, hoping that they would be profitable enough that local phone companies would not ask for politically controversial rate increases. But consumer groups reply that state regulators, who typically have small staffs, cannot adequately oversee local phone companies that employ thousands of people and often hire former state regulators.
Legal questions aside, many people also wonder whether the Bell companies, which are largely managed by engineers, will be adept in providing services. Jeffrey S. Silverstein, the publisher of the Information Industry Bulletin, a weekly industry newsletter, said that the Bell companies still thought like utilities rather than entrepreneurs, and were mainly interested in increasing the use of local networks, rather than thinking up new services
"Our basic feeling is that the competitive landscape is not going to change dramatically because of this decision," he said.
Newspaper publishers have been "crying wolf" when they warn that the advent of electronic Yellow Pages could someday decimate classified advertising, Mr. Silverstein added.

HEADLINE: UAL and Delta Air Lines Report Sharply Lower Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation and Delta Air Lines Inc. both reported sharply lower earnings yesterday, as the effects of the recession and the Persian Gulf war continued to hurt travel.
But the profits, however slim, were seen by some analysts as a possible sign of a recovery for the beleaguered airline industry. Last week, the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, also posted a small profit. 
 UAL, the Chicago-based parent of United Airlines, said its second-quarter profits fell 64.5 percent from a year earlier.
Delta said its net income was down 74.1 percent in its fourth fiscal quarter. The Atlanta-based airline also said it had lost $324.4 million in its fiscal year, which ended June 30.
 
Losses in Previous Quarter
 Both airlines blamed the industry's fare wars for cutting into profits during the last quarter.
The performances of UAL and Delta in the last three months were substantially better than in the first three months of 1991, when the two airlines posted losses as a result of higher jet fuel costs and the gulf war.
These improvements were partly discounted because the first quarter is usually weak for travel, whereas the most recent quarter normally reflects heavy summer travel.
Paul Turk, a travel consultant with Avmark Inc., said UAL's and Delta's lower profits indicated that many companies that clamped down on business travel last fall had not yet loosened their restrictions that much.
Following are details of the two airline companies' results:
 
UAL
 UAL, which operates the second-largest airline after American, reported second-quarter net income of $52.7 million, or $2.23 a share, down from $148.3 million, or $6.81 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 7.7 percent, to $2.95 billion, from $2.74 billion.
Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of UAL, said that paying customers had flown 13.1 percent more miles in the second quarter of 1991 than a year earlier, but that domestic revenue had been held down by the fare wars and a decline in high-profit business travel.
Mr. Wolf said in a statement that United was forced to match fare cuts by "financially distressed competitors whose primary focus appears to be on cash flow in the short term."
UAL's results were also depressed because trans-Pacific travel did not fully recover from the declines caused by the gulf war until late in the quarter, he said.
"Looking ahead, we see gradual improvement, although the level of improvement will depend on the speed and the strength of the economic recovery in the United States, as well as a return to financially justifiable pricing," he said.
UAL's shares rose $3.75 yesterday, to $141.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Delta
 Delta, the nation's No. 3 airline, reported fourth-quarter net income of $19.2 million, or 30 cents a share, down from $74.1 million or $1.47 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quater rose 12.7 percent, to $2.52 billion, from $2.24 billion.
Delta's net loss of $324.4 million in fiscal 1991 compared with a profit of $302.8 million, or $5.79 a share, in fiscal 1990. Revenue for the fiscal year rose 6.9 percent, to $9.17 billion, from $8.58 billion.
"Fiscal 1991's net loss reflects the turmoil the entire industry experienced during the year," Thomas J. Roeck Jr., the airline's chief financial officer, said in a statement.
Delta said growth in traffic during the most recent quarter was spurred partly by costly discount fare promotions, which caused Delta's profit yield per passenger mile flown to decline 1 percent.
The airline said its operating expenses had risen 16 percent because of its new international routes to Europe and Asia. In addition, cash expenses rose 30 percent because of higher costs for repairs and maintenance, rental and landing fees, and higher travel agency commissions.
Delta's shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $75, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Carol Laise, 73, Ex-Ambassador and High State Dept. Aide, Dies

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Carol Laise, an American Ambassador who was the wife of an American Ambassador and the first woman to be an Assistant Secretary of State, died yesterday at her home in Dummerston, Vt. She was 73 years old.
 Miss Laise died of cancer, a spokesman for the family said. 
She was named Ambassador to Nepal by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1966 and remained in the post until 1973. In January 1974 she married Ambassador at Large Ellsworth Bunker, a 79-year-old widower, in Katmandu, Nepal. She kept her maiden name professionally.
 It was the first marriage between two American Ambassadors. Miss Laise was a close friend of Mr. Bunker's first wife, Harriet Allen Bunker, who died in 1964, and it was Miss Laise's first marriage.
 For nearly six years after their marriage the couple saw each other only once a month when Ambassador Laise would take a plane provided by President Johnson and fly to Saigon, where Ambassador Bunker was trying to stabilize the situation in South Vietnam.
 
Named Director General
 In October 1973 she returned to Washington and was sworn in as Assistant Secretary of State in charge of the Bureau of Public Affairs, the first woman to hold so high a post in the department. Before her appointment as Ambassador to Nepal she had been director of the Office of South Asian Affairs,
 In 1974 Miss Laise became director general of the Foreign Service, the highest nonpolitical job in the Foreign Service, a post she held until she retired in 1977.
 Caroline Clendening Laise began her Government career in 1940 as an occupational coder for the Civil Service Commission. In 1946 she went to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, and in 1948 joined the State Department.
 From 1956 to 1961 she was an adviser to American delegates to various United Nations agencies and in 1962 was made deputy director of the Office of South Asian Affairs with responsibilty for diplomatic relations with Afghanistan, Ceylon, Nepal, India and Pakistan.
 In comparing the economic problems of Nepal with those of India, she said in a 1966 interview with Ann Terry Pincus of The New York Post, "You could explain that Nepal is like Appalachia, and India has the problems of Harlem."
 
An Adviser in New Delhi
 When Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey went to India and Pakistan in 1965, Miss Laise went along as his adviser. In the 1962-63 Chinese invasion of India, Ambassador John Kenneth Galbraith sent for Miss Laise for advice and she spent about a year in New Delhi.
 She was a winner in 1965 of the annual Federal Women's Award for outstanding contributions by women in government service, and in 1973 she received the Career Service Award of the National Civil Service League.
 Miss Laise, a native of Winchester, Va., was a graduate of American University and received an M.A. in political science from George Washington University.
 Her husband, Ambassador Bunker, died in 1984.
 She is survived by a brother, Frederick Laise of Santa Fe, N.M.; two stepsons, Samuel Bunker of Dummerston, Vt., and John Bunker of Wheatland, Wy.; and a stepdaughter, Ellen Bunker of Tucson, Ariz.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carol Laise (Associated Press, 1973)

HEADLINE: A Reversible Air-Conditioner, Heat Pump Warms and Cools

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Heating and cooling a house used to be separate jobs, but the heat pump, a device that does both, often at much lower cost, is gaining popularity. Nearly one in three new American houses uses a heat pump, according to a recent Government estimate; in some parts of the country heat pumps are nearly universal in new houses.
A heat pump is "nothing more than a glorified air-conditioner," said Robert M. Little Sr. of the residential marketing department at the Tampa Electric Company in Florida. 
 It is glorified because it is reversible. In summer it acts very much like a central air-conditioner, with its condenser sucking in heat and ejecting it outdoors. In winter, it collects heat from outside and pushes it inside. People may wonder how a machine can draw heat from a cold place and put it in a warm one, but that is exactly what a regular air-conditioner does when it lowers the indoor temperature to 75 degrees and sends the heat into a 90-degree outdoors.
An old-fashioned electric heater turns electricity into heat when its coils resist an electric current. When it is 50 degrees outside, a heat pump would use only a third as much power to warm the house to 68 degrees as would a resistance heater. For example, Mr. Little said, a typical house in the Tampa area would use 6,000 kilowatt-hours for a year of resistance heat, but only 1,440 kilowatt-hours if it had a heat pump instead. Farther north, the difference grows smaller; north of Washington, it drops to near zero.
 
Teaming Heat Pump and Furnace

In the Washington area, some people use heat pumps on most winter days and conventional gas- or oil-fired systems for the coldest days, although the capital costs of this combination are higher. Jack Stevenson, manager of residential energy services at the Potomac Electric Power Company, described another case in which a house might have both. Some houses are too big for a single forced-air system because of the length of the ducts, he said. The solution favored by builders is to put a second system in the attic; a heat pump is preferred for safety reasons.
In most parts of the country, the heat pump's main competitor for heating is a very high-efficiency gas burner.
Heat pumps, which were introduced 30 years ago, have generated some complaints, especially the early models. They can be noisy, can create drafts and can fail to remove humidity. Recent changes have reduced those problems and lowered operating costs.
Still, heat pumps are limited by climate. Their biggest drawback is that as outdoor temperatures go down, it takes more and more electricity to gather enough heat to help indoors. Below 30 degrees Fahrenheit, a heat pump usually needs help from a resistance heater, and below 15 degrees the heat pump will be nearly useless. In addition, when the outdoor temperature is below freezing, moisture in the air will form ice on the heat pump coils, somewhat as ice forms on the cooling surfaces inside an old-fashioned refrigerator-freezer, reducing efficiency. Heat pumps solve the problem by heating the coils, which also reduces efficiency.
Millions of houses use resistance heaters, but they are generally far more expensive to operate than the alternatives: natural gas, heating oil or propane. The amount of electricity a heat pump uses is crucial because installing one can cost 10 to 25 percent more than installing an electric air-conditioner and a conventional gas furnace. According to the Department of Energy, in areas where the temperature often falls below 25 degrees a heat pump would require so much supplemental resistance heat that it might not make sense.
In places where heat pumps are economical, electric companies are usually eager to see them installed, so the local power company is a good place for a homeowner to start inquiring. Many utilities will estimate the size of the heat pump needed and calculate the operating cost. But the installation is usually done by the homeowner's contractor.
To encourage efficiency in electricity use, some utilities offer rebates to people who install heat pumps. Carolina Power & Light, for example, will lend its customers money to buy heat pumps and, for particularly efficient models, will lower the interest rate. Carolina Power and other utilities have found it is cheaper to subsidize the purchase of efficient appliances than to build new power plants to supply inefficient ones.
The efficiency of a heat pump -- that is, the amount of temperature change it produces per unit of electricity consumed -- varies with the outdoor temperature and the desired indoor temperature. The Government requires heat pumps to be labeled using a standard called the seasonal energy efficiency ratio, a measurement that combines the efficiency ratings under all conditions. (A related measure, the energy efficiency ratio, is used for conventional air-conditioners.) Check with your electric company before buying from a private contractor; many utilities pay rebates if the heat pump meets a minimum standard of efficiency.
 
Efficiency Is Improved
 New heat pump designs are far more efficient than old ones. One reason is that most are designed to run at variable speed to keep the indoor temperature at the desired level, while conventional air-conditioners or furnaces run for a while to get the house to the proper temperature, and then shut off until the temperature drifts out of the desired range. Continuous operation means greater efficiency and eliminates a characteristic that many homeowners have found objectionable, a blast of cold air from the ducts on start-up.
At Carolina Power and elsewhere, heat pump experts stress that to work right, a heat pump system has to be well thought out. Houses with forced-air heating that use natural gas are not always good candidates for conversion because the existing hot air system blows air heated to 120 degrees or so. A heat pump may produce only 90 or 100 degrees, so it will have to move more air through the ducts at higher speed, which can cause howling.
Newer heat pumps are designed to produce higher-temperature air, which can also be critical. In winter, air at less than body temperature can create a draft that feels cold, even if it is warm enough to raise the room temperature to the desired level.
Another critical problem is size. If the heat pump is too big, it will not have to work very hard to cool the house, but this has a drawback. Humidity is removed from the air when it passes over a cold coil, but if the system is too big it will lower the temperature before all the air has had a chance to go through the coil, leaving the house cool but clammy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Photo: Jason Mills, left, and Gerald Scott install a heat pump. In background is Jack Stevenson of Potomac Electric Power Company. (George Tames for The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "A Pump That Heats and Cools," shows how in winter the heat pump extracts heat from cool outdoor air and delivers it to the house, using a compressor like the one in an air-conditioner or refrigerator. In summer the compressor pushes coolant in the opposite direction, so the system extracts heat from indoors and sends it outside. (The New York Times;Illustration by John Papasian)

HEADLINE: Petty Feud May Have Led to Youth's Death

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Lacey Jenkins and Lamont Simmions had what the police often describe as an "ongoing dispute."
It probably wasn't over anything much, they say. Just something small. It may have even been as petty as a putdown that witnesses told them Mr. Jenkins, 15 years old, had once made about the shabby clothing worn by Mr. Simmions, 20. 
 What was certain, however, was that early yesterday morning, Mr. Jenkins walked into the dank, yellow-tiled lobby of his apartment building in Harlem and was shot once in the head by someone lurking there, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene.
 
Site of Killing Over Jacket
 Late yesterday afternoon, the police arrested Mr. Simmions, of 70 West 115th Street in Harlem, and accused him of the slaying. Last night the authorities were weighing what to charge him with, said a police spokesman, Detective Joseph K. McConville. Witnesses to the shooting led the police to Mr. Simmions, who was picked up at his residence, the detective said.
The shooting occurred at 70 Lenox Avenue in the Martin Luther King Jr. Towers, a sprawling public housing project that was the site of a similar killing last November. In that case, Bernard Richardson, 20 years old, was shot and killed over the black shearling jacket that a friend was wearing, the police said. No arrests in that case have been made, the police said yesterday.
Yesterday morning, friends and relatives wept openly near the asphalt playground outside the youth's building. His mother, Jewel Jenkins, recalled how her son rose each morning before dawn to catch a commuter bus to Hackensack, N.J., where many relatives live and where he attended Hackensack High School. Ms. Jenkins, 32 years old, said she had graduated from the school and had selected it for her son because she trusted he would get a good education there.
The youth, an average student who had just completed the 10th grade, played on the football and basketball teams at the school and dreamed of becoming a professional athlete some day, relatives said. Ms. Jenkins said her son was quiet and serious and always stayed out of trouble.
 
'I Don't Smile a Lot'
 "He had a personality all to himself," Ms. Jenkins said, her voice breaking. "People would often ask him why he looked so serious. He would say 'I don't smile a lot.' That was his way."
Like a lot of other teen-agers, Mr. Jenkins played Nintendo video games and enjoyed renting movies. "He was just talking about Robocop II on Thursday," Ms. Jenkins said.
Yesterday, the boy's relatives and friends hugged one another and cried near the playground and later inside the apartment of the youth's grandmother, Leova Jenkins, who lives across the street. Though most spoke quietly of their grief, others periodically vented their rage loudly, often to no one in particular.
"Lacey didn't bother nobody," one young woman screamed as tears streamed down her face. "Why they kill him?"
The police said they were unable to answer that question definitively last evening.
But Lieut. Robert Nardoza, a police spokesman, said witnesses had related comments they said the youth had once purportedly made about the shabbiness of Mr. Simmions's clothing. The lieutenant said he did not know when those comments were made, but that they may have been the motive for the shooting.
"The victim came from a decent family," Lieutenant Nardoza said. "He had decent clothes, nice sneakers. There might have been some comments by the victim demeaning the shooter's manner of dress."
Detective McConville, the other police spokesman, said he did not know if Mr. Simmions had a criminal record. The detective said Mr. Simmions was unemployed.
It was clothing, or at the very least the status of it, that the police said led to the killing last November of Mr. Richardson in the King Towers, a project of 10 red-brick buildings with about 3,600 residents that was the subject of a three-part series in The New York Times in February. Mr. Richardson was walking with two friends at 1:30 A.M. on November 25 when a mugger demanded their coats, one of which was made of black shearling, a popular status symbol on the city's meanest streets.
When the three men resisted, the mugger fired four shots, killing Mr. Richardson and wounding one of his friends in the shoulder.

HEADLINE: Rare Sense of Optimism Stirs Anew in Hartford

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 26

 BODY:
There was enough optimism in the air at the Connecticut Capitol today for the House, the Senate and the Governor to set a deadline for adopting a budget for the fiscal year that began 26 days ago: one more week.
The feeling that progress is being made has been felt before in this roller-coaster special session, in which legislators have at times worked through the night and over weekends only to have one budget or another defeated or vetoed. 
 And the deadline, like nearly every deadline in this long deadlock over spending and taxes, is artificial: the House and Senate approved a one-week temporary budget, to keep government going through Aug. 4, vowing their work would be done by then.
 
A Need to Compromise
 What seemed different in the rococo corridors and chambers of this Gilded-Age Capitol was a determination that every possible idea for spending and taxing was now out in the open and being discussed in both the House and Senate, by both Democrats and Republicans.
"People are starting to realize they need to reach compromise, and that's what's happening," said Representative Edward C. Krawiecki, the House minority leader from Bristol who has led Republicans in their opposition to an income tax and their insistence on constitutional spending limits.
The Senate President, John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford who has staunchly opposed an income tax, said after meeting with Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., "There are a number of plans that are out there and people seem optimistic they can put something together, especially with Republican support."
 
'Spadework Has Been Done'
 And Mr. Weicker, who has said he can see no alternative to a first-ever tax on wages for Connecticut to both balance a budget and stimulate the economy, said, "We all know the facts so backward and forward that we could sit down and within 20 minutes come up with 20 cohesive programs.
"All the spadework has been done."
Governor Weicker signaled his optimism today by quickly signing the temporary one-week budget, ending the threat of another state shutdown when the current two-week temporary budget expires at midnight Sunday. He had let two previous tempo rary measures take effect without his signature, thereby furloughing 20,000 state workers for several days the first week of July when the state had no budget of any kind.
Today, the House proceeded with its one-week budget in the expectation that Mr. Weicker would take it as an indication of progress and go along. The Senate followed in little more than an hour, and Mr. Weicker began a news conference by saying, "The answer is yes, I'm going to sign it."
Mr. Weicker said he had been assured by Senator Larson and the House speaker, Richard J. Balducci, that they would do everything possible "to button up this baby" within the new one-week grace period.
 
Not Out of Woods Yet
 But he warned that he had not seen the details of any tax or spending plan. "Optimism is one thing," the Governor said. "Being out of the woods is quite another."
The sense of progress moving today's votes came from two sources: the House's failure on Tuesday to override Mr. Weicker's veto of a budget balanced without an income tax, and the subsequent release of new income-tax plans by two pairs of representatives, one Democratic and one Republican.
The Democrats, Representative. Ronald L. Smoko of Hamden and Representative. John W. Thompson of Manchester, captured attention on Wednesday by proposing a 20 percent surtax on Federal tax bills, so that someone who paid $10,000 to the I.R.S., for example, would pay $2,000 to Connecticut.
Their plan both simplified the tax process and allowed residents to take full advantage of their Federal tax deductions.
Then on Thursday two suburban Republicans, Robert Farr of West Hartford and William L. Wollenberg of Farmington, abandoned their opposition to an income tax and made their own proposal: a 10 percent surtax on Federal tax bills, coupled with a constitutional limit on the income-tax rate and a long-term reduction in the state's work force of 20 percent.
 
Republicans to Discuss Taxes
 While a few Republicans had participated in earlier income-tax proposals, this was new territory, indicating a willingness by long-time opponents to accept the new source of revenue in return for a restructuring of the spending side of the budget.
After the House vote today, Mr. Krawiecki, the minority leader, met with Mr. Weicker and told him a majority of Republicans still opposed any income tax, but that other members were interested in discussing the new plans that various legislators were working on.
He appeared optimistic that, with both sides realizing that compromise was required, Republicans could win some of the spending limits they have sought in this session, when Mr. Weicker's status as an independent governor with no party of his own has allowed them a much stronger role than usual.
Mr. Krawiecki said he doubted that any budget would pass without large spending cuts and constitutional limits on spending and tax rates.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard J. Balducci, left, Connecticut House Speaker, and Edward C. Krawiecki, the House minority leader, as the House approved a one-week temporary budget to keep the government going through Aug. 4. They vowed that their work would be done by then and a final budget would be adopted. (Steve Miller for The New York Times) (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: Dole Will Seek Backing of Bush On Bill Extending Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, said today that he was going to try to get the Bush Administration to agree on a plan to extend unemployment benefits for people who have been out of work at least half a year.
A $5.8 billion measure sponsored by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, will be taken up by the Senate on Monday. Mr. Dole still opposes that bill, an aide said, because he considers it too costly and because he believes it is being used as a political device to embarrass Republicans. But support for it among Republicans is growing. 
 The aide said Mr. Dole would talk with Lynn Martin, the Secretary of Labor, and Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, both of whom have opposed extending benefits beyond what current law provides. The aide said Mr. Dole would try to work with them to find an approach the Administration would support.
 
Only 3 States Benefit Now
 Under current law, the basic 26 weeks of unemployment benefits can be extended for 13 weeks when unemployment among insured workers in a state reaches 6 percent, or when it exceeds average levels in that state over the last two years by one-fifth. The unemployed in only three states are now eligible for extended benefits.
The Bentsen bill would make workers eligible for 20 more weeks of unemployment coverage when total unemployment is at least 8 percent; 13 more weeks when it reaches 7 percent, and 7 more weeks when it is 6 percent. In all other states, four additional weeks would be authorized.
A similar measure is to be considered Tuesday by the House Ways and Means Committee. A vote in the House is also planned for next week.
 
Support From Republicans
 The Bentsen bill, which won the votes of five of the nine Republicans on the Finance Committee on Thursday, picked up additional support from other Republicans today.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York said, "These are tough times and working people need protection." Referring to Mr. Darman's arguments against the additional spending as not in keeping with last year's budget agreement, Mr. D'Amato said, "When you can't feed a family and can't keep your dignity, all that business about keeping agreements, that just pales in the face of reality."
Mr. Bentsen said another Republican, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, had asked him to be included as a co-sponsor on the bill. "I'm quite encouraged," he said. "We're picking it up as we go along." Other Republcian co-sponsors are Senators Bob Packwood of Oregon, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and John Seymour of California.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Dip in Sluggish Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in light trading yesterday, as credit market participants used a weaker-than-expected report on second-quarter economic growth as an excuse to take profits.
The report showed that for the first time since last year's third quarter growth turned positive, but just barely. The increase of four-tenths of a percent was less than half what most analysts had expected. 
 Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher just after the report was released, but retreated later, as dealers moved to capitalize on the gains recorded over the last few days.
Aside from the urge to take profits, traders said the Treasury's refunding auctions, which will take place in less than two weeks, also acted as a disincentive to maintain positions through the weekend.
 
Awaiting Next Week's Data
 Moreover, while economic data released earlier in the week suggested to some analysts that the recovery may be stalling, a raft of fresh reports, including July employment data, are expected next week. Those reports could easily quash the notion that the economy is stalling out, traders and analysts said, which would have a negative impact on the bond market.
Recent data "point either to a slip back into recession or a very sluggish recovery," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a New York money management firm. "But market participants are worried both about supply and next week's numbers. So what we are seeing is people taking profits in an illiquid market."
Some See Strength in G.N.P. Data
Indeed, analysts said that a closer inspection of the Commerce Department's report on second-quarter growth showed that the economy was not as weak as the numbers seemed to suggest.
Specifically, economists said they were encouraged by a 2.5 percent increase in domestic final sales, a rise suggesting that consumption is beginning to gain momentum.
"On closer analysis, it became quite clear that the G.N.P. accounts confirm a turnaround in the economy," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "That in turn seems to decrease the likelihood that the Federal Reserve Board will move soon to ease monetary policy further."
Most of what was a modest selloff occurred in longer-term notes and bonds. Prices of shorter-term maturities were little changed on the day.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 97 1/8, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 8.38 percent, up from 8.37 percent late Thursday. The benchmark issue traded as high as 97 17/32 just after the numbers on second-quarter growth were released.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 23/32 late yesterday, down 3/32, to yield 8.19 percent. The 7 7/8 percent five-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.80 percent, unchanged from late Thursday. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were unchanged at a late offered price of 100 2/32, to yield 6.84 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.56 percent, up a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.67 percent. And one-year bill rates also fell by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.85 percent.
Two large corporations priced issues in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Pepisco offered $200 million worth of three-year notes, through an underwriting syndicate led by Lehman Brothers.
The 7 5/8 percent notes, which mature Aug. 1, 1994, and are noncallable, were priced at $99.696 to yield 7.74 percent, 51 basis points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The New England Telephone Company offered a total of $200 million worth of securities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Half the issue was 8 5/8 percent 10-year notes maturing Aug. 1, 2001. The notes were priced at 499.45 to yield 8.708 percent, 53 basis points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $100 million was 40-year debentures maturing Aug. 1, 2031.
The 9 percent debentures, which are noncallable for 10 years, were priced at $97.408 to yield 9.246 percent, 87.5 basis points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated AA-2 by Moody's and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Encore Reportedly Plans to Shut Plant

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 26

 BODY:
Encore Computer, the troubled computer manufacturer based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is planning to shut its plant in Marlboro, Mass., and lay off nearly all of the 200 workers there, according to a person within the company.
The company, which makes and sells multiprocessing computers used for flight simulation, energy management and nuclear power plant simulation, has been hit hard recently by economic problems exacerbated by continuing delays in shipping its new Gemini computer, said the person, who asked not to be named. 
 Encore's officials, including its chairman and chief executive, Kenneth G. Fisher, who founded the company in Massachusetts in 1983, could not be reached for comment today. Charles Anderson, a corporate vice president, did not return repeated telephone calls seeking comment.
Last week, William Avery, Encore's vice president in charge of technology, told Marlboro employees that the plant would be shut and that he would be leaving to create a start-up company, the person said. Mr. Avery also could not be reached for comment today.
Up to 20 employees in the Marlboro operation, which houses the research and development team building the newest computer, will be offered the opportunity to relocate to Fort Lauderdale, while the rest have been informed that the company planned to phase out the plant over 12 months, the person said. Encore has slightly more than 1,600 employees.
Encore, which lost $9.4 million, on revenues of $40 million, in the first fiscal quarter of the year, was hurt by losing a $460 million NASA contract to I.B.M. in May. Sales have dropped from $215 million last year to a projected $170 million for fiscal 1991.
The company has attributed the projected sales drop to delays in the Gemini computer series, which had been promised to customers before the end of last year and has yet to be shipped.
In 1989, Encore acquired Gould Inc.'s computer systems division and soon after moved its headquarters to Gould's Florida location.
In over-the-counter trading today, Encore's shares fell 18.75 cents, closing at $1.43 3/4.
