HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off After G.N.P. Data; Gold Prices Higher in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined across the board yesterday, depressed by an unexpectedly weak report on United States economic growth during the second quarter.
Gold prices rose in domestic dealings after declining overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $366.20 an ounce, up $1.70. Republic National Bank said gold rose $1.75 an ounce to a late bid price of $366. 
 The dollar fell sharply in both European and domestic dealings after the release of a Commerce Department repor showing that the gross national product, a measure of the economy's health, grew at an annual rate of four-tenths of a percent in the second quarter. That is well below market expectations of growth of at least eight-tenths of a percent during the period.
 
 Fear of 'Double-Dip Recession'

"With G.N.P. under expectations, it really gave the dollar another knock," said Randolph Donney, research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "It lent credence to the theory that we're going to see a double-dip recession and that the Fed is going to have to lower interest rates."
He said traders were beginning to believe that despite a few quarters of growth, a turnaround was not taking hold and the economy was going to slip back into decline, prompting the Federal Reserve to ease credit to stimulate growth.
Marc Chandler, an analyst with the consulting firm IDEA, said technical moves ahead of the weekend lifted the dollar from its session lows. He noted that activity died down once the market had digested the G.N.P. report.
In Tokyo, where trading ended before the G.N.P. report was released, the dollar rose to 138.35 Japanese yen, from 137.60 on Thursday. Later, in London the dollar rose to 137.85 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 137.60 yen, down from 138.85 on Thursday.
In London the British pound rose to $1.6880, from $1.6750. In New York it cost $1.6830 to buy a pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6730.
Against the German currency the dollar fell to 1.7430 marks, from 1.7588.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5220 Swiss francs, down from 1.5335; 5.9380 French francs, down from 5.9775; 1,301.00 Italian lire, down from 1,311.00, and 1.1488 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1523.
Gold prices declined overseas. In London gold fell to a late bid of $364.75 an ounce, from $365 bid late Thursday. In Zurich gold's closing bid was $364.35 an ounce, down from $364.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong gold fell 22 cents an ounce, to $365.56.

HEADLINE: No More Aid for M.B.A.'s in China

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALIAN, China

 BODY:
In a modest structure on the leafy campus of the Dalian University of Technology, just across from a huge statue of Chairman Mao leading his Communist flock, capitalism is the burning issue.
The Chinese at the school, who are not trying to outflank Communism's nemesis but to absorb more of it, are losing some ground. Despite Chinese protests, the Commerce Department has refused to renew an annual $400,000 contribution to a business school program here that has turned scores of young Chinese managers into freshly minted M.B.A.'s for service in their homeland. 
 The 11-year-old program was unique: a Government-to-Government arrangement, financed partly by each country, that offered management courses to officials from many of China's top enterprises.
It provided regular American M.B.A. degrees, under a program run by the State University of New York at Buffalo, which provided the curriculum and professors. The program at this campus in Dalian, a port city in China's industrial northeast, the region once known as Manchuria, also took senior Chinese officials and offered them midcareer training in American management techniques.
And the professors did not train the Chinese to work just in foreign ventures, as the management courses of some other countries in China do. The majority of the Dalian program's graduates returned to their state-owned enterprises, introducing American methods directly into the heart of Communist China.
But the Commerce Department's decision to stop supporting this program is a sign of the times inside China and in Sino-American relations.
The United States' decision to pull the plug on the M.B.A. program reflects the political realities as the American love affair with China continues the cooling-off that started with the killings of pro-democracy demonstrators two years ago in Tiananmen Square.
President Bush is currently struggling to renew China's favored access to American markets. An antagonistic Congress that has lost patience with what it considers China's poor human rights record voted Tuesday to impose restrictions on trade between the countries but the narrow majority is not likely to withstand a veto.
The shift in Washington is occurring as the Chinese have expanded foreign trade and encouraged foreign companies to invest in private businesses. The M.B.A. students here speak English as their second language, and use it to debate finance, marketing and labor management strategies, not class warfare.
Even with the setbacks that Western-style reform has suffered for three years, China remains eager to learn what it must to advance its hobbling economy and integrate it more closely with the industrialized democracies.
Ultimately, though, the decision to halt the program here raises the question of which measures taken by an angry United States against China really punish the country or soften its behavior, and which merely undermine the United States' goal of achieving political and economic reform.
"We admit we have a lot of problems trying to reform our system," said Zhu Shunqing, an economist who is the dean of the university's school of management. "The graduates of this school have new ideas, and they understand the thinking of foreigners. What we have to have is useful knowledge to help with the reform process, even from capitalists."
Like the dean of a Harvard or a Stanford, Mr. Zhu proudly ticked off the important government offices and corporations in which the graduates of the American program have landed, from the State Planning Commission and top provincial offices to some of China's largest state enterprises. President Ronald Reagan praised the program during a visit to China in 1984 and Henry Kissinger spoke at one of its graduations.
That record of success has only increased the dismay over the Commerce Department's decision to kill the program. The department has decided that it can spend the $400,000 a year it contributes to better effect elsewhere, perhaps in Eastern Europe.
"This is painful for me because I started the program 11 years ago," said Richard W. H. Lee, the Commerce Department's director of science and technology programs in East Asia. "Everyone considers it a great success, but it is a matter of priorities. The department's priorities have changed."
 
 'The Wrong Information'

Mr. Zhu, too, acknowledged the apparent shift in priorities. "The Department of Commerce said they wanted to change their emphasis from China to Eastern Europe," he said. "They said they didn't think we would reform our economy. I say they have the wrong information."
Many who have been involved in the program concede it had shortcomings; some of the young M.B.A.s found there was little use for their new skills in hidebound state-owned enterprises, for instance.
Mr. Zhu said some graduates were frustrated when they returned to a Chinese environment. Some were relegated to jobs as translators without real influence. But he said those problems were declining because the students were being chosen with more care.
But almost all felt that the positive aspects outweighed those flaws, and that the good will it generated for the United States was important.
 
 Better Business Relations

"It's a tragedy," said Joseph A. Alutto, the dean of Buffalo's business school until earlier this year, when he moved to Ohio State University. "You could not find a more cost-effective way of developing better business relations. And the need for this expertise and these relationships has never been greater."
Added David B. Matthews, the resident administrator of the program for the State University of New York: "We really do have an impact on the senior level of managers in the Chinese economy. If you close it down you lose that."
Although Commerce Department officials prefer to say the annual grant is just being suspended, the program's administrators say the likelihood of reviving it is slim because of the long lead time to attract students and professors.
The American Government has encouraged American corporations to consider picking up the program's decidedly modest cost. There is already an advisory counsel made up of some of America's biggest companies, including I.B.M., Xerox, Citicorp, General Electric and Coca-Cola. The companies have provided internships for the Chinese students and other forms of backing.
 
 Where Government Has Clout

But most agree the corporations could never replace the Government as chief sponsor. The fact that the course was Government-to-Government gave it clout in a country where the Government so tightly controls the economy. If it were a corporate program it would lose that important status, and possibly the backing of the Chinese Government, Mr. Zhu said.
"Part of the whole reason this has been so successful is the kind of students it draws, and that's because it's Government to Government," Mr. Lee said.
Mr. Zhu said: "China has really opened to these ideas. It is not a good choice for you to close that door."

HEADLINE: Economy Turns up With Gain of 0.4% in the 2nd Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
In its first expansion since last summer, the economy managed a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate during the April-June quarter as inflation pressure subsided, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Bush Administration was quick to hail the advance, which was marked by a surge in consumer spending, as confirmation that the economy has pulled out of the recession after a cumulative decline of 1.1 percent in the gross national product. That is about half the severity of typical postwar downturns. 
 "This further indicates that the recession appears to have ended in the spring and a recovery has begun," Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, said in a briefing. "We expect the recovery to continue and gain momentum."
 
Less Than Wall St. Expected
 Although the rise in G.N.P. was at the low end of the range expected by Wall Street and other private analysts, most also seemed inclined to view today's report in a largely positive light.
Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, found the upturn in personal spending and a further reduction of business inventories particularly encouraging. "The basic dynamics required to lift the economy off and give it some momentum are at work," he said.
At the same time, analysts were aware that five of the eight previous recessions since World War II have had at least one quarter of growth before finally ending.
 
Series of Positive Reports
 Today's report is the latest in a series of mostly positive or improved economic results so far this summer, covering, among other things, industrial production, employment, housing starts and the Government index intended to predict the economy's course -- which has risen for four straight months. At the same time, prices have remained in check, rising by only two-tenths of 1 percent at the consumer level in June while declining at the producer level.
This week, on the other hand, some analysts grew more edgy about a possible economic relapse on reports of a downturn in orders for manufactured durable goods, disappointing car sales and a rise in initial claims for unemployment insurance.
In an appearance today before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic counselor to Data Resources-McGraw Hill, pointed to various structural factors that he said would inhibit, perhaps threaten, recovery. They were high levels of private debt, weak income growth, an oversupply of commercial buildings, tighter lending standards and budget deficits at all levels of government.
But according to Walter D. Fackler, a professor of business economics at the University of Chicago, the only significant negative factor in today's G.N.P. data was a decline in the international trade sector. Exports grew at a modest $5.9 billion rate, aided by a return to normal levels of tourist spending and air fare receipts following the war in the Persian Gulf, but this gain was largely offset by lower profits from the foreign operations of American companies.
 
Oil Profits Decline
 A Commerce Department official cited shrinking postwar margins of oil companies as an important contributor to the profit decline. He also said that to compile today's report, the department estimated that the June trade deficit, not yet published, widened $1 billion, to $5.7 billion. Imports, meanwhile, rose at a $31.6 billion annual rate in contrast to a $15 billion rate of decline in the second quarter, the report showed.
Business investment in plants fell again but this normally lags behind during upturns as companies delay capital spending until they find capacity pinched. The decline, moreover, was only $2.9 billion at an annual rate, compared with a $22.6 billion rate of decline in the first quarter.
Residential investment posted a small increase during the latest period, the first rise in housing for more than a year.
Many analysts had predicted that inventories would rise in the second quarter, swelling the G.N.P., but the fact that they did not was taken as an encouraging sign.
 
Inventories Are Falling
 After reductions in non-farm inventories at annual rates of $16.3 billion in the spring, $28.1 billion in the winter and $28.5 billion in the fall, stocks are considered so lean that production will need to be increased fast if the recovery is sustained, analysts said.
They also said the rise in consumption showed that the inventory reductions were not the result of corporate pessimism but of strong demand. "Consumers haven't retrenched," asserted Richard D. C. Trainer, chief market economist at the Bank of Tokyo. "We are firmly in recovery."
The four-tenths of 1 percent rate of increase in the nation's second-quarter output of goods and services follows two straight quarterly declines -- at a 2.8 percent pace in the first quarter and at a 1.6 percent pace in the final quarter of last year.
For the third quarter of 1990, during which the recession actually began according to the National Bureau of Economic Research, the economy grew at a rate of 1.4 percent. The research bureau designated last July as the peak of a seven-and-a-half-year exansion.
 
Reassuring Numbers
 The price data contained in today's report were mostly reassuring even though much of the improvement reflected additional unwinding of the sharp increase that occurred before the Mideast war. The fixed-weight G.N.P. index, which assumes the components of output do not vary, was 3 percent in the second quarter, down from 5.2 percent in the first three months of the year.
The implicit price deflator, which captures changes in the composition of output but for that reason is not a pure gauge of prices, eased to 3.9 percent from 5.2 percent.
Perhaps most encouraging, suggested J. Antonio Villamil, the chief Commerce Department economist, was the fact that the fixed-weighted index for gross domestic purchases -- what is bought as opposed to what is produced -- rose only 2.4 percent after rising 3.7 percent in the first quarter.
 
Projected Growth
 "Modest inflation is a very positive development for the sustainability of the economic expansion," Mr. Villamil said, repeating an Administration projection that the economy will expand at a 2 to 3 percent pace during the second half of this year.
Reflecting the pickup in spending, however, the personal savings rate slumped during the quarter to 3.7 percent from 4.2 percent in the first three months of the year.
Other figures showe that G.N.P. expressed in current dollars rather than in 1982 dollars rose at a 4.6 percent rate in the second quarter to $5.62 trillion compared with a 2.2 percent rise in the first. The rate of real G.N.P. was $4.13 trillion.
Data included in the revision of the gross national product for the first quarter of 1991 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates:

HEADLINE: Reactors to Juice Cartons: Soviet Factory Adjusts

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PODOLSK, U.S.S.R., July 25

 BODY:
Across the Soviet Union, people are starting their days by popping open milk and juice containers that are produced here thanks to machines that used to produce sophisticated military components too secret to be discussed.
The Luch Experimental Works factory in this industrial city about 15 miles south of Moscow was an integral part of the vast and secretive military industrial complex, producing parts for nuclear reactors, lasers and metal optics used in advanced weapons systems. Now, as part of a joint venture with a Swedish company, the factory has been partially turned over to manufacturing machines that make cardboard containers for milk, orange juice, apple juice and guava juice. 
 Tetra Pak-Luch, as the joint venture is called, is a successful and apparently rare example of the Soviet Union's program to bolster its feeble economy and improve its deficit-riddled consumer market by converting military enterprises to civilian use as Soviet-American relations warm and new arms-control agreements are reached.
 
Secrecy and Ineptitude
 Operating in special areas of the plant marked off by cordons, Tetra Pak-Luch is an oasis of capitalism, a self-contained world of shiny tools, men in spiffy, pressed coveralls with the company logo and even imported toilet paper, a scene that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said he hopes to see replicated throughout the military industrial complex.
Defense Industry Minister Boris M. Belousov said last month that his ministry had significantly cut its military-related production -- for example, rocket launchers, tanks, armored personnel carriers -- and increased its production of, among other consumer goods, washing machines, tape recorders and perfumes.
He said that in 1988, civilian goods accounted for 35 percent of his ministry's industrial output, a figure he said would rise to 65 percent this year.
But Soviet and Western experts say the Soviet program to convert industry from military to civilian uses is marked by internal dissent, secrecy, bureaucracy and ineptitude that has vastly hindered this cornerstone of President Gorbachev's economic bailout blueprint, making it far from the economic triumph Mr. Belousov describes.
The vast military industrial complex is said by various informed experts to employ from 5 million to 8 million people in about 5,000 enterprises that occupy two percent of the country's territory and include about a third of all the enterprises in Moscow alone. This year the Supreme Soviet earmarked 96.6 billion rubles for the military industrial complex -- 35 percent of the Government budget.
But of the 400 enterprises scheduled for conversion, only five or six have actually been completely retooled, according to official sources, including Soviet television. It was not clear if that number included Tetra Pak-Luch, which once made not only reactor and laser parts but also things that employees said they could not discuss with a Western visitor.
Komsomolskaya Pravda reported recently that of the 120 products that were supposed to be manufactured by converted military industry enterprises, only 28 were actually being produced.
Successes like the Tetra Pak-Luch joint venture are rare examples, and even there, the Swedish partners say they must continuously break through bureaucratic logjams to push the project along, including getting special permission to come to work on weekends.
 
Some Kind of Military Tie
 One of the Swedish employees here said such weekend restrictions and other observations over several months have led him to conclude that despite protestations to the contrary, the plant continues some kind of military-related production, an idea supported by a couple of Soviet employees here who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"There are many odd things here at Luch that add up to that in my mind," said Bengt O. Hakansson, technical factory manager of Tetra Pak-Luch. "There are all these militia men with guns walking around patrolling the grounds. I can't work on Saturday or Sunday unless I request permission in advance. There are all these workshops I can't go into."
One Soviet employee said that raw materials for the plant were still provided through the Defense Industry Ministry, even though company officials say it has been at least two and a half years since the plant stopped military-related work and lost its defense industry sponsorship. The employee said workers were told to approach their jobs as they did before "conversion," and to regard their jobs as secret.
Whether the parts of the Luch Experimental Works not engaged in the Tetra Pak joint venture continue to serve the military industrial complex secretly is less important as a fact than as an example of the deep secrecy surrounding military enterprises and the conversion process, a secrecy many experts say is one of the chief obstacles to successful conversion.
 
Sharing Military Technologies
 For so long, the military and civilian sectors were kept so separate that despite the sophistication and technological advances of the military industries, that expertise was never brought to the long-suffering civilian economy.
"For too long we have been loading one side of the boat and now it has begun to sink," Vsevolod Avduyevsky, chairman of the National Commission for Assistance in Converting War Industries to Civilian Production, told a Soviet reporter last year.
An article in 1989 in the journal Kommunist caused a big stir in the military industry with a suggestion that for conversion to succeed and for the economy to rebound, the military-related ministries would have to share their technologies with the civilian sector.
The managing director of Tetra Pak-Luch, Aleksandr Panchenko, said his plant was so cut off from other enterprises even within the nation's network of military factories that there was a scramble among top management to find new products and new clients when they were told about two and half years ago that their military orders were being cut.
 
Top Military Opposition
 "We worked in a micro-world," said Mr. Panchenko, who insisted that all Luch's military ties had been severed.
But he said that while people at Luch sought new partners -- eventually hooking up with Tetra Pak through the Ministry of Atomic Power and Industry -- other military factories' directors were sitting back, sure that conversion was a passing phase.
"Everyone thought that they were protected, that the state was a bottomless barrel with inexhaustible resources," he said, sitting in the sleek Tetra Pak-Luch offices, enjoying the product of his enterprise's foresight, drinking imported Brazilian coffee, smoking foreign cigarettes, dressed in British sportswear. "Now these guys come to us to find out what steps they should take. They see that this is all for real and if they don't save their own factories nobody else will."
Yuri A. Ryzhov, a deputy in the Supreme Soviet who headed a legislative commission on national security, said the top military leaders oppose conversion because it erodes their power base and exposes their profligate management methods.
 
Testimony of Generals
 While some of the leaders publicly support the idea of stepping up consumer production at military plants, Mr. Ryzhov said, they continually find ways to undermine the process.
"Real conversion has no friends in the top structures of the Defense Ministry," he said.
Several years ago, when the Soviet leadership first introduced the idea of conversion, generals testified before legislative committees about the program's benefits, holding aloft pictures of baby carriages that were produced at missile factories and boasting that they were satisfied customers of washing machines built at military factories diversifying from their usual orders.
Now, leading generals often shrug off criticism of the conversion program.
 
Inappropriate Conversions
 "Your country has been fumbling with conversion for 40 years and still has no great solutions," a high-ranking general told an American military colleague during a visit to the Soviet Union this week by Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Opposition comes from places other than the top. Labor unions often protest a plant's conversion because on the whole, workers in military enterprises receive significantly higher salaries than their civilian counterparts and they object vehemently to the prospect of lower wages and possible unemployment.
But inefficient planning and a bumbling bureaucracy seem equally responsible for the conversion program's problems. Factories are often saddled with demands for producing things inappropriate to their technical resources. In one of the most outlandish cases, an enterprise that made components important for the Buran space shuttle was revamped to produce pots and pans.
"A factory should produce something that corresponds to its technical and technological potential," said Vyacheslav Malchevsky, production manager at Tetra Pak-Luch. "Pardon me, but if we were producing cosmetics or baby carriages, we would be floundering like all those other military enterprises."
But in the disjointed and crippled Soviet system, the benefits of success at Tetra Pak-Luch are elusive to the average shopper desperate for some evidence of an economic recovery.
"This country produces 24 percent of the all the world's milk and now we produce machines that can package all that milk efficiently and safely," Mr. Panchenko said. "But still, there's no milk in the stores."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Soviet Pact Signings

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
In addition to signing the first treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons, the United States and the Soviet Union plan to conclude at least three new agreements on cooperation in areas like space and aviation during the summit meeting in Moscow next week.
The White House said today that President Bush was also likely to present President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with the favorable tariff treatment that the Soviet Union has long sought, by announcing in Moscow that he is sending the Soviet-American trade treaty to the Senate for its approval. 
 The accord was signed by the two leaders in Washington in June. But Mr. Bush kept it on its desk until the Soviet Union enacted new legislation on emigration and met American concerns about other provisions of the agreement dealing with intellectual property rights.
The strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start, is to be signed by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev on Wednesday amid much pomp and ceremony.
At a separate meeting, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to sign three "memorandums of understanding," that will pledge new levels of cooperation in civil aviation crisis management, disaster relief and space exploration -- most likely in general terms.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev might also issue separate statements on the three economic areas in which the United States is most interested in aiding Soviet industry: oil exploration, the conversion of military plants to civilian use and distribution of food.

HEADLINE: Baker Addresses the Mongolian Parliament

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 26

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today became the first Western statesman to address Mongolia's Parliament, pledging support for its reform efforts and promising millions of dollars worth of United States aid.
"On behalf of President Bush and the American people, I come here today to lend our support and to work with you for the success of political and economic freedom here in Mongolia," Mr. Baker told a meeting of bot houses of Parliament in the capital, Ulan Bator. 
 Mongolia, an enormous land with a tiny population sandwiched between the Soviet Union and China, held its first free elections in 70 years in 1990. The ruling Communists were returned to power. Mr. Baker praised Mongolia as the first Communist state in Asia to initiate democratic reforms.
He pledged $6.4 million in aid to help Mongolia overcome a financial crisis created when its longtime mentor, the Soviet Union, withdrew crucial aid last year. He told the legislators that he would ask Congress to approve $10 million in additional aid to help tide Mongolia over.

HEADLINE: Chevron Profits Fall 40.7%; Shell Has Loss

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 26

 BODY:
The Chevron Corporation said today that its profits fell 40.7 percent in the second quarter. The Shell Oil Company posted its first quarterly loss since 1934, amounting to $68 million, after writing off $90 million for costs related to job cutbacks.
Other oil giants that operate mainly in the United States, as Chevron and Shell do, reported steep declines in earnings earlier this week for the quarter ended June 30. They included Amoco, ARCO and Phillips Petroleum. 
 Companies with bigger foreign operations, like Mobil and Texaco, reported comparatively smaller profit declines for the period, and Exxon posted a slight gain. They benefited partly from wider profit margins in refining and chemicals, and from higher natural gas prices in Europe.
Bernard J. Picchi, oil analyst at Salomon Brothers, said most leading oil companies would report lower profits for the rest of the year. Demand for gasoline and chemicals remains weak, and crude oil prices are likely to average far less than during the second half of 1990, he added.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
 Chevron

Net income for the nation's fourth-largest oil company fell to $384 million, or $1.09 a share, from $648 million, or $1.83 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. The spring quarter of 1990 was the third most profitable quarter in Chevron's history. Revenues for the San Francisco-based company rose 9 percent in the 1991 quarter, to $9.7 billion from $8.9 billion.
Kenneth T. Derr, Chevron's chairman and chief executive, said the company had a $16 million loss in refining and marketing in the United States. Pricing wars and lagging demand from a weak California economy were the biggest factors, Mr. Picchi of Salomon Brothers said. Chevron also said it had paid more to acquire crude oil for its refineries and had lost some refining efficiency because of unscheduled repairs.
Operating profits in domestic production rose to $65 million, from $43 million a year ago. The totals excluded a special gain from asset sales of $5 million in the 1991 quarter and of $48 million in the year-ago quarter. International operations posted earnings of $279 million, aided by $57 million from sales of reserves in Spain and the British North Sea, up from $167 million. Chemical profits fell to $36 million, from $65 million.
Chevron's share price fell $1.125 today, to $70.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
 Shell Oil

The nation's sixth-largest oil company said it lost $68 million in the quarter, after a special aftertax charge of $90 million to cover costs of severance programs and other expenses in paring 4,650 employees from its work force in the next 12 to 18 months.
The company earned $161 million in the second quarter last year. Revenues in the spring quarter rose 3.5 percent, to $5.35 billion from $5.17 billion. Shell Oil operates principally in the United States and is owned by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.
Frank H. Richardson said the Houston-based company was searching to pare costs in addition to the employment cutbacks announced July 1, which amounted to 15 percent of the work force.
"We are proceeding with the streamlining of our operations," he said.
The company, which operates the nation's largest gasoline retailing network, will likely post lower earnings in 1991 than at any time during the 1980's.
Refining profits in the second quarter fell to $5 million, from $73 million. Chemical profits declined to $58 million, from $90 million, but income from oil and gas production rose to $10 million, in contrast to a $22 million loss a year earlier. Capital spending rose to $791 million, from $650 million.

HEADLINE: States and Cities Fight Recession With New Taxes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Hard hit by recession, state and local governments are raising taxes and fees more steeply than they have in decades. The total amount to be raised this year may approach the $23 billion in Federal tax increases that Congress enacted last fall.
And despite all the political oratory about avoiding tax increases, public policy specialists say the trend is likely to continue because of the spiraling costs of education and prisons as well as health care and other social services.
 
A Wider Tax Net
 With expenses rising sharply and revenues plummeting, states and cities have cast their tax nets deeper and wider than ever before: 
 California faced a deficit of $14.3 billion, a figure that is almost as large as New Jersey's entire budget, and it increased income and sales taxes to take in a projected $7.3 billion, a state record. In Pennsylvania, the recession has for the first time in 30 years caused tax revenue to fall behind the previous year's. Still it could set a record in state tax revenue, as legislators are considering raising business, income and sales taxes by almost $3 billion to balance a $14 billion budget.
No sooner was the ink dry on New York City's $28.5 billion budget than city officials said that the $735 million increase in property and income taxes was inadequate and that they expected a $4.3 billion shortfall through fiscal 1995. Philadelphia enacted a new sales tax that is expected to bring in an additional $75 million to $90 million to help cover the city's chronic deficits.
Generally, cities and states are trying to tax everything that moves. California extended its sales tax to candy, newspapers, snacks and bottled water, Arkansas to used cars and New York to dating services. Delaware raised income taxes on non-residents, Wisconsin increased fees for hunting licenses and Oregon raised the price on copies of birth certificates to $13 from $10. New York City increased fines for fire code violations, Los Angeles raised taxes on real estate sales, Charlotte, N.C., raised taxes on meals in restaurants and Portland, Ore., increased park fees.
 
Recession the Culprit
 States and localities have acted, in part, because the recession has diminished their tax revenues, even as it has forced them to spend more on unemployment and welfare for those thrown out of work. The combination of declining revenues and increasing expenses this year created budget gaps in almost 40 states that totaled $40 billion to $50 billion; the amount of the combined budget gap, the difference between planned spending and expected revenue, shifted constantly as legislators added programs and reduced others.
States, whose fiscal years generally begin on July 1, appear to be closing half the gap with reductions in spending and the other half with increases in taxes and fees. Moreover, many budgets are precariously balanced on forecasts that a relatively strong economic recovery is under way.
Taxes or fees, or both, in the cities of nearly 40 strapped states also are expected to increase in 1992, although it is too early for estimates because most cities' budgets are on the calendar year. "I would be very surprised if this isn't a record year for city tax increases," said William J. Althaus, a Republican who is Mayor of York, Pa., and vice president of the United States Conference of Mayors.
The substantial tax increases, said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany, come as a result of the recession as well as the long-term shift in responsibility for national programs from Washington to state and local governments. He said that state and local taxes have risen to an estimated 44 percent of all taxes, excluding Social Security, that were paid by Americans in 1990 as against 32 percent paid in 1960.
"The trend for the 1990's in state and local taxes is up," Mr. Gold said.
Some governors say states cannot raise taxes quickly enough to cover the rising costs of programs that are required by Federal law. "It's like a dog chasing its tail," said Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania. "It never catches up."
 
A Call for Help
 Governor Casey, a Democrat, proposed the largest tax increase in this frugal state's history to help cover a 38 percent increase in the state's share of benefits paid under Medicaid, the federally mandated health care program for the poor, among other things. "The Federal Government has to give states more help paying for these costs -- it's as simple as that," he said.
Some public policy analysts disagree, saying that what is needed is further reductions in discretionary social service programs, not more money. "If the Federal Government steps out of the picture, there is no reason for states to step in," said Daniel J. Mitchell, an economist and a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington.
There is a consensus among public policy analysts that the state and Federal governments require far too many costly programs, although thare will never be agreement on just which programs are unworthy.
Still, it is primarily the recession, not increased spending, that has brought so many cities and states to their knees. State tax revenue, for example, grew by an average of only 0.9 percent in the first three months of this year; this was well behind the growth in the inflation rate of 5.2 percent, according to the Rockefeller Institute. New England and California had the deepest declines in revenue, and state revenue increases exceeded the growth in the inflation rate only in the Rocky Mountain region.
Some newly elected governors, including Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, a Republican who took office in January, criticize predecessors for not putting aside enough money in the booming 1980's. "It is disingenuous to say that states have been popped by an economic cycle," he said. "Taxpayers have a legitimate gripe when they ask: 'Why did you spend everything you could take from us in the good times and then raise taxes in the bad times?' "
Vermont is the only state without a law requiring it to balance its budget annually. It plans to take three years to resolve its fiscal problems with $75 million in spending reductions from fiscal 1991 and $85 million in sales and income tax increases. Officials say the tax increases will be rolled back in 1994 when they expect the deficit to have abated.
 
North Dakota Holds Spending
 But officials in some states say it is hard to save much money for future needs when there are always so many immediate problems. "How can you justify not meeting people's needs when there is a fairly decent economy?" asked Richard Rayl, director of the Office of Management and Budget in North Dakota. The state, whose economy has recently revived after an agricultural recession in the mid-1980's, balanced its budget this year by holding down spending on discretionary programs and without raising taxes.
Mr. Gold, at the Rockefeller Institute, estimated that state tax increases enacted for fiscal 1992, which began July 1 for 46 states, would bring in a total of between $17 billion and $19 billion. Such an increase would be the largest since 1971 when measured as a proportion of total revenue.
Pressures that will tend to keep taxes moving higher through the decade include annual cost increases of about 25 percent for health care, about 12 percent for corrections and about 8 percent for primary and secondary education, the National Association of State Budget Officers reports.
It has been a chaotic year, with nine states missing their July 1 deadlines for approving budgets and with state offices shuttered intermittently in Maine and Connecticut. In Pennsylvania, one of several states whose budgets are still incomplete, Republican and Democratic legislators have had shoving matches on the floor of the House of Representatives in Harrisburg, and about 79,000 state employees have been working without pay since July 1. Property tax rebates have been delayed in the state under a program for low-income elderly taxpayers, contractors have stopped work on roads and nursing homes have had to borrow money to stay in business.
Oregon, following the national pattern this year, imposed many new fees and raised scores of existing ones, including a $500 surcharge on state college tuitions; a $3 increase, to $13, for a copy of a birth certificate; and a 50 percent increase, to $3,000, for a license to transport radioactive waste.
 
High-Income Taxpayers Pay
 In addition to the many states that raised sales taxes and greatly expanded the taxes' reach, a handful, including New York, California, North Carolina, Minnesota, Missouri and Vermont, raised income taxes for high-income taxpayers. Connecticut, Tennessee, Texas and Florida are still considering enacting broad-based personal income taxes for the first time.
Relatively few states avoided raising taxes, and those that did were proud of it. "Indiana has weathered the most severe economic storm in a decade with our balances largely intact," said Gov. Evan Bayh, "and without raising taxes or shutting down government."
Massachusetts did not have to raise taxes this year, chiefly because tax escalations for this year were included in last year's $1.2 billion tax increase. And like many other states, Massachusetts may wind up balancing its budget, in part, by reducing aid to local governments.
"We could lose up to $360,000 of our $6 million school budget," said Robert B. Byard, superintendent of schools in Belchertown, a small town 15 miles northeast of Springfield. He said previous reductions in aid have forced the school district to charge high school students for busing, sports and use of the school swimming pool. Parents just finished building a $30,000 school addition with donated materials, and they are now trying to raise $23,000 to hire a sixth-grade teacher to reduce the class size below 33 students.
New Jersey, which stunned taxpayers last year with a $2.8 billion increase, avoided another one this year through several measures, including laying off as many as 3,000 workers and selling assets. In an unusual step, the state sold a four-mile section of Interstate 95 to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority for $400 million. The state repealed a sales tax on paper products that had stirred antitax advocates to rally in Trenton with rolls of unraveled toilet paper.
The National League of Cities reports that every year since 1988 more than two-thirds of the nation's cities have raised fees and charges and that more than 40 percent have raised property taxes in each of those years. Yet more than a quarter of the cities, large and small and scattered across the country, still face significant deficits this year, said Michael A. Pagano, author of the National League of Cities' recent survey of 525 cities.
The recession, which hit the Northeast first and hardest, has now jumped across the country, he said. "A greater proportion of Western cities have severe budget imbalances than do Eastern cities," said Mr. Pagano, who added that Western cities have exhausted their reserves and will likely raise taxes and reduce services by significant amounts next year.
"Cities in the Midwest and South are not missing the recession, but in comparative terms, it is less severe there," he said.

SOME STATES WITH TAX AND FEE INCREASES
 
Alabama: $173 million, mostly from sales taxes, which were extended to prescriptions, hospitals, nursing homes.
 
Arkansas: $300 million from sales tax on used cars, planes and mobile homes; new taxes on corporate income, gasoline and diesel fuel and tires. New landfill fees.
 
California: $7.3 billion in increased income and sales taxes. Sales taxes extended to snack food, candy, bottled water. Many higher fees, including vehicle registration.
 
Connecticut: $1.2 billion tax increase still being debated by legislators: either a new broadly based personal income tax or increasing existing taxes, like sales tax, and extending it things like haircuts and auto repairs.
 
Delaware: $96 million from several increased taxes on businesses, higher income tax for nonresident taxpayers and increased fees.
 
Idaho: $34 million, mostly from increased tax on gasoline.
 
Kentucky: $600 million over a two-year budget cycle from increase in sales taxes and personal and corporate income taxe.
 
Hawaii: $20 million increase from increase in gasoline tax.
 
Maine: $300 million in new taxes over two-year budget cycle from increases in income, sales and gasoline taxes.
 
Maryland: $90 million from increased taxes on cigarettes, capital gains tax, motor vehicle fees. Sales tax extended to soda sold in cups, food sold in school and hospital cafeterias.
 
Minnesota: $607 million from increased income and sales taxes, which were extended to cover many new areas including animal kennels and telephone paging services. Some of the revenue is set aside to help localities reduce property taxes.
 
Missouri: $385 million in taxes for education, raised through sales and income taxes.Voter approval necessary in Nov. 5th referendum.
 
New Hampshire: $130 in new taxes on businesses, utility-owned property, plus extensions of temporary sales tax on lodging and meals. Higher real estate transfer tax, higher surcharge on telephone calls
 
New York: $1.6 billion in new taxes on gasoline, natural gas and petroleum. Increased income taxes on high brackets. New sales taxes on computer software, telephone answering and dating referral services. New or increased fees and fines for auto license plates, traffic tickets, high school equivalency exams. 70 cents per month on every cellual telephone.
 
North Carolina: $637 million in higher personal and corporate income and sales taxes. Higher taxes on cigarettes.
 
Oregon: $189 million, over two-year budget cycle, in increased taxes on gasoline. Higher fees for hundreds of items from birth certificates to licenses for hazardous waste haulers.
 
Pennsylvania: $3 billion or so in tax increases still being debated by legislators. Would come mostly from new taxes on business, personal income, tobacco and alcohol and from extending sales taxes to cable television and long distance telephone calls.
 
Rhode Island: $127 million from corporate and personal income taxes, sales taxes, gasoline taxes.
 
Vermont: $85 million in increaseds (scheduled to expire in 1994) in sales taxes and income tax on highest brackets.
 
Wisconsin: $535 million in tax increases, over two year budget cycle is expected to be enacted. Increases in income taxes, corporate taxes, cigarette taxes, transfer fees on real estate, capital gains taxes.
 
CITIES WITH TAX & FEE INCREASES
 
New York City: $400 million in property taxes, $335 millon in income taxes, $20 million in many fines and fees, ranging from fire code violations to taxi medallions.
 
 Philadelphia: $75-90 million in new sales tax.
 
Los Angeles: $70 million in real estate transfer tax and fees.
 
Washington, D.C.: $48.8 million in taxes on utilities, cigarettes and increased fees for courts, newspaper vending machines, emergency ambulance services.
 
Charlotte, N.C.: $16.7 million from taxes on restaurants and hotels, water and sewer fees, and bus fare increases.
 
Portland, Ore.: $2 million from variety of fee increases, including those on park use and recreation.
 
San Jose, Calif.: $8.3 million from increased storm drain fees
 
Long Beach, Calif.: $16 million from increased taxes on electricity, water and natural gas
 
Phoenix, Ariz.: $8.6 million from fees on waste water and sanitation.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Looking For Giants

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
The Port Washington Public Library out on Long Island knows how to dampen a human's spirits. It has asked 50 people each to choose one or two books of the past 50 years "that have most profoundly affected the thoughts and actions of humankind."
 This is a reprise of an exercise the library conducted in 1942 when it asked 20 reading types to identify those books published between 1892 and 1942 that had "most profoundly affected the thoughts and actions of mankind." 
 One immediately notes that in 1992 "humankind" has replaced 1942's "mankind" in this competition. Is this perhaps the result of a profound impact on human thought created by a book? One immediately recognizes a concession to feminist demands that "sexism" be stripped from the language and wonders if the half-century may have produced a monumental feminist book. Betty Friedan's "The Feminine Mystique," perhaps?
 Yet something may be afoot that is more profound for humanity than feminism. Feminism's gains seem pretty much confined to women in Western, industrial societies. Affecting "humankind" requires touching a bigger percentage of earth's billions.
 If, however, we interpret the change from 1942's "mankind" to 1992's "humankind" as evidence that propaganda is on the march, we get to something more far-reaching. Has there ever been another age when people zealous to manipulate human thought and action have fought so tirelessly to control the language?
 George Orwell's "1984" did the great work of alerting us to modern tyranny's power to control popular thought by controlling the language. This of course is what the feminist language purifiers are also up to, though their political purposes seem somewhat nobler than Big Brother's, or Stalin's, or Hitler's, or even our Presidential campaign technicians who turn language into a weapon.
 Before putting "1984" on this list of important books, however, let's look at the library's 1892-1942 list. A quick glance suggests books had more weight back then. Here, for instance, are Hitler's "Mein Kampf," with its absolutely horrifying weight, and Freud's "Interpretation of Dreams."
 Then: William James ("The Varieties of Religious Experience"), Henry James ("The Golden Bowl"), Lenin ("Imperialism") and John Dewey ("Democracy and Education"), as well as Einstein on relativity, Admiral Mahan on sea power and Thorstein Veblen on economics.
 There were giants in those days. Have we then lived since 1942 in an age of midgets? One problem is that the literature of modern science and technology has been almost impenetrable to people outside the priesthoods that speak the lingo. As a result, any reader less assiduous than John Updike may be unaware of books of profound importance.
 I recall a friend, an engineer, in the late 1940's having his nose buried in a book by Norbert Wiener titled "Cybernetics, or Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine." It was, said my friend, a work of vital importance because it foreshadowed a new age when computers would change society.
 A glance left no doubt I would find it as baffling as Babylonic cuneiform, but now I wonder: Could this have been the book that has most profoundly affected the thoughts and actions of our entire half-century? Or perhaps there is some absolutely essential and utterly mystifying text on the chemistry of plastics without which today's world would be entirely different.
And where is the great book that caused the collapse of Soviet Communism? In 1942 Oswald Spengler's "The Decline of the West" ranked high on the library's list. We smile now at that title, but where is our own half-century's equivalent: "The Collapse of the East"?
 Of course the 1942 list had its duds. "The Golden Bowl," a favorite of that year's great-book selectors, now feels like paralysis by syntax. By contrast, James Joyce's "Ulysses," which changed our way of seeing the world, got only one vote, while Ernest Hemingway and Marcel Proust got none.
 Have we had a Joyce, a Hemingway, a Proust working out there, changing our vision, profoundly affecting humankind? I am afraid to say no, so sneakily change the subject with an even more vital question. Was there any book these 50 years past that influenced humankind's thoughts and acts half so much as the dimmest television show?

HEADLINE: Our Treadmill Economy

BYLINE: By Alfred E. Kahn; Alfred E. Kahn, professor emeritus of political economy at Cornell, was President Jimmy Carter's adviser on inflation.

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
America's international financial standing seems better than it did six months ago, but we have not made significant progress in solving our fundamental economic problems.
When the sum total of our assets abroad and foreign claims on us were recalculated from their original cost to their present market value, our net international indebtedness at the end of 1990 turned out to be not the more than $600 billion previously reported but $361 billion. We also learned that in the first quarter, our trade balance showed a small surplus, the first surplus since 1982. 
 Considered alone, this is all good news. The foreign trade deficit has been dropping each year since 1987, when it peaked at $162 billion; it was $99 billion in 1990 and is expected to reach $50 billion this year.
The fact remains, however, that every year since 1982 we have bought more goods and services from the the rest the world than we have sold to it. Foreign countries have financed those deficits by acquiring claims on us such as Government securities, bank deposits and ownership of factories in this country.
That's not necessarily unhealthy. We don't assess a corporation's economic health by looking only at the liability side of its balance sheet. The question is whether in incurring liabilities it adds to assets.
Has America used the infusions of foreign capital to increase its national assets? The answer is distressing. Over the last four decades, the percentage of our gross national income devoted to consumption has increased steadily and frighteningly, from 58.5 percent in the 1950's to 64.6 percent in the 1980's.
During those decades, the percentage of the G.N.P. we've used to increase our assets has remained just about constant, and net business investment in plant and equipment dropped about 20 percent.
The increase in consumption has been balanced by a decline in Government purchases of goods and services, from 25.1 percent of the G.N.P. in the 1950's to 19.8 percent in the 1980's. But while these purchases were declining, transfer payments such as interest on the Federal debt and entitlement programs like Social Security have risen dramatically.
The percentage of the G.N.P. accounted for by Government outlays for investment -- on education, the infrastructure, research and development -- has dropped very sharply. It would have made perfectly good sense for all levels of government to have gone into debt to make such investments; it would make sense today. But that is not what we have been doing.
Instead, we have transformed ourselves from the world's largest creditor to the world's largest debtor, not to prepare ourselves better for the future but to live better today.
When we look at the reasons for the sharp drop in our annual balance-of-payments deficits since 1987, again we find little ground for comfort.
The first was the economy's very sluggish growth in 1989 and 1990, followed by the recession -- not a healthy way to cut imports. Second, we received $23 billion from our allies in the first quarter of 1991 toward the cost of the gulf war -- no cause for rejoicing, unless we plan to go into the business of exporting troops as well as munitions to foreign governments.
The third reason for the drop in the balance-of-payments deficit has been the 35 percent decline in the foreign exchange value of the dollar. This means we have had to price our exports more and more cheaply, compared with what we pay for imports, as the net inflow of foreign capital has diminished.
A society that is unwilling to live within its means and that devotes a steadily decreasing portion of its income to saving and investment in physical plant, technology and people will inevitably be restrained once the flow of credit from the outside begins drying up. The restraint may be supplied by an increase in the prices it has to pay for its imports or by recession or depression or both.
That is exactly what has happened. We are now paying the price, in unemployment and in more and more families needing two wage earners to make ends meet. No wonder The Economist summarized the trends in our real incomes over the last 15 years under the headline "Running to Stand Still."

HEADLINE: Music in Review

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Magic Circle Opera Repertory Ensemble
Theater of the Open Eye at the West End Synagogue,
270 West 89th Street
Through tonight 
 With the recession nipping at the heels of many of New York's small opera companies, both commitment and a large measure of faith are required to start a new one. The Magic Circle Opera Repertory Ensemble, formed last year, has those qualities, and promising young singers as well. The group's triple bill of short 20th-century works, performed with piano accompaniment, opened on Thursday evening.
 The works, which were directed with a sensible simplicity by Jane Lind, were well suited to an ensemble of modest means: Samuel Barber's 10-minute "Hand of Bridge" requires only a table and a deck of cards. Gustav Holst's "Wandering Scholar" and Kenneth K. Guilmartin's "City of Gypsies" are nearly as spare.
In the Holst, the scholar of the title, trying to scare up some dinner, interrupts a tryst between a lecherous priest and a farmer's wife. He is sent on his way but returns with the farmer and repays his inhospitable hostess by pointing out the priest hiding in the haystack. The vocal quartet -- Mark Singer as the farmer, Michelle Couture as his wife, Glenn Braun as the priest and Ross Solomon as the scholar -- sang Holst's folk-tinged arias appealingly and with clarity of purpose.
The Barber, with a libretto by Gian Carlo Menotti, looks in on the private thoughts of two couples playing bridge: Sally obsesses about a hat; her husband, Bill, thinks about his mistress; Geraldine ruminates about her mother, and her husband, David, fantasizes about getting rich. Barber's music has an urbane, light-spirited jazziness that the singers seemed comfortable with. They were Madeline Tsingopoulos, Peter Castaldi, Mary Cidoni and Mr. Singer. Iris Savernik, a dancer, gave the individual fantasies a sense of dimension.
Mr. Guilmartin's "City of Gypsies," a 50-minute work composed in 1985, is a beguiling fantasy based on poetry by Federico Garcia Lorca, with the poet as its central figure. The music, richly chromatic with traces of flamenco figuration, creates a mysterious atmosphere that suits the Garcia Lorca poetry beautifully. And Mr. Guilmartin has arranged the texts as a coherent dramatic narrative that ends with Garcia Lorca's death.
The most notable singers in the large cast were Mr. Castaldi, whose portrayal of Garcia Lorca gave him greater opportunity than in the Barber to show off his attractive lyric tenor; Miss Cidoni, a powerful soprano, and Miss Couture and Miss Tsingopoulos, whose tandem choruses as the storytellers were especially alluring. Martha Wade's accompaniment was slightly heavy-handed in the Holst, but she caught the spirit of the Barber and the Guilmartin nicely.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene from Magic Circle Opera Repertory Ensemble's production of "A Hand of Bridge." From left were Peter Castaldi, Mary Cidoni, Madeline Tsingopoulos, Mark Singer and Iris Savernik, front. (Susan Calvin/Magic Circle Opera)

HEADLINE: New Influx of Cuban Refugees Is Creating Strains for Florida

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 26

 BODY:
Almost daily, newspapers and television stations here tell of Cuban refugees plucked by planes or cruise ships from the Florida Straits as they bob along in rafts or inner tubes. But deteriorating conditions on the island have also provoked a much larger and virtually invisible emigration -- tourist charter flights from Havana -- that has begun to strain this city's resources.
 Because a growing number of Cubans are arriving here as visitors and overstaying their visas, Florida officials are pressing the Federal Government for access to $35 million placed in an Immigration Emergency Fund that was established after the last big influx of Cubans a decade ago. 
But to their frustration, so far the Bush Administration has refused to authorize release of any of the money, even as American and Cuban policies continue to encourage people to flee one of the last bastions of orthodox Communism.
 "It is unfair in the extreme to ask one community to bear the consequences of a national policy on refugees, just as it would be if there were an emergency brought on by a hurricane or flood," Senator Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat, said recently in an interview. "A natural disaster is an act of God, but this immigration crisis is primarily an event controlled by the Federal Government."
 
Backlog of Visa Requests
 According to the State Department, which processed a total of 38,000 visa requests from Cuba in 1990, American diplomats in Havana have issued 36,000 visas since the 1991 fiscal year began Oct. 1 and still face a backlog of 28,000 applications. The figures include neither Cubans who have obtained visas at other embassies, like Caracas and Mexico City, nor the 1,378 Cuban rafters who have been officially admitted to the United States this year.
 No precise figures exist on how many of the Cuban tourists, whose airfares and processing fees are paid by relatives here, have overstayed their visas to settle in Miami. But Federal and local officials estimate, based on immigration and other statistics, that at least one-third of the visitors do not return to Cuba on their scheduled flights. This creates what Mr. Graham called "a silent, gradual influx" that has gone undetected because the Immigration and Naturalization Service's policy of not completely monitoring departures of foreigners from this country.
 "We're looking at an influx of approximately 40,000 people this calendar year," said Joaquin Avino, who as county manager is the chief government executive of Dade County, which includes Miami. "If we can put people on the moon, why can't we measure people going out?"
In May, the most recent month for which data are available, 7,600 Cubans arrived in Miami on chartered flights, as against 2,500 in May 1990. "The number of flights has increased, as has the size of the aircraft being used and the number of companies involved," said Antolin Carbonell, who tracks the situation for the Dade County Aviation Department.
 
Fears of a New Mariel
 Among local officials, the upsurge has led to fears of what they call "a new Mariel," a reference to the 1980 boatlift that brought 125,000 Cubans to the United States. The cost of assimilating that influx of asylum-seekers was borne largely by city, county and state governments here, and Florida officials say the Federal Government still owes them $50 million or more.
 The Miami area is already seeing "an increased demand for the whole spectrum of medical and social services, from job training to emergency housing" because of the new arrivals, Mr. Avino said. "If you suddenly put an additional 30,000 people in a community, that creates an additional stress on the fire department, the police department, the parks and public works."
 Government officials here said that whatever money they get from the Federal Government will be destined for hospitals, emergency housing programs and schools. Senator Graham, who plans to introduce legislation next week that would make it easier for Florida to obtain money from the fund, and other members of Florida's Congressional delegation are continuing to lobby both the White House and the Department of Justice.
 Leaders of the Cuban-American community and government officials expect the exodus to continue, perhaps at an even faster pace. Deprived of Soviet subsidies, Cuba is facing its worst economic crisis since Fidel Castro seized power in 1959, and his government has responded with increased political repression and a declaration of a "period of special austerity" that includes food and fuel rationing.
 As a safety valve, the Cuban Government has over the last 18 months gradually lowered to 35 from 65 the age at which Cuban men qualify to visit relatives in this country. Lisandro Perez, a professor of sociology at Florida International University who has studied Cuban emigration, said the younger Cuban arrivals who have grown up under Communism are likely to prove more difficult to absorb than previous waves of Cuban refugees because "their readiness for competition in the United States" is limited.
 Under existing legislation, both the President and the Attorney General have the power to declare an "immigration emergency," the latter when the number of requests for political asylum rises by 1,000 in any quarter. But many of the new arrivals apparently prefer to bypass the long and complicated asylum process in favor of a special adjustment program that exists only for Cubans, thereby keeping the number of asylum requests below the legal threshold.
 "We don't solicit political asylum claims," said Duke Austin, a spokesman for the immigration service. "That is not a function of the I.N.S." Mr. Austin also said it would be unfair to entering Cubans to deny them the right to the quicker and easier adjustment procedure "only to force the asylum numbers up just so a community can get the impact funds."
 
Dade County's Problems
 The new influx of Cubans comes as Dade County is still struggling to absorb a previous wave of politically inspired immigration that flooded the Miami area in 1989. County officials estimate that more than 100,000 Nicaraguans, the bulk of them anti-Sandinistas requiring public assistance, have settled in southern Florida in the last decade.
 The rapid increase of the Nicaraguan population in 1989 forced one major hospital here to write off more than $5 million dollars in health care bills and also led to an enrollment surge in the Dade County public school system. Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, has estimated the total long-term costs of settling just the Nicaraguans at more than $100 million.
 "We just can't continue to foot the bill," said Kate Hale, director of the Metro-Dade Office of Emergency Management. "There are Federal Government programs in place for just this type of situation, and we are frustrated by what appears to be the Federal Government's attempt to manipulate loopholes that preclude us from gaining access to funds designated for this purpose."

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
James Brown Is Up to His Old Tricks

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
Here's a concept: write songs and arrangements, convene a band, rehearse it hard, take it into a big room and record it. It's been a long time since that was standard operating procedure for a rock album, now that producers are hooked on the convenience of machines and performers like to tinker with endless overdubs. But James Brown knows he made his best music that way. On "Love Overdue" (Scotti Brothers 79392 75225; all three formats), his first album since he was paroled from imprisonment for aggravated assault and weapons violations, he ignores high-tech pop fashion to make the funk he wants.
It's a wise choice, wiser than the one Aretha Franklin makes on her new "What You See Is What You Sweat" (Arista 8628; all three formats). Any pop performer whose career stretches into the decades, like Mr. Brown or Ms. Franklin, sooner or later has to decide whether to continually update the music -- to try and keep up with the market -- or to follow private instincts and see whether the public pays attention. In trying to stay contemporary, Ms. Franklin, one of America's greatest singers, has landed in a limbo somewhere between Whitney Houston and Patti Labelle. And while "Love Overdue" won't eclipse Mr. Brown's finest music of the 1960's and 1970's, its better songs prove he can still summon his old vitality. 
 In the past, Mr. Brown, who is probably in his early 60's, has tried keeping up. During the 1960's, he was a radical who redefined the rhythm of popular music; his genius for syncopation transformed mechanical, repeating riffs into pure motion, lean and unstoppable. He was reduced to billing himself as "the original disco man" in the late 1970's, although his kind of funk had more sophisticated polyrhythm than most disco. His big 1985 hit, "Living in America," produced by Dan Hartman, sounded like a freeze-dried, reconstituted version of what Mr. Brown had done better more than a decade earlier. Mr. Brown is billed as both producer and executive producer on "Love Overdue," as well as writer and arranger on four songs and arranger on a fifth; he's clearly in charge.
He doesn't care about being contemporary, although his strategy is appropriate; the rhythms of his old hits are now reappearing as the foundations of innumerable rap songs. On "Love Overdue," his own efforts look back to the mid-1960's and before -- not, oddly, his startling modal funk from the late 1960's and early 1970's, which inspired performers from George Clinton to Miles Davis to Prince. "Love Overdue" concentrates on rolling rhythm-and-blues akin to "Please, Please, Please" and chugging gospel-rock that recalls "I Got You (I Feel Good)."
When Mr. Brown returned to public performing with his pay-per-view television special in June, he made a public display of spirituality in a backstage prayer with the Rev. Al Sharpton. "Love Overdue" continues his overt gospel references. In "Move On," over chattering guitars and punching drums, Mr. Brown trades call-and-response vocals with a gospelly choir; the song is about wanting to change a frustrating life -- no job, a recession -- but it's easy to imagine Mr. Brown dancing down the aisle of a church as he announces, "I'm getting happy!"
"It's Time to Love" directs its love to the Christian trinity and holds a surprise; partway through, it breaks into a propulsive rumba, complete with vocals in Spanish. "Standing on Higher Ground," a song by Hollie Farriss and Danny Countess whose title is a gospel staple, seems to refer both to Mr. Brown's recent travails ("Once we were up/ Lately we been down") and to the gulf war ("We'll clean it up/ Trying to get peace to last"), before it invokes "the Good Book."
The easy rhythm-and-blues is reserved for love songs: "Show Me," written by Mr. Brown and his wife, Adrienne; "You Are My Everything," which has one odd jazzy chord at its peaks, and Henry Glover's "Teardrops on Your Letter," a bluesy song originally recorded by Hank Ballard. Mr. Brown sings it in husky, after-hours tones, answered by woozy horn and guitar riffs.
Mr. Brown's gift for drama is intact; "Teardrops" climbs from calm reflection to screams, and he drives the rhythms of "Move On" and "Higher Ground" with lung power, note bending and canny timing. His singing only sounds false in the songs by other writers that try to be more contemporary: "Dance, Dance, Dance to the Funk" and "Later for Dancing." The lyrics seem to embarrass him; he would rather be a pious elder statesman.
"Love Overdue" is a short album, just 36 minutes of music, and except for the salsa of "Standing on Higher Ground," it doesn't offer much that can't be found on the magnificent retrospective album "Star Time" (Polydor). But as a token of Mr. Brown's confidence and cantankerousness, it's heartening.
Ms. Franklin's "What You See Is What You Sweat" is as awkward as its title. Like Ms. Franklin's recent albums, it tacks a 1960's oldie -- this time, a sassy, jazzy version of Sly and the Family Stone's "Everyday People" -- onto a group of new pop songs, with name-brand guests as duet partners (Luther Vandross and Michael McDonald). Ms. Franklin is handed over to a grab bag of producers. There are dance-pop hitmakers like Elliot Wolff and Oliver Lieber (Paula Abdul) and diva-ballad auteurs like Burt Bacharach and Carole Bayer Sager, but they seem to have handed Ms. Franklin the rejects from other projects.
The Lieber-Wolff "Mary Goes Round," about a man-stealing woman, comes out of a high-school mentality that the 49-year-old Ms. Franklin has probably outgrown, while the ballad "Someone Else's Eyes" offers banal psychobabble. The overblown "I Dreamed a Dream" shamelessly devalues Martin Luther King's words with its spokenintroduction: "I had a dream."
Ms. Franklin also wrote two songs. She produced her "You Can't Take Me for Granted," which lilts along after its overblown intro, letting her voice soar over a gospelly backup choir; despite the harp glissandos, there's a glimmer of a relaxed, mature Franklin style that the rest of the album disowns. Her "What Did You Give," produced by Michel Legrand, goes awry from its first words -- in French -- to its strings and finger cymbals and synthesizers. Not that synthesizers per se are the problem; Luther Vandross's computer-driven "Doctor's Orders" is negligible, but at least it sounds like fun.
The frustrating thing is that Ms. Franklin can still sing like no one else; her voice swoops, curves, coos, growls, caresses. Amid the trendy and pretentious trappings, it's a beacon of emotion. Trying to keep up with the latest pop only holds her back.
