HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Shot of Cultural Adrenaline at Lincoln Center

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

 BODY:
Maybe it wasn't all that surprising that the management of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, after watching real-estate developers get rich for two decades by filling its neighborhood with high-rise apartments, would decide to get in on the act itself. After all, why shouldn't the institution whose real estate has made profits for so many others get a little something for its own balance sheet?
 Thus was born 3 Lincoln Center, 60 stories of black glass recently completed at the corner of 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, intended as the most upscale of the many upscale condominiums in the Lincoln Center neighborhood -- and the only one with the right to call itself an actual part of the performing arts complex. Three Lincoln Center, which has been marketed as "the first opportunity to live at Lincoln Center," is, like Museum Tower, which rose in 1983 over the Museum of Modern Art, a case of commerce being put to the service of art. 
 Like the museum, the tower was not constructed, nor is it owned, by the cultural institution that gives it its name. It is an entirely private development built on air rights over a portion of the center's land, bought for $48.5 million by a developer, the Stillman Group of Scarsdale. But in exchange for allowing the Stillman Group to sell condominiums with the Lincoln Center address, Lincoln Center got more than this hefty cash payment. The developer also agreed to put up the basic structure for a second new building, a 28-story, stone-clad tower containing dormitory rooms for the Juilliard School of Music, nine dance studios, rehearsal studios, new theaters for the Lincoln Center Film Society and the Lincoln Center Institute, a recital hall, and offices.
 This smaller tower, now being occupied, is a stunning addition to Lincoln Center, which has not expanded in any significant way since the completion of the original performing-arts complex in the late 1960's. Known as the Samuel B. and David Rose Building, this structure contains so much in the way of new facilities that it's not hard to see why the administration of Lincoln Center felt moved to make one of those Faustian pacts with the world of private real-estate development.
 A film theater, an experimental theater, dance studios, first-class dorm rooms to make Juilliard competitive with non-New York institutions -- all urgently needed, and what's the harm of another condominium tower? Small price to pay for a shot of cultural adrenaline .
 There's no real answer to this question of the values of such trade-offs, at Lincoln Center or elsewhere. We like to pretend that our cultural institutions are clean and pure, not sullied by their connections to commerce, and the presence of a tower like 3 Lincoln Center stands, like Museum Tower, as a constant reminder that they are not. Surely that is why buildings like this are troubling -- they force us to confront a reality we might prefer to ignore. When a corporation writes a check to a cultural institution, the process of subsidy is invisible; when support comes in the form of a real-estate deal, its results stare us in the face at every moment.
 And no one could greet with enthusiasm the notion that the Lincoln Center neighborhood needs another high-rise condominium. The presence of the taller of these two new buildings can't really be justified on urban-planning terms ; it's only a question of the trade-off. Is it worth squeezing a 60-story tower into this part of Manhattan to bring Lincoln Center some financial stability, and to give the center and its users a panoply of superb new facilities?
 Well, maybe. For now, let me say only that this trade-off, problematic though it may be, has been accomplished with considerable planning skill. The main credit goes to the architects, the firm of Davis, Brody & Associates, who were responsible for the overall plan and for the design of the Rose Building; Harman Jablin Architects designed the 3 Lincoln Center condominium tower.
 The $150 million Rose Building, which has been named for the founders of Rose Associates, the New York real-estate firm whose chairman, Frederick Rose, made the major gift toward its construction, serves as a base on which rises both its own shorter tower and the tall condominium tower. The two towers are altogether different in design, and therein lies the first of several thorny architectural problems.
 The architects were faced here with contradictory goals. The taller tower, 3 Lincoln Center, is the economic engine driving the whole project, but if the place was to make any sense symbolically it had to appear less conspicuous than the Rose Building, which, though much smaller, was more fully a part of Lincoln Center.
 Thus the Rose Building was sheathed in Minnesota stone, a cream-colored stone similar to the travertine of the original Lincoln Center buildings (which was not duplicated mainly because it has proved to stand up poorly to New York winters). From a short distance the stone seems virtually identical to the rest of Lincoln Center, and it allows the Rose Building to aspire to be campanile to the performing arts complex.
 The condominium tower is set slightly back, a bit farther from Lincoln Center Plaza, and it is sheathed in black glass, with some accents in red and others in stone to tie it subtly to the Rose Building. It doesn't quite disappear, to be sure, but it is about as deferential as a 60-story skyscraper can be. The corner facing Lincoln Center is sliced off at a 45-degree angle, a gesture that reduces the apparent bulk in a further act of deference.
 From a distance it all works, and the two buildings appear to be distinct and only distantly related. The black tower is the classiest condominium tower in the neighborhood, as befits Lincoln Center. The Rose Building tower is a solid-looking box, visually much more a part of Lincoln Center than of the overall West Side skyline.
 And to give it its due from close up, the design of the Rose Building does a lot to ameliorate some significant flaws in the original Lincoln Center design. Lincoln Center has always turned its back toward Amsterdam Avenue; this complex opens at least partially toward it. In the original design the pedestrian bridge over 65th Street was a bleak concrete wasteland; as part of this project Lewis Davis, the architect in charge, has redesigned the bridge, the plazas around it and the entire entrance sequence to Juilliard to make of all of this a viable urban presence.
 Alas, once you get beyond these urbanistic strengths there is not a lot of magic to this structure. On the skyline it is solid and workmanlike, but it is a triumph of architectural logistics much more than a triumph of architecture. In many ways the most interesting thing about this building is not its presence as an esthetic object but the brilliant intricacy with which the dance studios, auditoriums, rehearsal halls, dormitories and offices have been intertwined.
 This is a three-dimensional jigsaw puzzle of a building. Every floor in the base is different, which is a tough enough architectural problem in itself. But not only were the spatial needs completely different, so were the clients, since each floor had what was, in effect, a different organization calling the shots -- the New York City Ballet for its segment, the Lincoln Center Film Society for its portion, for example. The architects seem to have pulled off a masterwork of diplomacy in getting it all to fit. And the result of this effort, if not the most striking event on the skyline, can only enrich and strengthen the city's cultural presence at a moment when the need could not be more urgent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: 3 Lincoln Center (black glass) and , in front, the Rose Building. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The Office Market;
The Gloom Persists On Offices

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
CHEMICAL BANK had ardent suitors. George Klein hoped it would move to the office complex he plans to build at Times Square. Douglas Durst hoped it would move to a site that is mostly under his family's control, cater-corner from Bryant Park. Stanley Stahl hoped it would remain in his skyscraper at 277 Park Avenue.
The courtship ended this month in a striking twist that left the city's commercial landlords with one less headquarters for their rent rolls. Chemical will simply move its main offices across the avenue and into Manufacturers Hanover Plaza, which is owned by its merger partner. 
 It is not known yet whether the bank will vacate any or all of the 800,000 square feet it occupies at No. 277, between 47th and 48th Streets, when the merger takes effect. That space is under lease until July 1994.
But the consolidations within the merged bank, whose workforce is to shrink about 14 percent, will affect its extensive presence around the city. Some 70 branches will probably close and hundreds of thousands of square feet of office space could be thrown into an already glutted market.
Some 56.7 million square feet are now available in Manhattan, the Edward S. Gordon Company has found. That is as much space as in the entire office market of San Francisco. And it represents an increase of 5.5 million square feet -- the equivalent of two Empire State Buildings -- from this time last summer.
When will the market improve? It may take years, the optimists say. From where will the tenants come to support a rebound? No one is quite sure.
What confidence there is seems to based mainly on the certainty that markets are inherently cyclical; that if there are valleys, there will just as surely be peaks.
Today's valley is deep. The overall availability rate in Manhattan is 18 percent, Gordon's figures show. And that figure considerably understates the situation in two of the most troubled sub-markets: west midtown, which continues to sag from the weight of skyscrapers built before the West Side zoning incentives expired (but after the market had peaked), and the financial district, which is still feeling the effects of a devastated securities industry.
In the financial district, the vacancy rate is 24.4 percent, according to Gordon. On the West Side, the figure is 27 percent.
"The extended construction cycle and current contraction in demand could cause the vacancy rate to rise to nearly 19 percent before the market begins to bottom out by the mid-1990's," wrote Therese E. Byrne and David Shulman, in a recent analysis of the market, published by Salomon Brothers.
"IF we use the 1970's decline as a clock, we are only four years into a decline that could last as long as eight years," the Salomon report stated. "In terms of magnitude, as of year end, the contraction in financial-services employment is already equal to that of the 1970's. But we are not so optimistic as to think that the down cycle is over."
"Both Wall Street and banking are in the process of restructuring their activities," wrote Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. He noted that the financial-services sector had about 50,000 fewer jobs than three years ago -- with 60 percent of the decline coming from Wall Street firms and the rest from banking.
"The process continues with no end in sight," he said, "a shrinkage in jobs that reverberates throughout the economy."
"There's going to be no question about an abundance of sublease space available as a result of the mergers and consolidations," said Barry Gosin, president of Newmark Real Estate Services, which reports 56.2 million square feet of available space.
"However," Mr. Gosin said, "in the next six months to a year, there will be a lot of tenants making commitments to the city in significant blocks of space, as did Sony. For the next two to three years, we'll be muddling along probably at the same level."
Mr. Ehrenhalt shied away from predictions. "The forecasting track record," he said, "does not offer much in the way of precision. The economic crisis of the 1970's came unheralded by the forecasters, as did the resurgence that followed."
"The Rudins are betting on cycles," said Lewis Rudin, whose family real-estate concern owns nearly 7 million square feet of office space, about 9 percent of which is currently available. "There was the same mentality in 1974, 1975, 1976 -- that it's not going to happen anymore."
"The European mentality, the Far Eastern mentality, the South American mentality of the rich movers and shakers is that New York is the place to be," Mr. Rudin said, "because it's a cosmopolitan, international city. Why is Galeries Lafayette opening in New York? Why is Takashimaya building on Fifth Avenue? Why is Regent Hotel building on 57th Street? Those are the signs."
Indeed, the market is not entirely becalmed. James S. Vanderslice, of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage, believes he has discerned the "first sign of revival" in mid-Manhattan. The vacancy rate dropped to 16.2 percent in June, from 17.4 percent in May. That is the first month-to-month drop since last October. "Significantly missing this month," he wrote, "was the addition of any major large blocks of space."
Even 1540 Broadway, whose emptiness is particularly noticeable because of its prominent position on Times Square, may be filling up. Ian Bruce Eichner, the developer of the 44-story skyscraper at 45th Street, said earlier this week that "there are major negotiations going on, as we speak, with two separate tenants that would commit to all or substantially all of the building."
The 860,000-square-foot skyscraper has been vacant more than a year. The lenders, Citicorp and a syndicate of Japanese banks, began a foreclosure proceeding about six months ago that is still pending.
The largest lease signed in June was by Katz Communications for 180,000 square feet at 125 West 55th Street, Harry Macklowe's new tower near the Avenue of the Americas.
The next largest lease was signed by Sun Life Insurance of America for 54,000 square feet in 733 Third Avenue, the Durst family's 31-year-old building at 46th Street. "We see the market becoming more active," Douglas Durst said. "It's not returning to the rents of a few years ago, but it is certainly returning to the activity of a few years ago."
Increased activity does not, however, necessarily mean decreased vacancy. The Park Avenue sub-market, for instance, experienced a slight increase in leasing in the first half of this year, compared to the same period in 1990; to 467,000 square feet, from 441,000 square feet. Nevertheless, so many big blocks became available that the net result was an increase of 885,000 square feet of vacant space, Gordon's figures show.
As Mr. Durst noted: "It's a lot of moving around. I don't see a great deal of additional absorption. I think we'll have to wait for the economy to improve a bit more for that."
"Obviously, the prospects for new office space are not very bright at the moment, so we feel that major moves will constitute a good chunk of work," said Richard M. Kielar, senior vice president of Tishman Realty & Construction Company.
As an example, he cited the recent deal between A.T.&T. and Sony USA, which is to lease the whole 674,000-square-foot tower on Madison Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets. It was built in 1982 as the telephone company's headquarters.
THE lease for the skyscraper, whose broken-pediment roof makes it one of the more distinctive on the skyline, begins Jan. 1, by which time A.T.&T. will have moved 1,100 employees who are now at 550 Madison to other buildings in New York City. The company has said it "will continue to maintain its headquarters" in New York.
At the time of development, A.T.&T. was given a 10-year property-tax abatement, valued at $42 million, by the city's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board, with the understanding that the tower would be used as the phone company's headquarters and not rented. On July 8, as it confirmed the Sony deal, the company turned over a $14.5 million check to the city, representing the value of taxes forgiven since 1987.
It is too early to tell what Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover will do with their space once they merge under the Chemical name. But it is worth noting that they are spread through midtown and downtown.
Chemical has roughly 1.5 million square feet in 55 Water Street, at Old Slip, owned by the Reichmanns; 500,000 square feet in 95 Wall Street, at Front Street; 325,000 square feet (the entire building) in 52 Broadway, at Exchange Place; 250,000 square feet in 380 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets; 150,000 square feet in 633 Third Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets and 150,000 square feet in 30 Rockefeller Plaza, between 49th and 50th Streets.
Manufacturers Hanover owns its 1.4 million-square-foot tower (the former Union Carbide Building) at 270 Park Avenue, directly across from Chemical's headquarters, and Four New York Plaza, a 900,000-square-foot building at Water and Broad Streets. But it also leases 410,000 square feet in Two Grand Central Tower, 140 East 45th Street; 397,000 square feet in 450 West 33rd Street, at Tenth Avenue; 273,000 square feet in 130 John Street, at Water Street; 262,000 square feet in 40 Wall Street, near William Street and 124,000 square feet in 55 Water Street.
Another question hanging heavily is the fate of Morgan Stanley, which has yet to decide between staying in New York or moving to Stamford, Conn. Its main office is in 1251 Avenue of the Americas, between 49th and 50th Streets, It also has space in 1221 Avenue of the Americas, between 48th and 49th Streets; 1633 Broadway, between 50th and 51st Streets; 55 Water Street and One Pierrepont Plaza in Brooklyn.

LENGTH: 1559 words

HEADLINE: When New York State Becomes a Stockholder

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
WHEN Regeneron Pharmaceuticals announced this month that it was beginning construction of a new plant here, two ranking state officials were on hand for the occasion. The plant will manufacture drugs that Regeneron will be testing for the treatment of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and Lou Gehrig's diseases, as well as for other nerve disorders.
Vincent Tese, the State Commissioner of Economic Development, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came to the company's headquarters here to represent the state's $250,000 support of Regeneron, and to describe government investment techniques that are as up to date as the neuroscientific work being done by Regeneron researchers. 
 The state had not simply made a loan, Mr. Tese said. It had made an equity investment in Regeneron, "and we now own 80,000 shares of your stock."
He got a laugh when he added: "During the recent budget negotiations the asset looked so good, some of the legislators wanted to cash in. But not us. We know when we have a good investment."
 
'Little Piece of the Action'
 Mr. Cuomo said the state had never previously made equity investments. "But recently we took a piece of a baseball stadium in Buffalo," he said. "Our deal is, we'll put up the money but we're going to take a little piece of the action; so if you get a franchise, we want the profit.
"The profit would not be for us: the state can't declare dividends. But we can use the money for people who are disabled. Or have more money to invest in the next Regeneron, and the one after that."
Addressing the scientists who had gathered for the occasion, Governor Cuomo said: "We want you to return the money we lend to you. And we want profits and dividends, too, if they are there to be had."
He twitted Mr. Tese for suggesting a reluctance to sell the state's Regeneron stock. "I ought to explain that we also invested in Clestra," Governor Cuomo said, referring to a high-technology company in Syracuse. "Clestra stock went to the moon, but Tese bailed out early."
In fact, the state made a handsome profit on the Clestra investment, receiving $185,000 for its $90,000 investment. Clestra produces contained environments for sterile assembly procedures and will provide technology for Regeneron's new plant here.
 
State's 'High-Tech Squad'
 Clutching a mock stock certificate representing the state's 80,000-share investment in the pharmaceutical company, Mr. Cuomo said, "We're not going to make that mistake with Regeneron."
The executive director of the New York State Science and Technology Foundation, H. Graham Jones, described Regeneron as typical of the companies the foundation had sought to help through its "hi-tech squad," the Corporation for Innovation Development. "We try to get industry and universities to work closer, help technology-based industry get started and keep the companies in New York State, all of it while maintaining an informal investment limit of $250,000 per company," Mr. Jones said. The corporation has invested more than $10 million in 46 companies since 1983, and has drawn an additional $49 million in matching grants from private investors.
In one sense, Regeneron represented a risk for the state because "in the bio-tech field, they either click or they don't," Mr. Jones said. "This one has clicked; it seems to have a magic touch. The company doesn't even have a product yet and they're attracting investments from all over."
Three years ago Regeneron consisted of Dr. Leonard S. Schleifer, now its president and chief executive, and three associates working in a former superintendent's apartment with buckling floors on York Avenue in Manhattan. Today, with 109 researchers among its 122 employees, it occupies space previously filled by the Union Carbide Corporation in a scientific/industrial park on Old Saw Mill River Road.
 
State Support Called Crucial
 Union Carbide, with corporate headquarters in Danbury, started building the Tarrytown site in 1959. Six years ago it sold the complex, leasing back about half the space for three divisions still functioning here. Edward B. Harris, director of administration for Union Carbide's Tarrytown site, said that Regeneron was one of a dozen companies renting space.
The state's support in 1988 was crucial, Dr. Schleifer said, enabling the fledgling company to resist bids from the high-technology centers near Boston and in Silicon Valley near San Francisco.
"We were also being wooed to go to Texas, where we could have had all the land we wanted almost for nothing," he said. "But we thought New York had a great environment, and the fact that there were not a lot of biotechnology companies was a tremendous advantage to us, because those people really interested in doing this sort of thing would not have to relocate great distances. So we sort of captured the local market, which is quite extensive."
Albany's support also generated $5 million in matching funds from private investors and that was followed by links with two major companies. In 1989, the giant Sumitomo Chemical Company of Japan bought $4.4 million of Regeneron stock and paid $5.6 million for product development. Last fall a biotechnology company in California, Amgen, made an investment commitment of up to $53 million in Regeneron over the next five years.
When Regeneron became a publicly traded company in April, it raised $99 million on its first trading day, the second largest amount ever raised by a biotechnology company in its initial public stock offering. (The largest amount, $115 million, was raised by the Cetus Corporation in 1981.) This pleased but did not surprise Dr. Schleifer, who speaks of his company as taking a new approach to developing drugs that could alleviate the symptoms, if not cure the diseases, that affect the nervous systems of 6.5 million Americans.
 
Maintaining Nerve Cells
 "The pharmaceutical industry has tended to focus on small molecules, which work to a limited extent, but which do not act to promote the survival of a nerve cell," he said. "Traditional drugs are designed to replace the natural molecules, called neurotransmitters, which nerve cells use to communicate between themselves. Regeneron's product candidates are nerve growth proteins, which act to maintain the vitality of the nerve cells themselves."
In the case of Parkinson's disease, for example, neurons in the brain carrying a substance called dopamine degenerate and die, resulting in a lack of coordination, trembling and rigidity. Current drugs mimic or enhance dopamine, reducing the symptoms of the disease, but over time the brain responds less and less to the increased dopamine and the patient's condition worsens.
These therapies do not treat the underlying causes of Parkinson's, which are not known. But in animal cells in the test tube, Regeneron has shown that a growth factor for nerve cells -- which they call BDNF, for brain-derived neurotrophic factor -- can promote the survival of the dopamine-carrying neurons that degenerate in Parkinson's.
 Articles in two leading scientific journals recently described discoveries made independently by two groups of researchers, at Regeneron and at the University of Southern California. Both used BDNF, which was first isolated in 1989 by two scientists at the Max Planck Institute in Munich, Dr. Hans Thoenen and Dr. Yves Barde.
When the Regeneron researchers added BDNF to brain cells in a test tube, they discovered that it stimulated the cells affected in Parkinson's disease. BDNF was also found to protect those cells from being killed by MPTP, a toxic drug that causes symptoms of Parkinson's disease in laboratory animals.
 
Brain Cells May Be Dormant
 Parkinson's experts are especially interested in the new findings because of evidence that many cells in the brains of Parkinson's patients are dormant or dying, not dead.
Dr. Jesse Cedarbaum, a neurologist who is program director of the clinical affairs group at Regeneron, said the company's advisory team included three Nobel Prize winners: Michael S. Brown and Joseph L. Goldstein, for their work in cholesterol metabolism, and Arthur Kornberg, for work involving genetic codes.
The discovery stage is followed by "producing for research," which Dr. Cedarbaum said was being done in existing quarters but would be transferred to the new plant. Research-level production is followed by laboratory experiments and then the clinical trial stage.
This last step requires a go-ahead from the Federal Drug Administration and has three phases: administering the drugs to a small number of patients to learn how safe the drug is and how it is tolerated; expanding the patient group to 200 to determine dosages; and, finally, using thousands of patients.
"After that, you can request approval to market the drug," Dr. Cedarbaum said. The first of the test phases can take six months to one year; the other two can last one to two years each.
"In light of AIDS," he said, "the F.D.A. has promulgated fast-track regulations to compress the process from five years to two or three years for diseases where there is no treatment and which are fatal or severely debilitating.
"That's something we're hoping to do for the sake of patients suffering from diseases like Alzheimer's disease and Lou Gehrig's disease, for which no effective treatment currently exists."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Too Early to Ski But Not to Save

 BODY:
While visitors to the Berkshires of western Massachusetts sweltered in the heat this month, one of the region's ski areas announced a 20 percent discount on season passes for next winter. The offer was from Jiminy Peak in Hancock, which said the discount is available to skiers who purchase their passes by Tuesday. Season passes are available for weekends, midweek and night skiing as well as combinations of these periods. For a ski-anytime season pass, individuals will pay $394; the prices then gradually rise until Nov. 16, when it is $492. Two adults in a family will pay $675 instead of the Nov. 16 price of $844 and a family of five will pay $1,342 instead of $1,677. The area described the discounts as a response to "tough economic times." Passes can be purchased at Jiminy Peak's main ticket office or by telephone, (413) 738-5500, with a credit card. The number of weekend passes is being limited to 900.

HEADLINE: Style Makers;
Susan Sloan, Antiques Guide Publisher

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO

 BODY:
Susan Sloan is convinced that undiscovered treasures are sitting in antiques shops all over New England. The trick, she says, is to look beyond the quilts and weathervanes.
"There is wonderful potential for discoveries if you look for items outside the scope of Americana, like continental and Asian antiques," said Miss Sloan, author of "Sloan's Green Guide to Antiquing in New England." "A lot of trade was done here in previous centuries." 
 Miss Sloan, who is 46 years and a former administrator at a Chicago options arbitrage firm, began publishing her annual guide in 1989, two years after moving to Boston. An enthusiastic collector of antique silver, she was dismayed that there was no comprehensive guide to antiquing in New England. So she decided to write one.
In 516 pages, her 1991-92 guide describes 2,500 dealers, auction houses, antiquarian booksellers and flea markets. It also has a calendar of antiques shows, itineraries for antiquing tours, maps and profiles of major art and antiques institutions.
Miss Sloan, who is working on the 1992-93 guide, to be published Nov. 15, said three distinct trends are shaping New England's antiques business: the region's sluggish economy has forced a number of dealers to band together in multiple-dealer shops; more and more collectors are bypassing dealers and buying directly at auction; and flea markets are proliferating.
The current guide, priced at $14.95 and distributed by Globe Pequot Press, is sold at bookstores nationwide. It can also be ordered for $17.95, including postage and handling, from the Antique Press, 9 Brimmer Street, Boston, Mass. 02108; telephone (800) 552-5632.

HEADLINE: The Economy Lives, but Will It Ever Dance Again?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
It May Be a Recovery, But It's Less Than Robust
The recession is over and the recovery is here, according to everyone from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan to New York real estate agents. But hold the bubbly and break out the beer. Most economists expect the kind of slow, shuffling climb that will cause many to wonder if the recovery will stick around come Labor Day. 
 "The indicators are mixed in any recovery," said Roger E. Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc., an economic consulting service. "The weaker the recovery, the greater the proportion of negative reports." Indeed, the news last week that the gross national product grew at a trivial 0.4 percent in the spring fanned fears that the recovery was sputtering.
 The economists at DRI/McGraw-Hill are a shade more upbeat than the blue-chip consensus of economic forecasters. Even so, they expect the economy to expand at a 3.5 percent rate over the next year -- a crawl compared with the 6.5 percent average for the first year of any post-war recovery.
Three forces will probably hold down the pace of recovery. One is a hawkish Federal Reserve and an Administration that has not seemed inclined to bolster the economy with tax cuts or job programs. Another is the legacy of shaky debts from the overbuilding in many of the nation's commercial real estate markets. Finally, there is no 1980's-style consumer spending spree on the horizon: Households are forming more slowly and saving is already low.
 
A Battle of Nerves - The Consumers', That Is
 In retrospect, the first stirrings of a recovery began last winter, only a month or two after the Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve and the International Monetary Fund had declared a recession. Though the economy was free-falling, hundreds of thousands of jobs were disappearing each month and the headlines were dire, the forces that first tipped the economy into recession were beginning to recede.
Alan Greenspan drove down short-term interest rates. Long-term rates eased as well. The money supply, which had barely increased during the fall, took off. Oil prices plunged, taking inflation down with them. The consumer price index, which spurted at a 10 percent rate in October, actually fell in March.
Most important, the Persian Gulf war ended in victory for the United States. Foreigners snapped up the dollar and investors celebrated by sending the war-bludgeoned stock market back to old highs.
Because this recession, more than any in memory, was brought on by a case of nerves, a brightening in consumer spirits was critical. Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait caused the biggest one-month plunge in American consumer confidence that had appeared the survey's history. When oil prices surged after the invasion, consumers expected a repeat of the 1973 and 1979 oil crises, a surge in inflation and deep recession.
Their fears were self-fulfilling. Consumers stopped buying big-ticket items that could be postponed, namely houses and cars, and business panicked too, cutting production last fall at an even faster rate than sales were declining. The better economic mood, in essence, set the stage for a reversal of fortunes.
 
And It's All Coming Out of the Saving Rate
 Consumers, who dragged the economy into the recession, appear to be pulling it out again. That's the indication from Friday's G.N.P. report for the second quarter.
After falling for two consecutive quarters -- one of the worst retrenchments in post-World War II history -- consumer spending rose at a robust 3.6 percent. Outlays for big-ticket items jumped even faster, by 5.2 percent. "The mood shift led to strong consumer spending, particularly on cars, furniture and other durables whose purchases were postponed when consumers thought the sky was falling, " Mr. Brinner said.
Spending bottomed out in January, the month the air war against Iraq began and oil prices plunged. Despite the fact that companies were cutting deeply into their payrolls, consumer spending rose in February as employees' worries about layoffs lifted.
First to recover was home buying. As mortgage rates dipped below 10 percent, housing became more affordable than at almost any time in more than a decade. By February, buyers were straggling back to car dealers' lots, and the traffic really picked up when manufacturers started offering better deals in May and June. Consumers began buying a little more of everything else, too, though the pattern has been erratic from month to month.
Initially, consumers were not spending because they were any flusher. One indication: Consumers, whose income was falling or stagnant, managed to do more shopping by saving even less of their take-home pay. The saving rate has slipped to less than 4 percent recently, from around 5 percent last summer.
 
So When Will Mores Hands Be Put to Work?
 Consumers may have the will to keep on spending. All they need is the way -- fatter wallets. That will depend on the prospects for jobs and inflation.
As in past recessions, the labor market has been the last to show signs of improvement. When consumers started spending again, businesses did not immediately rev up production and rehire laid-off workers. Instead, companies filled orders by dipping into stocks on shelves and in storerooms -- to the tune of a $21.2 billion annual rate this spring, not much less than in the fall and winter. Industrial production did not turn up until April. Even then, businesses relied on on overtime, not extra hands, to churn out the goods.
Companies finally started to add to their payrolls, but not until May. Payroll employment swelled by 119,000 that month, the first increase since last summer, before falling by 50,000 in June. If that net expansion is not revised away in next week's employment report, said Mr. Brinner, the recession's final month may well turn out to have been April.
A slow recovery is likely to mean, among other things, that job growth will be less robust than after the 1981-82 recession. DRI/McGraw-Hill expects the number of payroll jobs to grow just 1 percent next year, compared with 2.6 percent in 1989. And the forecasters do not see the unemployment rate, which reached 7 percent in June, dropping below 6 percent until after 1992.
The number of jobs is likely to grow more slowly for another reason. As the continuing stream of layoff announcements shows, companies in the defense, computer and service industries from banking to airlines, are cutting payrolls, consolidating operations and pushing fewer workers to produce more products.
The good news is that income, especially wages, has been edging up since March. And DRI/McGraw-Hill's forecast is for income after inflation to advance at an average 1.5 percent annual rate.

LENGTH: 1853 words

HEADLINE: All About/Baby Formula;
Price-Fixing and Other Charges Roil a Once-Placid Market

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
For decades, infant formula was a placid, magisterially profitable industry with a captive market of newborns. It operated pretty much out of the public eye. But all that has changed dramatically.
Now, formula makers are routinely referred to by critics as an "oligopoly." Two giants, Abbott Laboratories and Bristol-Myers Squibb, share almost 85 percent of the market. They and the handful of companies who divide what's left stand accused of a variety of misdeeds and sharp practices, ranging from undermining infant health to price-fixing and bid-rigging to gouging the Government to unfair marketing tactics. 
 The industry steadfastly denies charges of collusion and is sanguine about its future.
"We look at formula and breast-feeding as complementary," said Robert C. Gelardi, executive director of the Infant Formula Council, an Atlanta-based trade association. "There will be a need for formula."
Analysts say that Government investigations into price-fixing and the introduction of competitive bidding for Government contracts in recent years have cut into the 25 percent profit margins the companies in the $1.7 billion industry were once thought to have made on formula. But infant formula remains a steady source of cash for manufacturers and analysts believe a recent lurch in profits is most likely over.
"The damage is done and it is lasting, but the negative trend is now factored into growth rates and profit margins," Neil Sweig, a formula industry analyst at Brenner Securities in New York, said of the impact of competitive bidding for business with the Agriculture Department's Women, Infant and Children nutrition program. "It is still very profitable," he added.
 
The Basic Game
Getting Parents To Pay $500 a Year
 Baby formula, for the most part, is modified cow's milk with nutrients added, although there are some soy-based products for infants who are allergic to cow's milk.
A tiny part of the market comprises specialty formulas for babies with serious digestion problems. Most formula comes in "ready-to-feed," concentrated and powdered form. A 32-ounce, ready-to-feed typically costs about $3.00 in a supermarket.
For all the emotional attachment parents often have for their baby's formula, nutritionally the major brands are virtually identical; their contents are regulated by the Infant Formula Act of 1980.
The largest formula maker, with 50 percent of the market, is Ross Labs, a unit of Abbott Labs, which makes Similac and Isomil, a soy-based formula. Second, with about 35 percent, is Mead Johnson Nutritionals, a Bristol-Myers unit which makes Enfamil.
Wyeth-Ayerst, a unit of American Home Products that makes Nursoy and SMA, follows with 9 percent. Two companies share most of the remaining market: Carnation, the Nestle unit that sells Good Start, and Gerber, which markets a formula made by Bristol-Myers.
Demographics keeps the industry grounded in reality: the driving force of the business is the birth rate, and since the baby boom ended in 1964, the rate has only spiked up once or twice, creating evanescent boomlets. But the industry also tends to respond heavily to social change. The widespread acceptance of infant formula by women in the United States began with the rise of scientific medicine in the early part of the 20th century. In the belief that feeding babies was too complicated and important to be left to laypeople like mothers, medical practitioners touted scientifically concocted formula, given in sterilized bottles.
Breast-feeding declined for several decades and bottomed out in 1970, when fewer than 20 percent of new mothers were breast-feeding their infants. A surge of research since the late 1960's, however, convinced pediatricians that mother's milk is the "optimum" food for infants.
"There is evidence it protects against infection. It obviously has a psychological value. And it is economical," said Dr. Antoinette Parisi Eaton, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics. "It costs about $500 a year to feed an infant on formula."
The pediatrics community has managed to reverse the decline in breast-feeding -- in the early 70's, it began to trend back up, and by the early 80's, nearly half of the newborn population was being breast-fed. But the increased entry of women into the work force has slowed the trend, to the benefit of the formula industry.
"More moms are working moms. They may stay home with the baby, but when they go back to work, the majority wean them off breast milk and start them on a formula," said Jeffrey Isaacs, director of research at Robert Everszcq & Associates, a market research firm in Los Angeles. A.A.P. research indicates that breast-feeding has dipped to 45.6 percent.
 
Marketing
Loyal Customers, Two Approaches
 The physicians' preference for breast-feeding creates a marketing problem for the industry: how to position a slightly-less-than-optimal product.
The three leaders -- Abbott, Bristol-Myers and American Home -- market directly to physicians or hospitals, who usually give the formula free to mothers. The strategy works: research shows that 90 percent of women stick with the brand the hospital gives them. "We don't do consumer promotion," said Cathy Babington, a spokeswoman for Abbott Labs, in an oblique reference to the new and controversial practice of marketing directly to nursing women, which the industry giants oppose.
Industry leaders can remain aloof from the vulgar area of consumer marketing, in part, because of their market dominance. Three years ago, Carnation began advertising its weaning-formula entry into the market directly to consumers.
"It was a shock to the physician community," said Mr. Isaacs, the market researcher.
The move helped precipitate soul-searching by such organizations as the American Academy of Pediatrics, which decided not to accept contributions from companies that market directly to consumers. "We oppose direct marketing because of our concern that it will adversely affect the decision to breast-feed," said the A.A.P.'s Dr. Parisi Eaton.
Gerber followed with its own ads in 1989, and the two companies did indeed manage to gain a share of the market, albeit with minimal effect on the shape of the market.
Carnation says it is simply giving women -- the decision-makers on infants feeding -- information and choices: the ads commend breast-feeding as the best form of infant nutrition, but also offer formula as the alternative when breast-feeding is difficult or not the mother's choice.
 
Public Money
Some Competition Is Creeping In
 Part of infant formula's enormous profitability is the result of its involvement in the the special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known for short as WIC, an Agriculture Department nutrition program for low-income women and their children.
Although definitive figures are not available, at least one analyst estimates that the WIC program accounts for 40 percent of the formula market. For many years, in the relaxed regulatory atmosphere of the Reagan Administration, the leading formula makers quietly sold their products through state-administered programs -- at retail prices.
Since 1986, however, several states have instituted competitive bidding for rebates, with varying degrees of resistance from the formula industry. It is the companies' contention that the dependence on a single supplier developed in the competitive bidding process diminishes freedom of choice for poor women.
The bidding controversy focused attention on the industry's pricing strategies. Between 1980 and mid-1991, infant formula producers more than doubled their prices. During the period, formula prices have gone up an average of 11 percent a year, while the price of milk has risen an average of just 2 percent annually, according to a study by the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington, a group that studies poverty-related issues. For its part, the industry contends that milk is only a small part of steeply rising production costs.
An investigation of pricing policies is pending at the Federal Trade Commission. All the companies deny engaging in collusion.
The revenue impact of competitive bidding on formula makers is impossible to determine because the companies don't break down financial data by unit. But after an initial shock, analysts say, the companies adjusted to the new order.
There is no question, as some feared, that WIC will be left without providers or that the giants will drop formula. "The companies are forever tied to this business," said Neil Sweig at Brenner Securities.
 
 
 
NESTLE -- BATTLING THE BOYCOTTS
 The consumer boycott of Nestle S.A. ended in 1984 with the multinational company's compliance with the World Health Organization's guidelines on marketing infant formula. And activists relaxed for the first time since the boycott began in 1977.
But the rest period didn't last long. Almost immediately, according to its critics, Nestle, the world's biggest infant formula maker with 50 percent of the overseas market, began backing off on its promises. In 1988, the boycott was called again.
"It was reinstituted to finish what we started," said Nancy Gaschott, a consultant for Action for Corporate Accountability, a group based in Minneapolis and New Haven that took over from Infact, the Infant Formula Action Coalition, which had gone on to other issues.
Critics argue that Nestle routinely violates several provisions of the World Health Organization's infant feeding codes, which were formulated to promote breast-feeding as the healthiest way of delivering infant nutrition.
The practice of distributing formula to mothers in the hospital, which is widespread in the United States as well as in developing countries, is a particular concern. Critics believe that formula given with the imprimatur of a hospital encourages women to choose bottle-feeding over breast-feeding -- to the detriment of their children.
"Children in developing countries live in very insulting life situations," said Doug Johnson, the consumer activist who founded Infact and is now the board chairman of A.C.A. "Water is often unavailable or contaminated. It is virtually impossible to sterilize bottles. Formula tends to be overdiluted. Children are not getting the nutrition they need." But Nestle regards infant formula as essential. "In developing countries, mothers do have to go out to work. They must supplement breast milk," said Dr. Thad Jackson, director of issues management at Nestle.
The boycott's financial impact on the $36 billion company is virtually impossible to calculate. Nestle says it is nil and that the company is working with the World Health Organization and the United Nation's Children's Fund to support healthy infant feeding practices. "We should be working together to provide the best options for vulnerable mothers instead of fighting," said Dr. Jackson.
But activists have forced Nestle to the table before. And this month, the boycott got a lift from an influential quarter: the Church of England joined in.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 21-26

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
THE ECONOMY
 
A Victory -- Perhaps -- for the Baby Bells 

 The Baby Bells are on the verge of winning the right to lose as much money on information services as they want. On Thursday, a Federal judge lifted a ban that has kept the regional Bell companies from bringing electronic yellow pages, banking, shopping and news into the nation's homes. The judge, Harold H. Greene, acting reluctantly at a higher court's direction, warned that the Baby Bells could turn their dominance of local phone service into information service monopolies. Maybe so, but, if the ruling stands on appeal, the companies will enter a business where Sears, I.B.M. and several media companies have lost millions. The phone companies do have the advantage of a line into every home, said Jack Grubman, an analyst at PaineWebber. "But you have to be careful and not get carried away in fantasyland here," he said. "The only thing we know for sure is there are going to be a lot of up-front costs." The most likely winner: A.T. &T., already the Baby Bells' largest supplier and now also the owner of NCR's technology for bank, airline and other computerized transactions.
 
Cyborg Wants Better Billing
 
Wait 'til Arnold Schwarzenegger's agent hears about this: a cyborg paid at a higher rate than the star. At Industrial Light and Magic, 35 computer animators spent 10 months producing images of the T-1000 cyborg for the movie "Terminator 2: Judgment Day." I.L.M., a very special special-effects shop owned by George Lucas, the movie producer, received at least $5 million for the job, while Mr. Schwarzenegger is said to have earned at least $12 million. But the computer-generated cyborg spends only about five minutes on screen -- at $1 million a minute -- and Mr. Schwarzenegger about two hours, leaving him with just $100,000 a minute. The cyborg was evidently programmed with a fine knowledge of Hollywood deal-making. In future films, I.L.M. promises to seek better billing as well as bigger bucks.
 
 The Sidewalk Tunnel Network
 
As most areas of construction are crawling out of the recession, one specialty appears strong. Sidewalk tunnels, to shield pedestrians from construction, renovation and crumbling facades, keep going up and over everywhere, especially in New York. At this rate, it might soon be possible to walk from Wall Street to Washington Heights in a downpour without an umbrella. With other projects scarce, architects and designers are taking the time to giving some canopies a more appealing look; postmodernists like to mimic arches and moldings from the buildings behind. Critical acclaim sometimes follows. The American Institute of Graphic Arts has recognized two sidewalk tunnels, including one, crowned by a colorful jumble of boxes, so fitting in front of a new Crate & Barrel store that the shop owners could do worse than to leave it up.
 
Kuwait: Back in the Oil Business
 
Oil is about to trickle from Kuwait, and possibly Iraq. The Kuwaitis have doused enough flaming wells to resume exports, although slowly at first. And the Bush Administration publicized a plan last week to ease a ban on Iraqi sales of petroleum. Reports of starvation and disease have persuaded some American officials that the restrictions are hurting the Iraqi people more than President Saddam Hussein. With other nations pumping more to compensate for Iraq and Kuwait, many in the oil industry say that renewed exports by these Persian Gulf foes can only push prices down further. Gasoline prices, adjusted for inflation, have already fallen to historic lows.
 
The Unimpressive Recovery
 
The road to recovery may be bumpy, but economists generally do not expect another dip. A report last week that the G.N.P. grew four-tenths of 1 percent during the second quarter -- "kind of blah," said Samuel D. Kahan of Fuji Securities -- brought more shrugs than scowls. Industrial production, housing and trade numbers the week before were all more encouraging. Businesses are cautiously selling off their inventories, retarding growth now but reducing the prospect of production cuts later.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Building a Better Soviet Car
 
Millions, perhaps a billion, in Western currency is only part of what the Soviet Union hopes to earn from selling at least 30 percent of its largest auto maker. Under a plan announced last week, Moscow also wants help in building better cars.. The Lada sedans made by the Volga Automotive Plant Association ride as rough as second-class bunks on Soviet trains. "Once you open the country up to all sorts of communications and knowledge, you can't keep producing 1936 Packards," said Herbert S. Levine of the University of Pennsylvania. The auto maker will be the first major Soviet company to sell a large stake to foreigners. Don't look for many other large businesses to follow; few would attract such strong foreign interest.
 
The Soviet Union surprised its Western industrialized friends by applying for full membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank just a week after winning their backing for a more limited association with these agencies. American officials reacted as if guests invited for drinks had suddenly blurted out, "Well, what's for dinner?"
 
China's Trade Status
 
China, the largest importer of United States wheat and a major exporter of textiles, is likely to keep its trade privileges. A bill restricting trade with China failed to gain enough Senate votes to overcome a likely veto.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
NCNB Lures C&S, Finally
 
After his first bid for C&S failed in 1989, Hugh L. McColl Jr., NCNB's chief executive, denied that his hard-charging style had clashed with Bennett A. Brown's more countrified ways. Told that Mr. Brown, the C&S chief, prided himself on his backyard barbecues, Mr. McColl said, "I hope I'm invited." Last week, Mr. Brown and his board finally agreed to serve Mr. McColl. C&S, now called the C&S/Sovran Corporation, will be merged into NCNB in a $4.3 billion stock swap. The resulting institution, dubbed Nationsbank, will be America's third largest, with assets of about $116 billion, dominant by far in Texas and the Southeast. Mr. McColl, trying hard to sound chummy, said that most of the company's cutbacks would come through attrition. But C&S/Sovran employees will find that working for this former marine is no picnic. He plans to immediately fly in his NCNB platoons to attack C&S/ Sovran's troubled loans.
 
Detroit's Losses, as Predicted
 
The Big Three auto makers together lost more than $1.3 billion in the second quarter, but that was no worse than expected. Still too many auto plants, too few buyers. Industry analysts say the companies will continue suffering from the ravages of the recession for many more months to come. Like losing baseball teams, the auto makers are already predicting a stronger season in 1992.
 
Flight of the 'Vulture Fund'
 
 Three partners who had managed a Goldman, Sachs "vulture fund," which bought securities of troubled companies and then pressured the companies to restructure, are flying to other fields. Goldman had decided to wind down their Water Street Corporate Recovery Fund after the firm's predatory behavior made some clients nervous. Alfred C. Eckert 3d and Mikael Salovaara are forming their own vulture fund, while Kenneth D. Brody plans to concentrate on private investments, charities and Democratic politics.
Computer Makers' Lucky Losses
 Computer makers are finding few better ways to support their stock than confessing to all their troubles. Unisys and Digital Equipment shares jumped last week after the companies announced heavy cutbacks and billion-dollar charges. The Unisys Corporation said on Tuesday it was taking a $1.2 billion charge against second-quarter earnings, for a total loss of $1.3 billion, and laying off 10,000 of 70,000 employees. On Thursday, Digital came in with a $1.1 billion charge, resulting in an $871 million loss, and plans for laying off more of its 121,000 employees. Years ago, said George Elling, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, major write-offs caused shares to plummet. Now, he said, "everyone thinks they're wonderful, and the larger the better; it's a strange phenomenon." Analysts are far more optimistic that Digital's pains will prove therapeutic, restoring profitability.
 
Delta Is the Favorite
 
Wall Street is still betting on Delta Air Lines to succeed in buying European routes and the shuttle from Pan Am World Airways. Trans World Airlines bid $310 million last week to Delta's $260 million, but T.W.A. has only narrowly avoided following Pan Am into bankruptcy. The Delta bid is "real money," said Thomas Longman, an analyst at Bear Stearns, "and creditors can see cash in the near future."
 
B.C.C.I's Concealed Losses
 
British regulators said the Bank of Credit and Commerce International resorted to bribery and phony loans -- "probably one of the most complex deceptions in banking history" -- to conceal billions in losses. American and British officials fended off accusations that they had responded too slowly to the scandal.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
How the Dollar Spells Relief

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
This month's break in the dollar's rally could offer some relief to global investors, even if the pause is brief.
For starters, the decline in the dollar will help the German Bundesbank, which is struggling with rising inflation, and could also take some pressure off interest rates throughout the rest of Europe. 
 German consumer prices rose 4.5 percent over the last year, the highest increase since the 12 months ending in December of 1982, according to a preliminary report released by the German Government on Friday. A stronger mark would lower import prices in Germany, easing some of the pressure on the inflationary front. This is not likely to mean a near-term cut in rates there, but it could delay or reduce any increase. And it could prompt action elsewhere in Europe by giving countries like France and Britain more maneuverability than the Germans in reducing interest rates. Since the dollar began to fall, Britain has cut rates once.
For the international investor, a weaker dollar and the potential for lower interest rates abroad could make the United States stock and bond markets a little less attractive while enhancing the appeal of Europe and even Japan. The falling dollar means Europeans' American investment gains are worth less when converted into their home currencies. For Americans, the opposite is true. Investments abroad get a little lift when translated back into dollars.
The decline in the dollar started with an ambush in mid-July of aggressive and orchestrated dollar selling in the foreign exchange market by central banks in Europe and the United States. It weakened further because of disappointing economic data, which has raised concern that the American recovery will be very weak. Indeed, on Friday, the Commerce Department reported that the gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, rose four tenths of one percent in the second quarter, at the low end of expectations. And durable goods orders in June fell an unexpected 1.6 percent.
After rising 27 percent against the German mark since early February to a high of 1.84 marks two weeks ago, the dollar has dropped 5 percent, closing on Friday at 1.7440 marks.
And there's no consensus on its outlook. Guy Rigden, director of strategy at UBS Phillips & Drew in London, thinks the dollar is on a trend down that could bring it below 1.70 marks to the dollar next year. "We don't expect the dollar to collapse but just to drift down some," he said. "It is limiting the impact on inflation and helping the overall interest rate environment. But it takes away the biggest attraction of buying American assets if the dollar is not going to appreciate."
Barton Biggs, global strategist for Morgan Stanley in New York, believes the dollar in the longer run will continue to rally but that the stumble in July will last for some months. In the nearer term, he said, the fall could spark a small summer rally in the stock markets around the world.
And he likes the fact that the falling dollar will, for the first time this year, add a little premium on investing outside the United States. Through the first six months of the year, the rising dollar turned stock market gains in Europe of 14.5 percent to a loss of 4.7 percent in dollar terms.
Still, any prediction on the dollar at this point seems bold. The foreign exchange market has made a regular practice of fooling analysts. But there are some factors that may support a temporary swoon of the dollar.
Intervention, which helped push down the dollar recently, works only temporarily. In the longer run, intervention's impact fades if it is not followed with changes in interest rates to back up the dollar selling. This would mean a lowering of interest rates here and higher rates abroad.
Michael Rosenberg of Merrill Lynch said that with the report of rising inflation in Germany, pressure is building on the German Bundesbank to raise interest rates to try to dampen growth. Such a move is the kind needed to back up intervention.
Mr. Rosenberg also argues that central banks seem to be learning to time their interventions better, which means they can catch thousands of traders when they have large or so-called overbought dollar positions. This increases the sting of the dollar selling and can give it a longer-lasting impact.
That, combined with Mr. Rigden's view that the American economic recovery may be disappointing, is the case for a less spunkier dollar, at least for a while. Beyond that, who knows?
 
Elsewhere
 While many stock markets have been sluggish this summer, Britain and Hong Kong are charting a different course.
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 Index jumped to a record 2,587.9 on Tuesday, slipped a little and then rallied again on Friday, closing at 2,589.3, for a new high.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index reached new record closes on Tuesday, Wednesday and again on Friday, closing at 4.031.29. Its jolt came from the failure of the United State's Senate this week to approve restrictions on China's special trade status with enough votes to override a Presidential veto. Hong Kong's economy thrives on the China trade that moves through the British colony.

HEADLINE: An Auto Glut That Won't Go Away

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Just a stone's throw from the rusting carcass of the Chrysler Corporation's defunct Jefferson Avenue plant on this city's east side, workers are installing machine tools in a gleaming new factory. Elsewhere in town, many who will work on the assembly lines of the new plant on Jefferson Avenue are attending classes in such subjects as statistical process control and just-in-time inventory.
By the time the first Grand Cherokee Jeep, a new luxury model, is produced here in January, Chrysler will have spent about $1 billion. 
 In one sense, Chrysler's huge investment symbolizes Detroit's determination to catch and surpass the Japanese. But it also embodies one of the most serious ailments facing the American auto industry: too much manufacturing capacity chasing too few buyers.
Worldwide capacity now stands at 57 million cars and trucks, which would normally exceed demand by about 8 million but is even more out of line now because of the recession. North American auto makers and auto makers exporting here account for a disproportionate 6 million units of excess capacity.
The Big Three's 56 North American plants have the capacity to turn out an estimated 11.5 million cars and trucks annually. This year, because of the recession, only about 60 to 65 percent of that capacity will be used, compared with 70 percent last year and 85 percent in 1985. Analysts say that the 85 percent rate is generally needed to break even, but they are not sure the Big Three will achieve that, even when the recession is over.
That is because American overcapacity has such deep roots, going back to the sharp growth of the Japanese, who went from a worldwide capacity of 10 million in 1979 to nearly 17 million last year, including 1.7 million in plants operated in the United States. Last year, the Japanese sold 3.3 million cars and trucks in the United States, including imports, taking away even more of Detroit's share of the American market. That share has eroded to about 75 percent.
 
Some Close, Some Open
 Detroit has been dealing with the problem by fits and starts. It has closed some plants and consolidated operations in others, with the Ford Motor Company leading the way. But critics say Chrysler and especially the General Motors Corporation have dragged their feet. And paradoxically, as its market share has dwindled, Detroit has redoubled the pace of new model introductions, like the Grand Cherokee, to win back buyers. Naturally, the new models have meant more rapid retooling of plants and the need for plant space.
The Grand Cherokee may yet turn out to be a big moneymaker, as Chrysler says it will, and the new plant a smart investment. But the arithmetic of overcapacity is simply too nasty to allow every model -- and every plant -- to survive. Overcapacity not only saddles Detroit with unproductive overhead, it also leads to punishing price-cutting ploys -- including rebates, low-interest financing and fleet discounts -- to sell the surplus that is produced.
"The ongoing increase in production capacity, coupled with lower industry sales, has heightened competition for market share and forced virtually every manufacturer here into costly marketing wars," said Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman and chief executive. For the past year, Ford, Chrysler and G.M. have been paying an average of $900 to $1,100 per vehicle in consumer rebates.
The Japanese have also had to discount, but they are better able to do so because of lower costs from higher capacity utilization rates back home and lower labor expenses in this country, where the Japanese spend less than Detroit on health care and pensions because their work force is younger. Some Japanese factories in the United States are nonunion; in others, the Japanese have won more favorable contracts than the Big Three.
Capacity utilization rates at Japanese plants here are roughly comparable these days to rates at American-run plants, excluding G.M. factories, which are far more underused as a group. But Detroit can take little solace in that. While the Japanese have also been hurt by the recession, the bigger reason for their unused capacity is that several assembly lines are in a startup phase with full production a year or so away.
For their part, the American car makers have lost billions of dollars in the past year, including big losses reported late last week for the second quarter. The worst may be over, now that the recession itself seems to be over. But analysts say much more must be done to avoid further damage from overcapacity.
 
The $64 Question
 "We've known this crunch was coming since the early 1980's," said John O'Donnell, an economist who specializes in vehicle research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Sooner or later someone will have to bite the bullet. The question is who?"
In one form or another, all of the Big Three have been taking their bites, though obviously not deeply enough. Inventories are actually quite light these days, in part a reflection of numerous temporary shutdowns of plants.
Over the past few years, Ford has been the most aggressive, and in the late 80's it was the only one of the Big Three to achieve something close to parity between capacity and demand. But demand for Ford products has softened in the last year or two along with everyone else's. For the year ending Sept. 30, the company is expected to have a 76 percent utilization rate, according to Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco.
Just a week ago, General Motors bit the bullet again. It announced that it would close two plants -- in Van Nuys, Calif., and Scarborough, Ontario -- in line with a pledge by Robert C. Stempel, its chairman, to balance capacity with demand by the end of 1992. Analysts said, however, that three or four more plants would have to close to meet that goal. G.M. capacity utilization for the year ending Sept. 30 is expected to be 55 percent, Mr. Glantz said.
And Chrysler, which has taken about 600,000 units of capacity out of its system since 1988, has to shut at least one or two more plants as well, analysts say. Its rate: 66 percent.
In some respects, Detroit says it cannot slim down much faster, given the constraints that it faces under union contracts. G.M. signed a pattern-setting three-year agreement last year guaranteeing workers nearly full salary and benefits whether they work or not. Little wonder then that Detroit has concluded it can sometimes lose more money closing a plant than building cars that are unprofitable.
"The economics of the decision to manufacture or not to manufacture have been completely distorted by the labor issue," said Jerry Paul, automotive analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York.
 
A Last Stand?
 In other respects, Detroit simply does not want to do more about overcapacity -- at least not yet -- viewing factory shutdowns as a final ceding of market share to the Japanese.
Closing a plant increases efficiency and lowers operating costs but temporarily forecloses the opportunity to bring out a model that might become a sudden profitable hit, like Chrysler's 1984 minivan. As the Detroit cliche goes: "You can't sell 'em if you don't build 'em."
"The age-old dilemma, as with housing and banking, is how one adequately forecasts the future," said Mr. O'Donnell, the auto researcher. "There always is the hope the market will recover" and wipe out excess capacity.
Not surprisingly, the United Automobile Workers union is strongly opposed to further plant closings, arguing that the American auto industry is unfairly bearing the brunt of what is really a global problem. Overcapacity is concentrated here, the union says, because Europe and Japan are aggressive exporters and stingy importers. The solution, the U.A.W. says, is legislation to protect American markets.
"Plants have closed; lots of them," said Owen Bieber, U.A.W. president. "But where's the payoff? The domestic industry is in as much trouble as ever. Maybe closing Big Three plants isn't such a magic bullet after all."
Whatever the cure, overcapacity appears to be a fixture of the cyclical car industry. "During the last slump, in 1982, there were about 6.2 million units of unused capacity in the North American auto industry," said Chris Hosford, a Chrysler spokesman. "When sales rebounded by 1985, unused capacity fell to half of that, with a resulting 82 percent utilization rate and good profitability."
The fact that the industry is now back at about 6 million units of unused capacity does not faze Chrysler. "If our forecasts are right," Mr. Hosford said, "when the next sales resurgence comes, unused capacity and utilization rates will be at almost exactly the same level as in 1985." And Chrysler, he added, is "well positioned for a market upswing."
But the Japanese competition is far stronger than it was five years ago. And so far Detroit has not proven that its newest models can halt the Japanese advance, so there is no assurance that will happen when the market rebounds.
Certainly, the Japanese don't think so. By 1995, according to industry forecasts, Japanese capacity will grow by another 2 million vehicles worldwide, to 19 million. Much of that growth will come in the United States, where Japanese-run factories, known as transplants, will add 800,000 units of capacity.
In the early 1980's, the Big Three unwittingly encouraged much of this growth when they criticized Japan for importing to North America without manufacturing here. Wary of trade restrictions on their imports and heartened by a weakening dollar, the Japanese accepted the challenge. Initially, the Americans were eager to see how Japanese manufacturing and management practices worked here. G.M., Ford and Chrysler each opened transplants with Japanese partners.
 
Urge to Build
 That experience further convinced the Americans of the need to operate as efficiently and productively as the Japanese. And that meant Detroit sometimes decided to build new plants, like Jefferson Avenue, and new models, like the Grand Cherokee.
But that is a billion-dollar crapshoot. No matter how estimable the Grand Cherokee turns out to be, it will have to fight for a place in a market already clogged with too many similar products churned out by too many plants. Besides facing a host of similar Japanese models, the Grand Cherokee will be competing against Ford's Explorer, G.M. utility vehicles like the Oldsmobile Bravada and even Chrysler's less expensive Jeep Cherokee, produced in an aging plant in Toledo, Ohio.
Marketing experts think Chrysler will be hard pressed to avoid paying rebates if it wants to keep sales of both Jeep models strong. "In a very crowded segment it's going to be difficult," said Mr. Paul of Bernstein & Company. "When you start slicing market segments, the slices get very small."
Chrysler says the new plant is not adding capacity, since it is taking the place of the old Jefferson Avenue facility. But critics say Chrysler should have phased out the existing Cherokee line or closed the Toledo plant and combined production of the two models here or even dusted off a recently closed St. Louis plant instead of spending so much on a risky new facility.
"Somebody wasn't doing his homework when Jefferson Avenue was planned," said James Harbour, a manufacturing consultant based in Troy, Mich.
Yet others say up-to-date plants like Jefferson Avenue and G.M.'s new Saturn facility in Spring Hill, Tenn., have so many technical advantages over older factories that it makes sense to build them, even though they are adding capacity to the market.
Ford has concentrated more on wringing increased production from existing plants than building new ones. After closing several factories during the recession of the early 80's, Ford executives decided they had been courting financial disaster by operating too much capacity.
So Ford invested heavily to make its assembly lines more efficient. It also persuaded the U.A.W. to accept a great deal of overtime. By not opening more plants, Ford in effect limited its ability to prosper during periods of peak demand. By the same token, however, losses would be lower during recessions.
The cautious strategy allowed Ford to surpass the much-bigger G.M. in profitability for a while in the 80's. But with the industry now swimming in overcapacity, Ford no longer can stay dry. Like the less-cautious G.M. and Chrysler, it too must resort to expensive discounting, a painful reminder of just how insidious the overcapacity problem has become. If things don't improve soon, Ford might also have to shut or consolidate some of its factories, analysts say.
"If one player is sick with too much capacity, it affects everyone," said Mr. Paul.
 
 
 
GETTING MORE FROM A PLANT
 Besides shutting and consolidating some factories with unused capacity, Detroit is also trying to squeeze more output from "fully utilized" plants by expanding to three work shifts or three work crews from the normal two.
Full capacity utilization has traditionally been defined as a plant's output for five working days, Monday through Friday, from two eight-hour shifts, with the line running at full speed.
Near round-the-clock assembly was once an unthinkable notion. Technical experts claimed machinery needed more maintenance than would be possible during the few hours of downtime. Moreover, the United Automobile Workers union, which allows overtime under certain conditions, didn't want to institutionalize round-the-clock production.
But technical puzzles were solved, and executives won the agreement of the union, which understands as well as anyone the mounting pressures from highly efficient Japanese competitors.
In mid-July, workers at G.M.'s huge assembly complex in Lordstown, Ohio, approved a "three-crew, two-shift" production schedule for subcompact cars starting in 1992. Under this system, Lordstown will have two 10-hour production shifts on weekdays and one on Saturday and Sunday, with three crews each working four days a week. Workers will get extra pay for the longer shifts and weekend assignments. G.M. already operates two plants in Europe under a similar system.
Earlier in the year, Chrysler workers in St. Louis approved a pact to build minivans on three seven-hour shifts, including some weekend shifts, starting as early as January. This will mean a 35-hour week, instead of 40. But the workers will continue to be paid at the rate of 40 hours in exchange for agreeing to late-night and weekend duty.
By running plants nearly full-time, companies can increase output by about 20 percent. Chrysler thinks it can add 50,000 minivans to the annual total of 225,000 built in St. Louis, saving the $500 million it might cost to retool another plant for minivan assembly.
 
 
 
THE OUTLOOK FOR EUROPE
 Until last year, Western Europe's 101 car plants were operating at very close to full capacity, helping to generate huge profits for, among others, Ford and G.M.
But the profits have diminished rapidly as the auto makers have added capacity to take advantage of an expected -- but thus far unfulfilled -- buying spree from Eastern bloc countries, according to Autofacts Inc., a West Chester, Pa., consulting firm.
In 1989, European assembly plants, with a potential annual output of 15 million cars and trucks, operated at 96 percent of capacity. During the following year, capacity increased by almost one million units. But sales slowed and utilization for 1990 dropped to 87 percent.
G.M. has been able to maintain brisk production and strong profits in Europe because of the high proportion of business it does in Germany, where the automotive sector has remained robust.
But Ford, whose strength is in Britain and Spain where business has been miserable, has suffered a big drop in utilization and has lost money.
The outlook over the next several years, according to Autofacts, is for even more dramatic growth in European excess capacity as several companies chart big expansions. This time, the auto makers plan to cash in on sales increases expected to result from the 1992 unification of the European market. But several will suffer major losses instead, Autofacts predicted.
