HEADLINE: Does Military Adventurism Proclaim Our National Decline?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Don't we have any national leaders who will tell the country that we are falling into the trap that the historian Paul Kennedy described as typical for nations in decline? Mr. Kennedy noted that as a nation senses it is weakening politically and economically, there is an impulse to resort to military adventures to demonstrate power, even though this activity ultimately accelerates decline. 
 As some observers have commented, the remarkable exercise of our sophisticated weaponry in the Persian Gulf created a high level of euphoria among our citizenry because it was a demonstration of power at a time when most people agree that our country is losing ground to foreign industrial and financial competition, and lacks the quality of education essential to halt this loss. This fits the picture painted by Mr. Kennedy.
It is far easier for our political leaders, many of whom rightly predicted that a war in the Persian Gulf would not achieve political stability and progress toward lasting peace and democracy for that region, to go along with the self-deception that the gulf war was a great success and to approve yet another Pentagon budget of close to $300 billion to buy still more advanced weaponry for unspecified needs.
This huge outlay for military purposes seems likely to be approved at a time when, far from subsidizing schools so that they can hire qualified science and mathematics teachers, the Federal Government has shown no sign at all of being interested in preventing the firing of about 40,000 teachers across the country as a result of the budget problems of state and local governments.
As Mr. Kennedy told us, the pursuit of military prestige in a period of decline serves only to speed that decline. With a severely crippled education system our country may never be able to recover its competitiveness.
 
FREDERICK S. LIGHTFOOT
Greenport, L.I., July 10, 1991

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mother of Yankee Draft Pick Says Michael Is Disrespectful

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEAUFORT, N.C., July 27

 BODY:
The mother of Brien Taylor, the 19-year-old pitcher and the No. 1 choice in the baseball draft last month, today accused Yankees General Manager Gene Michael of being disrespectful and questioned whether racial and economic considerations had entered into the unsuccessful relationship between the team and the family.
"As things go along, I'm beginning to wonder," Bettie Taylor said in a telephone conference call joined by Scott Boras, an attorney and an adviser to the family. "Is it because we're back here, we're poor and we're black? I'm not saying that is the case, but if it is I can live with that, too." 
 Mrs. Taylor emphasized that she was not making an accusation, but said the thought had occurred to her in the past few weeks. The most recent Yankee offer, reportedly for $650,000, is barely half the $1.2 million agreement made last year between the Oakland Athletics and a Texas high school pitcher, Todd Van Poppel.
Michael, when informed of Mrs. Taylor's remarks through a club spokesman late this afternoon, said he would not respond today. Michael has repeated that the Van Poppel contract should not be held as a precedent because he had informed teams before the 1990 draft of his intention to attend the University of Texas. As a result, Van Poppel was not chosen until Oakland gambled with the 14th pick.
At the time of the 1991 draft, the Yankee organization thought Taylor did not intend to go to college and had indicated that he wanted to play professional baseball. Yankee officials believed at the time that he would be signed relatively quickly and reportedly hoped his career would begin as soon as June 12.
Mrs. Taylor said today that her son had been accepted at Louisburg College, and communication with the Yankees would end if he should begin school on Aug. 25.
"When that No. 14 pick was signed, with the deal that he got, in my opinion the market was established," Mrs. Taylor said of Van Poppel's contract. "My son is as good a pitcher." Nearly eight weeks after the Yankees chose Taylor, an overpowering left-hander from East Carteret High School, Mrs. Taylor said she and Michael have never met. To protect her son's college eligibility, the family has chosen to accept offers from the Yankees by mail. Mrs. Taylor said that face-to-face negotiations would begin in the event of an offer similar to Van Poppel's contract.
But she also said that Michael had failed to introduce himself to her when he came to watch Taylor pitch. "Mr. Michael came down here twice," she said. "He didn't even give me a hello. If you ask me, that was downright disrespect. He could have said hello. I've lived with that sort of thing all my life. I mean, disrespectful people."
Mrs. Taylor added that Boras, who also served the Van Poppel family as an adviser and then as a representative, had informed her that Sandy Alderson, Oakland's vice president for baseball operations, had been present from the start of those negotiations.
If Taylor should enroll at Louisburg, the Yankees would retain negotiating rights during a period following the junior college season and before the 1992 draft. But Mrs. Taylor said: "Once Brien goes to college, the Yankees will have no chance at him. They have the opportunity now. If they want him, now is the time to get him."
She said her son would not speak publicly. Brien Taylor's first summer without competitive baseball since his childhood has been spent working as a brick mason with his father. "That's the way he has been raised," she said. "We've always worked for what we've got."

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
New York Grand Prix? Decision in 90 Days

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO

 BODY:
The decision on whether the Meadowlands Indy-car race will move next year to a site using the streets around the World Trade Center is fewer than 90 days away. And the fate of the proposal rests on the resolution of three issues.
The three key elements are whether the revenue projections are enough for the city of New York to justify the expense in a time of fiscal crisis, how much of a disruption would the race create in lower Manhattan and whether the race's current sponsor, a cigarette company, would prove unpalatable to the city government. 
 Deputy Mayor Barbara J. Fife, who has been part of the discussions with the current promoter of the Meadowlands race, Motormarketing International, said that the first issue is whether "the cost to the city won't overwhelm the benefit to it."
 
Will It Pay?
 That is, when the estimates are done as to how much the race could bring in the form of added sales taxes, business revenue and that ever-nebulous matter of "image enhancement," New York had better be able to justify whatever it spends in police and fire overtime and other such costs.
There is no shortage of rosy predictions on the race's financial success. Matt Scheckner, head of the New York City Sports Commission, a joint public and private agency whose purpose is to bring new events to the city, said the race's projected economic impact is about $56 million, or slightly less than the figure for the Big East basketball tournament.
Bud Stanner, chief executive of MMI, predicted that the Manhattan race would draw 65,000 to 70,000 spectators. The original projection for the Meadowlands race was about the same, and that race never drew much better than half that figure.
In this case, it will probably come down to what the city wants the promoters to pay for, and how much they think they can afford to pay. For example, the streets that would make up the 1.3-mile dipper-shaped track need repaving to accomodate the low-slung Indy cars, and MMI may wind up paying for that.
 
TV Could Pay for Police
 As for police overtime, Fife said, New York may decide that it should get a share of television revenue to help pay for that expense.
"There's about a $1.5 million to $1.6 million difference between a permanent circuit and a temporary one," said Chris Pook, the organizer of the Long Beach, Calif., street race, when asked how much more expensive it is to run a race on a temporary track.
"And you have to re-establish the site as a motor-racing destination every year," Pook added, referring to promotional costs. "You have to re-educate, re-remind the public. And that's very expensive."
For any New York motorist, the second issue is of great urgency. The track as planned would use a section of West Street, the main north-south traffic artery to the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, between Chambers and Liberty Streets. The track would also limit access to the PATH station at the World Trade Center as well as a few subway stations.
Besides the race weekend itself, several days would be required to set up and dismantle the concrete barricades, safety fencing and temporary grandstands lining the track. Every manhole cover on the race circuit would have to be welded shut, as well. Although the streets would probaby be kept open while all this was done, there figures to be some disruption.
And the streets must be shut on the race weekend itself. Since it is a business district, traffic tie-ups should be minimal on whatever July Saturday and Sunday the race would be held. But Indy-car race weekends are three days, including a Friday.
MMI, realizing it is probably too much to ask to freeze traffic in the Wall Street area on a Friday, is planning a two-day race weekend. That would allow only enough practice and qualification time for the Indy-car main event and one preliminary race, instead of the usual two.
It would mark the first time that Championship Auto Racing Teams, the Indy-car sanctioning group, tried to compact a race weekend into two days. Could CART do it? "I would say yes," said Mel Poole, a CART spokesman. "But that would have to be cleared top to bottom, because it's so unusual."
The last issue involves Marlboro, the race's sponsor. Fife, who said that Mayor David N. Dinkins wants to limit cigarette advertising on city property, said that in the case of the Indy-car race, "It's a question of looking at the pattern of the advertising." Her comments did not sound like an outright unwillingness to allow Marlboro to sponsor the race. Stanner refused to comment on the sponsorship issue. But if Marlboro is unhappy with whatever demands the city makes, the proposal's future does not look bright.

HEADLINE: Brady Backs Japan Finance Minister

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 27

 BODY:
In a highly unusual move in international relations, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady spoke out about the growing public furor over the Japanese stock market scandal, expressing support for Japan's Finance Minister.
In a telephone interview today from Washington, Mr. Brady said he was alarmed at signs that the political survival of Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Finance Minister, was suddenly being threatened by the Japanese Government's handling of the scandal. 
 American officials rarely comment publicly on another country's domestic political matters, and until now officials in the United States have remained silent about the Japanese stock market scandal to avoid the appearance of interfering in it.
But Mr. Brady indicated he had taken the step because Japan's Government had been so helpful to the United States during the Persian Gulf war and because he hoped that the relationship would not be jeopardized by an upheaval in Japan's leadership. He also indicated that the United States was eager that it not lose such a cooperative ally at a time when the world is faced with a host of tough economic issues, like financial aid to the Soviet Union.
 
 Scandal Is Now a Political Crisis
 The stock-market scandal turned into a political crisis last week when the Japanese Government refused to force disclosure of the names of the big corporations and powerful individuals who were improperly reimbursed for stock-market losses.
Although Mr. Brady is not personally close to Mr. Hashimoto, he said Mr. Hashimoto and the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had been particularly helpful when the United States was seeking huge amounts of financial aid during the Persian Gulf war.
"Mr. Hashimoto has been a pretty good partner of the United States, and we hope he'll be all right," Mr. Brady said.
The stock-market scandal has been particularly sensitive politically because it comes a few months before Prime Minister Kaifu's term as party president ends. Mr. Kaifu is expected to campaign to remain party president, and thus Prime Minster. There are no indications that the scandal could bring down Mr. Kaifu's Government, but it could upstage several important bills he is pushing and thus weaken him.
 
American Economic Implications
 Until now, the complex details of the Japanese scandal have not excited much interest among Washington officials, who see it as a distant storm, Mr. Brady said. But, he said he now believes that the scandal holds economic implications for the United States because it is suddenly emerging as a political issue in Japan.
"To the extent that Americans want to be fairly treated when they go to Japan, that's important to us," Mr. Brady said of Americans wanting to invest in the Japanese stock market. But, he added of the scandal, "To be honest with you, it has seemed too far away to do anything about."
By speaking out now, however, the Treasury Secretary is indicating that because the domestic scandal appears to be weakening Mr. Kaifu's Government, the affair has become a subject of international concern.
Officials at the United States Embassy in Japan would not comment on the matter.
 
'He Deserves a Pat on the Back'

Mr. Brady spoke of his deep gratitude to the Japanese leadership. It was at American urging that Japan pledged a total of $13 billion in aid, loans and direct financing to support the United Nations efforts to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Because of constitutional restraints Japan was unable to send troops to the Persian Gulf.
"He said yes in 15 minutes" to the American requests for billions of dollars in war funding, Mr. Brady said of Mr. Hashimoto. "I was impressed with the way he said yes right away. It was the kind of reaction from a partner that was very helpful. He never came back and said 'less, less.' He deserves a pat on the back."
Whether Mr. Brady's comments can help Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Kaifu remains to be seen. Many Japanese were reluctant to have any involvement in the Persian Gulf war, and there was some criticism here that Mr. Kaifu practiced checkbook diplomacy in response to American demands, rather than display independence.
In the current scandal, Japan's largest securities houses have admitted to making improper payments of more than $1 billion to about 200 stock-market investors to cover losses in the crash last year. The admissions have reinforced long-standing suspicions that individuals and foreigners in the huge Japanese stock market are discriminated against, while the country's more powerful corporations and individuals enjoy unfair advantages.
There is also growing speculation that some politicians may have benefited from these improper reimbursements of losses, which is why disclosure of the list of the recipients has become such a sensitive issue. But disclosure is regarded as the only way the ruling Liberal Democratic Party can erase the perception that it is protecting itself or powerful interests.
 
Proposals for Reform
The Prime Minister personally stepped into the fray Friday in an effort to halt the flow of damaging publicity. He used the occasion of a speech to newspaper editors to issue a three-part directive to the Finance Ministry and his own party.
He said the securities laws should be toughened to clarify the ban on compensation for market losses. He also suggested that the Government consider scrapping the cozy regulatory system that currently exists and create an independent regulatory body for the financial industry.
He also made clear why this had become such a priority. Mr. Kaifu said he did not want the issue on which he has staked his prime ministership -- reform of the electoral system -- to be pushed aside by the scandal.

HEADLINE: Americans Share Soviet Economic Pessimism

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
Separate polls of the American and Soviet people, released this week, show skepticism about efforts to restructure the Soviet economy and illustrate the differing domestic climates that President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev must contend with as they meet to chart the course of the relations between the two countries.
Soviet citizens, interviewed in the European part of the Russian republic and in the Ukraine, expressed overwhelming concern with economic problems. 
 They also reported a widespread sense of national decline from five years ago, but indicated apprehension about many aspects of the free-market economy that is being urged on them by reformers, according to a poll conducted for the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press.
Americans in the latest Gallup Poll saw Soviet economic problems as being very serious, but had mixed views on the type of foreign aid that the United States might extend.
More than three out of four people in the Soviet poll cited economic concerns as "the most important problem" facing their country. And more than 8 out of 10 rated their country's situation as worse now than five years ago.
The 1,123 respondents in European Russia and the 586 people in the Ukraine were interviewed in person in April and May under the auspices of the Institute of Sociology of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points for the Russian poll and six percentage points in the Ukrainian survey. Both polls were sponsored by the Times Mirror Center.
While a bare majority in each Soviet republic approved in general of "efforts to establish a free-market economy," further questioning showed that less than a quarter favored "a free-market form of capitalism such as found in the U.S. or Germany." The greatest number of those questioned favored "a more democratic type of socialism" or "a modified form of capitalism such as found in Sweden."
Farming was the only one of 13 economic activities that most people agreed should be "mainly run privately." Majorities said that heavy industry, the telephone system, electricity, trains and buses, banks, schools, and radio and television should be operated by the state, rather than privately.
In the Gallup Poll, 71 percent of 1,002 Americans interviewed July 18-21 said they thought that the Soviet Union's economic problems were "very serious" and 23 percent more said "somewhat serious." At the same time, Americans' confidence that "President Gorbachev's attempts to restructure the Soviet economy are likely to succeed" fell from 65 percent in mid-1989 to 47 percent in the new poll.
The Gallup telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
When it came to extending various types of economic aid to the Soviet Union, the American public made clear distinctions.
Sixty-nine percent favored "providing technical assistance, advice and expertise," while 58 percent favored "donating American grain and other farm products." At the same time, 48 percent favored "providing financial loans," while another 48 percent were opposed; 6 percent favored "providing cash that would not have to be paid back," while 92 percent were opposed to that form of aid.
In polls over the last 20 years, questions about foreign aid to many countries have elicited negative views from the American people.
In this survey, Americans showed little conviction that their Government needed to increase aid to the Soviet Union. Sixty-four percent of those questioned said the Administration is doing "about the right amount to help the Soviet Union in its current economic crisis." Twenty percent said it is doing "too much," while 9 percent said "not enough."

HEADLINE: U.S. FACES TROUBLE MAINTAINING UNITY OF ALLIES ON IRAQ

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Nearly a year after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the Bush Administration is finding it more and more difficult to forge a consensus among its allies over steps to bring down President Saddam Hussein and pave the way for a successor Government in Baghdad.
The growing strains on the military coalition were most evident this week, when a deadline passed for Iraq to make full disclosure on its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs. 
 After the Pentagon briefed major allies on plans to bomb what is left of Iraq's secret-weapons sites, senior officials said, a number of the allies voiced reservations or even opposition. The officials, who are involved in day-to-day management of Iraqi policy, said the doubts would have to be overcome should President Bush decide to use force.
 
Egypt Expresses Concern
 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has expressed deep concerns to Washington about any further bombing in Iraq, United States and Egyptian officials said.
Saudi Arabia has told Washington that it wants Patriot missile batteries redeployed to protect its air bases and cities from possible Iraqi retaliation should allied bombers launch any new attack from Saudi soil, United States and Saudi officials said.
Turkey has demanded detailed consultations on any military operations mounted from its bases, and last week it briefly interrupted United States reconnaissance flights over Iraq in a dispute over the allied chain of command, a United States official said.
And Israel has asked for 72 hours' notice of any attack to prepare its defenses and requested that its hotline to the Pentagon, dismantled this spring, be reinstalled, the official said.
 
Hussein Could Be a Target
 As these management problems flared, United States military officials were briefing their British and French counterparts on preliminary American plans to bomb not only Iraqi nuclear sites, but also "leadership targets," including Mr. Hussein if his whereabouts is known at the time of the raids, a Pentagon official said.
France, while agreeing to take part in any military operation to protect Iraqi Kurds from repression, has reserved a decision on whether to join broader punitive raids against Iraqi weapons installations, a United States official said.
British officials were also briefed and are believed to be generally supportive of Washington's plans to use force if diplomatic pressure fails. Mr. Bush reportedly told Prime Minister John Major at the summit meeting in London that he wanted the broadest possible participation in any new military action, and Mr. Major is said to have agreed.
The American plans, however, await the results from a new round of inspections of Iraqi weapons installations by a United Nations team that was due to arrive in Baghdad at the weekend. A satisfactory Iraqi accounting of its weapons of mass destruction would defer any military action for the time being, officials said. Washington and the United Nations have charged that Iraq has failed so far to provide the information called for in the Security Council resolution ending the war last winter.
The continuing tensions between Washington and Baghdad reflect the intensity of the Bush Administration's postwar strategy to topple Mr. Hussein as the anniversary of his seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2, 1990, approaches. The invasion brought on the Persian Gulf war and the first major crisis of the post-cold-war era.
The centerpiece of this strategy for the long and agonizing end game that may lie ahead in Iraq will be the maintenance of the most severe economic sanctions that Washington's coalition partners and the United Nations Security Council will support, Administration officials said. In addition, Mr. Bush will resort to military force if necessary to prevent violent repression by Mr. Hussein inside the country and to insure that Iraq fulfills its pledge to destroy its weapons of mass destruction, the officials said.
In the aftermath of the war, Shiite groups in southern Iraq and Kurds in the north rebelled against the Government and were defeated in heavy fighting. At that time, the United States did not attack the Iraqis, fearing the dismemberment of the country. But Washington eventually undertook to protect the Kurds and an allied strike force based in Turkey is ready to respond if there are new attacks on the Kurds.
 
'Significantly Diminished'
 Whether the United States will prevail against Mr. Hussein remains very much an open question. Defeated on the battlefield, Mr. Hussein is by no means defeated at home, where he is relentlessly organizing the survival of his increasingly family-based regime and maneuvering for a comeback in regional politics.
Still, White House, State Department and Pentagon officials express confidence that as a result of the coalition war effort mounted against him in January Mr. Hussein has lost his ability to dominate the Middle Eastern political scene, and, they assert, this counts as the overriding factor in the allied success.
"He has been significantly diminished," said a White House official, who has taken part in policy management since the invasion of Kuwait. "One reason he is less dangerous is not just because his power has been reduced in absolute terms, but the world is so much more suspicious and prepared to cooperate against him."
As the postwar campaign against Mr. Hussein gathers momentum, significant gaps exist in the Administration's policy, say critics outside the Administration as well as some Government officials.
Though Mr. Bush has made it plain that he will not tolerate needless suffering among Iraqi women and children, widespread disease and malnutrition have been documented in the country, but have not yet been addressed.
 
Arab Sympathy for Iraqis
 A senior Egyptian official in Washington said that public opinion in the Arab world has turned markedly sympathetic to the plight of the Iraqi people. Some of these demonstrated their disillusionment with Mr. Hussein through widespread rebellion in March, but they continue to suffer the effects of the international sanctions.
Western suspicions that Mr. Hussein is cynically promoting much of the suffering and shortages in Iraq to break support for the embargo has only retarded humanitarian efforts and prompted Washington to demand an accounting of Mr. Hussein's cash assets. At the same time, Administration officials are studying ways to further undermine Mr. Hussein's rule, removing his hand from control over any oil sales to finance emergency food or medicine shipments.
If the Security Council approves Iraq's pending request to sell $2.4 billion in oil to buy food, "to the extent possible we will do it in a way that reduces any discretion on Saddam's part to use the resources to strengthen his political base," the White House official said. "That argues for an extremely intrusive, extremely vigilant, extremely regulatory sort of approach," he added.
Judith Kipper, a Middle East specialist at the Brookings Institution, said, "We should make it very clear to the Iraqi people that the regime cannot govern without making the people pay the price."
 
Another Arms Problem
 Other gaps remain in the Administration's goal of stemming the Middle East arms race, even as Washington has become the dominant arms supplier in the region. If war and embargo have stanched Iraq's arms appetite, there still is the problem of stemming the temptation in other Middle East capitals to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons in a region where Iraq no longer serves as the Arab deterrent to a nuclear-armed Israel.
In addition, Iraq's success in hiding its extensive nuclear weapons program has demonstrated a surprising new reality that knowledge and old technology may be more important in producing nuclear weapons than access to the well-guarded high technology of the nuclear supplier nations.
If Washington succeeds in bringing Mr. Hussein down, Administration officials say, there may be a long transition before a stable leadership emerges in Baghdad -- and there is no guarantee what it will look like.
"It is unlikely that any successor to Saddam, even if it is one of the fairly nasty people he keeps close to him, would exercise the same degree of authority that he does," the White House official said. "And once the process of political change is under way it is not likely that there would be one turn of the wheel and then no others."
"But clearly," he continued, "Iraq's ability to establish a normal relationship with the outside world is going to depend on normal behavior and it may be that a post-Saddam Iraq is willing to entertain the possibility of reforming its national behavior."
A leading Iraq specialist in the Administration said this assessment in the White House indicated that Washington might cooperate with a post-Hussein government led by a member of Mr. Hussein's family or clan so long as the new Government made a commitment to reform.
A number of Middle East specialists have criticized the Bush Administration for not tapping into the network of Iraqi opposition figures in exile. They represent a broad range of political orientation, from radical Islamic fundamentalists based in Iran to Kurdish separatists, cashiered army officers and former government ministers who seek parliamentary democracy.
But Administration analysts continue to believe that any successful move to oust Mr. Hussein will come from the Sunni Muslim minority, which has always represented the center in Iraq. this leadership class,
"A lot of political leaders in exile have weak ties to Iraq," the White House official said, "and it's not clear that they could have much, if any, influence there while this remains a totalitarian political entity."
 
Intelligence Called Crucial
 Administration officials said repeatedly that one of the most serious requirements for the future will be monitoring of Iraq's behavior and compliance with United Nations resolutions.
The Bush Administration's frustration in anticipating events and problems in the Persian Gulf has been heightened by the failure of American and other Western intelligence agencies over the last 18 months to foresee Mr. Hussein's military ambitions in the region, detect the full scope of Iraq's nuclear program and predict the effect of the war on Mr. Hussein's power base in Baghdad.
A number of officials and experts said the intelligence agencies would have to recognize that in the post-cold-war era intelligence collection and analysis in critical third world areas must improve.
But the White House official noted: "Whenever you're dealing with a government whose policy is essentially the whim of a single individual, prediction is hard. You've got to be constantly prepared for him to surprise you."

HEADLINE: The World;
For Castro, the Hemisphere Gets Smaller and Lonelier

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
AT the height of his power, Fidel Castro was hardly a welcome guest at most Latin American political functions. The revolutionary fervor of Cuban society and the fragility of their own regimes caused most regional leaders to view Mr. Castro with mistrust, if not outright fear.
So it was a sign of something other than strength or prestige when Mr. Castro took his place this month at the first summit meeting of 21 Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking nations in Guadalajara, Mexico. Fortified by a region-wide turn toward democracy and market economics, other participating heads of state felt they could safely regard Mr. Castro at close range. Shorn of his socialist allies and caged by his own failing economy, Cuba's aging revolutionary lion could roar but he could no longer bite. 
 For leaders like the conference host, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, Mr. Castro's presence was actually regarded as a stabilizing influence. Far from worrying about the risk of contracting a revolutionary virus, Mr. Salinas and other openly pro-American pragmatists welcomed the chance to demonstrate a commitment to Latin American non-alignment and, in the Mexican leader's carefully coined term, "diplomatic diversity."
Likewise, for Mr. Castro, the incentives for close contact with his regional counterparts had fundamentally changed. To the aging guerrilla leader, the countries of Latin America no longer loomed as potential converts to Cuba's revolutionary gospel, but as sources of economic salvation for the Cuban regime itself.
The process that led to Mr. Castro's changed role is almost invariably ascribed to the collapse of the Communist bloc, and the reduction of enormous Soviet subsidies to the Cuban regime. But it is equally a product of the striking convergence of political and economic thought in Latin America itself.
As recently as 1989, a meeting like the Guadalajara summit would have been all but unthinkable. In addition to Mr. Castro, a region-wide conference in that year would have required the reconciliation of such controversial, mutually antagonistic leaders as Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile, Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama and Gen. Alfredo Stroessner of Paraguay.
 
A Living Gauge of Change
 Of those, only Mr. Castro still clings to power. Now, 38 years after he led the July 26, 1953, attack on a Cuban Army barracks to begin his overthrow of the Batista Government, Mr. Castro is a beleaguered survivor of a different era -- a living measure of the regional changes that have left his country behind. Once regarded by many as a pathfinder for a possible socialist future for Latin America, his regime has become an exception that proves the increasing region-wide rule of capitalism, pragmatism and democracy.
Looking aged and at times visibly agitated by sharp remarks aimed in his direction, Mr. Castro devoted his formal conference speech to a familiar denunciation of the United States and its policies toward the third world. And he reserved special contempt for regional economic initiatives originating in Washington.
"There is always a new siren's song for the eternal navigators that we have become," Mr. Castro averred, his voice assuming its famous timbre for the first and only time in the two-day conference.
"I am no longer speaking of blockades, dirty wars, mercenary invasions," he said. "I refer to illusions like the Alliance for Progress, the Baker Plan, the Brady Plan and the most recent of the fantasies, the Initiative for the Americas."
But at a table of regional leaders who have increasingly staked their national policy and their political fortunes on just such American-style economic strategies, Mr. Castro's well-worn diatribes fell on deaf ears. Even less well received was the Cuban leader's insistence that the United States, more than Cuba, was marked for imminent economic collapse. And the suggestion that Cuba was being forced to conform to a new regional orthodoxy was dismissed with caustic asides from such leaders as President Felipe Gonzalez of Spain.
"We don't want uniformity -- not the uniformity of uniforms," Mr. Gonzalez observed dryly.
Having lost their fear of Cuba's socialist example, other Latin American leaders made clear that they had lost their interest in it, as well.
Analyzing the summit's importance, the participating heads of state invariably looked straight past Mr. Castro's national predicament, focusing instead on the hardheaded business of building a new global negotiating bloc that could unite the markets and policies of their nations. The question of Mr. Castro's presence -- and indeed his fate -- was treated as a short-term issue.
Railing against his diminishing importance, the Cuban leader pointedly rejected any suggestion that he would voluntarily relax his rule in return for outside aid. He appeared almost to relish the vision of leading his countrymen into a twilight struggle of ideologies, a glorious fight to the finish.
"We are preparing ourselves economically, preparing ourselves politically, preparing ourselves morally, and preparing ourselves militarily," Mr. Castro declared to reporters. "What are we going to do? Anything is possible except that Cuba should raise the white flag."
But in a region preoccupied with its own, far different plans for the future, other heads of state nodded in sleep rather than agreement. In the conflict of Latin American politics that he helped provoke and define, it appeared that Mr. Castro would even be denied the honor of a final, losing battle.

HEADLINE: U.S. Wondering if Interests Lie in a United or Divided U.S.S.R.

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
As President Bush approaches a Moscow summit meeting that has been billed as a turning point in Soviet-American relations, the Administration is grappling with the fundamental question of whether American interests are best served by a united Soviet Union or a group of smaller states built from its 15 republics.
Should Mr. Bush go beyond his overtures to the Soviet republics and encourage the Baltics, the Ukraine, Georgia and other restive areas to withdraw from the union? Or should Washington help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold his country together -- peacefully -- as it gropes for a new economic and political path? 
 In interviews this week, senior Administration officials said that for the time being at least, Mr. Bush believes that American interests are best served by a largely intact Soviet Union, one in which economic powers are more widely dispersed to the republics but foreign policy and nuclear weapons remain under control of a central authority.
 
Confidence in Treaties
 This would permit the United States to negotiate treaties with confidence that they will be enforced and to maintain the formal state-to-state, president-to-president diplomacy that Mr. Bush favors, the officials said.
From a business viewpoint, according to Government officials, Soviet analysts and business strategists, American corporations could deal with republic leaders who might be more amenable to free-market reforms while keeping the advantage of some predictability and preserving the vast national market that is the primary attraction for American investment in the Soviet Union.
"With the exception of the Baltic states, a united Soviet Union, federated in the sense that it respects the rights of minorities, permits economic reform and free markets and gives the republics some leeway is probably the best model for the republics, for the bilateral relationship and for the region," an Administration official said.
 
Bush Will Visit Kiev
 Mr. Bush's actions in recent months have clearly been designed to encourage this outcome, even though the President has taken great care not to offer more than a general call for political pluralism and free markets. Mr. Bush is likely to be just as circumspect during his visit to the Soviet Union starting Monday, especially when he travels to Kiev, capital of the Ukrainian republic, to address the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, said on Friday that the meeting will be "the first post-cold war summit," in which the old arms control agenda will be closed out by the signing of a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons. He said Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev would focus on Soviet domestic problems, on trade and economics and on ways for the once-competing military giants to work together on the world's most difficult problems.
Mr. Scowcroft said Mr. Bush would also explore ways to expand American ties with leaders of the emerging Soviet opposition, without taking sides on questions that Mr. Bush and his advisers have not resolved for themselves.
The Kiev speech is especially sensitive. The President's senior advisers said it would be an example of his effort to promote negotiations between Moscow and the republics, without encouraging steps toward independence that Mr. Gorbachev will not tolerate and the United States cannot support.
 
Exception in the Baltics
 The exception to the policy of non-interference between Moscow and the republics, officials said, is in the Baltic republics, since the United States does not recognize Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia as part of the Soviet Union. But even there, Mr. Bush has stopped short of endorsing the secessionist movement and chose not to visit the area during his trip to the Soviet Union.
American officials said Mr. Bush was acutely aware that however difficult these questions are for him, they are even more perplexing for Mr. Gorbachev, who is locked in an intense debate over how far to go in dismantling the current Soviet system. The officials said Mr. Bush knew also that his ability to influence events in the Soviet Union was also very limited.
"The Soviet Union can stay together or it can fall apart, but what we want to do is stay clean so we don't get blamed whichever way it goes," another official said. "We're going to sit on that fence until we get splinters."
Officials acknowledged that this policy is based on pragmatic, short-term goals, rather than a sweeping vision of what kind of Soviet Union might emerge from the current turmoil.
 
Discouraging Use of Force
 That vision, they said, is clouded by their inability to predict with any confidence what course Mr. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders will take. The officials said Mr. Bush was also convinced that the most important thing was to discourage the Soviet authorities from using force to stop the country from splintering.
After a few months of doubt, beginning last fall when Mr. Gorbachev seemed to lurch back toward the use of military and political coercion and increasing in January with the violent crackdown in the Baltic republics, Administration officials said they were now confident that the Soviet President was moving steadily toward reform.
As long as that is the case, they said, the United States believes that the precise final result is less important than insuring that the process is carried out democratically and peacefully.
"It's a lot easier, and I think justified, to talk about process as being more important than outcome, given that it's very hard right now to see an outcome that involves a reunited Soviet Union aggressively mobilized against the outside world," said Jeremy R. Azrael, a Soviet analyst with the Rand Corporation.
One case often made for maintaining a strong Moscow Government is concern over who would otherwise control the Soviet nuclear arsenal. But officials said that argument was losing credence in the Bush Administration.
"The Soviet Government has taken steps to centralize deployment and control of nuclear weapons, and none of the republics have said they want to republicanize them," a senior official said. "Russian policy, as opposed to Soviet policy, is that over time, they want influence over doctrine and strategy, but tactical control would be in a central command."
Still, officials said Mr. Bush was convinced that maintaining a central Soviet Government is important to his attempts to capitalize on the new level of superpower cooperation in areas like the Arab-Israeli conflict and the spread of nuclear and high-technology weapons.
"Our job isn't to say, 'Look, for our convenience, could you remain one nation,' " a senior official said. "But for a major military power and a major force in Europe and Asia, you would like to be able to work with someone or some body who speaks with authority on issues affecting actions outside its borders."
 
Worry About Muslims
 In addition, Administration officials said they were concerned that breaking apart the Soviet Union would produce intractable and violent disputes over borders that now cut across ethnic and religious lines.
Arnold Horlick, a Soviet specialist with the Rand Corporation, said the debate reflected the "enormous paradox shift that has taken place in the way we think about the Soviet Union."
"If you asked Western statesmen and analysts 10 years ago whether the break up of the Soviet Union is something to be hoped for or feared, you know what the answer would have been," Mr. Horlick said. "Now we are in a position where the weakness of a disintegrating Soviet Union is feared more than a monolothic one. Yugoslavia with nuclear weapons. That's what we fear."

HEADLINE: The Region;
After 14 Years, Is It Time For Another Look at Love?

 BODY:
Since 1686, this has been the official seal of New York City. Each element recalls a bit of history: the sailor on the left holds a plummet for testing depths when seeking a good harbor like New York's, and he stands beneath a cross-shaft, the early navigating instrument Henry Hudson is supposed to have used to plot the local latitude. On the right is one of the Algonquian Indians who lived in Manhattan. In the center are Dutch windmills and the beaver skins they traded, and the barrels of flour the English later exported. In 1977, the City Council changed the date on the seal. It had been 1664, the year four English warships took New Amsterdam from Peter Stuyvesant in the name of the Duke of York. Now it is 1625, the year New Amsterdam was founded after it was purchased for 60 guilders by Peter Minuit on behalf of his employers, the upstart Dutch West India Company. But over the years, other images -- sometimes even their mere silhouettes -- have come to say "New York City" far more effectively: The lady at right. The Brooklyn Bridge. The Flatiron Building. The Empire State Building, sometimes accessorized with a large ape. Even the Coney Island Parachute Jump. 
 Then, in 1977, another image cropped up, this one on a napkin the graphic artist Milton Glaser was using to sketch out an idea for a friend in the state Commerce Department who was trying to turn around a depressed tourism market. Before the logo became a commonplace, its appeal was that it had to be interpreted. "You feel smart when you figure it out," Mr. Glaser said. The agency that was given the campaign, Wells, Rich, Greene, started with the slogan: "I Live in New Hampshire but I Love New York," but later decided that shorter was sweeter. The logo succeeded so well that it has been imitated nearly to death, turning up even as "I <heart> Soweto" and "J'<heart> Fromage." Nonetheless, says Stephen Morello, deputy commissioner for marketing of the Department of Economic Development, given that the state has spent $150 million over the 14 ensuing years to ingrain it in the popular mind, "we are not scrapping I <heart> New York." But last year, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, New York's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Development, said she might like to find a logo just for New York City, one to be unveiled in time for next year's Democratic National Convention and the 500th anniversary of Columbus's Voyage. The New York Times asked a group of graphic artists and advertising agencies to submit their own ideas for such a logo. At right are some of their responses.

HEADLINE: The World;
Germany's East Wing of the Common European Home

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
WHENEVER Russia has opened a window to the West, it has looked to Germany. Germany, too, has always been drawn more east than west -- as an agent of trade and enlightenment in past centuries, of destruction and disaster in this.
Now, with the cold war finally dissipating, not only the Soviet Union but all the countries of Eastern Europe are looking again to the Germans for economic help, despite their considerable political misgivings stemming from memories of Hitler and World War II. 
 And Germans, because of a wish to redeem their past and because of their geographical and cultural closeness to the Russians, would like to give even more aid than they already have.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl has temporarily run out of money because of the costs of absorbing East Germany, but he will be, in effect, an advocate in absentia for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when President Bush goes to Moscow for the Soviet-American summit this week.
Earlier this month, in London, Mr. Kohl was very much present and on Mr. Gorbachev's side at his historic encounter with the leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies; he unsuccessfully tried to persuade the United States, Japan, and his European colleagues that they should step up and give as much for the cause of change in the Soviet Union as the Germans had done -- $31 billion in pledges, loans or outright payments in the last year.
 
Working Within Europe
 While Germany leads the rest of Europe on building economic relations with the Soviet Union and the emerging democracies of the old Warsaw Pact, it is by no means alone. Italy and France have long been on the side of doing more for the Russians than the Americans wanted.
And while Prime Minister John Major of Britain went into the London summit resisting full Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund, his aides said he came out saying Britain was not against it, but had to go along with the United States, Canada and Japan.
Germany was also the reason for Mr. Major's change. To keep his job, Mr. Major has to win a general election some time within the next 11 months, and he has chosen to do it not as his predecessor Margaret Thatcher did, leading Britannia invicta against all non-English-speaking foreigners, but as a European among Europeans. He is cultivating good relations with Mr. Kohl and his colleagues to increase Britain's influence inside the European Community, which is where he has decided Britain's future lies.
It isn't only geography that explains the Germans' new eastward attraction, the Drang nach Osten of the 1990's. Some of it is guilt and the wish to atone for the sins of the Nazis, by extending a helping hand now. Some of it is relief: They are so grateful for the Soviet Union's agreement last year to let the two parts of their country reunite within the NATO alliance that it sometimes seems there is little they won't do, short of quitting NATO, to try to help Mr. Gorbachev.
Germany didn't protest strongly earlier this year when Soviet soldiers guarding a missile base in eastern Germany shot at German officers trying to get a close look at it, nor when high-ranking Soviet military commanders flew in without permission to inspect some of their 300,000 troops who will not be withdrawn until 1994.
Worrying that the Germans would be too compliant with the Russians was a cold war preoccupation of anti-Soviet hard-liners in Washington. They were bothered as well by what seemed a perhaps overly romantic notion that the Germans had -- that only they really understand the Russians and the people of what they call Mitteleuropa.
This notion persists. What is more, it has an echo on the Soviet side, particularly evident to anyone who observed the personal chemistry between Eduard A. Shevardnadze, when he was the Soviet Foreign Minister, and his German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher. To some extent, the Germans got their unity by schmoozing up to the Russians, and they feel that their economic and trade position in the new Europe of the future will depend on preserving good relations with them as well.
Some American diplomats here see a risk that all this bridge-building could end up endangering the strategic economic interests of the United States in Europe in the 21st century.
There are those in Central Europe who worry about being absorbed in some latter-day greater East European co-prosperity sphere dominated by Germany. They need foreign capital, and General Motors and other large American companies have made some big plant investments. But the smaller investments on which continued economic development depends seem likely to come mainly from Germany.
Czechoslovakia, for instance, now has 330 joint business ventures with Germany and 348 with Austria, but only 49 with the United States, according to the German Chamber of Trade and Commerce; Germany is the largest exporter to Czechoslovakia and has become Hungary's biggest trade partner as well.
But because of the history of the first half of this century, the Germans have to be careful. Sensitivities in Yugoslavia are particularly acute, whether the Germans say they favor keeping the country together or favor letting Slovenia and Croatia have their independence if they want it; Yugoslavs, like all other Eastern Europeans, remember too vividly how the Nazis took them apart and wonder, unfairly perhaps, about German designs on them today.
The Soviets, after being fixated on the idea of strategic military parity with the United States, may have decided that America is now far away and too far ahead to catch up with. Germany is right at their doorstep, eager to please, and probably better able to help them rebuild their shattered economy.
Two hundred years ago, Catherine the Great -- a German -- imported tens of thousands of hard-working German farmers to bring Russian agriculture out of the mud. Today their descendants are returning to Germany, at a rate of more than 50,000 a year. But the welcome is wearing thin with the mounting problems of reunification, and nearly a quarter of the labor force in eastern Germany is now out of work.
Bonn turned down almost all of the 57,430 applications for asylum it received from Eastern Europe last year. Now, the fear that millions of Russians will be knocking at their doors if the Soviet Union collapses may well be the biggest reason of all why the Germans want to help Moscow.

HEADLINE: Price Rises Rule Postwar Cairo's Scuttlebutt

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
Across this city as summer builds, the talk has turned from war's high drama to far more humdrum scripts -- the cost of gas and taxicabs and most other things afflicted by a scourge of suddenly rising prices.
During the Persian Gulf war, President Hosni Mubarak staked a claim as leader of the so-called moderate Arabs, America's most resolute Arab ally in turbulence that seemed to offer gains to offset the risks. The economic crisis befalling his land, by contrast, is far less easy to either confront or wish away and has now re-emerged to haunt him. 
 In some ways, the crisis -- so deep rooted and long running that it is part of society's fabric -- reflects a familiar phenomenon in this region.
In Egypt, the discussion turns on a peculiar legacy: For decades -- some would say centuries or even millennia -- this society has endured on a crude but effective social contract that is now threatened by economic reforms instilled at the behest of the International Monetary Fund.
"The pharaoh has always been responsible for supplying the minimum, and the Egyptian expects it," said Galal Amin, an economist at the American University of Cairo. "It is so much part of Egypt, this expectation that the Government is morally obliged to have the children accepted at school, to put bread in the bakery, to provide the basics."
Since the fall of the monarchy in 1952, that relationship has been cemented in place by subsidies that kept prices of staple goods low, by jobs in the bureaucracy for college graduates and by guaranteed free education for the rising population of over 55 million.
But Western economists say those subsidies and bloated Government expenditures have also contributed to a skewed and indebted economy that has lost all claim to self-sufficiency.
That, in turn, has produced its own paradox. Diplomatically, Egypt has by tradition been the centerweight of Arab diplomacy; it is Washington's main regional ally and the most populous nation in the Middle East. But, economically its underpinnings are frail.
The International Monetary Fund, in negotiations with the Government over the last three years, has offered help in debt rescheduling and financial aid in return for changes that strip away subsidies and send prices skyward.
"Over the next year or 18 months, the old social compact here is going to be under a lot of strain," a Western diplomat said. "It's going to be difficult to keep on providing what people expect."
That shows through in many conversations across Egypt's social strata.
"I'm planning to get married," said a 24-year-old middle-class office worker. "But suddenly, I find the fridge I wanted has gone up by one-third because there's a new sales tax. So I can't afford it."
Talk to any cabby and he'll say gas prices went up by a third in May. Kerosene for cooking stoves increased by 50 percent while the cost of utilities -- telephones and electric power -- has increased by 30 to 50 percent. Significantly, though, the price of bread, which was allowed to creep up last year, and sugar, of which Egypt is a major consumer in sweet tea and pastries, have not gone up again this year.
"There has been a considerable period of crunch," said a Western economist, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "And there are more price rises to come in only a few months' time."

HEADLINE: Beijing Cracks Down on Mongol Dissidents

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 27

 BODY:
Internal Government documents made available today show that the security forces have suppressed two dissident organizations in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia and detained their leaders.
The documents, obtained and made public by Asia Watch, a New York-based human rights group, report that the two organizations "sowed dissension" and opposed socialism while encouraging a rebirth of Mongol culture. Two leaders were arrested in May, and 26 members of one of the groups were kept under house arrest. Some of those detained were Communist Party members, the documents say. 
 The documents were noteworthy not only for the report of the crackdown, but also because they were the first clear evidence of a pro-independence movement in Inner Mongolia.
The Government always insists that the ethnic Mongols in Inner Mongolia are happy to be under Chinese rule, and in recent years there have been few signs of open discontent.
Unrest in the Soviet Union's minority areas has alarmed Chinese leaders, who want to insure that such problems do not erupt in China. Already there have been serious protests and what appear to be growing pro-independence movements in Tibet and the northwest Xinjiang region, inhabited by people ethnically related to Turks.
Over all, ethnic minorities in China account for less than 8 percent of the total population, so the threat from minority uprisings is not as significant in China as it is in the Soviet Union. Still, Inner Mongolia has considerable potential for ethnic unrest, and the discovery of the two organizations has almost certainly sent alarm bells ringing among the security forces throughout the area.
"The two illegal organizations ostensibly used the discussion of 'national culture' and 'national modernization' in public," says one of the documents, which was stamped top secret. "But in fact their erroneous stand and reactionary views and the many illegal activities they engage in clearly show that their real aim was to oppose the leadership of the Communist Party, the socialist system, to incite a national split and to undermine the unification of the motherland."
It is not clear whether the two groups, called the Ih Ju League National Culture Society and the National Modernization Society, actually tried to overthrow the Government, as one of the documents says. It acknowledges that the groups tried to register legally, but were refused by the authorities.
It also says that dissidents in Inner Mongolia were trying to reunite with the neighboring country of Mongolia, which declared its independence in 1921. In the last year, Mongolia has essentially abandoned Communism and embarked upon an ambitious economic and political restructuring program.
The United States and international organizations are giving assistance, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Mongolia on Thursday for a short visit before he makes his way to Moscow for the summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev next week.
The documents suggest that the changes in Mongolia may have inspired the Inner Mongolia dissidents. The documents contain excerpts from what appear to be the groups' newsletters, including one that says that this is a "very opportune moment" with "favorable conditions for the reunification of the Mongolian nation."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Tying a Yellow Ribbon 'Round the Election

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE nation's capital lives from news cycle to news cycle action followed by reaction followed by fallout. For many, the military victory in the Persian Gulf is an old story, quickly superseded by the continued friction with Saddam Hussein, the worries over Iraqi weapons capabilities, all the troublesome aftermath of the war.
But for the public at large, the war remains a powerful memory, and it is likely to have lasting political consequences. One year after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, President Bush strides the scene as a tested Commander in Chief with extraordinary approval ratings. Democrats are only beginning to stir from a crippling, months-long defensive crouch. The Presidential campaign is lurching to one of its latest starts in years. And in towns and cities across America, there are still banners flying that welcome soldiers home, still local celebrations of victory in the gulf, still yellow ribbons and placards declaring, "We support our troops." The monuments to the war are everywhere in American politics. 
 To be sure, the public opinion polls show a few signs of reappraisal. The general euphoria about the direction of the country just after the war has eased, reverting to a more pessimistic, pre-war level. There is concern about the aftermath of the war: A poll released last week showed that the percentage of adults who considered the war a "great victory" had dropped to 62 percent, down from 84 percent in March. Still, 80 percent say they believe America "did the right thing" in the gulf, according to the survey by the Americans Talk Issues Foundation.
 
Worrying About Saddam
 "The war is precious to people and I don't think they're going to give it up," said Stanley B. Greenberg, one of the polltakers. Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat who voted against the resolution to use force in the gulf, agreed: "There are a large number of Americans concerned about Saddam still in power, but that doesn't detract from their feeling that the war was a tremendous military success, and they feel good about it."
There are numerous theories about the psychic importance of the war in the gulf, many revolving around a yearning for redemption after Vietnam.
Others, like Harrison Hickman, a Democratic polltaker argue, "The country needed a success, and it wasn't a pivot so much off of Vietnam as off the clear end of the go-go 80's." Whatever the cause, the war has taken its place in popular culture as a transcendent, heroic moment in national life, some analysts say, and Democrats expect endless replays of it in the 1992 campaign.
The war clearly was a transforming experience for Mr. Bush. "I don't think he'll ever hear the word wimp again," said Fred Meyer, the Texas Republican chairman. Somewhat more delicately, Bob Teeter, Mr. Bush's polltaker, said: "The public got to watch him handle the most difficult problem any President can handle, every day, almost on a play by play basis. It sharpened, it hardened, it firmed a definition of him as a leader."
Most important, it cast him as Commander in Chief, rather than as the beleaguered head of a country in recession. Democrats can play many sad variations of "what if" these days, and most begin with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last August as the turning point. Remember, they say, that Mr. Bush a year ago had just broken his promise to forswear new taxes, faced outright rebellion on his party's right, seemed bogged down in a morass of domestic and budgetary woes as the nation was heading into a recession.
Even today, as Democrats struggle to turn the debate to domestic issues, Mr. Bush clings to his role as head of state, traveling abroad and focusing on trouble spots from the Middle East to the Soviet Union.
The war transformed the Democrats as well: It froze them for months. With half a million troops arrayed in the gulf against Saddam Hussein, it was not an auspicious moment to mount a partisan challenge to the President. Moreover, most Congressional Democrats opposed the resolution authorizing the use of force in the gulf, which put them on the defensive. After the war, many Democrats seemed dispirited, stunned into inaction by the President's popularity. "The war essentially has delayed the active pursuit of the Presidency by Democrats for almost a year," said Thomas Donilon, a veteran Democratic Presidential campaign strategist.
Such a delay can have important consequences, Mr. Donilon said. In the summer of 1983, Ronald Reagan was taking his hits from Walter F. Mondale and a bevy of other Democratic hopefuls. Until only recently, one had to look hard for signs of an imminent Presidential campaign, leaving Mr. Bush above the fray. The late start also means that many of the Democratic hopefuls, who are mostly novices in Presidential politics, will have to find their footing, their finances and their voice very quickly.
 
Case for Change
 "His rationale is, 'I'm Commander in Chief, I've won a war, we're coming out of recession, there's no compelling case for change, and they're risky,' " Mr. Donilon said. "The other side is, there is a compelling case for change."
Many Democrats have pinned their hopes on the domestic concerns of the middle class. "George Bush seems to have an economic recovery program for the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Kuwait, and I think a lot of Americans are saying we need an economic development plan for America," said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman.
Kevin Phillips, the conservative analyst who predicted a tide of economic populism after the 1980's, argues that these trends still exist, but have been suppressed by the war, just as Watergate suppressed the conservative tides in the mid-70's. Mr. Phillips said these issues of economic equity will inevitably rise in the 1990's.
But Republicans seem unlikely to let the debate shift away from foreign policy for very long.
"It's clearly there in the public's mind," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. "Politicians don't create images and issues, they discover them. You ask my mama about George Bush and she's going to bring up the war." Mr. Gramm also argues that a vote against the use of force resolution will be "a silver bullet" in Senate races next year.
Mr. Bush's polltakers speak with simple confidence of the power of the war in the public's consciousness. Regardless of the aftermath, Mr. Teeter said: "There was both a principle and a favorable result. We did what we said we were going to do. It was a principle worth going to war for." For now, the "welcome home" banners still fly. And the Democrats are still struggling to adjust to a politics remade by the Persian Gulf.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 984 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
New Rows to Hoe in the 'Harvest of Shame'

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
IN his famous 1960 CBS documentary, "Harvest of Shame," Edward R. Murrow pleaded for Federal legislation to protect, house, and educate the "workers in the sweatshops of the soil," migrant farm laborers. In dribs and drabs, the years that followed produced a succession of laws designed to lessen the worst abuses against farm workers caught in a life Mr. Murrow likened to bondage.
But despite decades of intended reforms, Government investigators are finding that farm workers are still denied the basic health, safety, and income protections enjoyed by most other Americans. 
 At a Congressional hearing this month, an official of the General Accounting Office depicted a tattered social safety net. He said that some of the holes were created on purpose, as with safety laws that specifically omit farm workers. In other instances, he said, the problems stemmed from lax enforcement of existing laws.
As a result, many migrant laborers continue to be exposed to dangerous pesticides as they work in the fields and denied access to toilets and drinking water. Because they frequently travel, they have difficulty enrolling in state-run social programs, like Medicaid. At day's end, many still go home to shacks, with minimal enforcement of housing codes.
And a bad situation may be getting worse. Advocates say that many employers are using new accounting practices that deprive farm workers of unemployment benefits and worker's compensation and leave many unable to collect full Social Security benefits.
"The farm workers are a forgotten society, and their rights are completely ignored on a daily basis," said Representative Edward R. Roybal, the California Democrat who heads the House Select Committee on Aging. One Federal estimate put the number of migrant and seasonal farm workers, and their dependents, at 4.2 million.
At a hearing convened last year on the 30th anniversary of Mr. Murrow's broadcast, Mr. Roybal asked the G.A.O. to study the gaps in Federal programs designed to protect the laborers. Joseph F. Delfico of the accounting office returned this month, along with several advocates, and gave Mr. Roybal an earful.
Mr. Delfico said that Federal regulations do not require farmers to tell laborers what pesticides they use, the potential dangers, or the relevant first aid procedures. Employers in other industries are required to disclose such information about dangerous chemicals.
In addition, he said that the Environmental Protection Agency had inadequate regulations for pesticide use and enforced them loosely. The E.P.A. found 663 violations of pesticide laws in 1990, but ordered fines in only 42 cases. Even when fines are assessed, Mr. Delfico said, they are often too low to act as a deterrent.
A similar pattern exists with laws regarding field sanitation, which exempt many small farms from rules requiring toilets and drinking water in the fields.
Mr. Delfico said that on farms where such facilities are required, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration found sanitation violations in 69 percent of its inspections last year but rarely fined first offenders.
Labor organizers and farm workers testified that many of the problems stemmed from the growing practice of defining migrant laborers as independent subcontractors, rather than employees.
Reducing their number of formal employees allows many farmers to avoid health and safety laws, which generally exempt farms with fewer than 11 employees. But the practice exacts large costs from the workers.
Farm workers defined as subcontractors must pay 15.3 percent of their income in Social Security taxes, rather than the 7.65 percent that regular employees pay. In addition, they cannot collect unemployment insurance or workers' compensation.
Many farm workers find themselves owing large debts to the Federal Government, including fines and interest, because they failed to pay the proper amount of Social Security taxes. In other instances, contractors for whom the laborers worked failed to make the required contributions, and retired farm workers collect less money as a result.
Mr. Delfico described an array of problems for farm workers seeking income supplements and health benefits. In many states, they earn slightly too much money to qualify for welfare. This, in turn, can keep them from getting Medicaid, since the two are often linked. And those farm workers who do qualify for Medicaid coverage often travel and have trouble finding doctors who will treat them under out-of-state programs.
The Federal Migrant Health Program operates rural clinics set up to address such gaps, but because of budget constraints has only enough clinics to serve about 16 percent of the nation's farm workers, Mr. Delfico said.
One encouraging note in the day's testimony came from a three-way collaboration to improve farm labor conditions in northwest Ohio. There, the H.J. Heinz Company, the Farm Labor Organizing Committee and a group of growers negotiated an agreement that provides for increased spending by the companies on health and housing and pledges from the laborers to boost productivity. The agreement makes all the laborers employees, rather than subcontractors.
Among those appearing before Mr. Roybal was Elizabeth Whitely of the American Farm Bureau Federation, which represents growers. She had little to say in direct response to Mr. Delfico's findings, but told Congress that most farmers have "a genuine regard" for their workers.
Mr. Delfico's conclusions, like Mr. Murrow's decades before, were less bright.
In 1960, Mr. Murrow told viewers that, "the people you have seen have the strength to harvest your fruit and vegetables. They do not have the strength to influence legislation. Maybe we do."
This month, Mr. Delfico told Congress that, "if history is any guide," progress in the lives of farm workers "may prove to be difficult and slow."

HEADLINE: Black Journalists Fear Setbacks From Recession

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 27

 BODY:
Members of the National Association of Black Journalists attending its annual convention here say the group made great strides in the last decade in promoting diversity in newsrooms around the country. But at the same time the members are worrying that the recession could impair the future hiring of blacks and undercut past accomplishments.
"One of the things that is discouraging about this year is that we are revisiting, as if it was brand new, the issue of affirmative action," said Reginald Stuart, political editor for The Philadelphia Daily News. "There had been a half-dozen reports presented at this convention on that issue, and they say nothing that we didn't know 20 years ago when the first generation of journalists were entering the newsrooms." 
 The effects of the recession were very much in evidence at this year's conference. The number of registrants, 1,300, while more than association executives had projected, is still far less than the 1,800 people who registered for the 1990 conference, in Los Angeles, and the 1,900 at the New York conference, in 1989. Several of those attending this year, including members of the association's executive board, said they had had to pay their own expenses to attend, unlike in previous years when many of their news organizations picked up the tab.
In addition, many who are looking for work or looking to move into larger job markets found fewer recruiters than in past years, and many of the recruiters did not have jobs to offer.
"It's a horrible time to be out of work," said Kuae Noel Kelch, a 25-year-old television producer who was seeking employment. "Jobs are scarce and are more scarce in broadcast than in print. We're all approaching the job market skeptically."
 Several people recruiting for news organizations acknowledged that fewer jobs were available this year, but they said they did not necessarily see the picture as bleak as it might appear to others.
"We have jobs available for a general assignment reporter, copy editor, feature writer and a position in sports," said Leslie Ansley, who was conducting interviews for jobs at USA Weekend, a Gannett publication. "It's not as many as in the past; but unlike other companies, we are hiring."
Similarly, Drew Berry, news director for WCAU-TV in Philadelphia, a CBS affiliate, said his station was also looking for new employees.
"What people have to understand is that just because Booth A may not have a job if you are a talented applicant, you're going to write that name down and pass it on to other recruiters or to colleagues for future reference," said Mr. Berry, whose station was looking to hire a reporter, a writer and a producer.
 
First Woman as Leader
 Among other activities here was the election of officers; the association chose a woman as president for the first time in its 17-year history.
In a closely contested race in which more than half the 1,300 people attending the conventioncast votes, Sidmel Estes-Sumpter, a television producer, was elected to lead the 2,100-member group, which represents blacks in the broadcast and print media.
In another first, four of the remaining five top executive positions in the association, whose membership is two-thirds female, also went to women.
 "We have shattered a ceiling," said Gayle Pollard Terry, a former member of the board and an editorial writer at The Los Angeles Times. "Women have always been allowed to lead at midlevel in this organization, but to elect a woman as president says that we can lead and manage not just at that level in the N.A.B.J., but also at our various news organizations."
Mrs. Estes-Sumpter, who has served on the association's board for the last year and who produces the evening news program for WAGA-TV in Atlanta, said she planned to appoint men to top-level positions in her administration.
"We will be practicing our own affirmative action within the N.A.B.J.," Mrs. Estes-Sumpter said. "We want the board of the association to be representative of the N.A.B.J.'s population."
