HEADLINE: A World Trade Center For Westchester

 BODY:
On June 30, the Westchester Weekly featured an article under the headline "With Soaring Taxes Forecast, Development Can Offer The Answer." Then Business Day printed a seemingly unrelated Careers column [July 2]entitled "Creating Jobs By Building Export Trade." These articles, on closer look, are intimately entwined.
In 1989, the Work In Westchester Task Force sounded a clarion call to cure the deficiencies in the workforce or face the unpleasant fact that "Westchester will become a less attractive place to live and work."
In just two short years, the focus of economic alarm has shifted to the stagnation of new business development in the county. We continue on a very troubled path. 
 The fine BDO Seidman report, Business Development and Economic Vitality, tells it like it is and presents an extremely professional argument for immediate action to stimulate new business development. But as it clearly states up front, it does not pretend to be a "how-to" manual. The "how" is left to the readers' imagination and ingenuity.
Quite coincidentally, after reading the BDO Seidman report, I was participating in a meeting on international trade in the New York World Trade Center when the answer to Westchester's current economic woes suddenly lit up my mind:
"The answer is here, surrounding me in these twin towers," I thought. "A Westchester World Trade Center!"
As founder of a Westchester group of former executives of the International Business Machines Corporations who are developing customized training and computer programs to stimulate trade, I've witnessed first-hand the incredible thirst and demand for United States products and knowledge overseas. Today, 80 percent of our national growth is driven by international trade and this proportion is increasing rapidly.
With the American economy locked to the global economy, the growth of new business activity is inextricably linked to international trade. Wherever a World Trade Center has been built, it has acted as a prime stimulus for a region's international commerce. Such growth means more jobs, greater community stability, greater wealth, lower property taxes, and healthier business, retailing and banking climates -- just what the BDO Seidman report calls for.
One need only look to the twin towers at the tip of Manhattan to find a very successful model. It encompasses a modern hotel, meeting rooms, trade-show facilities, state-of-the-art communications, an international electronic network tying together bids to buy and sell, a World Trade Institute for training and language instruction, XPORT (the Port Authority's Trading Company, which helps businesses establish trading operations) and thousands of offices.
It is time for the barons of Westchester to unite in a common vision and strategy, to realize our potential as a world-class community by making it a center for international commerce.
 
STANLEY FREID
Yonkers

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Reshaping of New York City Hits Black-Hispanic Alliance

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Merely remaking the maps was as simple as playing with blocks. But the process of redistricting New York City's Council opened old wounds between black and Hispanic politicians that may take years to heal.
The purpose behind expanding the City Council was to greatly enhance the representation of minority groups, from nine of the existing 35 members who are black or Hispanic to a larger proportion among the 51 new ones. 
 But after years of waiting for a chance to share political power with whites, the city's minority groups began fighting one another over how to parcel out that power, each pushing for what it saw as its fair share.
 
Convoluted Map Pleased Few
 The map that resulted was a convoluted tangle that pleased few besides incumbents, and pleased Hispanic groups least of all. The United States Justice Department, playing referee, agreed with their contention that the lines favored black candidates.
 On Friday, Federal officials approved a new map that had been revised in small ways to meet their concerns, although legal challenges still thrreaten the elections. But while the plan was accepted, the conflicts that had emerged may prove to be the central challenge for politics in New York for years to come.
Religion and ethnicity have traditionally defined New York City politics; today race does.
Driven by the most visible change in its population in four centuries, the nation is redefining itself in multicultural terms, which, if encapsulated in a book about the emerging identity crisis, might be titled: "Goodbye Columbus."
Typically, New York, like California and Florida, is on the cutting edge of change. For the first time in nearly 400 years, non-Hispanic whites now constitute a minority in the nation's largest city.
"New York has become a polity without a clear-cut ethnic majority," said Louis Winnick, an urban analyst.
For the first time, New York's Mayor is black. Yet while politics remains a vehicle for mobility, social and economic power remains overwhelmingly in the hands of whites, whose dominance may be perpetuated beyond their numbers unless the political newcomers coalesce.
 
Multicultural Appeal for Unity
 Last week, Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn, who is black, and Dennis Rivera, the hospital workers' union leader who is of Hispanic heritage, appealed for unity.
"The city's permanent government -- that group of private interests who continue to receive, with no accountability, the benefits of our society regardless of who holds office -- remains intact," Mr. Owens and Mr. Rivera said in a statement. "And they are the ones who stand to gain from this so-called division."
It is arguable whether the latest rifts signal a new parochialism, but what is certain is that they have been worsened by changes in the way politics works.
"What's different is the role of the Department of Justice and the decline of the party," said Nathan Glazer, the Harvard professor of sociology and education who was the co-author of "Beyond the Melting Pot" with Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
As a result, he said, "instead of hammering these matters out in the smoke-filled clubhouse where it doesn't get onto the front pages and where you're doing basically the same thing -- protecting an incumbent or making it easier for newcomers if you decide their time has come -- you have the searchlight of attention that just exaggerates the conflicts."
Those conflicts were heightened by the Justice Department's objections, which coincided with the Republican Party's national strategy of appealing to Hispanic voters.
The latest political divisions also represent a predictable strain on an alliance based largely on a common economic agenda -- "short people drown first in the floods," was how Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democratic leader, put it.
 
Test of Dinkins's Coalition
 The first test of whether the coalition between black and Hispanic politicians that brought Mayor David N. Dinkins to office can survive redestricting may come in the Council elections themselves. The stakes will be even higher two years from now when not only the full Council will be up for re-election, but Mr. Dinkins will, too.
But the coalition between black and Hispanic New Yorkers was riven from the start by social and cultural distinctions and by the personal political ambitions that had split others before them.
"There's no automatic alliance," said Herman Badillo, a former Congressman and Bronx Borough President, any more than there is one between Jews and Italians, except that whites were quick to lump black and Hispanic New Yorkers together as a group -- just as members of the non-Hispanic white minority are often referred to as a group now, regardless of their ethnic origin or religion.
"The white perspective is that blacks and Hispanics never disagree," said Representative Jose E. Serrano, a Bronx Democrat, "and if we disagree, it's the end of an era."
 
Partners in Poverty
 By the time Puerto Ricans arrived, they and blacks were partners in poverty. They witnessed newer immigrants -- Asians, but also black and Hispanic newcomers from the Caribbean and South America -- beginning to pass them by.
The velocity of change can be measured in one City Council district in western Queens where a divisive race -- between candidates of Chinese and Korean origin -- was only narrowly averted this summer.
The competition that had begun earlier over the division of anti-poverty money flared again in 1977 when neither Mr. Badillo nor Percy E. Sutton, a black man who was Borough President of Manhattan, would defer to the other in the Democratic mayoral primary. Eight years later, the tenuous coalition between black and Hispanic politicians -- united in their opposition to a white Mayor, Edward I. Koch -- collapsed when blacks endorsed Mr. Farrell for Mayor over Mr. Badillo.
But the coalition that helped elect Mario M. Cuomo Governor in 1982, came together again for the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson in the 1984 and 1988 presidential primaries and, most pivotally, for Mr. Dinkins two years ago.
Transforming the ideal of minority representation spelled out in the city's new Charter into a reality was daunting. Members of the Districting Commission itself were supposed to reflect the city's population, but, with the Mayor sharing appointments with the Council Speaker, black political insurgents predominated over the Hispanic appointees. Diversity among blacks themselves was evident in Brooklyn, where black mayoral appointees to the commission tried to unseat a number of black incumbents tied to the Democratic organization.
Political realities distorted the process: a desire by the Council Speaker's appointees to protect incumbents; the dispersion of Hispanics and Asians, which made it more difficult to place them neatly into districts where they constituted a majority; and the fact that even where Hispanic residents made up most of the population, many were ineligible to vote.
In no district did Hispanic politicians find favoritism toward blacks more blatant than in Jackson Heights, Queens. Three days before the final districting plan was approved last month, the Lefrak City housing development, with its large bloc of black voters, was drawn into the district -- still giving it a bare majority Hispanic population but favoring Helen Marshall, a black Assemblywoman who is seeking the Council seat.
 In revising the maps last week to meet the objections of Hispanic voting rights advocates, the Districting Commission shifted Lefrak City to an adjacent district.

GRAPHIC: Table:"Adjusted Racial Makeup of New Districts," shows estimated racial breakdown of City Council districts in the plan adopted June 3 and the revised plan approved by the Justice Department on Friday. Districts whose borders were altered but whose racial makeup was not significantly changed are omitted. (Source: Districting Commission) (pg. 27)

HEADLINE: 92d Street Y Seeking Gift of $40 Million

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
The 92d Street Y, whose lecturers and performers have included Albert Einstein, Zero Mostel, T. S. Eliot and Yo-Yo Ma, is celebrating its 117th anniversary this year with a $40 million fund-raising campaign.
"The Y never loses sight of its roots and traditions, even as it changes to meet developing needs of the population it serves," said Daniel R. Kaplan, a New York lawyer and the Y's president. "At a time of fiscal crises and cutbacks in services, we're saying New York City is livable and we are helping to make it more livable." 
 Visits from Einstein, Eliot, Mostel and the cellist Mr. Ma were part of the Y's annual schedule of programs, which now includes more than 1,800 classes and events.
 
Diversity of Activities
 "We lack the elegance of a Lincoln Center or the cachet of Carnegie Hall," said Sol Adler, the Y's executive director, "but we offer an almost dizzying diversity of activities."
Programs at the Y range from infant care to dance and exercise for older adults. And then there are the uncounted, unplanned activities for people like Lillian Goldberg Lieber, who says she is 70-plus and calls the Y "a great place to hang out."
Part of the money from the fund-raising drive will go toward renovations: adding a marquee over the main entrance on Lexington Avenue and another at the concert hall entrance on 92d Street, and installing floodlights to illuminate the building's carved limestone facade. The Y's 62-year-old health and fitness center will be also be renovated, and its residence for 400 young adults, which is operating below capacity, will be modernized.
The Y gets 75 percent of its $20 million annual budget from fees and ticket sales and must raise $4 million to $5 million from contributions and income from its $20 million endowment. Another $594,000 was received last year from Federal, state and city governments for programs in the arts and social services, but such support is certain to be reduced because of budget cuts.
 
Running Against the Tide
 Starting a $40 million fund-raising drive in tight economic times is running against the tide, Mr. Kaplan said. Last spring, Y employees picketed for three weeks before a contract dispute was settled without a strike.
Already, Mr. Kaplan said, $21 million has been pledged by foundations and private contributors. The Tisch family has pledged $5 million toward reorganizing Y programs, like concerts by the New York Chamber Symphony, Jazz in July and Monday night poetry readings. The programs will be grouped under a new Tisch Center for the Arts.
Another $5 million has been pledged by the Samuel C. Bronfman Foundation toward the establishment of the Bronfman Center for Jewish Life. The center's program includes annual services for the High Holidays and seminars by Jewish scholars.
An unofficial roster of artists and writers who are part of the Y's history is kept by Steven Siegel. Zero Mostel taught at the Y in the 30's, he said, and the comedian Sam Levenson came to the Y and remembered, "as a child I scratched a little on the violin."
There are dozens of affectionate comments in the files: T. S. Eliot wrote, "There is no place in America where I more enjoy giving a reading." And Mr. Ma wrote, "I will always be grateful for the encouragemment I received when I needed it most."
Albert Einstein visited during the 30's, Mr. Siegel said. He was the only living person whose name was enshrined on the walls of Kaufmann Concert Hall. "Some of our elderly members tell us he looked at his name, and said, 'You shouldn't have done it,' " Mr. Siegel said. "But he obviously was deeply moved."

HEADLINE: Owner of Happy Land Building Faces Foreclosure on Properties

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Alexander DiLorenzo 3d, the owner of the Bronx building that housed the Happy Land social club and an heir to one of New York's larger real-estate empires, faces foreclosure proceedings on about 100 properties.
Some real-estate professionals say they believe he may have provoked the foreclosures, which affect about 40 percent of his holdings, to force the renegotiation of his debts. 
 The foreclosure proceedings are contained in lawsuits filed in recent months in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. All involve the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was created by the Federal Government to bail out bankrupt savings-and-loan associations.
The largest foreclosure involves 72 Manhattan properties controlled by Mr. DiLorenzo. The holders of the $68 million mortgage on the properties are the BRT Realty Trust, a company with headquarters in Great Neck, L.I., and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which took over a failed savings and loan in Southern California. They declared Mr. DiLorenzo in default in May, after he missed three monthly payments.
 
In the Hands of a Receiver
 The company initiated the foreclosure proceedings in June and all 72 properties have been placed in the hands of a receiver, according to legal papers filed in State Supreme Court.
Mr. DiLorenzo did not return telephone calls yesterday seeking comment. An official of the BRT Realty Trust and lawyers representing the company declined to comment.
The recession and the real-estate slump have caused a financial squeeze for many developers and property owners, and led to a rise in foreclosures. In some cases, developers have deliberately defaulted to force banks, which in most cases would prefer not to become the owners of the properties, to stretch out payments or revise mortgage rates.
Several real-estate professionals speculated that Mr. DiLorenzo may have defaulted to force BRT to renegotiate his mortgage. He was paying an interest rate of 12.37 percent, according to the lawsuit, and may be seeking more favorable terms.
 
'Trying to Work Something Out'
 "I don't think he intends to let the properties slip away," said a real-estate professional familiar with Mr. DiLorenzo's holdings, who agreed to be interviewed on the condition that he not be identified. "An effort is being made and will be made to try to work something out."
Sue Brown, a spokeswoman for the Resolution Trust Corporation in Washington, said yesterday that officials were "trying to work something out." She said that, in all, 106 properties controlled by Mr. DiLorenzo were now subject to foreclosure proceedings by the corporation.
Two developers familiar with Mr. DiLorenzo's holdings said, however, that they believed the defaults were not strategic, but instead reflected deep financial distress.
They said many of the properties were small, rundown buildings with little value in the current real-estate market. Many are in midtown Manhattan, and were apparently bought in the hope of assembling large parcels of land that could be redeveloped for office towers. It will be a long time before such assemblages have much market value, given the current oversupply of office space, they said.
 
'Ups and Downs of the Cycle'
 "These long-shot, speculative strategies are always subject to the ups and downs of the cycle," said a developer who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. DiLorenzo, along with his brother and sister, inherited a large real-estate empire from his late father, Alexander DiLorenzo Jr. It includes land under several prominent buildings, including the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South and buildings on Wall Street, Madison Avenue and Fifth Avenue. The land is often leased to the building owners.
The defaults and foreclosures are primarily on the less valuable parts of the portfolio, including the rundown midtown sites intended for assemblages and many older apartment or commercial buildings in Harlem, Inwood, and other parts of Manhattan.
The Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, decided last November that Alexander DiLorenzo was not criminally responsible for the arsonist's fire that killed 87 patrons at the Happy Land social club in March 1990. Mr. DiLorenzo leased the building on Southern Boulevard in the Bronx to two real-estate brokers, who in turn sublet the site to Elias Colon, who owned and operated the club, and died in the fire.
Last February, the Dinkins administration filed five misdemeanor charges stemming from building-code violations against Mr. DiLorenzo and one of the real-estate brokers, Jay Weiss. They face as much as six months in jail and maximum fines of $5,000.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Still Looking: The Changing Job Market/A special report.;
For Forlorn Millions, the Recession Goes On

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BEDFORD, Mass.

 BODY:
The experts say the economy is growing again after a year in a recession, but tell that to Charles Moreira. A despairing 22-year-old waiting for yet another job counseling session in the New Bedford office of the Massachusetts state employment agency, Mr. Moreira is his family's sole wage earner because his wife stays home with their 3-year-old child.
Mr. Moreira, a mechanic, lost a $6.75-an-hour job in an automobile dealership last December and has been looking fruitlessly for work since. His $170 a week in unemployment benefits has run out. He is vying with scores of similarly strapped contenders for a warehouse job that pays $6 an hour. 
 "I'm kind of disgusted," he said. "I'm losing all my ambition. I wanted to be the greatest." What about going to a boom town somewhere? "I don't have the money," he said.
Although the Government announced on Friday that the overall economy gained by four-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June quarter, nearly nine million people are still out of work and looking for jobs. The Government does not count several million more among the unemployed because they have given up looking. For all the unemployed, the recession is still going strong. Worse, more of the jobs that are now being offered are inferior to the old ones.
 
 Fewer Jobs, Worse Jobs
 High-wage jobs with full benefits are losing ground to lower-wage jobs with fewer benefits, many of them part-time or temporary. More than in the past, the unemployed find themselves treated like anonymous commodities, hired and then fired, bought out or laid off, with less of the old premium allowed for loyalty or seniority.
As recessions end, some disappointment is predictable. On getting wind of an improving economy, people who have dropped out of the labor force start looking again. Others look more earnestly with the end of their unemployment benefits, which are often more than $1,000 a month and usually last six months. That makes it harder for all to find jobs.
At the same time, employers put off hiring while they wait to be sure business is truly improving. Instead, they ask the workers whom they have kept on board to work longer and harder.
Mostly for those reasons, economists say, the unemployment rate rose only slightly in June, from 6.9 percent to 7 percent, even as most other gauges of the economy were gaining. In 1983, a whole year after the last, longer and harsher recession ended, the rate was 9.6 percent, hardly different from the high point of 9.7 percent in 1982.
But job seekers in New Bedford, Iowa City and Tyler, Tex., three vastly different cities, are encountering more unsettling trends.
New Bedford (population 99,992) is a sick old mill town, despite the mid-1980's signs of a renaissance there, with one of the nation's highest levels of unemployment. In Iowa City (population 59,738), the unemployment rate is rock bottom. But that's largely because so many workers there have part-time jobs. Tyler (population 75,450), like much of Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Colorado, rides the booms and busts of oil. Unemployment there was declining last year when elsewhere it was rising, but now it seems to be worsening again.
These cities are not typical. No city truly is. Yet the three illustrate common themes of the national economy, in particular the new instability of anyone's job. And all three are feeling the heat of the bleak new features of the current job market.
One is hiring freezes and layoffs among government workers, an enormous army that accounts for 15 percent of all workers, following layoffs that major banks, computer companies and oil companies have announced in recent days. Another is the deterioration in the quality of jobs, portending further erosion in the standard of living that began for tens of millions of Americans more than a decade ago.
Government jobs used to be recession-proof. But in the year that ended in June, a Federal work force of 3.3 million has been cut to 2.9 million because spending cuts, so those people have joined the competition for private jobs. This summer, many state and local governments are preparing to dismiss thousands of their 15 million workers.
Unlike Washington, most state capitals are required by law to balance their budgets. With sharp cuts in Federal aid, on top of their declining tax revenues from recession-stalled businesses and consumers, many are plunging into the red.
Because of a 3.25 percent cut in all Iowa state spending, Hunter Rawlings 3d, president of the University of Iowa in Iowa City, said: "We're going to have to lay off some people. How many I can't tell. It won't be insignificant. Maybe 100."
New Bedford's Mayor, John K. Bullard, said his city had eliminated 300 of 2,800 workers, including half its park and cemetery crews.
Meanwhile, job seekers in New Bedford, Iowa City and Tyler find employers more miserly than ever. They are holding down wages and cutting benefits because of the burdens of both the debt that many amassed in the high spending 1980's and the doubling of medical-care costs in the decade.
Employers who provided employee health insurance are now asking employees to foot part of the bill. For the average non-executive American worker, whose wages have fallen 14 percent in real terms since 1977 because of inflation, this simply means another cut in pay.
"A lot of traditional patterns are being broken," said Richard Belous, senior economist at the National Planning Association, a research organization supported financially by both business and labor groups. "Once, you had a husband working and bringing home $12 an hour. Now, you can have a husband and wife working and bringing home $9 an hour together."
 
Tyler
Tough Times Amid the Roses
 Tyler is the hub of Smith County, the wettest dry county in Texas, people there say. The city grew first on peach farm ing, then on cotton, then on rose bushes, of which Tyler pro vides a third of the nation's suppply.
But in the 1930's the discovery of oil in Kilgore, 27 miles east, and the surge in oil prices a decade ago sparked Tyler's big growth, with real estate development and oil drilling, financed by loans from ever-ready banks.
Servicing the oil operators earned $150,000 a year in the early 1980's for Richard Clark, who is 38 years old and the father of four children. He has a business hauling gravel to oil fields. He used to have two trucks, but demand for the service is a quarter of what it once was. "I'm down to one truck," he said, "and it's been sitting in front of the house for the last four months."
Mr. Clark went back to school and became a freelance photographer, taking pictures at weddings and sporting events. His wife Linda, 34, quit her job this month as manager of a bakery. She said her paychecks were bouncing. Until she left, the Clarks were earning $35,000 a year.
For Tyler, as for most of Texas, the bubble burst with the plunge in oil prices in the mid-1980's. Construction stopped dead in Tyler, and banks sank under the debts of bankrupt speculators in oil and real estate.
The city's unemployment rate hovered near 9 percent for two years, while the nation's economy was generally thriving. Tyler suffered less than some other Texas communities, because hospitals, colleges and manufacturing companies lent the economy some diversity. But the recovery of the local economy that started in 1987 appears to have stalled this year: unemployment has been bouncing each month between 6 and over 7 percent after dropping to 5.5 percent in February.
 
 Coming Home to Hardship
 It is the best-paid jobs, in manufacturing, that are slipping away. The area has lost 500 of 12,100 factory jobs, most in the past year. Two leading manufacturers, a boat builder and a television maker, have shut down. Employment counselors tell people who cannot find jobs to go back to school or move.
Roy Cofer, 40, has made two big moves. With opportunities in Tyler scarce 20 years ago, Mr. Cofer went to Detroit. He was a polisher at a steel mill, earning $15 an hour two years ago. He lost the job. Unable to find other work in Detroit, Mr. Cofer, his wife, Colleen, then a cook at a restaurant, and their three children headed back home.
It paid off for about a year. In June last year, Mr. Cofer found work as a mold maker at a manufacturer of pipes for pipelines. He took a big cut in pay, to $6.40 an hour, and Mrs. Cofer was unable to find work. Still, the cost of living was lower, and Mr. Cofer started saving to make a down payment to buy their rented three-bedroom trailer home for $18,300.
Then, in March, Mr. Cofer was laid off with 400 other workers. He could be recalled -- a few have been -- but while waiting, he said he had mailed out 10 applications for other jobs and had not got a single interview.
This month, his unemployment benefits ran out. Now the Cofers are living mostly on $160 a month in food stamps. "It can't get worse," Mr. Cofer said of the Tyler economy. "It's to the bottom."
 
 Taking Another Route

Bill Knight took the other route to a better job -- going back to school. A plumber, he ruptured two disks opening a sewer line, and after three operations his doctors told him to take up another career. With help from the state and workers' compensation, he entered Tyler Junior College four years ago at 34. Then he entered the University of Texas at Tyler and earned a bachelor's degree in May.
Father of two children, 9 and 13, with a wife who works in a stamp-and-coin shop, Mr. Knight is dismayed to find no better opportunities than he says he could without a degree.
"What I would really like to do," he said, "would be child welfare work for the Texas Department of Human Services." But the state, facing a projected $4.6 billion deficit next year, has imposed a hiring freeze and may lay off 1,000 employees rather than raise taxes to keep them on.
Some signs of recovery have emerged in Tyler. After a four-year hiatus, construction and the oil business have revived.
But those industries each employ just under 3 percent of the area's 62,400 workers. Factories, accounting for 17 percent of the work force, are still sliding. Jobs in stores, services and offices acount for just over half, and it is in those jobs primarily that Robert Sullivan, a labor market analyst for the Texas Employment Commission, sees most of the erosion in the quality of work.
"We're definitely seeing a strong trend in using temporaries and part-timers and another thing -- employee leasing," he said. "Companies lay their work force off, put it on the payroll of a leasing company, which leases them back to the companies. The leasing company becomes responsible for their pay and benefits."
It can save the companies some money, he said, but it frays the bonds of loyalty between the companies and workers and makes jobs all the more unstable.
 
Iowa City
Lots of Jobs, Lots of Poverty
 Iowa City is a lively and cosmopolitan university town. With patches of wood and soft hills, a river bisecting it and roads that bend and slope, it is an anomaly in a state of perfect grids. People like that. The population of Iowa City grew by 10,000 in the 1980's, to 60,000, while the state's population was shrinking nearly 5 percent.
Despite all the newcomers, despite the recession's toll on factories there and on state financing for the University of Iowa, Iowa City and the rest of Johnson County have created jobs enough to keep local unemployment about 2 percent throughout the recession. Among 271 urban areas that the Bureau of Labor Statistics monitors, only another university town, Lincoln, Neb., can match the rate as the lowest in the nation.
Still, Iowa City has lower incomes and higher poverty than many communities with higher unemployment. Thomas F. Pogue, an economics professor at the university, said the average Iowa wage earner also lost more ground to inflation in the 1980's than the average American.
The reason is that much of the work people there do is low-wage, low-benefit and part-time. The Iowa Department of Employment Services says 27 percent of the workers in the state work 34 hours or less, compared with 18 percent nationally.
Daryl Anderson is a temporary part-time elections technician paid $6 an hour. "I service, set up and do diagnostic repairs of computerized voting machines," he said. "I'm used as needed. My last job ended in June. I go back at the end of August." His wife works at two part-time secretarial jobs.
Between jobs last year, Mr. Anderson was a census taker. Other times, like the present, he makes himself available for day labor. Kathy Kick, an interviewer at the employment office, lists about 50 day laborers in a spiral notebook. People call in for workers to mow lawns, bale hay, unload trucks, do housework.
 
 Worried About Security

The Andersons do not have children, but at 39, Mr. Anderson has begun to worry about job security, a pension and his health. "I need insurance," he said. "If I have to get sick, I would literally lose everything I have."
The 29,000 students at the university, who on average spend $7,000 a year for tuition, room and board, set the standards for hours and wages. Single and healthy, they demand little more than the minimum wage and have little desire for health insurance. Students hold nearly all the jobs in stores, restaurants and bars.
Older workers who compete with students for jobs cannot demand much more, said Tom M. Bullington, manager of the Iowa City office of the state job-placement service. "If we've got someone with the skills an employer wants and the employer's not willing to increase the wages," he said, "they just take the next-best qualified."
Around here, some people seem not to resent wages that are about $1 an hour less in Iowa than the national average of $10 and still lower in Iowa City. Working harder to keep afloat is just part of the ethic.
Thomas Hardin, 30, is looking for a manufacturing job that would pay $1 or $2 more than the $6 an hour he earns at a full-time job with full benefits in a key-making concession in a store. His wife runs a day-care service at their home, but with three young children, they need more money.
Mr. Hardin said his other option was a second job, part time. He did this a few years ago, and would like to avoid the strain. Another thing he did not like was the Senate's voting its members a $23,200 pay increase, to $125,100, this month. Nor does he like welfare: "I don't think it's right, sitting on their rear end collecting money. I don't think anyone should get money without working."
 
New Bedford
Dead Industry Has Monuments
 Whaling created New Bedford, and even now, with the high price of the scallops it takes from the Atlantic, New Bed ford earns more money from seafood most years than other port cities.
But fishing is a small employer, and most of the textile and apparel companies that drove the city's growth early in the 20th century have perished or fled. They have left behind a graveyard of multistory brick tombstones with painted-over windows.
New Bedford never found much to take the place of the old mills. Among cities, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says only Modesto, Calif., and McAllen, Tex., have higher jobless rates than the 13 percent in New Bedford and the neighboring mill town of Fall River.
"We're ways away from turning things around," said Jessie Ealy, manager of the state employment office. "I'm looking at more like a year for the economy to turn back."
 
 'The Nowhere Jobs'

That is sad news for Alan and Debra Monroe. Mr. Monroe is 29, father of a 5-year-old, and has applied for unemployment benefits, which in his case would be around $100 per week. "I just lost my job," he said. "I was a maintenance worker at Muldoon's Restaurant, cleaning and vacuuming, part time, 20 to 24 hours a week. I got $5.50 an hour. I'm checking all the nowhere jobs."
Mrs. Monroe's own benefits run out in August. She is 34, mother of two other children, 13 and 14, by a previous marriage. She lost a job in January. "I was an office clerk," she said. She has found nothing since: "You can't even find a job in your own country."
Mayor Bullard is cheered by renewed hiring at some apparel companies, by a Polaroid Corporation commitment to build a big plant and by the city's longer-term prospects as a center for sea-related industry.
But he noted, too, that over the last year New Bedford had lost a Goodyear Tire and Rubber plant and a company called Chamberlain Manufacturing that made artillery shells. The adjacent town of Fairhaven has lost a data-storage center of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. All were big employers, providing the area's best wages and benefits -- and once the best job security.
A few of their castoffs may do all right. Alan Machado, 44, was laid off June 28 by A.T.&T., which, he said, has shifted the plant's work to Florida, Georgia and Missouri. He managed systems that stored billing information, earning $560 a week plus overtime. Now he receives $307 in unemployment benefits. He has one child, and A.T.&T. is letting him keep his health insurance for six months. He said his experience in computer technology gave him confidence that he could find another good job.
The company would move him to Georgia or Florida, he said, but his wife, Deborah Robillard, 33, could not be assured of a job. A buyer for a local retail chain, she was laid off in December but will return when the company gears up for the Christmas season.
For families like Wilbur Chase's, however, the closings mark the last gasp of a happier era in New Bedford. "I worked for Goodyear until they stopped production Jan. 11," said Mr. Chase, who is 56. He was paid $14 an hour. "It was a good steady job. I was there 27 years."
His wife has never had to work, he said. Their two sons, 29 and 30, single and still living at home, followed their father's tracks. "One worked at Goodyear," Mr. Chase said. "One worked at Chamberlain." Mr. Chase said he has a pension and some health insurance and believes he can get by if he can find a part-time job. His sons may leave town.
One job hunter, Joseph Fabio, 33, captures the dismay of many others in New Bedford. "Psychologically, the condition of being unemployed and looking for a job, I did not comprehend," he said. "It takes a lot of stamina and bravery to deal with rejection."
Single, Mr. Fabio has junior college degree in electronics technology. He lost a good job working for a professor at Boston University after the professor's government grant ran out. Four months ago he was laid off from a $7-an-hour, full-time sales job.
"In our society, you are what you do," he said. "When you end up not even having a job, it becomes really strange. You're not hooked to anything."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 655 words

HEADLINE: Last Of the Old-Time Summits

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
President Bush's trip to Moscow this week marks the end of the superpower era, not just for the Soviet Union but for the bilateral Soviet-American focus of world affairs. The end of the cold war did not produce the giant condominium that many feared. But neither is there a renewal of what Henry Luce called "the American century," a lonely U.S. superpower minding and ministering to dependents.
The main event of the Moscow summit meeting will be the signing of the Start treaty, reducing strategic missile arsenals on both sides. The U.S. and Soviet Union will still have enough nuclear power to destroy the world many times over, but the meaning of that power has changed. They won't run the world. 
 Foundations of a new global political directorate were laid at the London summit of the Group of Seven last week. Mikhail Gorbachev called it G-7 plus 1, but G-7 1/2 comes closer to reflecting the partial yet established participation of Moscow, which will continue on several levels.
A European leader present said Mr. Bush obviously preferred dealing one on one to the multilateral setting. But he will have to get used to the club approach and explain to the American public why the U.S. can't direct the way to his "new world order" on its own.
There is an analogy to the emerging management system in the 19th-century Concert of Europe, worked out at the Congress of Vienna in 1815 after the Napoleonic wars. There was no blueprint, no charter for running Europe then, as there won't be now for trying to keep the world on keel. But there were understandings capable of absorbing most frictions for a century.
That world order broke down cataclysmically in 1914, leading to the bloody inhumanities of the 20th century. There must be no temptation to revert to the 19th-century patterns as the new concert of powers evolves, a danger already visible in Balkan rivalries and in nationalisms in Eastern Europe.
The 19th-century concert, a triumph of conservatism over the revolutionary urges unleashed by Napoleon, provides two key warnings of what not to do.
The new concert must not set out to repress change, as the old one did, but to provide openings for peaceful accommodation to inevitable challenges. And it must not rely on a balance of power, which encourages shifting alliances and the unscrupulous search for advantage.
It will have to be clearly aimed at collective security, a Wilsonian ideal discredited between the world wars that is now regaining its hopeful sheen because there is no acceptable alternative.
For Americans, flushed with pride at the demonstration of their indispensable leadership in the gulf war, this may not be obvious. Mr. Bush himself seems halfhearted about partners who don't accept Washington's decisions without cavil. And it is true, as Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the New York Democrat, said recently, that "collective security can only work if American leadership makes it work."
But the Moscow meeting will show that it isn't only Soviet weakness that has made a bipolar world obsolete. It is also the necessity of cooperating with other players whose decisions affect American power to act. Of course, the G-7 1/2 can't keep the helm to itself for a century, as the Vienna powers did. It is a haphazard group formed in response to the 1973 oil crisis and successive economic threats, but gradually accepting political responsibilities.
Others will knock at the door as the transition to global management develops. But the Group of Seven does share basic values, an idea of how the world ought to work and a common interest in keeping peace. Its members have arguments -- over how to bring the Soviets to the stage the modern world considers normality, how to regulate trade and monetary relations -- yet they know they have to agree on big issues.
Soviet-American summit meetings are no longer the critical point of decision. The world has moved on.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Summits Still Matter

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
This week's Bush-Gorbachev meeting has the air of a last superpower summit, the farewell to the dramatic days when Washington and Moscow seemed to hold the worldwide reins of war and peace, the ritual end to a titanic bipolar struggle that sucked up energies and resources and lives, yet effectively maintained a nuclear peace.
Compared to the cold war meetings, this will be a Potemkin summit. The United States and the Soviet Union -- separately and together -- no longer shape global destiny. 
 Which does not mean summits are useless, and which raises two questions:
First, what will replace the superpower forum as the organizing vehicle or principle for international politics? The short answer is no single grouping of states, but ad hoc arrangements. President Bush is already practicing this approach skillfully, though he has botched its articulation. Ad hocism is the most that can be done to bring some semblance of peaceful change to an increasingly messy and fluid world.
Second, what will be the value of this and future Soviet-American summits? The short answer is that they will become one of many needed clearinghouses for dealing with the old issues like arms control, the Middle East and Afghanistan. But such meetings can also become an effective means for Washington and Moscow to confront their most important mutual concern -- the Soviet Union itself.
For all Mr. Bush's talk about a new world order, he frets about Mikhail Gorbachev's political survival and the disintegration of the Soviet Union. The American President is simply most comfortable in the orderly old bipolar world. As much as he would like to hang on to it, however, he knows he needs a new security policy.
Mr. Bush has made collective security his rhetorical trademark, yet knows its limitations. It worked well enough in the Persian Gulf war. But the Iraqi threat was egregious and near universal, and thus is unlikely to serve as a model. In any event, the United Nations is constituted to handle only old-model wars -- one nation attacking another. It will always resist intervening in current-style conflicts -- civil wars and wars of national independence. Such intervention is too likely to end up one day in one's own backyard.
Nor are regional security groups eager to police "internal" wars. True, African states did the job recently in Liberia. But the highly touted Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe ran away from the imbroglio in Yugoslavia. The European Community, led by Britain, France and Germany, could not get its act together there either. And these European organizations are generally better positioned than their counterparts on other continents to take such action.
It is similarly unrealistic to expect the leading industrialized democracies, known as the G-7, to step into and up to political-military quarrels. Their interests simply are not sufficiently convergent on these matters. That should not be surprising given their paltry performance in coordinating economic policies, their principal reason for being.
All of which points to an even larger role for the U.S. Forget this idea. Though the U.S. is now the lone superpower, it is so by default. It no longer has the economic strength to make the sacrifices required to run the world, and could not do so anyway.
Mr. Bush has taken the far wiser course. He is energizing every available combination of states to confront specific problems on an ad hoc basis, from free trade to missile sales to Cambodia. And where most conflicts will be internal and economic, that is the only sensible approach.
Mr. Bush heads toward the Moscow summit in just this spirit. He is planning to spend most of his time on Soviet internal politics and economics. He will give primary attention and help to Mr. Gorbachev, a proven friend who has bravely overthrown Communist totalitarianism and finally committed himself to a confederal and democratic future for his country. But he will also confer with Boris Yeltsin, Gorby's archrival, just in case. Then he will visit the Ukraine to underline America's support for confederation.
In the bad old days, Soviet leaders would go ballistic at any mention of their internal situation. Now it is the only subject they want to discuss. And it is precisely the right focus for Soviet-American summitry in a new, nonpolar and disorderly world.

HEADLINE: Allies

 BODY:
The possibility has been a long time coming, but it's startling nonetheless. After six years of Mikhail Gorbachev's warming winds, the cold war is over and it is now reasonable, as Presidents Bush and Gorbachev prepare to meet in Moscow Tuesday, for their countries to think of each other, in fundamental ways, as allies.
Not since Yalta has the thought been even thinkable. For half a century the superpowers stood locked in fearsome, fearful hostility. Yet now they share four goals, a fact that makes the idea of alliance more than a semantic flourish. And at this summit meeting, the two leaders can make progress toward all four. 
 The common first purpose can be stated simply: to integrate the Soviet Union economically and politically into the world, and give it a stake in peaceful relations with its neighbors.
Communism's thrust toward worldwide revolution has masked the insularity of the Soviet Union. It was protectionist in profound ways, trying to keep out people, goods and, above all, ideas. Now some Soviet leaders want to integrate the country with the West, open it, transform it.
That has long been America's hope. Yet it's naive to assume that the transformation will necessarily be liberalizing. The shock of a collapsing economy and shattered values are certain to spark reaction, and possibly conflict. That raises the second common goal. The West cannot afford to stand by and watch the struggle of Westernizers in the Soviet Union without trying to help.
The U.S. and the Soviet Union also share a common enemy -- the destabilizing force of weapons proliferation. Both countries need time for cutting arms and making plowshares, and need assurance that competition among nations will not assume a threatening form. That requires collaborative efforts at controlling the spread of nuclear, chemical, biological and conventional weapons.
There is no guarantee that even energetic collaboration can succeed; the most obvious recent evidence is named Saddam Hussein. Hence the fourth joint Soviet-American purpose: to promote collective security. Traditional alliances pit some countries against others. Collective security aggregates many against an aggressor. That approach was tested in repelling Iraq.
Mr. Bush can do much to advance these goals in Moscow. He can grant most-favored-nation trade status -- and speed up economic engagement. By meeting with Boris Yeltsin and the leaders of other republics and addressing the Ukraine's Parliament, he can lend moral support to far-flung reformers.
President Bush also can cooperate in converting Soviet military production and curbing arms sales. And he can discuss ways to act collectively for peace in the Middle East and the Balkans.
Much good can come of this summit meeting if, in short, both men act like allies.

HEADLINE: A Fix Too Quick on Unemployment

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats are suddenly seized with the idea that unemployment benefits for the nation's jobless are inadequate, and must be improved by next Friday. The House is developing a more honest fix than the Senate.
Bills to authorize up to 20 additional weeks of benefits are moving quickly in both houses because (1) members want to go on vacation at the end of the week, and (2) the Democratic leadership wants to show concern for victims of the recession, even if they've been slow to do so. 
 The problem is how to pay. Under last year's budget agreement, new spending must be offset by new revenues or by cuts in other programs -- except for emergencies. If there is a genuine emergency, certified by the President, no offset is required. But it's not cricket to use emergency funding as a trick to skirt the pay-as-you-go agreement. The deficit is large enough.
The Senate Finance Committee's bill opts for the emergency route. Arguing that President Bush has declared three foreign emergencies this year -- for Operation Desert Storm, for Kurdish refugees and for flood victims in Bangladesh -- the Democrats say it's time he acknowledged an emergency at home. But the Administration says the recession doesn't qualify, especially since the recovery may have already begun.
A more forthright approach is offered by Representatives Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Thomas Downey of Long Island. Their bill invites Mr. Bush to declare an emergency, but if he won't it lays out a valid alternative: increase the taxes employers pay into the unemployment insurance fund.
The insurance system needs more than either bill proposes. It is a smaller safety net than it used to be for several reasons, including stiffer standards adopted to avoid raising the tax. Also, the 1986 tax reforms made jobless benefits fully taxable as income, but made no provision for higher benefits. Alas, the time for fundamental improvements is when the economy is in good shape -- and Congress isn't interested.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
High Technology on a Large Scale

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
SAY what you will, there is still nothing like a big American sedan, at least for those of us who grew up lusting after Lincolns and Packards and Cadillacs. True, the likes of the new Lexus coupe make the luxury market a delightfully different ball game, but some of the domestic entries must be given their due.
Lincoln's Town Car is an exercise in quiet mobility, for example, and it is a car that I would happily own. Cadillacs, too, have been a longtime love, and I have owned a bunch of them, making me a member of a very large club. The other members have been uncommonly reticent this year, but even with bad days piling up in showroom upon showroom, Cadillac remains the nation's leading luxomobile. 
 And, for '91, the dealers have been given a new lure to mix with the Coupes de Ville, Sevilles, Broughams and the rest. The car is a de Ville Touring Sedan, and it packs luxury, comfort and surprisingly high technology into a hefty 17-foot-long package with front-wheel drive.
Perhaps it is the size itself that creates the surprise; instead of a small gem bristling with goodies at every turn, the new Cadillac has something here, something there -- with a lot of space in the middle.
The technology is not especially innovative, either, particularly in a car costing $36,316. There are the rolling locks pioneered by Lincoln, the antitheft ignition key stolen from Corvette, the central locking system which, among other things, allows all doors to be opened when you open the trunk. No, not sensational, but nice in the way that it comes together.
One thing that is new is the feature that makes this a "touring sedan," which is auto-speak for a stiffly sprung four-door that you can fling into a corner with some hope of eventually getting straight again. Cadillac calls it Computer Command Ride, and the retuned chassis and big aluminum wheels are helped by four electronically controlled struts that adjust the suspension as speed increases.
The struts remain in the "comfort" mode up to 40 m.p.h. From there to 60, they automatically adjust to "normal" mode. At 60, the struts shift into their firm state, allowing better control. The system also reacts to pitch and dive when brakes are applied, and a lateral accelerometer uses the struts to counter body roll at any speed.
The car drips chrome. It has bumper guards and the formal roofline of other Sedan de Villes, but it adds its own bits of trim and exclusive tan leather seats and interior. The trunk is huge by today's standards, and the rear seat matches it for space. One thing that's hard to understand, however, is that with those big back doors and all that length, the rear windows go down only half way. Unforgivable.
Up front, our metallic black sapphire Caddy had American walnut accents on dash and doors and a digital dash that was coy about troubling the driver with mundane information. Unless you go looking, the Touring Sedan is only candid about speed and miles traveled. For more, you need to go to the driver information centers on each side of the steering column, where the push of some buttons will let you know such things as range and fuel remaining.
As it turns out, quite a lot of that premium fuel does stay in the tank, and economy is estimated at 16 miles per gallon, city, and 26, highway. In a week's driving, the actual average was 19.9, more than respectable when you are moving a vehicle that weighs almost two tons with a V8 engine that puts out 200 horsepower.
The 4.9-liter aluminum powerplant will take the sedan from zero to 60 in 8.7 seconds, and it is hooked to an electronically controlled automatic transmission that uses a viscous clutch to improve smoothness in its shifts. Smoothness, of course, is Cadillac's middle name, and the car is quiet and comfortable, despite its sporting nature.
The steering wheel is wrapped in leather and houses an air bag in its center. Antilock brakes are standard as well, and there are the usual Cadillac niceties: an efficiently self-dimming rearview mirror, a 200-watt stereo system that includes a compact-disk player, headlights that come on by themselves when the sun goes down, and power everything.
In fact, when I looked at the window sticker, I thought for a moment that I had seen the ultimate in servo-assists. On the sticker's equipment list were these four lines:
 MIRROR -- AUTOMATIC DAY/NIGHT
 MIRRORS -- ILLUMINATED VANITY
 TRUNK LID PULL DOWN -- POWER
 TRUNK MAT
A power trunk mat, now that would be real technology. It turns out that the car has an electric pulldown for the lid and somebody just forgot the punctuation. Shucks.

HEADLINE: Inflation and Taxes Eat Up Treasury Bills

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Interest Rates, the Real Ones," a July 2 Business Scene column, points out that the 6.3 percent return on one-year Treasury bills is actually a 1.8 percent rate after adjusting for inflation at the current rate of 4.5 percent. From this the article then concludes that these investments of savings are "winners" because they yield a net return after inflation. 
 This calculation, however, does not tell the whole story, for it ignores the effect of income taxes, which are imposed on the entire 6.3 percent, even though most of the income is illusory, in reality representing merely a protection of principal.
Thus, assuming a 28 percent income tax rate, the real rate of return is virtually zero: 1.8 percent after-inflation return and 1.764 percent for income taxes. Few people realize that the effect of taxing the inflationary segment of the nominal return dramatically increases the effective income tax rate. In the above example, income taxes consume almost 100 percent of the after-inflation return.
I might add that there is, of course, a direct connection between this disastrous result for savers and the level of Government spending. Until Congress eliminates the enormous increases of recent years in Federal Government spending, which are widely believed to be the root of our inflation problem, this situation will only continue.
Is it too much to hope Congress will finally put aside its desire to curry favor with the recipients of Government largesse and proceed to reduce spending?
 
DWIGHT W. FAWCETT
Winnetka, Ill., July 10, 1991

HEADLINE: Soviet Economy Defies Improvement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Several of your July 14 articles taken together expose the predicament of the Soviet economy. Leonard Silk says in The Week in Review, "The economic disaster in the East has exceeded the gloomiest expectations of Western economists." 
 In the Forum (Business section), Marshall I. Goldman reminds us that "Since 1989, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has embraced -- only to discard -- about 10 economic reform plans." You summarize the latest, via Harvard, in the same Forum: it declares that "the basic principle is the creation of a market economy."
But your front-page article from Moscow observes that "in the absence of any experience of free enterprise, all the talk of free markets, ruble convertibility and privatization raises only vague and ominous images for most Soviet citizens." You then detail how the bold new programs "disappear in the tangle of competing jurisdictions or founder in a legal system utterly inadequate for its new tasks."
It seems the only valid advice for Soviet-type economies that are attempting reform is the old Irishism, "If I wanted to get there, I wouldn't start here."
 
AVINASH DIXIT
University Professor of Economics, Princeton University
Princeton, N.J., July 14, 1991
