HEADLINE: The Network Takeovers: Why ABC Survived Best

BYLINE: By KEN AULETTA; Ken Auletta is the author of "Three Blind Mice: How the TV Networks Lost Their Way," which will be published in September by Random House. This article is adapted from the book.

 BODY:
DAVID W. BURKE WAS A formal man. A vice president of ABC News, he was renowned for his starched white shirts with gold cuff links, round tortoise-shell glasses and fastidiously trimmed sandy hair. High-minded and exacting, the son of a Brookline, Mass., policeman, he was known around ABC News as "the headmaster." But here he was at the Arizona Biltmore in Phoenix, on his feet, clapping like an Amway salesman. He looked down at his hands, and willed them to stop. "Christ, what the hell am I doing?" he remembers thinking. He glanced around and saw 160 fellow executives, more than half of them from ABC, hollering like cheerleaders at this, the first management retreat since Capital Cities Communications officially swallowed the network on Jan. 3, 1986. 
 For three and a half days in late January, officials of the two companies met in the Arizona desert. When David Burke looked up at the Biltmore's stage, he saw Thomas S. Murphy, the lanky, avuncular chairman of the merged companies, winking at familiar friends, flashing a perfect row of white teeth. He listened as Murphy singled out the Cap Cities divisions that had had great years. "He was like a politician playing to his old constituency," Burke later remembered.
"Stand up and give them a round of applause," Murphy urged everyone -- especially, Burke felt, the folks from ABC.
So Burke, like everyone else, jumped up and, a moment later, felt miserable.
He was not alone. Employees at all three networks were feeling anxious. Ownership of ABC, CBS and NBC would effectively change hands within nine months. ABC was first, acquired by Capital Cities Communications, a notoriously "lean and mean" company that owned radio stations, TV stations (several of them ABC affiliates), cable systems, newspapers and magazines. In June 1986, NBC's parent company, RCA, would be acquired by General Electric, an industrial giant that had shed 25 percent of its work force in the past five years. And in September, Laurence A. Tisch's Loews Corporation, a holding company known for rigorous cost cutting, would gain control of CBS, William S. Paley's "Tiffany" network.
The adjustment to Cap Cities was difficult for many old ABC hands. Indeed, the month of January had been one prolonged insult. It was unnerving enough to be taken over by an affiliate, but even more so by a company whose local newscasts were among the first to billboard sensationalist crime stories. Employees took a punch in the nose when Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC, was replaced by a Cap Cities executive, John B. Sias, a ramrod-straight for-mer paratrooper with a fondness for peculiar practical jokes -- he once bounced through ABC's network newsroom on Lincoln's Birthday disguised as the former President.
A second jolt came when Sias informed Roone Arledge that he would no longer be president of ABC Sports, a title he had held for 18 years. Cap Cities said it wanted him to concentrate on managing the network's news division, which he had run since 1977. Arledge wasn't buying it. He knew Cap Cities abhorred his chauffeured Jaguar, thought he was the exemplar of what Sias and Murphy and Daniel B. Burke, the president and chief operating officer of Cap Cities, referred to as ABC's "limousine mentality." The line on Arledge was damning. As Sias put it, "He likes to spend money."
Like much else at ABC, the limousine mentality was a holdover from the flush era when the networks enjoyed a monopoly. Ten years earlier, in 1976, 90 percent of American viewers watched evening shows on ABC, CBS or NBC. On a typical night, the average household received just seven stations, and TV Guide listed only 14 viewing options. Neither Showtime nor ESPN nor CNN nor the Disney Channel nor MTV was included among the 14 -- aside from services like the struggling HBO, cable programming barely existed. Only the Big Three could afford to exhibit recent Hollywood movies. There were few if any syndicated shows, and none bulldozed a time period the way "Wheel of Fortune," "Jeopardy" or "The Oprah Winfrey Show" does today.
There were, in early 1976, few commercially available VCR's or cordless remote controls, no satellite distribution of programs, no backyard dishes, no superstations, no Fox network and just over 100 non-network commercial independent TV stations in the entire United States. Advertisers wishing to reach mass audiences were held hostage by the networks, whose revenues swelled by 324 percent between 1976 and 1984. The network was king.
Ten years later, the networks had reason to feel like trapped mice. Only 75 percent of viewers on a typical evening now watched the three networks. And in the 1990-91 season, when the average home would receive 33 channels, and 7 out of 10 homes would have VCR's, the network share would plunge to 62 percent.
Gripped by a sense of crisis, Cap Cities did what came naturally: it pounded away at costs. Every extravagance -- from ABC's six private dining rooms and six daily mail deliveries to its 17-room duplex penthouse at the Plaza Hotel and the $2,600 that "Good Morning America" spent each week on breakfast snacks for its guests -- would have to go. When the ax began to swing, some ABC employees worried that their new owners would cripple the network's ability to turn out a quality product.
As David Burke looked up at Tom Murphy, his mind raced over the first month of the Cap Cities rule, and as he later remembered thinking: "It will never be the same again. The business is going to evermore be different; be managed, be cost-conscious. Will they listen to a creative idea? Or does it all have to be cost-perfect?' "
 FOR CAP CITIES AND ABC, a more important clash lay ahead. May is the month when each network makes final decisions about the prime-time schedule for the fall season. In Los Angeles, Brandon Stoddard, head of ABC Entertainment, sat with his team and watched the 31 pilots submitted for consideration, compared them with shows currently on ABC and then prepared a draft schedule to present to the Cap Cities/ABC hierarchy in New York on May 15, 1987.
The 40-odd executives who entered the 38th-floor conference room at 1330 Avenue of the Americas had received tapes of the pilots. They knew ABC had lots of holes to plug. Because of ratings duds like "Starman" and "Life With Lucy," ABC would end the 1986-87 season in third place. Few in the room knew what Stoddard would recommend, though John Sias had a clue. Before the meeting Sias had phoned Arledge and told him, "Get your research together." Since Arledge had only two shows in prime time -- "20/20" and "Our World" -- he understood he had to be prepared to defend them against Stoddard.
But Arledge was not prepared for what happened next. Standing beside a magnetized board displaying the seven-night schedule of shows that would probably run on ABC, NBC and CBS, Stoddard, a short, perky, self-confident man, laid out at machine-gun speed the three building blocks that would support his proposed schedule. First, he had a hot new variety hour -- "Dolly," starring Dolly Parton -- that he wanted to broadcast Sunday from 9 P.M. to 10 P.M., the most-watched hour of the entire week. It was an hour dominated by the CBS Sunday night movie, which got a strong lead-in from "60 Minutes" at 7 P.M. and "Murder She Wrote," with Angela Lansbury, at 8.
Dolly could dent CBS's lead, Stoddard insisted. She would appeal to many of the older viewers now tuned to CBS, and she would be up against movies on both CBS and NBC. Dolly was hot, Stoddard assured the executives. Her "Smoky Mountain Christmas" on ABC came in fifth among made-for-TV movies in the 1986-87 season. When she'd teamed with Kenny Rogers for a Christmas special on CBS, the ratings had gone through the roof. Just to be sure, Stoddard proudly announced that ABC had tied her up with a three-year personal and production contract that, it was later revealed, would cost the network $34 million.
BUT THERE WAS A problem. In order to schedule Parton on Sunday, Stoddard said, he would have to find another night for ABC's Sunday movie, his second building block. He couldn't shift the movie to Monday: that belonged to Monday night football. Tuesday was also out of the question. It was already a winner, with comedies like "Who's the Boss?" "Growing Pains" and "Moonlighting." Wednesday, another strong night, was out as well. Neither Friday nor Saturday night would work either: the VCR had deflated these as movie nights. The ABC movie would have to be moved to Thursday.
Stoddard was now ready to unveil his third block. To make room for a two-hour movie at 9 P.M., he would shift the news division's magazine program, "20/20," from Thursday at 10. He would move it "right here," Stoddard said, slapping a magnetized "20/20" plate next to Thursday at 8 P.M. and shoving aside the plate for "Our World," a "you were there" montage of historical news clips.
There was a collective gasp. "20/20" would be up against NBC's blockbuster Thursday schedule, anchored by "The Cosby Show," the top-rated program in television. And not only would Barbara Walters, star of "20/20," and News languish in this forlorn time slot, but "Our World," after being mauled by Cosby for the last year, would disappear entirely. The way intramural score was kept at the networks, Arledge's division was "losing" an hour of programming to Entertainment, and the one prime-time hour it still had was being offered as another sacrifice to the Cosby juggernaut.
All eyes turned to Roone Arledge. An elegantly tailored man, with a carefully maintained coiffure, he sat absolutely silent for what seemed an eternity. Finally, Stoddard's deputy, Ted Harbert, jumped in, telling the assembled executives: "Research reports that the audience at 8 P.M. Thursday is potentially larger. '20/20' could kick off ABC's entire night. And if the movie was terrific, and if it ran more than two hours, it would be possible to shorten '20/20' and start the movie earlier."
Now Arledge reacted. "Stop!" he shouted. "This is out of the question!" The move was outrageous, a deliberate slap in the face of News.
"Why don't you run Dolly Parton at 8 P.M. on Thursday?" David Burke asked.
"What, are you crazy? You tell Dolly!" said Stoddard.
"You tell Barbara!" Burke shot back.
"This is the way it's gonna be," Stoddard announced. He had reason to feel emboldened. So far, Tom Murphy and Dan Burke had backed his every decision. Against their own business instincts, they had approved his requests for expensive mini-series. They had kept John Sias out of his hair. They had treated him as if he were an expert, even a high priest, as if he alone knew the secrets of network programming.
The room again fell silent. Stoddard knew Arledge had allies besides David Burke, the only other executive from News in attendance. The sales division, a bigger player in programming since Cap Cities had taken over, was a fan of the program, which commanded prestige advertising prices. The affiliates liked it because it pulled fairly good ratings, compared with many of ABC's other prime-time programs, and made a natural lead-in to their own late-night newscasts. And management liked it because the $20 million or so in profits that "20/20" generated helped put News in the black.
Stoddard, prepared to compromise, wandered over to the schedule board. He reached up and moved "20/20" from Thursday to Friday at 10 P.M.
"Try Tuesday at 10," countered Arledge, picking ABC's strongest night and a position right after "Moonlighting."
"Impossible," said Stoddard, noting that the slot was reserved for a terrific new series -- "Thirtysome thing." The audience flow from "Moonlighting" to a series about yuppie angst made a perfect fit. To stick "20/20" there would suddenly skew to older viewers.
Arledge lost Tuesday. He didn't much care about the demise of "Our World," a ratings disaster. But he did feel passionate about "20/20" and his good friend Barbara Walters. To move "20/20" from Thursday to Friday at 10 would mean a smaller available audience, he said, since Friday and Saturday were the least-watched nights of the week. That would translate into a revenue loss, since advertisers paid less for smaller audiences. And he knew that if the program no longer produced a profit, News would lose clout.
ARLEDGE WAS GENUINELY irate. "20/20" was a workhorse for the third-rated ABC; in its eight years on the air, it had always earned a bigger audience share than its lead-in show. And there was something else. Roone Arledge, more than anyone else in the room, had put ABC on the map. Using hand-held cameras and shotgun microphones and instant replays, he had pioneered the modern look of TV sports on shows like "Wide World of Sports" and "Monday Night Football." And he had brought showmanship to news, with split-screen interviews and socko graphics.
In pursuit of the right look, Arledge sometimes drove his minions crazy. For years he had badgered the anchor Frank Reynolds to wear dark suits and avoid button-down collars and polka-dot ties -- they did not convey "authority," he announced. When he was dying, Reynolds and his wife, Henrietta, hatched a conspiracy. Although the coffin would be closed, as a final protest he would be dressed in a cream-colored suit, button-down collar and polka-dot tie.
Roone Arledge respected Stoddard, but he didn't understand why he was treated with such reverence. As a scheduler he was surely no genius. Recently he had put "The Betty Ford Story" against the second installment of CBS's smash mini-series "I'll Take Manhattan," which appealed to the same female audience. Lose this fight, and Stoddard would be liberated to move News wherever he pleased. Arledge threw down the gauntlet: "If '20/20' goes to 8:00 Thursday, we won't produce the show."
The stalemate was now complete. And Murphy would have to break it. He would have to decide between News and Entertainment, a forbidding prospect even for an experienced network hand. Rising, Murphy looked squarely at Stoddard and said, "You are one tough son of a bitch." They would sleep on it, announced Murphy, and gather in a smaller group tomorrow.
But the next day's session produced deadlock again. Finally, after yet another day of acrimony, Murphy announced a decision to the entertainment division: "We'll go with Friday at 10 P.M."
Stoddard's staff burst into applause.
"How dare you applaud?" exclaimed Murphy. He was angry, disturbed that Stoddard's people saw the decision as a victory for themselves. That wasn't the way Cap Cities did things. Murphy himself didn't bother to read press clippings about himself, not even when Business Week put him on the cover. He prized teamwork. Murphy adjourned the meeting, saying he would talk to Arledge.
"We've made a decision," Murphy announced as soon as he, Dan Burke and John Sias were seated in Arledge's fourth-floor conference room, where they were joined by David Burke and two other News vice presidents. "We're going to move '20/20' to Friday at 10 P.M."
"We have had eight years of success with '20/20,' " Arledge said. "And we are being badly treated. The decision is wrong. The research department said it is wrong. The affiliates said it was wrong. Sales said it was wrong." The jabs stung, for the Cap Cities people felt uneasy with the decision they had made.
Before they could respond, David Burke squared off against Tom Murphy. "It's been hard on everyone going through the merger, hard on you, Tom, and hard on us," Burke said. "We've tried to anticipate your management style. The people involved on both sides don't share the same jargon or history. And we in News are arrogant, for good reason. We feel the weight of public responsibility." Burke paused, then threw a wild punch: "That little twit on the West Coast has no right to push aside News!"
"He isn't a twit!" shot back Murphy.
"Yes he is!" Burke shouted. "But as time went on, Tom, I got comfortable. News management and I were on the team. And you were my leader. And yet, as my leader, you come in and say Brandon Stoddard, not Tom Murphy, is my leader. Well, I don't want to have Brandon as my leader."
Dan Burke was stunned, but before he could utter a word in his boss's defense, an unruffled Tom Murphy said: "I understand how hurt you are. This is the toughest decision I've ever made."
Tom Murphy was serene. He saw the sometimes bitter negotiations as another step toward encouraging frankness, unbottling feelings. This belief was reaffirmed in the weeks and months afterward; when the papers were filled with stories on the squabbles at CBS and NBC, Cap Cities management never read about the sulfurous things David Burke had said to Tom Murphy.
The May scheduling battle was the first big institutional fight within ABC in the nearly 17 months since the takeover, and the lessons it taught would help change the way Cap Cities managed its network. Murphy and his team came to understand that a network was not like one of the Cap Cities stations or its publishing division. Institutional rivalries and conflicts came with the turf. But the No. 3 network could not afford a fratricidal war. And Dan Burke, a stern, even moralistic taskmaster ("the Cardinal," some called him), wasn't about to allow it. Cap Cities would have to modify its decentralized approach and become more involved in decision-making. And ABC's competing divisions would have to learn the meaning of teamwork.
Entertainment had won the battle, but perhaps it had lost the war. Murphy and company began to see that picking programs and deciding on a prime-time schedule was not the arcane science they had thought. Soon after the meeting, Sias later recalled: "Tom and Dan told me they wanted me to be a little more heavy-handed. Tom was frustrated and concerned that we were not making progress in prime time. By insisting that Dolly be on Sunday at 9 P.M., it caused us to lose the Sunday movie. And we had invested $350 million in movie product. After May, I was a little less reluctant to come in there and have a say."
In the aftermath of the scheduling sessions, Murphy summed up his changed thinking: "The area we're least comfortable with is the most important -- entertainment. But we're no longer virgins."
 "DOLLY" WOULD QUICKLY expire in the next season, confirming to the new owners of ABC that they had made a mistake in deferring to Stoddard's judgment. Variety shows no longer pulled viewers, and Parton turned out not to have universal appeal. Moving "20/20" to Friday did not turn out as badly as Arledge had predicted, but since many fewer viewers watched television on Friday nights, its audience was off.
Still, there were some grounds for optimism. Even Brandon Tartikoff of NBC, television's reigning programming genius, declared in the fall of 1987, "I'd say that ABC has planted a few seeds that could develop into something." Shows like "Thirtysome thing" offered distinctive drama, prompting TV critics to proclaim that ABC, not NBC, was the new champion of "quality" programming.
There were other signs of progress as well. By the end of 1987, nearly two years after it officially took over ABC, Cap Cities was further ahead of its network rivals in creating a more congenial place to work. At NBC, the new president, Robert C. Wright, was cheap with compliments; even more damaging to morale, he kept wondering out loud whether network television might not be doomed to extinction. Laurence Tisch, the president of CBS, also believed that compliments encouraged complacency. Rarely venturing from his corner office to schmooze, he was generally regarded as a Scrooge-like figure, chained to his Quotron machine and calculator. Both NBC and CBS managed by instilling fear, believing that it kept employees on their toes.
The Cap Cities way was different. Dan Burke and Tom Murphy believed that contented, less fearful employees would be unafraid to stick their necks out, to take chances. This was one reason why, after an initial round of job cuts, in which 1,800 people were let go, they planned to avoid layoffs in the future (and did until July of this year). It was the reason why in 1989 they decided to assure Arledge and News that their newest creation, "Prime Time Live," would not be subject to the tyranny of the Nielsen ratings; the program would be given a full two years to succeed or fail. While Tisch and Wright lunched privately in their own suites, Murphy, an easygoing backslapper who called everyone "pal," ate at least three times a week in a communal dining room open to 145 company executives, as did Dan Burke.
The people at ABC came to feel that Murphy and Burke might truly be different from the dreaded new owners at CBS and NBC, that they understood television as an institution. With more fervor than either Wright or Tisch, Murphy and Burke championed "the public trust" (although Cap Cities tolerated a glut of crime stories and "happy talk" on most of its local newscasts). "A network," Murphy said, "touches 100 percent of the people every day. I consider being in broadcasting special, and with it comes a special responsibility."
Slowly, Cap Cities seemed to be getting a grip on the entertainment side of the business as well. Plunging feet first into Hollywood, Murphy was looking more closely at research reports on entertainment shows, attending focus groups designed to spot the strengths or vulnerabilities of series already on the air. His confidence grew. "I have very common taste," Murphy explained that fall. "I have been surprised by the correlation between what I like and what the viewers like. I'm more confident of my own judgment now."
Murphy also came to appreciate that in Hollywood a network had to spend money to make money. A single hit meant millions for ABC. Talent was expensive, but it was even more expensive to watch NBC lock up the best producer-writers. So in the fall of 1987, Murphy signed off on an extraordinary "talent" contract to tie up Steven Bochco, creator of ABC's promising series "Hooperman" and NBC's breakthrough "Hill Street Blues" and "L.A. Law." The package, linked to a syndication deal with 20th Century Fox, was said to be worth up to $50 million. ABC, said Bochco, was sending a signal. "People assume, correctly, that if I'm willing to work at ABC it's because I've got freedom," he said. "That's a wonderful message to send to this community."
Confidence grew throughout ABC. Surely the good feeling would translate into higher ratings, just as it had under the legendary Grant Tinker at NBC in the first half of the 80's. Handicapping the three-network race in late 1987, Peter A. Lund, then an independent TV executive and now executive vice president of the CBS Broadcast Group, echoed a common refrain about Cap Cities: "I keep thinking that ABC will be the winner of this crowd. Why? Because Murphy and Burke are broadcasters, and because I have never heard so many people say so many nice things about their bosses. People at ABC think they're terrific managers. They have created an atmosphere that can lead to success. At a time of insecurity in the business, that's important."
As Murphy and Burke learned that crafting a schedule was not a science, so they learned that producing and orchestrating what gets on the air could be an art. Throughout the organization, a sense spread that Murphy and Burke were coming to think less about costs and more about the magic of television. A turning point came when they took a close look at ABC's masterful coverage of the 1988 Winter Olympics, produced by Roone Arledge. "The Cap Cities people went up to Calgary and saw what a network does," said Michael P. Mallardi, who had been ABC's chief financial officer and who now oversaw their TV stations and radio and video-enterprise divisions. "They came away with a real appreciation." They showed that appreciation to Arledge not long afterward, when they awarded him a new five-year contract, boosting his annual salary from $2 million to nearly $3 million.
More good news arrived in March 1988, when Ted Koppel, who had been working without a contract, agreed to remain at ABC. The decision came just after Peter Jennings had been signed to a new contract and was given a new executive producer. For ABC, the payoff came quickly. After several years of turmoil, the gifted anchor relaxed, and viewers responded. By February 1988, Jennings occasionally edged into first place in the weekly ratings, a pattern that would solidify into a permanent lead beginning in 1989.
 IN THE THREE-NETWORK competition, ABC was gaining. Compared with NBC and CBS, it suffered the smallest audience decline in the 1987-88 season. Its schedule was not dominated by aging shows -- on average, its series were two years old, compared with a little more than six for CBS. And ABC was a strong No. 2 in its demographics, with more youth and urban appeal than CBS. Shows like "China Beach," "The Wonder Years," "Moonlighting" and "Thirtysomething" demonstrated that ABC was doing distinctive television. And with its lineup of comedies on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday at 8:00, it had the table-setters to entice viewers on several nights. ABC already had more shows in the top 30 than CBS, and the following season, "Roseanne" would knock the mighty "Cosby" out of first place. In 1989-90, ABC would be the only network to gain viewers.
In a newly competitive industry, Cap Cities/ABC enjoyed some strategic advantages. It had the most-balanced portfolio of holdings. It owned ESPN, the nation's largest cable programming service, eight TV stations rated No. 1 in their urban markets, as well as AM and FM radio stations, newspapers and magazines. ABC was a major investor in the Broadway theater, owning stakes in such hits as "Cats," "Phantom of the Opera," "Amadeus" and "Dreamgirls" -- theatrical investments made with an eye to the future potential of pay-per-view. And overseas looked promising, with ABC poised to become what Dan Burke described as one of "the six or so integrated companies" that would compete in global communications. Under Bob Wright, NBC would race to catch up and diversify from broadcasting to cable. CBS, meanwhile, had already shed most of its cable-programming investments; under Tisch it would sell its remaining nonbroadcasting holdings, including its magazines and publishing division and CBS Records.
While the ultraconservative Larry Tisch invested most of CBS's cash in Treasury bills, and NBC's managers followed the risk-oriented General Electric philosophy, Cap Cities steered a middle course. It had grown from a single Albany TV station by relying on prudent acquisitions and cost cutting. Success taught Cap Cities that rewards came to the slow and sure.
This impression of "balance" both shaped the new culture at ABC and helped convince broadcasters and industry analysts that ABC was the network to watch. A 1989 Broadcasting magazine poll of securities analysts found Wall Street touting Cap Cities/ABC stock. In 1989 ABC posted profits of more than $165 million, up from a loss of $4 million the year before. In prime time, the youthful reach of ABC's shows would whittle away at NBC's ratings and demographic leads. In the morning, in the wake of the Jane Pauley fiasco, "Good Morning America" shot past "Today." In the evening-newscast race, Peter Jennings and ABC News came to be seen as the best of the three news organizations, as Jennings's and ABC's handling of the gulf war confirmed. In sports, as CBS suffered heavy losses and NBC lost its baseball franchise, ABC turned a modest profit.
But ABC was "winning" a loser's game. By the end of the 1990-91 season, the damage from the earthquake that had struck broadcasting was unmistakable. The three networks lost 5 percent of their prime-time audience this season, as their share fell to 62 percent.
For the second year in a row, no network opened the season with a certifiable hit. And what hits the networks did have -- shows like "Cheers" (NBC), or "Murphy Brown" (CBS), or "Roseanne" (ABC) -- now attracted ratings one-third to one-half smaller than those of network hits of past years. This year, pounded by falling ratings and a recession, the three networks together are likely to lose money.
Yet, even though ABC's prime-time resurgence seems to have stalled, analysts have tended to note Cap Cities/ABC's strengths -- its advertiser-friendly demographics, its news and sports divisions (the most profitable among the three networks), its diversified portfolio of investments. And a management team so strong that when Tom Murphy turned over leadership of the company to Dan Burke in June 1990, it seemed less a break than a graceful transition.
 FOUR YEARS AFTER rallying the troops at the Arizona Biltmore, Tom Murphy delivered an emotional thank-you to industry executives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. "I always thought it was something special to be a broadcaster," he said. "The part of the network most dear to my heart is the news division. . . . The greatest personal satisfaction I have gotten out of being associated with ABC is when the slide goes up and you see the ABC logo and it says under it, 'More Americans get their news from ABC News.' "
Tom Murphy was saying something special, something that Peter Jennings and Tom Brokaw and Dan Rather and other journalists who come to work each day at the networks craved to hear.
They wanted to feel appreciated. And they wanted to hear something else, something that Murphy would also say, as if by reflex. Before the applause subsided, Murphy hushed the crowd, and invited one of his executives to stand and bask in the spotlight, alone. When the light reached its destination, Murphy introduced "the genius behind the great ABC News operation -- Roone Arledge!"
Later in the evening, after Peter Jennings paid a brief but poignant tribute -- "Tom, we are proud to work for you" -- the sportscaster Jim McKay rose to lift his glass. "Frankly, when Cap Cities took over some five years ago," he said, looking at Murphy, "all we knew about them was that they were supposed to be 'lean and mean' and run a tight ship. Didn't sound like us, did it, Roone? Well, we found they were lean but really weren't mean at all. . . . We found this was a business organization that used words like 'integrity' and 'honor' and 'responsibility' -- and meant them."
Like their counterparts at the other two networks, Dan Burke and Tom Murphy have at times been quite ruthless in terminating employees. And ABC, like NBC and CBS, has sacrificed quality for ratings, has too often chosen to entertain rather than instruct. But amid the turmoil in television, ABC was simply a better place to work. Not because it had invented some new management technique like General Electric's "workout sessions" or improved its ratings, but because, while keeping an eye on the bottom line, Cap Cities seemed more sensitive to the human factor. "I've never met anyone who tired of compliments," observed Dan Burke.
Unlike the top management at either NBC or CBS, it did not seek to defeat the old culture. It became more involved in Hollywood. Just as important, Cap Cities management took the time to mingle and laugh, to give pats on the back, to share credit. It respected the sometimes passionate reasoning and traditional totems of its workers, knowing that anxiety and ambition, pride and panic can overwhelm dollars-and-cents business logic, can boost or retard profits. In the middle of an earthquake, Tom Murphy and Dan Burke radiated a sense of security.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2894 words

HEADLINE: Pop Radio Suffers a Midlife Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID BROWNE; David Browne is a senior writer at Entertainment Weekly.

 BODY:
As Wilson Phillips' "You're in Love" booms through the control room of Z100, you would think the New York-area radio station was doing everything right. At its Secaucus, N.J., headquarters, the "morning zoo" disk jockeys Gary Bryan and Ross Brittain are bustling around making prank phone calls to executives and rattling off traffic and news updates. Every so often, Mr. Bryan scans the music log -- a computerized list of songs he must play every hour -- and grabs a pile of tape cartridges, each containing a current hit. Those marked with blue dots indicate songs that, in the words of the show's producer, Mike Opelka, are "really happening." For a Top 40 station, one that plays the pop hits of the moment, life doesn't get any more normal.
But at Z100, officially known as WHTZ-FM, and many other pop radio stations around the country, things are seriously out of tune. Z100 had been No. 1 in its market from 1987 through the summer of 1989, three times earning a competition-squelching 6.2 share (percentage of the listening audience, based on Arbitron data). By the spring, Z100 was lingering at 3.6, lagging behind stations specializing in oldies (WCBS, with a 5.2 share), dance pop (WRKS, with 5.1), soft rock (WLTW, with 4.8) and six others. 
 Z100's sinking ratings are an indication of the dire circumstances of Top 40 radio, which, when it was the only game in town, used to determine what was a hit record. Top 40 has experienced slumps before, but now must compete with formats that specifically appeal to fans of rock oldies or hip-hop or hard rock. This fragmented audience, combined with the increasing role of MTV and the aging of the baby boomers, is taking its toll on old-fashioned Top 40. The national Arbitron/Billboard share for the format went from 14.4 percent in the spring of 1990 to 11.9 percent in the winter of 1991.
And it's not just Top 40. No longer the sole backbone of the music business, pop radio as a whole is having a midlife crisis. Unsure of whether to grab teen-agers or baby boomers, station owners have switched formats faster than listeners can switch stations; last year alone, 1,050 stations -- roughly one-tenth of all commercial stations -- changed formats, lurching from Top 40 (Paula Abdul) to Adult Contemporary (Gloria Estefan), from hard rock (Guns 'n' Roses) to Classic Rock (the Doors). As station playlists focus narrowly on one type of music fan, and as stations become more attuned to advertisers than listeners, the result is a significant change in what we hear and where we hear it.
Granted, Top 40 is still instrumental in making hit singles. "Unless radio brings it home, it won't be a hit," says John Boulos, a vice president of promotion and field operations at Virgin Records. But as Steve Kingston, Z100's vice president of programming, says, "The rules have changed -- it's a whole new ball game."
Much of the conundrum is radio's own fault. In the 60's, it was possible to hear the Rolling Stones, the Supremes, the Monkees and Aretha Franklin on one Top 40 station in an hour. Today, with the expansion of the FM band that began in the early 70's, those acts would probably be found on separate stations. The FM dial is sliced and diced into as many different music formats as there are shredded vegetables at a salad bar.
Top 40 -- or CHR, Contemporary Hit Radio -- blares hits from Billboard's singles chart. For the latest in synthesized dance pop, rap and club beats, there's UC (Urban Contemporary). For primarily white rock-and-roll, there's AOR (Album-Oriented Rock). For mellow soft rock, AC (Adult Contemporary).
If you're not yet confused, each has subdivisions (like Adult Urban Contemporary, which features upscale black performers like Luther Vandross, or Classic Rock, an offshoot of AOR). There are formats so new they have not yet developed acronyms -- alternative-rock stations that dare to play bands (Depeche Mode, the La's) with members under the age of 40.
This fragmentation and segregation has done wonders for advertisers, who love niche marketing. It has also alienated people who would sooner watch MTV than turn the radio dial in search of music they like.
In the record business, radio is both tolerated because it helps sell records and scorned because it is too static and formulaic. Record companies have been stung by the lack of "back announcing" on radio, the practice of telling listeners what songs they just heard. (A sign of discontent: "When You Play It, Say It!" stickers pasted on new albums as forceful reminders to careless disk jockeys.) In fact, it is increasingly common for record companies to forgo radio initially and introduce a song on MTV.
The very idea of a mass-appeal station -- one that would attract a wide class and age range with something for everyone -- has been lost. Given the cultural fragmentation of the country itself, maybe it was inevitable. In the 60's the weekly WABC-AM Top 40 show "Cousin Brucie's Saturday Night Dance Party" had a 25 share in New York and reached an audience between the ages of 10 and 60. These days, a Top 40 station would be lucky to get a 5 share with an audience aged 18 to 24.
Possibly the decline is a backlash against rap or the pulsating dance music of groups like C&C Music Factory and Tara Kemp. "Top 40 has become a real balancing act," says Mr. Brittain of Z100. "In '83, there was Michael Jackson, the songs from 'Flashdance,' Cyndi Lauper -- all these mass-appeal artists who crossed boundaries. Now it's difficult to play rap without the adults saying, 'Goodbye!' And you can't play the softer pop without the kids saying, 'Too wimpy!' It's a problem."
 
Demographics
Wanted: Young Single Female
 Top 40 used to be simple -- the hits just kept on coming. When the baby boomers came of age (and took the lion's share of buying power with them), radio began singing the tune of pinpoint demographics.
The result? Too much dance pop. Not enough dance pop. Too much Led Zeppelin. Not nearly enough Led Zeppelin. Everyone complains about radio except the advertising community. In that demographic-dominated world, keeping listeners apart is precisely the plan. Music is a tool to reach a specific consumer, preferably age 25 to 54 and female, advertisers' ideal consumer.
If you listen to a particular station, the radio world already has you pegged. According to the Radio Advertising Bureau, Top 40 listeners -- those who tune in to KISS-FM in Los Angeles or WBBM in Chicago, for example -- are 18- to-34-year-olds who buy CD players, drink Coors Light beer and drive a Toyota Celica. Album-Oriented Rock and Classic Rock stations (WNEW in New York, WYSP in Philadelphia) are targeted at 25- to-35-year-olds who drink Corona beer, buy audio components and drive a Toyota MR2. Those who listen to soft rock on Adult Contemporary stations (WBZ-FM in Boston, KOST-FM in Los Angeles) are 24 to 44 years old, gulp Miller High Life, buy TV sets and drive a Toyota Corolla.
"You have to sell specifics -- the whole idea of 'wide' is gone," says Warren Potash, the president of the Radio Advertising Bureau. "The only one who wants to reach everybody is the census."
 
 
Pushing Product
All the Hits, All the Time
 To reach these specific demographics, radio stations must make sure they are playing exactly the right songs at exactly the right time, reducing playlists to a science. Program directors gauge phone requests, conduct phone surveys, scan the Billboard charts, study the playlists of competing stations and listen to relentless pitches from radio promotion executives at record companies. Although dozens of singles are released each week, only three or four (at most) are added to the average Top 40 station.
Shady characters have long been a part of the music promotion business, and they still lurk in the shadows. Flogging performers like Vanilla Ice and Wilson Phillips through independent promoters -- hired guns who, in exchange for large salaries, pitch records to stations -- continues unabated despite the Justice Department's most recent payola investigation. (The case ran aground when charges brought in Los Angeles were dismissed last year against the leading promoter, Joseph Isgro, and other industry figures.) Independent promotion is not illegal, but payola is.
One former executive at a major record label (who insists on anonymity) says her company's radio promotion department would routinely entice program directors and other personnel with vacations in the Bahamas and prostitutes. "People in radio promotion have unbelievable expense accounts that they don't have to justify," she says. "There was an attitude of 'Whatever it takes. . . .' "
Labels spend an average of $70,000 on independent promotion for high-priority albums, according to a survey by a Los Angeles accounting firm. The promoters' influence means that banal songs are often added to radio playlists.
Once songs are selected, many stations use a computer to group them into hourly music blocks; the computer insures that the same artist isn't played twice in a row and that certain cuts are played regularly. The big hits, called "powers," are played about every two hours. In a technique called "day parting," hits and easy-on-the-ears pop are played in the morning, ballads in the afternoon and hard rockers later in the day and into the night. Mr. Kingston of Z100 says there is no other way for radio stations to compete for narrow demographics. "The alternative is to put a box of records in the studio with the deejays," he says. "But the business is too sophisticated these days for the primitive ways of the past to work."
Mr. Bryan, the Z100 deejay, agrees, but with reservations. "Programming is too research driven," he says. "There's too much money at stake for people to make decisions based on gut feelings."
 
 
Competition
The Video Takeover
 Research, among other things, dictates that Top 40 stations play catch-up with video. "MTV is the single most important factor on your side," says Mark Di Dia, general manager of the record company Def American. "You still need radio, but if MTV's on your side, it's the equivalent of 100 radio stations playing your song."
The Top 10 success of the Divinyls' "I Touch Myself" provides a textbook example. Until this year, the Australian band had never had a hit and was regarded as a cult rock act -- a hard sell to Urban Contemporary stations. So John Boulos of Virgin Records developed a multitiered approach to convince Top 40 radio to add the song.
In a process that Mr. Boulos calls "a relay race," Virgin first established the song at college and alternative-rock stations and sent its provocative video to MTV. The network immediately took to the clip. It was six weeks before "I Touch Myself" was shipped to pop radio, at which time program directors had no choice but to play the song.
"We set it up so that, when it went to pop radio, everything was ready," says Mr. Boulos. The tab for making "I Touch Myself" a hit, he says: more than $500,000 spent on making a video, independent promotion and air fare for Mr. Boulos and others to visit radio stations around the country, plus the use of most of Virgin's 25-person radio promotion staff. The payoff: 500,000 albums sold.
 
Adults Only
Nothing but Love Songs
 The power of the baby boomers is reflected in the Adult Contemporary formats, which have grabbed the largest slice of the pop radio pie. These playlists -- the perfect way to reach 25- to 50-year-old listeners -- program pleasant, midtempo soft pop, from Chicago to Londonbeat. Unlike Top 40 announcers, Adult Contemporary disk jockeys are calm and mild-mannered, and the general mood is as reassuring as a phone message from a good friend. "We play songs you can sing along to but not get depressed over," says Robert Dunphy, vice president of programming at WNSR-FM, a New York Adult Contemporary station.
But there are many different kinds of adults. Basic easy-listening Adult Contemporary relies on Barry Manilow, Kenny Rogers and other relative old-timers of the genre. For a slightly "hipper" alternative, there is Hot AC (also called Mix), which favors a younger, more rhythmic generation: Phil Collins, Sting, Mariah Carey, even Billy Idol. Other specializations include Lite (heavy on love songs), Beautiful Music (instrumental selections a la Muzak) and light jazz-fusion. Adult Contemporary stations are so numerous, in fact, that the format leads in overall ratings even though any one station may not be No. 1 in its market.
"AC does better when times are economically shaky," says Mr. Dunphy. "People don't know where the country's headed, so they're looking for a safe haven."
WNSR and other Adult Contemporary outlets may be in for some competition over the male component of the demographic. Several stations around the country have switched to the latest variation on the format -- Rock AC, essentially singer-songwriters and country-rockers of the 60's and 70's like Jackson Browne. "Instead of just playing the Eagles' 'Desperado,' " says Mr. Dunphy, "they'll go deeper into the album and play, say, 'Tequila Sunrise.' " He adds, not at all facetiously, "It's a variation with a lot of promise."
 
 
What's Missing?
Between Rock And a Hard Place
 Wonder where brash, new, innovative rock-and-roll fits into this bleak scenario? You're not alone. Since the advertising world's targeted age group is 25 and up, rock stations tend to dwell in the past -- the Rolling Stones, Jethro Tull, Crosby, Stills and Nash and other baby-boomer war horses. According to Broadcasting magazine, the number of Classic Rock outlets went up 160 percent -- to 240 stations -- from 1989 to 1990.
Nor is new rock welcome on Top 40 stations, whose audience favors electronic dance-pop and rap. Stations are therefore often reluctant to add guitar-based rock bands to their playlist. Current albums by Van Halen and Skid Row have both hit No. 1 without the benefit of a Top 40 single. Even an eagerly awaited single like Guns 'n' Roses' "You Could Be Mine," a thundering rocker from the band's long overdue "Use Your Illusion II" album, has not been immediately embraced by Top 40 stations.
If any new rock band could have attained a foothold on either Album-Oriented Rock or Top 40, it should have been the Black Crowes, the Atlanta boogie-rockers who sound like the illegitimate sons of the Rolling Stones and Humble Pie. Nonetheless, pop radio turned a deaf ear to all four singles from their first album, "Shake Your Money Maker." As a result, their label, Def American, opted to promote the band through touring and MTV. It worked: the album sold two million copies with hardly any radio air play. Only now is the band's third single, "Hard to Handle," which was released last fall, receiving consistent air play.
"It's a sad state of affairs," says Mr. Di Dia of Def American. "If people are buying it and radio isn't playing it, something's wrong."
The drought of Top 40 rock could end when Bruce Springsteen, Guns 'n' Roses and U2 unveil new albums this year; pop radio's acceptance of R.E.M.'s brooding folk-rock single, "Losing My Religion," could be a harbinger of things to come. Or, says Ken Barnes, the editor of the trade magazine Radio and Records, "it could also be the last hurrah" for rock on Top 40.
 
 
Forecast:
Increasingly Cloudy
 There is no denying the continued appeal of Top 40 radio, nor the exhilarating feeling of hearing a favorite oldie or a compelling new single boom over the airwaves. "Radio is a comforting and comfortable medium," says Mr. Barnes. "It attempts to communicate one-on-one."
There is no denying that pop radio still has a few tricks up its sleeve. A year ago, it would have been unimaginable that the Top 40 hits would include "Losing My Religion," E.M.F.'s "Unbelievable" or the Extreme's Beatlesque ballad "More Than Words." But that's just what happened. It might be rash to expect a return to Top 40's most recent golden era of 1983 to 1985, but such loosening up does mean that listeners will be able to hear a little variety -- or at least something other than the thump-thump of a drum machine -- on their local stations. In radioland, this is considered progress.
Yet even Mr. Barnes says he believes that, in the 90's, pop radio will continue to fragment, reflecting the aging of the baby boomers, their continued spending power and their outright disdain for beat-heavy pop.
Says Sean Ross, radio editor of Billboard: "The days when 'American Pie' came out on Monday and everyone was talking about it by Friday are gone. But I believe it can happen again."
The Z100 crew hopes so, too, but it's easier said than programmed. Gary Bryan says it has been his dream to invite a bunch of legendary black 50's disk jockeys in and let them play their favorite 45's from that period. "You know, it might be fun to return to that sense of anarchy," he muses, turning to his co-host. "Ross, will anarchy ever happen here?"
"Nope," says Mr. Brittain, chuckling and shaking his head. "Highly doubtful." Case closed.
Outside the confines of the Z100 studios, though, the situation is not such a laughing matter. Lost in a morass of generation gaps and market research, pop radio's power and signal grow a little dimmer every day.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC: 'Cav' and 'Pag' Visit Little Italy;
Sunny Villages In Calabria And Sicily . . .

BYLINE: By KENNETH FURIE; Kenneth Furie is a former music editor of High Fidelity magazine.

 BODY:
As you have undoubtedly heard, "Cavalleria Rustica na" and "I Pagliacci" are moving. By Saturday eve ning, assuming all goes well, the New York City Opera will have completed the relocation of Mascagni's and Leoncavallo's perennial verismo twins -- cartons unpacked, curtains hung, dishes put away, breakage and loss tallied -- from their ancestral homes in, respectively, Sicily and Calabria to New York's Little Italy.
Actually, City Opera is becoming a practiced hand at these long-distance hauls. Only last night, Verdi's "Traviata," formerly resident in stodgy old Paris, was safely ensconced in present-day New York and Paris. 
 And perhaps it will all work out. There's nothing inherently impossible in this business of transposing an opera setting. Still, the business shows signs of getting out of hand, and in the specific case of the verismo twins, the theory -- that transposition can make the subject matter more available to an audience -- seems especially dubious.
These are operas that openly aspire to reality, and Leoncavallo provided a stirring and seemingly misunderstanding-proof manifesto in the Prologue to "Pagliacci." To cite just the famous climax (better still would be to listen to it from the throat of a good baritone): "And you, rather than our poor actors' cloaks, consider our souls, since we are men of flesh and bone, and like you we breathe the air of this orphan world." A worthy goal, one would think, for any kind of opera.
Nevertheless, the popular understanding of "verismo" seems to inspire attention mostly to those actors' cloaks. For example, in a recent published interview, City Opera's general director, Christopher Keene, ventured that verismo opera "should really shove your face in the grit and grime," as if "truth" were equivalent to "grit and grime." "No more happy peasants in pretty costumes," Mr. Keene promised. "These will likely be the most violent productions of the two operas that New York has seen."
And yet, who are those people in the opening scenes of both operas if not "happy peasants" -- and at least in "Cavalleria," on Easter Sunday morning, in their prettiest costumes. For that matter, the merchants and homemakers of "Cavalleria," which takes place in the village square, would probably have something to say about this "grit and grime" stuff -- don't you get the feeling from the score and the setting that this village glistens under the Sicilian sun?
Nor is it apparent what "violent productions" have to contribute to these operas. The world of "Cavalleria" is in fact one of extreme order. It certainly contains violence, but you would hardly know it from most of what happens in the opera, and even the act of violence in which it culminates is specific and contained -- Turiddu knows the inevitable outcome of his involvement with Alfio's wife. The world of "Pagliacci," apart from the demons lurking in Canio's mind, isn't noticeably violent at all.
If you wanted to find the truth of these operas, like any great work of art, you would surely want to start by discovering their worlds. Their concerns are closely linked to time and place: the orthodox social-religious values that permeate the Sicilian village depicted on this hot Easter Sunday in "Cavalleria"; the entertainment-starved Calabrian village that provides a backdrop for the rootlessness of the traveling players depicted in "Pagliacci."
The values represented in these operas, and the conflicts that grow out of them, surely have universal relevance. Isn't that why we have great composers? Transpose the setting, and what are the chances of finding sufficiently close and consistent equivalents? Isn't it likely to be harder rather than easier to to make an audience recognize and identify with those values and conflicts?
"Cav" and "Pag" were meant to be revolutionary operas, and they are. It shouldn't be held against them that the hoped-for revolution never really happened, that it was co-opted by cartoon images of "verismo." It shouldn't be held against the composers that neither came close to matching this relatively youthful achievement. (Mascagni was 26 when "Cavalleria" had its premiere, in 1890; he died in 1945. Leoncavallo was 35 when "Pagliacci" had its premiere, in 1892; he died in 1919.)
So where might one look for the revolutionary truth of the verismo twins? An example from each opera may serve to show how a performer has found real life in the score, guided by the "Pagliacci" Prologue's admonition that its author "was inspired by what is true."
 
Conducting 'Cavalleria'
 In 1940, the 76-year-old Mascagni accepted an invitation to conduct a recording of "Cavalleria," complete with a wonderfully stagy spoken introduction. The recording isn't generally much admired. The performance is slow. There's not much aural evidence of passionate involvement on the part of the orchestra and chorus of La Scala. The general explanation is that the composer was old and tired, not to mention 50 years removed from the act of composition, and there was after all a war going on.
And yet, whether or not Mascagni would have conducted the opera the same way 50 years earlier, he seems to me in close touch with the compositional impulse. He produces a dramatic coherence and power unapproached by anyone else I've heard -- the only conductors who even pursued this direction being Herbert von Karajan in his recording and Leonard Bernstein at the Met.
From the opening theme of the Prelude, sweet and sultry, Mascagni's performance seems generated by the physical life of the village: the heat through which the inhabitants move with stength of purpose but economy of energy, the communal investment in the morning preparations for the Easter service and then the service itself.
The "Regina Coeli" can have such a monumental impact that one almost sympathizes with Francis Ford Coppola's impulse to cheat in "Godfather III," pretending that this great chorus is the climax of the opera rather than a relatively early event.
For the villagers, it may in fact be the climax of the year. For the opera, it is the basic reality that provides context for subsequent events: the ringing affirmation that "the Lord is not dead" answers all the Big Questions for the villagers and binds them in answer, even as it excludes poor excommunicated Santuzza, for all the fervor of her prayer.
Excommunication in fact seems to have given Santuzza a shred of identity, however heartbreaking: "Sono scomunicata!" -- the central fact of her existence, which nobody in the village appears even to remember. (She has to remind both Mamma Lucia and Turiddu.)
Make Santuzza's place in the community real, and she can be among the most heart-rending protagonists in opera. To hear how the opera's gruesome climax emerges from the texture of daily life in the village, listen to the composer shape his own score.
 
Singing Silvio
 "Pagliacci" is a more straightforward piece, and comes with a built-in road map to reality in the form of the Prologue. So a different form of example may be helpful.
A decade or so ago, before the present glut of wonderful baritones made his services unneeded at the Met, the Canadian baritone Allan Monk lent considerable distinction to the second-line principal roles in which he was cast. These came to include Silvio, the second baritone in "Pagliacci," who has the great scene in which he persuades Nedda to "fly with me," and then returns at the end to become Canio's second victim.
Essentially no information is provided about Silvio. There's just what can be gleaned in the passionate utterances of the duet. Since lovers in the throes of infatuation tend to sound similar, it's easy to think of Silvio as a more dashing and gallant alternative to the outwardly charming and inwardly raging Canio.
And then there was Allan Monk: a somewhat dumpy looking fellow with a lovely, cultivated voice and a highly developed sense of truth in his singing -- the instinct and ability to sing as a human being. And for once the scene made real sense. Silvio is offering Nedda peace, relief from the physical and psychological rigors of her itinerant life with Canio, of which the audience has just seen a fairly brutal sampling.
"The author has sought to paint for you a slice of life," the "Pagliacci" Prologue sings. "His only maxim is that the artist is a person, and that he must write for people." The authors of both these operas have done their job too well, in that both operas have a built-in emotional power that's hard to spoil. But if their inspiration were to be found in "what is true," they might then rise to a whole other kind of power.
 
 
 
'CAV/PAGS' ON CD, AND OTHERS MISSED
 As a group, the "Pagliacci" recordings are stronger than those of the trickier "Cavalleria Rusticana." (All available recordings cited are on CD only.)
First, some overall choices. For "Pagliacci," a pair: the low-key but well-sung 1954 New York recording with Jussi Bjoerling, Victoria de los Angeles, Leonard Warren and Robert Merrill (Angel CDC 49503; mono), and the vibrant 1961 Scala recording with Franco Corelli, conducted by Lovro von Matacic (Angel; currently unavailable).
For "Cavalleria": Bjoerling's 1958 Florence stereo remake, with Renata Tebaldi and Ettore Bastianini (RCA, then London; currently unavailable).
Among the available stereo versions, tread carefully. Herbert von Karajan's 1965 Scala coupling (Deutsche Grammophon 419 257-2), while somewhat overrefined, is beautifully played and well enough sung. London's 1960 recordings (421 870-2) offer slightly stodgy but idiomatic performances with forceful singing by Mario del Monaco and Cornell MacNeil, plus capable colleagues. London's presentable 1967 "Pagliacci" (uncut) with James McCracken, Pilar Lorengar, Robert Merrill (now Tonio) and Tom Krause has been reissued by Innovative Music Productions (IMPX 9017).
Finally, some interesting supplements, beginning with the Canio and Turiddu of Beniamino Gigli -- still in ringing form in the 1934 "Pagliacci" (Angel CDH 63309; mono), vocally stressed out in the moving composer-conducted 1940 "Cavalleria," with Gino Bechi (Angel CDHB 69987; mono); Bongiovanni has issued a listenable 1938 composer-conducted "Cavalleria" from The Hague (GB 1050-2) -- also slow but more urgent. There are points of interest in the work of Callas and company in their 1953-54 recordings (Angel CDCC 47981; mono).

HEADLINE: Scientist Champions Cause of Natural Gas as Fuel

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
BACK in 1982, Prof. Enoch Durbin was pondering an offer to study solar energy in the Negev in Israel when one of his engineering students at Princeton University stopped by to ask him to breakfast with his father, a high-ranking government official in British Columbia.
That casual invitation eventually led Professor Durbin to forgo his desert expedition to spend his sabbatical leave instead in the cooler climes of western Canada. There, he took up a challenge issued over coffee that morning in Princeton -- to help wean the province off its dependence on imported oil. 
 To make that happen, Professor Durbin and the British Columbian Minister of Science, Patrick McGeer, set up a system to re-equip vans and cars to run on compressed natural gas. Today, a network of service stations that dispense natural gas to a growing number of retooled vehicles has reduced British Columbia's oil imports.
Professor Durbin returned from Canada convinced that he could transplant his experience to the United States. Ever since, he has been a tireless supporter of natural gas as the alternative fuel of the future. He supports this source of fuel, he says, because it is plentiful, cheap and better for the environment and would make the United States less dependent on the Middle East for energy needs.
To promote his cause, he has been traveling around the country, calling on Washington politicians, Detroit auto makers, state lawmakers or anyone else who can advance the cause.
"He is a very stimulating individual," said Bernard Robertson, general manager of jeep and truck engineering at the Chrysler Corporation. "Yes, I would certainly describe him as a crusader."
 Such efforts are hardly likely to gain Professor Durbin much popularity in a country where any tampering with the automobile is regarded as a sacrilege, Professor Durbin said. Describing himself as a Don Quixote, Professor Durbin said that when he told his family he would take on the quest of "changing the way America fuels its cars," his wife, Marilyn, responded, "You must be out of your mind?"
Professor Durbin says he does not expect everyone to want to drive a car powered by natual gas. But he argues that if just a few big operators of buses and vans were to switch to that type of fuel, the payoff would be enormous. "If we doubled our consumption of natural gas to replace oil, we could just about wipe out our foreign oil imports," he said.
 Even if many people are skeptical about the prospects for radical change in gasoline consumption levels, Professor Durbin said he was encouraged by several recent developments. One is the decision by the United Parcel Service to convert its vans to natural gas. Federal Express and Entenmann's Bakery are expected to follow suit.
A breakthrough on the government side, he said, occurred when Texas voted to give financial incentives to fleet operators to switch to natural gas. Yet another experiment will occur much closer to home: Princeton University is preparing to convert some of its vans to natural gas.
Not everyone involved in the search for petroleum substitutes agrees that natural gas is the answer. Researchers have been exploring other ideas, including hydrogen, ethanol, methanol and battery-powered engines.
Professor Durbin said he believed that these ideas were all grievously flawed and that natural gas was the superior fuel. Hydrogen, for example, is clean but is easily ignited and is therefore too dangerous, he said.
Methanol, now being promoted by some Bush Administration officials, is "highly toxic, and because it is soluble in water it can easily contaminate our water supplies," Professor Durbin said, and ethanol, though a renewable source of energy, "uses up more energy to make than we get back." Electric vehicles will not be feasible until a lighter battery is designed; currently, batteries equivalent to a 12-gallon tank of gasoline weigh 7,000 pounds, he said.
 
Some Drawbacks to Natural Gas
 Not surprisingly, however, each of these options has its supporters, and auto manufacturers are exploring a number of alternatives to the gasoline engine. Even a champion like Professor Durbin concedes that natural gas also has some drawbacks, mainly that natural-gas tanks hold less fuel and would therefore limit the range for most cars to about two-thirds that of a tankful of gasoline.
But Professor Durbin says the advantages of natural gas far outweigh the disadvantages. On the positive side, natural gas costs about 50 to 80 cents a gallon and reduces smog by producing lower levels of pollutants like carbon monoxide. "It's a superb fuel," he said.
A longtime resident of Princeton, Professor Durbin, 63 years old, has three grown children and has served on the Borough Council. Professor Durbin, who has been on the Princeton faculty for more than 30 years, is also director of the university's Instrumentation and Control Laboratory, situated in the Engineering Quadrangle. There he has been working to perfect an auto engine that could burn natural gas as well as oil. But in the last few years he has also been striving to build grass-roots support for natural gas, a more elusive and frustrating task, but one that he seems to enjoy nonetheless.
Just recently, he spoke to groups ranging from the Princeton Club of New York City to the New Jersey Engineers Club in Trenton to the Unitarian Church in Princeton (of which he is a longtime member) to a panel of auto makers at the Automobile Show in New York City. He is now involved in establishing a federally financed center at West Virginia University to study alternative transportation fuels.
To excite the average person about the propsects for natural gas is not a simple matter, but Professor Durbin approaches the subject with a mixture of wit and cynicism.
 
A Typical Rendition
 "There are many concerns that might motivate you -- the environment, the troubled Middle East, the balance of payment deficits, my children's and grandchildren's obligations to pay those bills," he said, in a typical rendition of his pitch. But, he added with a laugh, "nobility is too slow. It's more effective to appeal to only baser motives -- fear and greed."
The fear side, he said, was helped by the Exxon Valdez disaster, which heightened concerns over damage caused by oil to the environment. The instability in the Middle East was more than amply demonstrated by the Persian Gulf war, he said, adding that in the last decade, the United States has drastically increased, rather than reduced, its imports of foreign oil. "Our energy policy is based on Saddam today; tommorrow, some sheik in Saudi Arabia," he said.
"For roughly the cost of our military operations in the Middle East, we could convert about a million vehicles a month" to natural gas, Professor Durbin wrote in a recent article.
That leads, he said, into the greed part of the equation. "Here's a way to put money in your pocket," he said, touting economic advantages to consumers. In Texas, where some stations are equipped to pump natural gas, it is selling for about 69 cents a gallon versus $1.09 for gasoline.
An experiment now under way there capitalizes on this point, he said. A new law requires owners of fleets to operate a certain percentage of their vehicles on natural gas by 1992, unless they could show they would be economically harmed by the switch. In fact, Professor Durbin said, the law will likely benefit some of these operators because they can save money on fuel and apply the savings to their operations. He likes to cite the example of a school superintendent who, he said, could save enough by switching a fleet of school buses to natural gas to hire two new teachers.
 
Engine Life of 500,000 Miles
 Natural gas is also kinder to the pocketbook in other ways, he said. Gaseous fuel prolongs the life of engines: an engine life of 500,000 miles would not be improbable. It is safe, he said, asserting that there has never been a fire in a natural-gas vehicle. And the known reserves of natural gas far exceed those of oil; there is enough natural gas in Canada alone to meet the needs of North America well into the next century. Natural gas has the added advantage of being renewable, he said, because it can even be produced from garbage.
Professor Durbin said he used a similar approach with politicians. He recently told a group of Congressmen that reducing the nation's dependence on oil "is one of those issues that can help you get re-elected -- and do some good at the same time," adding, "it's rare that the two coincide."
Alternatives to the standard automobile have been around for a long time; a fleet of solar- and battery-powered cars rolled into New York City recently as part of an alternative fuels promotion. But only a major push by the automobile makers could lead to a sizable effort concerning alternatives.
Natural gas vehicles are more common in some other parts of the world, Professor Durbin said, noting that Italy has 350,000 cars that run on the fuel. But none of the 750,000 natural gas vehicles now operating in various parts of the world were built in an auto factory, he said. "They were all built in someone's backyard," he said.
There are some signs that auto makers may be taking a step toward production of a natural gas auto. Mr. Robertson, of Chrysler, said the company was "bullish" about the use of natural gas. "We do see a demand for compressed natural gas vehicles," he said, "especially for fleets with a central fueling station."
 
A Higher Price Tag for Cars
 An initial problem will be to overcome consumer resistance to the higher price tag of natural gas vehicles, Mr. Robertson said. "The early vehicles are going to cost $4,000 more than the standard models," he said. "We don't see that many customers standing there with orders, but we do see a potential market for it."
 Dr. Roberta Nichols, a research director at the Ford Motor Company, expressed skepticism about the development of natural gas vehicles on a large scale. "We don't see it for the family sedan," she said. "It's wrong to single out any one fuel as a winner."
Since it does not pay oil companies to explore for natural gas they simply vent the natural gas that is released when oil is produced. The Soviet Union alone flares off gas equivalent to 100 million barrels of oil each year, Professor Durbin said. "If you flew around the earth in a satellite," he said, "the brightest object on earth is the Saudi or Soviet fields flaring -- or venting -- natural gas."
Such imagery may make the case for natural gas a little more tangible to the average driver of a gas-guzzling automobile. But in the near term, any change in the way the United States uses gasoline must be marketable -- by making it financially advantageous, he said.
New Jersey's major urban areas, like Newark and Camden, could benefit from converting public buses and taxis to natural gas, Professor Durbin said. Because these vehicles consume large amounts of fuel and contribute heavily to pollution, he said, the payback would be immediate.
The other day, as he prepared to go to Washington to push natural gas to members of Congress, Professor Durbin reflected on his decadelong crusade. Before his stint in Canada, he said, he had been involved in fusion research. And if it had not been for his meeting with his student's father, he may have gone into another field. Now, however, natural gas as a solution to a major transportation issue is his main focus.
"Call it the lucky accident and the prepared mind," said Professor Durbin, recalling a favorite phrase of a Princeton colleague. He employed the same principle after he developed tennis elbow a while ago. He designed a new racquet that reduced vibration and sold it to a manufacturer; it was rated one of the best racquets by a German sports society.
Natural gas may be more esoteric than tennis but Professor Durbin believes he can convince people of its benefits. "I have been talking about it, writing about it, helping people to understand it," he said. "I think it is irresponsible to simply do the research and then say, 'Here stupid world, this is what you ought to do.' "

HEADLINE: Loans for the Elderly Tap the Untapped

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
AS the owner of a successful beauty shop in Mamaroneck, Josephine Cairo, who now is 71, managed to accumulate enough money to fulfill her fondest wish: owning her own home.
"In 1967 I had a ranch house built in Rye Brook," Miss Cairo said. "It was my dream come true, and I hope to live in it forever." 
 But although Miss Cairo owns her house free and clear -- the mortgage was paid off years ago -- until recently she worried constantly about being able to afford to keep it.
 
'I Couldn't Keep Up'
 "Some years ago, I had a serious heart attack, which required a five-way bypass operation," she said. "I had to retire and sell the shop. I've been in poor health ever since. Doctors' bills and real-estate taxes were becoming too much for me. I couldn't keep up."
In June 1990, Miss Cairo, whose house was appraised at more than $300,000, received a five-year reverse mortgage from the Hudson Valley Bank. It pays her $1,495 a month.
"With that and the $681 I get from Social Security, I am just about managing," she said. As repayment, the bank will receive part of the proceeds from the eventual sale of her house.
 
Untapped Equity
 Miss Cairo is one of millions of Americans living on fixed incomes who have untapped equity in their mortgage-free homes. In 1982, Congress passed legislation enabling financial institutions to make home-equity conversion mortgages, commonly known as reverse mortgages, to people like Miss Cairo. The loans are for homeowners over 60, and allow them to borrow against the appraised values of their homes.
Yet banks were reluctant to issue such mortgages, and it was not until 1989 that reverse mortgages were available in Westchester, under a program sponsored by the Westchester County Office for the Aging and the Hudson Valley National Bank in Yonkers, which was then the only bank that agreed to make such loans.
The limit on the term of home-equity conversion mortgages like the one held by Miss Cairo is 10 years, said Doris Schear, the program director for Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit group that advises the elderly on housing issues.
But reverse mortgages with lifetime terms are insured through a Federal Housing Administration program that began in January. The program covers reverse mortgages of up to $124,875 from financial institutions making F.H.A. loans. Eligible borrowers are people over 62 with paid-up mortgages.
 
'Good News' for the Elderly
 "It started as a demonstration project by the Department of Housing and Urban Development two years ago, and it's now become a permanent program," Ms. Schear said. "No repayment of the loan is required until the house is sold or the owner moves somewhere else for more than 12 months."
The F.H.A.-insured reverse mortgages offer borrowers several options, including receiving monthly payments and getting lines of credit, said Yola Corbett, an assistant vice president of Prudential Mortgage Company in White Plains. Her company is an independent mortgage banker designated by the Federal housing agency to make F.H.A. reverse-mortgage loans in the Westchester area, and has no connection to the similarly named life insurance company.
"The maximum claim amount is determined by an appraisal, which is done by a H.U.D.-approved appraiser," Ms. Corbett said. "The mortgage rate is set with a formula using the U.S. Treasury securities rate. The borrower is also charged for mortgage insurance."
Prudential Mortgage, which has been reviewing and processing loans in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Vermont since January, made its first closing in New Jersey, Ms. Corbett said.
 
Paying Medical Bills
 "My clients were a couple aged 76 and 75," she said. "Their reason for receiving the reverse mortgage was to pay for excessive medical bills and other bills they had incurred within the last year. They chose payment of a lump sum up front and the remaining they took in a line of credit for future use."
Unlike a traditional residential mortgage, which is repaid monthly, a reverse mortgage is repaid once: after the death of the borrower or when the borrower no longer occupies the property as a principal residence, Ms. Corbett said.
"Most often, the reasons given by my clients who want this type of financing is that they need the money to pay off large medical bills or to make repairs to their property," she said. "Other clients want it to pay for private nursing care or for living expenses.
"The older you are, the more you can benefit, as the maximum monthly payments made to someone 85 years old are almost four times as much as the payments made to someone 62 years old. It's the same dollar amount, but it's spread out."
 
Bailed Out in a Recession
 Reverse mortgages with the 10-year limits, like those being issued by Hudson Valley National Bank, have been godsends to people who never thought they would need them, Ms. Schear said. "In this recession, what we're seeing is so many people who can't get a second mortgage because their income has dropped," she said. "They are being bailed out by being able to use the equity in their homes."
A woman in her 60's who lives in Hartsdale recently came in for a loan application, Ms. Schear said. "Her husband, who had a good job as a middle manager, lost his job in a corporate takeover. But the wife is working, and she wanted to keep her job for four more years in order to get her pension."
"The problem, which is a very common one in Westchester where most houses are worth over $250,000, is although their house was valued at over $400,000, without the husband's salary their income dropped so they didn't have the money they needed for taxes and expenses."
Now with monthly payments of $1,500 from their reverse mortgage, Ms. Schear said, "they're able to hang on for four more years, when they plan to sell their house and move to Florida."
 
$8 Million Committed
 Hudson Valley Bank has committed $8 million to reverse mortgages since the bank began the lending program two years ago, said Elizabeth M. Lindberg, a bank vice president.
"When the county asked us to participate in the program, in order to get it off the ground, we felt as good neighbors we should become a lender," said Ms. Lindberg. "To date, we've made 61 reverse-mortgage loans. Most people take an up-front advance. They can borrow up to 75 percent of the appraised value of their home, up to a maximum of $125,000, and the income from a reverse mortgage is not taxable."
Ms. Schear mentioned another client,"a lively woman in her 70's," who owns a house worth over $400,000.
"She plans to sell it in five years and move out of the state. She told us she borrowed the money to take trips, which she feels she's strong enough to do now but she may not be able to manage five years from now, when she sells her house."
