HEADLINE: For Los Angeles, an Office District by Consensus

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

 BODY:
THE plan for Central City West, an ambitious new office district in this city, seems to invite skepticism. Consider these bare facts: A small number of affluent developers buy land in a Hispanic neighborhood and decide to remake the area into a high-rise office center.
The developers hire their own consultants and pay for their own land-use plan, which is readily approved by City Hall. They then pay to transform the streets from cramped byways into gracious boulevards suitable for skyscrapers. 
 With the stage thus set, the developers have the right to build 25 million square feet of office space, almost as much as currently exists in downtown Los Angeles.
Proponents of Central City West say the plan is not an assault on good public policy, as some critics claim. They say the plan for the 325-acre area directly west of the Harbor Freeway may represent a new standard in consensus-building in city planning.
To devise the plan, developers met face-to-face with local residents, politicians and planners. In the end, the developers agreed to pay more than $1 billion for transportation amenities like freeway off ramps as well as social benefits like low-income housing and open space.
The Central City West plan represents "a public-private approach, rather than the city just imposing regulations," said Dan O'Donnell, a planner for the city of Los Angeles who monitored the process for the planning department.
Both land and location are the attractions of the area for Central City West Associates, a group of 26 developers and land owners that spearheaded the planning effort. The group includes, among others, Hillman Properties of Newport Beach, LaSalle Partners Ltd. of Chicago, the Hospital of the Good Samaritan of Los Angeles and United Parcel Services.
With few construction sites remaining in the core of the financial district, developers in general have bought land just west of the Harbor Freeway, even though the 10-lane corridor has traditionally been the Great Wall separating the financial district from the working-class Hispanic neighborhood on the other side of the freeway.
Local conditions, however, appeared to thwart high-rise development. The west side of the freeway is largely lacking in off ramps, while surface streets are narrow and discontinuous. Neighborhood residents who feared displacement objected to new projects.
The process that resulted in the plan for Central City West began three years ago when a group of landowners and developers approached Kenneth Topping, then planning director for the city, with a plan for traffic improvements. Mr. Topping told the developers to go further and create a land-use plan for the area. Shortly after, Gloria Molina, who was then a City Councilwoman and has recently been elected a Los Angeles County Supervisor, demanded a role in shaping the plan. She remained an aggressive advocate of affordable housing and neighborhood preservation.
From the beginning, Ms. Molina made it clear that she would oppose any displacement of working-class residents. The Hispanic community in downtown Los Angeles has experienced such displacements in Bunker Hill, a downtown neighborhood razed in the 1960's to make room for office buildings, and in Chavez Ravine during the 1950's, cleared to make room for Dodger Stadium.
Into the 80's, residents like Mauricia Miranda, a homemaker, continued to face threats of eviction and displacement by commercial developers. In 1986, Mrs. Miranda succesfully fought such an eviction, and later emerged a leader in United Neighbors of Temple-Beaudry, a 300-member group formed by Ms. Molina to represent residents in talks with the developers.
A five-person steering committee, representing council districts, city agencies and the developers, oversaw the often-rancorous planning process for Central City West. The negotiations, which lasted for two years, "had a lot of friction," recalled Clifton Allen, a planning consultant who drafted the plan.
Residents wanted to remain undisturbed, and Ms. Molina wanted to preserve the fast-dwindling stock of local housing. City officials wanted transportation solutions, including rail and van pools, that made sense on a regional level. The developers wanted a policy to guide their projects through an increasingly turbulent and uncertain approval process.
Ultimately, the developers agreed to replace all housing demolished since 1984, and to build another 10,000 units, a 235 percent increase in the area's housing stock, at a cost of $300 million. Child care and other services would cost $100 million more.
Transportation improvements, to cost the developers an additional $650 million, are to include freeway-lane widenings, a second level to the Harbor Freeway for buses and vans and pedestrian bridges over the freeway. A commuter rail station is planned near the office district, where planners expect a daytime population of 79,000 people.
Safeguarding the process is a strategy of phased development. Every five years for the next 20 years, the steering committee is to determine whether the developers are keeping their promises to build housing and traffic improvements before further projects are approved.
With Ms. Molina's support, the Los Angeles City Council approved the plan in February.
The first phase of Central City West, the $300 million, 840,000-square-foot, 41-story Los Angeles Center Phase I office tower, starts construction this winter. The project is a joint venture of Hillman and Smith & Hricik of Glendale, Calif. Another development partnership, made up of Shimizu America, a subsidiary of Shimizu Corporation of Tokyo, and PRP Development of Riverside, Calif., plan 1.1 million square feet of office space, a 640-room hotel and another 100,000 square feet of retail, to start construction in 1993.
The Central City West plan continues to be a source of controversy among city planners and planning consultants. Critics ask whether the plan is a subversion of the public policy process, since development is driven by a small number of developers with major land holdings in a traditionally residential area. Without the push from interested developers, those critics say, the plan would not exist.
But it also has its defenders. Neil Peterson, executive director of the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, praised the plan as a "forerunner of the way land-use decisions are to be made in the future," by planning for transportation along with buildings.
Central City West's large-scale approach resembles "the 'special-purpose' districts in New York we did in the Lindsay administration, such as the Fifth Avenue Special Zoning District," said William Fain, a former New York city planner who is currently a principal of the local architectural firm of Johnson, Fain & Pereira. The firm created the 18-acre site plan for Los Angeles Center and designed the first two buildings.
Mr. O'Donnell of the city's planning department remains positive about developer-sponsored planning, observing that the city lacks the manpower and resources to create comparable urban plans. "If it were not for the development community, the city would not have done anything close to what is in this plan."
The process of getting diverse groups to agree to create Central City West was ultimately "more important than the plan itself," said David Grannis, a planner who represented the developers on the steering committee.
"The development community needed to open itself up a little bit to participating in public policy, and the city needed to open up to the economics of development," he said.
Mr. Allen, a planning consultant, acknowledges possible hazards in a planning process initiated by the private sector. "There is a danger of imbalanced representation," he said, "that one group will dominate the process." He said such public-private negotiations need strong political leadership like Ms. Molina's, and a powerful referee like the plan's steering committee.
Mrs. Miranda is one person who does not question the process. "The plan represents a lot of things to the Hispanic community," she said through an interpreter. "There is no reason to change it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Model of Central City West, the planned new office district west of the Harbor Freeway in Los Angeles. (Johnson Fain and Pereira Associates)

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: WILLIMANTIC;
Paper, Paper Everywhere, but Who Wants It?

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
JAMES DeVIVO watched as newsprint was unloaded from a garbage truck at his Willimantic plant, and he pointed out the egg cartons, plastic-foam plates, cereal boxes, plastic bags and paper towels that were mixed in the shipment.
"One of the problems we're having is the quality of paper from the towns has gone way down, to the point it's almost worthless," said Mr. DeVivo, 55 years old, who has spent 40 years in the recycling business, the last 35 with his own company. 
 When recycling was voluntary, he said, people who were committed to the cause separated their trash. Now everyone is supposed to do it, but many people are less than careful, Mr. DeVivo said.
 
Can't Predict Prices
 "I keep hearing the state talking about education, about how we have to educate the public how to recycle," he said. "But I keep getting trash in these loads. It's going to take two to three generations for people to really be trained."
The quality of paper is not the only problem facing Mr. DeVivo's company, Willimantic Waste Paper. Mandatory recycling has produced such a glut that he cannot predict the price, or even whether he can find a market, for recycled paper, glass, metal or plastic, he said.
"We shipped out 3,000 tons of newsprint in the last two weeks," he said, "but only because I have so many contacts. And even then I had to pay $15 a ton to get rid of it. It's the first time in our history we've had to pay to get rid of it."
Mr. DeVivo now accepts paper and other recyclable goods only from towns that have him under contract, more than a dozen municipalities in all.
"The markets are not great," acknowledged Kim M. Trella, a senior environmental analyst with the State Department of Environmental Protection. "We had done a lot of market studies for the things that were on the mandatory recycling list. But there were a lot of things, including the poor economy, that came together, and we don't have any magic formula to set things right. That will have to get better with time."
Ms. Trella said the problem is worse for paper than it is for glass, tin and aluminum, which all seem to be finding markets, although their prices are down.
"The towns that had set up long-term contracts to get rid of their material are doing fine," she said. "The towns that are on the spot market, that try to sell to the highest bidder, are the ones having trouble. Some of those towns have to pay to have their newspaper hauled away."
 The board chairman of the Connecticut Recyclers Coalition, a trade organization, Frederick P. Goodrich 3d, acknowledged that "government-mandated collection is far outstripping the ability of the markets to absorb the materials being recycled."
 The prices that some recycled materials fetch are stable, "but they're not going up," Mr. Goodrich said. "But our collection and processing costs are going up, so we're still hurting."
Mr. Goodrich said New Jersey has a program to lend or give money to businesses that use the recycled products, and he would like to see Connecticut do the same.
"The small businesses -- the end users, the processors -- have to be stimulated," he said. "And I don't see that happening in Connecticut."
 
'So We Do It'
 Walter Gudzunas, the First Selectman in East Windsor, one of the towns that was turned away by Willimantic Waste Paper last month, said the town is now paying $30 a ton to get rid of its paper.
"But even what we're paying is cheaper than bringing it to the landfill, where it costs us $65 a ton," Mr. Gudzunas said. "I don't think we have a choice. The state statutes say we have to recycle, so we do it."
Noting that East Windsor only started recycling this year, Mr. Gudzunas said towns that are longtime recyclers are probably more frustrated at having to pay to have paper hauled away when they used to get as much as $40 a ton for it.
 Mr. DeVivo's business, started in 1956, is one of the state's older recycling centers (they were called junkyards in the old days, he notes) that are experiencing a glut.
He said the state upset a delicate balance when it established mandatory recycling.
"Years ago the Boy Scouts and volunteer groups picked up paper and brought it to a recycling center as a way to raise money," Mr. DeVivo said. "When the supply got to be too great, the prices would drop, and these groups would no longer collect. Then the mills would work off their backlog, the prices would go back up, and everything stayed in balance.
"With mandatory recycling, the flow never stops, never even slows down."
 
New Rules Cut the Load
 The tide of paper, glass, metal, and plastic onto Mr. DeVivo's 14-acre property threatened to bury him until he began turning it away. Where he was once taking in a few hundred tons a month, he found himself receiving 10,000 tons a month. His paper baler had to be rebuilt after running three shifts a day, six days a week, for months.
By instituting new restrictions, which included no longer accepting paper brought in by the carload, Mr. DeVivo said he managed to cut his workload back to a more manageable 3,000 tons a month.
"The government has done nothing with mandatory recycling except cost the towns more money," he said. Although a heavy international demand still exists for newsprint, Mr. DeVivo said his buyers understand the situation he faces.
"The Koreans and the Japanese know our market better than we do, and they know we're oversupplied," he said. "One of my Korean contacts came out here to see me recently, and the minute he drove in the yard and saw these mountains of paper, he knew he had me."
White office paper, which once brought $200 a ton because of its high quality, is now being accepted by the mills only if the recyclers deliver it, he said.
 
Processing Adds Costs
 "I had mills begging me to get into plastic, milk jugs and soda jugs and that type of stuff," Mr. DeVivo said. "So I got a baler and I went to work. Now those same guys won't take my calls."
Another problem has been the quality of the recyclable materials he has taken in, he said. The loads are so contaminated that he has to have his employees sort them before they can be pushed into the baler for compacting. That adds more expense to processing the paper, Mr. DeVivo said. It now costs him $25 to $30 a ton to process newsprint and $85 a ton to dispose of any trash mixed in with the paper -- expenses he has to pass back to the towns collecting the paper, he said.
"Older people, who were used to landfills, can't be trained to recycle," Mr. DeVivo said. "It's evident here that they're not doing what they're supposed to be doing."
The State Department of Environmental Protection, which has been pushing recycling, has also made it more difficult for him, he contended.
At first the department told him his glass and can recycling business would be "grandfathered," because he has been doing it so long. Then officials decided that his expanded operation required a new permit, meaning he will have to pay $7,500 for the application fee, $1,500 a year for the license, $5,000 for a survey and more money for a consultant to prepare the permit application.
"By the time I get done, you're looking at $50,000 to get this permit," Mr. DeVivo said. "That's what they want me to pay at a time that business is terrible."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Paying For Spending of 80's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 3 news analysis of the Connecticut state budget crisis attributes it to "falling tax revenues due to the recession." Our study on the fiscal condition of the states found that in the 1980's Connecticut tax collections rose 161 percent. Connecticut ranks third of all the states in per capita tax collections. This is hardly a state starved for revenues. 
 The real reason for the fiscal crisis in Connecticut is not even mentioned: runaway spending in the 1980's -- a path toward fiscal ruin that has finally caught up to the state. Connecticut's spending rose by a whopping 173 percent from 1980 to 1989. Only one state, Arizona, had a faster spending splurge. Given this mushrooming of the budget, Connecticut taxpayers are wise and fiscally prudent to resist imposition of an income tax, which would only further encourage wasteful expenditures.
 
STEPHEN MOORE
Director, Fiscal Policy Studies
Cato Institute
Washington, July 10, 1991

HEADLINE: The American Games;
For Games in Cuba, the Athletes Come to Compete and Politics Come Into Play

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
They will begin to trickle in this evening. By Friday, more than 17,000 athletes, journalists and tourists representing 39 nations will have converged on Cuba for the largest international event ever on the island nation.
The 11th Pan American Games will begin in Havana with opening ceremonies on Friday followed by 16 days of competition among member nations of the Pan American Sports Organization. 
 The United States, which has by far the richest and most sophisticated sports machine in the hemisphere, will send a delegation of 700 athletes to compete in Havana and Santiago.
 
Dominating the Field
 The Americans are expected to dominate most events in track and field, gymnastics, women's softball, swimming, shooting, taekwondo and judo. The women's basketball team, which has built a reputation for invincibility once enjoyed by the men, will attempt to extend a 41-game winning streak in major international competition.
The men's team, embarrassed at home by Brazil at the 1987 Pan Am Games and relegated to a bronze medal at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, will attempt to rebuild its diminished international stature.
A young but talented United States baseball team will have to finish in the top four to gain a berth in the 1992 Olympics. In a move that still angers amateur baseball officials, the team lost seven key players to the professional baseball draft.
Cuba, the defending Pan American champion, is the baseball favorite while Nicaragua, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic are strong contenders for an upset and an Olympic berth at the very least.
"This is a tough road trip, and we feel the pressure," said Ron Polk, the coach of the United States team. "Baseball is our national pastime, but it's theirs, too, and the fans are going to be pumped up. They'll have sirens and bongo drums. It can be intimidating."
There is an electrifying quality over all to this year's competition because it is being held on what, for many Americans, is a forbidden island, a place that has been off limits, with a few execeptions, for more than two decades.
For United States athletes from archers to sailors, the trip to Cuba is almost as important as their respective competition.
"It's going to be exciting; I've heard so many different things that I'm anxious to see for myself," said Naomi Hewitt-Couturier, one of three top rhythmic gymnasts representing the United States in the competition, which lasts from Friday to Aug. 18.
A native of New York, where she attends the United Nations School, Hewitt-Couturier will celebrate her 15th birthday on Thursday.
The year she was born, 1976, marked the last time Cuba and the United States competed in the same Olympic Games. (The United States boycotted the Moscow Olympics in 1980; the Soviet Union and its allies, including Cuba, boycotted the 1984 Games in Los Angeles and Cuba boycotted the 1988 games in support of North Korea).
 
Curiousity Sets In
 Like many of her fellow athletes, Hewitt-Couturier is too young to remember the events that triggered enduring animosity between the United States and Cuba. But like many athletes, her curiosity has been piqued by exhaustive procedures and precautions surrounding the trip.
"I never had to fill out so many forms before," she said. "When I asked why, they said that it was because of what was going on between them and us. That made me curious. I'm curious to find out what happened between us."
In some respects, the Pan Am Games is one of the most significant public events in what President Fidel Castro has called "A Special Period in a Time of Peace." The slogan refers to an era of austerity forced by Cuba's diminished support from the Soviet Union and changing ties with Eastern European nations.
There is speculation that the games could help Cuba thaw its relationship with the United States at a time when the Government and the Cuban people are coping with economic hardships.
That Cuba is pursuing a multimillion-dollar construction project during a time of economic retrenchment -- there are plans to make bicycles the primary form of transportation and animal power the fundamental technology in agriculture -- may not be as large a contradiction as it first appears.
 
'We Would Postpone It'
 Cuba was awarded the Pan American Games in 1986. During an interview with ABC-TV yesterday, Castro said that if the decision were to be made last year Cuba would have not played host the games. "If at present we had to make that decision, we would postpone it," he said. "We would say, 'No, we can't.' "
But he also said that Cuba would recoup its investment during the next three years because the Olympic Villa and hotel would be devoted to international tourism.
"Besides, it gave us a possibility to have excellent sports facilities that our people have wanted to have," he said. "The cost of these Pan American Games constitutes 1 percent of what the country has invested in sports and sports activities in the last 30 years."
At a more visible level the games, which are being produced at a cost of an estimated $156 million, will allow the sports-minded Cubans to reinforce their reputation as the Caribbean's sports juggernaut. Last week an official of the local Cuban weight-lifting federation told the president of the Pan American weight-lifting federation that the Cubans expected to win more gold medals in weight lifting than in any other sport.
 
Lots of National Spirit
 They are equally confident in men's and women's volleyball and Greco-Roman wrestling. There is also hope that Cuba's fierce rivalry with the United States in water polo and team handball will produce gold medals.
But Cuban officials say that the national spirit runs deeper than medals. Much of the construction for the Games was performed by 300,000 volunteers on weekends as a supplement to professional contractors, they said.
Outside of a synthetic surface for the track that was purchased from Germany and bowling lanes from Japan, Cuban-made materials were used for most of the major venues, they said.
 
Partisan Rooting
 While politics and nationalism provide an undercurrent to the games, the Cubans' appreciation of sports for sports' sake could surprise American participants accustomed to highly partisan rooting.
"Especially in a sport like baseball," Polk said. "The fans cheer good plays by the opponent and won't hesitate to get on their own players for shoddy plays.
"I remember a game we played them earlier this year: one of our guys hit a home run and they gave him a standing ovation. When he came back to the dugout he said it was one of the weirdest feelings he'd ever had."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terry Schroeder of the U.S. competing in the 1988 Olympics. (Paul J. Sutton/Duomo)

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1144 words

HEADLINE: Art Museum in Detroit Tries to Cope With Cuts

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 26

 BODY:
At any given time, on the abbreviated days when you can visit the Detroit Institute of Arts, half the galleries are sealed and darkened, their stairways roped off and their medieval sculpture and Chinese hand scrolls guarded by forbidding black signs warning, "Galleries Closed."
For months now, loyal patrons have watched the proud, embattled museum trim pieces of itself in response to deep cuts imposed by a state Government that is also embattled. It is the most desperate example of the hard times facing museums around the country as deficit-ridden states and cities cut their arts budgets to pay for schools and roads, and as philanthropic dollars grow scarce because of the recession. 
 While other beleaguered museums, like those in Brooklyn and Boston, are beginning to reduce costs, the 105-year-old Detroit Institute of Arts has already taken drastic measures. It has cut back the days it is open, from six to five; closed half its galleries in the morning and the other half in the afternoon, and in May it started charging admission for the first time since the Great Depression.
The museum, which previously eliminated 54 positions, sent dismissal notices this week to 32 curatorial, managerial and custodial staff members and canceled a major Picasso exhibition planned for the coming season. "We are no longer cutting into the fat," Samuel Sachs 2d, the museum's director, said. "It is now meat and bone."
 
Painful Questions at Core
 At the core of the crisis are painful questions about the role of government in preserving what many long considered a public trust. Museums around the country are closely watching Detroit with an eye to their own survival as the priorities of besieged governments are reordered.
"Our fear is that what is happening in Detroit is a predictor of the future for all museums," said Edward Able, executive director of the American Association of Museums, which represents the nation's 8,000 institutions. "Because our museums have been functioning and flourishing for so many years, people think it will always be thus. No one listens until the museum closes its doors. We are in great distress at what we see."
The museum and the rest of the art world here have been in turmoil since January when the state, facing a $1 billion deficit, imposed cuts of as much as 38 percent on the arts and froze all state payments to the museum. Gov. John Engler, a Republican, even went so far as to abolish the state agency that makes grants to arts organizations, the Michigan Council for the Arts, saying he wanted to reorganize it.
Acting on a legislative mandate, Mr. Engler imposed across-the-board cuts of up to 17 percent early in the year on every Government service except education. When further cuts were needed, it came down to hospitals and roads or the arts. To him, the choice was clear. "The arts budget was seen as a nonessential service," said John Truscott, the Governor's press secretary. "It didn't address the basic human needs of people."
 
Institutions Left Reeling
 Since then, several theater groups have canceled productions, galleries have laid off entire staffs and the Detroit Institute of Arts has been left scrambling to stay open. The institute, a city-owned museum that gets nearly 60 percent of its $26 million operating budget from the state, has not received a single state payment so far this year. It had been scheduled to receive $11 million by now.
"We've been pedaling backward as fast as we can go," said Mr. Sachs. "It's chaos. There is a sense of abandonment and betrayal. Things are totally unstable. A stable partner has suddenly become evanescent."
For Detroit, a city still trying to catch up from the last recession, it is like watching one of the last of the family jewels being hocked, carat by carat.
"It is one of the things in Detroit that is working," said Maurice Parrish, the museum's deputy director. "When you look at a city with no museum, no symphony, no cultural institutions, you not only can't attract businesses, you will lose them."
 
'Between Today and Forever'
 Indeed, it is the city, conceding the truth in those words, that has been backing the museum, dipping into its own treasury to keep the institute afloat until some state dollars come in. "But it can't support us forever," Mr. Parrish said. "We're somewhere between today and forever. We're forced into taking a very short-term view."
Several arts organizations, most notably some smaller theater groups and a dance unit, have already shut their doors. "It's made life a nightmare," said Marilyn Wheaton, executive director of Michigan Advocates for the Arts. "You went to sleep with your body intact, and you wake up without your arms and legs."
And those that are left are all fighting for private donations in the same dwindling pool. "As all of us keep hitting up the same sources, they are beginning to laugh at us," said Cynthia Clair, executive director of the Michigan Alliance for Arts Education, a nonprofit group based in Grand Rapids. "They're saying, 'I'm sorry, I don't know where you think we're getting all these resources.' "
Things are not likely to change any time soon. As the Engler administration sees it, the good old days of the state's playing big daddy and prime patron are over. It argues that government should not be in the art business, and it says it wants a new, as yet undefined relationship with the arts.
 
Too Dependent on State?
 "What we've been doing is subsidizing the museum," Mr. Truscott said. "We've been paying for their water and electricity and security and staff. They have become too dependent on the state, which leaves them subject to the whims of the Legislature."
The Governor and leaders of the Michigan arts community have scheduled a summit for early August to try to reach some kind of agreement.
But how much they will resolve is uncertain. There is no more money now than there was when the crisis began. Indeed, further budget cuts are planned for the state's coming fiscal year, and the administration is going into the summit with one key message. "We want to explain how difficult times are and how little money we have," Mr. Truscott said.
All of this many leaves museum patrons feeling helpless and fearful. They dutifully plunk down the new $4 suggested admission fee or whatever they can afford and plan their visits around the abbreviated hours of cherished galleries. And they stare, as Raymond Sayegh, a Detroit dentist, did the other day beneath his favorite part of the museum, the signature Diego Rivera murals, with a glint of awe and sadness in their eyes.
"You just hate to see what's happening to the institute," Dr. Sayegh said. "The arts should be glorified. All these sections should be open. They belong to the public. It's so painful to watch."

The institute, which gets nearly 60 percent of its $26 million operating budget from the state, has not received a single state payment so far this year. Visitors looked at the Diego Rivera murals. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Freshman, No Novice, Does Battle For a Base

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
When Robert E. Andrews walks the streets of this city, he can easily be mistaken for a lanky, clean-shaven Capitol Hill aide. But his anonymity vanishes when he returns to Bellmawr, N.J., each weekend.
At home, he is the local Congressman who cannot even go to the store without being asked how he plans to save the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard and Naval Station. 
 "When you're in Washington and you're a Congressman -- big deal -- there are 435 of them," he said. "At home, you're a franchise."
Representative Andrews, at 33 years old, is the chamber's youngest Democrat, and he has found himself in the thick of a situation most freshmen only have nightmares about.
Within nine months, he has fought against, and now must prepare to endure, what has become virtually inevitable: the Federal Government's decision to close the shipyard.
He has estimated that the move will cost his district approximately 15,000 jobs that are associated, directly or indirectly, with the base.
The sprawling, gray waterfront base -- the largest of the 25 major installations that are targeted for closing by a Federal commission -- has become Mr. Andrews's chief obsession.
"If I'm in a diner, nobody ever comes up to me and says, 'What do you think about the civil rights bill or the striker replacement bill or the proposal to save the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge?' " he said.
What they do ask him about, over and over, he says, is how they will find work after the closing of the shipyard, just across the Delaware River from Camden, which is economically depressed.
For lawmakers like Mr. Andrews, the problem is a lot more complicated and politically lethal than simply deciding how to cast a vote.
Unlike other bases proposed for closing, the Philadelphia docks will be mothballed. That means that the Navy will be able to lay off workers, but that it will preserve the site for future emergency use. That means Philadelphia will not be able to reap the benefits of turning the yard over for economic redevelopment.
Now that President Bush and Congress have moved to ratify the base closing commission's recommendations, Mr. Andrews has found himself in the exclusive, essentially powerless, club of Washington lawmakers who are trying to cope with the political fallout of base closings.
 Mr. Andrews is the son of a shipyard worker who lost his job in 1968 when the private New Jersey yard he worked for closed down. "For me this is deja vu," he said.
Since taking over the Congressional seat last November that was held by New Jersey Governor Jim Florio, Mr. Andrews has spent nearly half his time attending hearings, holding meetings or sending out missives in defense of the Philadelphia base.
Rumors that the yard would be on the list for closing had begun months before the first recommendations were released on April 12.
The Pennsylvania and New Jersey Congressional delegations have tried to fight the decision on the shipyard on several fronts, including inserting language into an appropriations bill requiring the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Kennedy to be rebuilt at the installation.
But Pentagon officials hinted in a hearing last week that the Kennedy may not be overhauled at all, and the lawmakers' last hope may be a lawsuit aimed at overturning the recommendation.
He insists that losing the battle does not mean that the voters will sink his candidacy in 1992. But just in case, he does not hesitate to deal his most partisan cards when asked about the Philadelphia base's future.
"The reality is, we have a political process driven by Pentagon politics instead of Congressional politics," Mr. Andrews said in an interview.
And in testimony before a House subcommittee last week, Mr. Andrews produced a chart he said proved that 76 percent of the civilian jobs lost as a result of the base closings would occur in Congressional districts represented by Democrats.
He dismissed the defense offered by the base closing commission's chairman, Jim Courter, a former New Jersey Congressman, that the process was insulated from politics.
"It's sort of bitterly amusing that people contend that in this city, in this political structure, that these decisions were made without consideration of politics," he said.
"In this city, decisions about who gets furniture are not made without political consideration."

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1006 words

HEADLINE: Toward the Summit;
Soviet Bid to Join I.M.F. Still a Puzzle

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's applications to join the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank last week are something of a financial mystery.
Administration officials and academic experts here are asking why President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union did not warn other leaders two weeks ago at the meeting of seven industrialized nations that his Government had already prepared an application for full membership in the I.M.F. and possibly the World Bank. The seven leaders endorsed only a "special association" for the Soviet Union with both multilateral lending agencies. 
 The experts are also asking how much the Soviet Union would have to pay to join both institutions, how it would raise the money and how long it would have to wait for loans.
President Bush will discuss a possible Soviet role in the I.M.F. and the Worl Bank with Mr. Gorbachev when the two men meet in Moscow, the White House has said.
 
Brady Is Critical
 Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady criticized the Soviet applications on Wednesday as "counterproductive" and said, "We were completely surprised by their move." Soviet membership in the institutions is "not going to happen," he added.
Mr. Brady suggested, and other Administration officials privately agree, that Mr. Gorbachev may have been responding to political pressures at home in seeking full membership. Associate status has been described as second-class citizenship in the world economic order for a military superpower.
Soviet officials in Moscow and Washington have said that obtaining full membership could take several years and is best started early. Associate status can come first in a two-step application process, they said.
Reuters reported from Moscow last week that a Soviet spokesman said the applications to both institutions were submitted on July 15, the day before Mr. Gorbachev went to London. Both were received July 22.
Congress apparently also regards the Soviet move as premature. On Wednesday, the Senate approved an amendment to this year's foreign aid bill that would force the United States to vote against the Soviet applications.
The amendment, sponsored by Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, would direct the Administration to vote against Soviet membership unless the President first certified to Congress that the Soviet Union was instituting certain free-market economic policies, adopting democratic political structures and shrinking military and other Government spending.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said the increasing assertiveness of the Soviet Union's republics raises questions about the ability of the Soviet Union to comply with I.M.F. rules. "You have to assume that someone is politically and economically in control" before a country is allowed to join, he said in an interview.
The Soviet Union needs the huge loans that the I.M.F. and the World Bank could provide. Its economy shrank by 10 percent in the first quarter, it is having trouble paying the interest on foreign debts already totaling about $70 billion, and international prices are low for oil and gold, two of its biggest exports.
President Bush is widely expected to send a trade treaty to Congress this week that would reduce tariffs on Soviet imports. But United States trade with the Soviet Union is small and opening Western markets to Soviet goods promises little immediate benefit to the Soviet Union because many of its exports are commodities on which tariffs are already low.
 
Technical Difficulties
 Several sticky technical problems lie ahead of the Soviet applications, including the size of Soviet contributions and whether the Soviet Union would have a seat on each institution's 22-member executive board.
Five countries have individual seats on the World Bank's board and six countries have individual seats on the I.M.F. board. Other countries are represented by regional directors.
The amount of a country's contribution, its voting strength and the allocation of seats on the board are all determined by the size of its economy. But the size of the Soviet economy, Mr. Brady said, is "the most vexatious question of all: it ranges all the way from big to not very big."
If the Soviet economy is as small as India's, as some economists now estimate, its one-time contribution to the I.M.F. would be $4.41 billion, assuming all contributions are raised as planned at the end of this year. If its economy is as large as Italy's, the contribution would be $6.1 billion.
Unless an exception were made, a quarter of this amount would have to be paid in convertible currencies such as the United States dollar or the German mark, which are traded on world markets at rates set by supply and demand, while the rest could be paid in rubles, which are nonconvertible.
And while the I.M.F. does not require that members have convertible currencies to join, it does insist that members later try to make them convertible. Some economists fear that in the Soviet case this could mean high inflation.
The World Bank has a different system and would be slightly less expensive to join. The World Bank lends mostly to support specific economic development projects while the I.M.F. lends money to countries facing balance-of-payments difficulties.
Raising this money would not be difficult for the Soviet Union, said Horst Schulmann, the managing director of the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based trade group. Although the Soviet Union does not publish figures on its foreign currency and gold reserves, as one of the world's largest gold producers it can sell enough gold to raise the money.
Once the initial contribution is made, a member can quickly borrow large sums of foreign exchange. For example, Czechoslovakia contributed nearly $800 million to join the I.M.F. last September, a quarter of it in internationally traded currencies.
In January, Czechoslovakia got lines of credit from the I.M.F. totaling almost $1.5 billion, all of it in international currencies.

HEADLINE: Toward the Summit;
Soviets to Embrace Bush, But Not All He Stands For

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 28

 BODY:
Gone are the days when Soviet citizens looked on an American President as the lord of a hostile empire or a white knight come to rescue Russia from its misery. But if President Bush arrives in Moscow this week as the representative of a far more familiar land -- less exotic, less threatening, less all-promising -- it is still the one to reckon with.
The propaganda about a land of scheming imperialists, or the whispered legends of a land of untold prosperity, have long given way to "Dallas," CNN, Arnold Schwarzenegger, McDonald's, Estee Lauder and the accounts of thousands of Soviet travelers and emigres in forming images of America. 
 Thirty-one of the 64 movies showing in Moscow today are American, from "Lethal Weapon 2" through "Dead Poets Society," and neither the endless bounty of an American supermarket nor the misery of urban slums are a mystery any more. Old fears have abated. No longer do people anxiously sidle up to Americans in the streets and ask if there will be war, or presume that every American is a spy.
 
'A Fundamental Change'
 "A fundamental change has come to Soviet-American relations," Georgi A. Arbatov, head of the Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada, wrote in Izvestia. "Serious, honest, normal people in America have come to the conclusion that there is no 'Soviet threat' to the United States. And identically serious, honest, normal people in the U.S.S.R. have come to the conclusion that the U.S.A. does not intend to attack them or 'explode' the country from within."
Soviet citizens and emigres now crisscross the Atlantic constantly, and their accounts and impressions have profoundly revised the former attitude of adulation toward American culture.
On the contrary, many intellectuals return dismayed by what they see as a superficial culture and by "political correctness," militant feminism, self-conscious egalitarianism and other manifestations of what they identify with the very intellectual conformity and intolerance that they spent their lives fighting against.
 
U.S. Lacks 'Spirituality'
 Soviet citizens who have been to the United States regularly bemoan the absence of "spirituality" and of the intensity of Soviet intellectual life.
"One Soviet woman went to an American doctor and tried to strike up a conversation about Toulouse-Lautrec," Tatyana Tolstaya, a writer who spends much of her time in the United States. "She was shocked that he had no idea who he was. Our doctor typically would have known all about Toulouse-Lautrec, though he would have only a vague idea where her liver is."
Soviet citizens have also become far more familiar with American attitudes toward them. The current issue of Moscow News, for example, carries a bemused survey of American views under the headline "American Tries to Make Sense of Us."
Konstantin Pleshakov, the author, wrote: "The Soviet Union is in disarray. A country Americans throught they knew well -- the winter of Stalinism, mummified leaders, fighters for human rights -- has all at once turned into a formidable crossword puzzle. Today's Soviet Union does not fit any pattern. America is accustomed to the logic of categories of good and evil, black and white. In the U.S.S.R. it is hard to find logic."
Gone, too, is the early illusion of perestroika, Mr. Gorbachev's program of economic and political restructuring, that the shedding of Stalinism would bring the United States and the West rushing in to bring happiness and running shoes to every Soviet family.
At the summit meeting of seven rich industrialized nations in London earlier this month, the nations' leaders decided to wait on any extensive aid to the Soviet Union. The decision met with considerable understanding among Soviet commentators, who agreed that it was imperative for the Soviet Union first to set its own house in order.
 
Global Foe No Longer
 However great the changes in the Soviet Union and its world view, even if the United States no longer figures as the global foe or the promised land, it still remains for many Soviets "the other one," the nation by which they measure their own destiny.
Whether from tradition or from a perception of the United States as the only other country that can match the Soviet Union in sheer size and ethnic diversity, America still holds a mystique that neither Western Europe nor Japan, for all their wealth, can match.
The departing American Ambassador to Moscow, Jack F. Matlock Jr., gained considerable popularity across the Soviet Union by demonstrating a familiarity with Soviet problems in fluent Russian. Invitations to his residence at Spaso House became something of a badge of merit.
Mr. Bush may not be greeted here as Ronald Reagan or his other predecessors were, by a monolithic system eager to assert its might and legitimacy against the leader of an opposing system. There may not be the fascination and awe that the cold war fostered in an American President.
The President, moreover, will be meeting already for the sixth time with Mr. Gorbachev, and in the absence of military confrontation, the strategic arms reduction treat, which will cut long-range nuclear weapons, does not carry the drama of earlier disarmament agreements.
But Mr. Bush still represents a land that stands for many Soviet citizens as the ultimate yardstick of democracy and market economy, and he comes to Moscow at a time that the political debate between the Kremlin and the republics, between the central Government and the supporters of fundamental change in the system, is approaching a decisive stage.
Stanislav Kondrashov wrote in the Government newspaper Izvestia: "In the time of the czars, the Russian upper class imitated the English or the French. In the time of the commissars, the open or tacit yardstick became America. Nuclear arms and intercontinental missiles confirmed this: it is America we have to match."
The significance of Mr. Bush's visit, he wrote, is that the main issue will not be Soviet-American relations, as it was at past summit meetings, but the question of the Soviet Union's fate. "In the time of Gorbachev, we have begun talking of becoming civilized, and the main criteria for this, once again, we see in the United States, from the two-party system and division of powers to evangelists and hamburgers."
If past U.S.-Soviet summits were contests of opposing systems, Mr. Kondrashov wrote, now the contest has shifted to the domestic political arena, and Mr. Bush comes not as adversary but as arbiter. The opposition will claim him as an ally in the struggle for reform; Mr. Gorbachev will tout him as proof of his own importance as an irreplaceable contact with the West.
"I will not hazard a guess on what conclusions, apart from the well-known ones" that Mr. Bush will draw, Mr. Kondrashov wrote. "I doubt they will be new. But for us also before the face of the trans-oceanic guest, the main conclusion is not new: without self-help, without a proper measure of agreement and responsibility in the construction of our common fate, we cannot count either on a better lot nor on retaining the respect of other people and politicians."

HEADLINE: Peru Takes Bigger Role In Production of Cocaine

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
 For years, Peru seemed to be a secondary front in the South American drug war. Though the country produced 60 percent of the world's coca leaf, the Government lacked the will to risk alienating the peasants who scraped out an existence growing the raw material for cocaine.
There was little violence and no cartels, and the crop was quickly transported north to Colombia, where powerful drug organizations processed pure cocaine for shipment. 
 But Colombia's two-year war on its Medellin cocaine cartel has transformed the drug business in Peru, shifting the emphasis away from simple agriculture.
Government officials and narcotics officers here say they see the first signs that drug cartels are forming. Large amounts of cocaine are being refined in Peru's jungles, they say, and traffickers are organizing direct shipments to the United States and Europe.
 
U.S. Awacs on Patrol
 Cultivation of coca in Peru has been gradually increasing despite American aid spent on eradicating coca plants. The United States has become so concerned about Peru's drug trade that it deployed its highly sophisticated Awacs planes here three months ago to help the Peruvian police. The radar-scanning jets, normally based in the Caribbean, are used to find and force down small planes moving drugs and money between Colombia and Peru.
Drug investigators warn that the Cali drug organization is profiting from the setbacks of the Medellin cartel, including the recent surrender of its leader, Pablo Escobar Gaviria.
"We have very good evidence that for six or seven months, Peruvians have been dealing with Cali as opposed to Medellin," said a Western official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "And remember how smart the Cali cartel was. While Escobar was killing policemen and politicians, the Cali people were quietly going about their business."
For the Peruvian Government of Alberto Fujimori, the most alarming development was the discovery of a big cocaine laboratory in the eastern jungle province of Ucayali in early June. The laboratory had a weekly production capacity of more than 100 kilograms of pure cocaine, with a street value of $1.5 million in Miami and $5 million in Madrid. Even by Colombian standards, that is a very large cocaine laboratory.
 
Once There Was a Middleman
 Until recently, any pure cocaine produced in Peru was intended primarily for the country's consumption. Peruvian peasants have traditionally sold their coca leaf to a middleman who might carry out the first stage in processing, turning the leaf into coca paste. The paste was then usually shipped to Colombia, where it was turned into a cocaine base and finally into pure cocaine in labs.
The Ucayali laboratory, which experts say had been operating for at least a year, carried out both of the final two processes. In a complex of five buildings disguised to look like a farming operation, at least 20 people worked with tons of kerosene, sulphuric acid, ammonia, ether and acetone to produce cocaine.
The authorities also found modern communications equipment, 16 microwave ovens for drying the cocaine, two generators, and, in a nearby storage shed, 250 kilos of pure cocaine.
"I don't think there is any doubt we are seeing a move toward an integrated drug industry here in Peru," a senior Western diplomat here said.
Also worrying the Government is the discovery of shipments originating in Peru. Drug-related violence, which many people say was almost nonexistent two years ago, is also on the rise, and members of the military are increasingly coming under attack by groups associated with the drug trade.
Police corruption has hindered efforts to crack down on refiners and traffickers. Western officials say it is hard for an officer with a monthly salary of $80 a month to resist bribes that often range as high as $25,000.
The officials described raids in which agents swooped down on laboratories only to discover that operators had been tipped off beforehand. In checking the 250 kilos of cocaine seized in June at the Ucayali plant, the authorities discovered this month that 54 kilos had since been replaced by flour.
Meanwhile, in areas where peasants once barely made a living off coca growing, large amounts of wealth are being accumulated.
"There are these old huge houses in the countryside from the days of the rubber boom here," said a high-ranking Government official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The owners tried to sell them for years but you couldn't even get $100,000 for them. Now people are coming in, laying down $300,000 in cash and saying, 'I'm moving in.' That's big-time drug money. That's the beginning of drug organizations."
 
Issue Is Clear for U.S.
 From Washington's perspective, the developments call for a simple response: to fight the drug war on all fronts, eradicating coca seedlings, shutting laboratories, forcing down planes and putting as many people in jail as possible.
At a base at Santa Lucia in the Upper Huallaga Valley, a region in which much of the country's coca is grown, the United States Drug Enforcement Agency has a rotating contingent of 15 agents. Another 15 members of the agency operate out of Lima or other parts of the country.
But for Peruvians, the issue is more complex, and colored by a long distrust of the United States. Peruvians say the nation's peasants have grown coca for hundreds of years, using it as a mild stimulant and a hot beverage, and that it is Western industrialized countries that have turned its chemical base into a powerful drug.
Some Peruvians also argue that proceeds from the sale of coca leaf, estimated at $500 million to $1 billion a year, are desperately needed in a country where more than 80 percent of the population lives in poverty.
"In this country drugs and the sale of coca is not the central issue, so don't expect strong public opinion on the side of Americans," said Roberto Lerner, associate director of the Information and Educational Center for the Prevention of Drug Abuse in Lima. "The central issue is survival."
 
Accord Signed in May
 Nevertheless, Peru signed an important agreement with the United States in May that provides for a joint offensive against the drug trade. It calls for $220 million in economic aid and $57 million in military and police assistance in fiscal 1991, more than twice what Peru received the previous year.
While the Peruvian Government says it plans to take strong action against traffickers, it has tried to signal the 250,000 peasants involved in coca growing that they will not be treated as criminals, and that a plan will be found to wean them from coca and help them start other crops.

The Economy
The Bush Administration is under growing pressure to propose ambitious, potentially expensive improvements in the nation's health-care system to protect people who are uninsured. A report drafted for an advisory panel appointed by the Administration recommends expanding Medicaid to cover doctors' services and hospital care for 10 million poor people, at an annual cost to the Federal Government of at least $4 billion a year. [Page A1.]
Federal regulators have begun renegotiating some of the biggest sales of failed savings and loans to private investors and have started to withdraw many financial breaks granted to other investors. Exercising some options has already produced savings of more than $1 billion, the regulators say, and the renegotiations could produce as much $2 billion more in savings. [A1.]
Orders for American-made machine tools jumped 13 percent in June from May, helped by a surge in foreign demand. But they still remained far below the levels of June 1990. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Rose by 13% Last Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Helped by a surge in foreign demand, orders for American-made machine tools jumped 13 percent in June from May, according to an industry trade group's monthly report, but they still remained far below the levels of June 1990.
Indeed, domestic orders were down sharply from May and from a year earlier. Analysts interpreted this as a sign that manufacturers had not yet seen much recovery from the recession. 
 The overall increase in machine-tool orders came after three straight monthly declines.
 
Foreign Orders Triple
 In its report scheduled for release today, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said machine-tool orders increased to $172.9 million in June, from $153 million in May. Foreign orders, which nearly tripled in June, more than offset the 14.2 percent decline in orders from domestic customers.
Compared with June 1990, machine-tool orders were down 34.8 percent, with domestic orders down 49 percent. But orders from foreign customers were up 36.1 percent.
For the first half of this year, new orders were down 17.8 percent, with domestic orders plunging 24.8 percent. Foreign orders were up 15.3 percent for the first six months of the year.
"We are encouraged by the increase in orders and particularly by the strength of the export market, said Albert W. Moore, president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va.
Despite the decline in domestic orders, Mr. Moore said, "there are signs that the economy is taking a more positive turn."
"Industrial production is up for the fifth straight month," he said. "Capacity utilization rates are rising, car production was up in late June and early July, and real earnings for production workers rose in both May and June."
Machine-tool makers said that despite the decline in domestic orders, they had seen an increase in inquiries about new equipment from manufacturers in a broad range of industries, particularly automobile makers.
Still, analysts said the figures indicated that capital spending by American manufacturers continued to show little sign of rebounding.
Machine tools are used to cut or shape metal parts used in durable products like appliances, automobiles, aircraft and building components. The level of orders and shipments of machine tools is considered an important indicator of the health of American industry.
 
'Little Early to Tell'
 "It's a little early to tell for sure, but activity has not worsened and June was a somewhat better month than May, which was quite soft," said Richard O. Priebe, a spokesman with Cross & Trecker Inc., a large machine-tool maker that last month agreed to be acquired by a competitor, Giddings & Lewis Inc. "It remains to be seen if there will be any continued upward move."
Machine tool orders have been hurt by the economic troubles of car makers, which typically account for more than a third of the industry's new orders. And some analysts suggest that an increase in orders from auto makers, which are expected to retool soon for new models, will help stimulate the machine tool industry.
One large order that affected the orders from foreign customers was a $45 million contract awarded to Litton Industrial Automotion by Volga Auto Works, the largest producer of automobiles in the Soviet Union. Litton will provide two machining systems for the production of engine components.
The backlog of machine tool orders for June was $1.33 billion, down from $1.37 billion in May.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Colombia Emerges as a Large Exporter of Books

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CALI, Colombia

 BODY:
For years, Colombia has been renowned for its coffee. Soon, it may win equal renown for its coffee-table books.
Starting from scratch in 1980, the year that book paper was first manufactured here, Colombia's printing and publishing industry has grown to make this country Latin America's largest exporter of books. 
 With modern presses and wages of $1 an hour, Colombia is rapidly emerging as an offshore printing center for American publishing houses. And with paper mills here doubling their book-paper capacity this year, Colombian publishers predict an aggressive expansion in the 1990's.
 
Looking to the United States
 "Colombia is already among the 15 major exporters of books to the United States," said Jorge Valencia Jaramillo, president of the Camara Colombiana del Libro, which represents about 180 publishers, distributors and bookstores. "By 1995 we will be among the top 10, and by the end of the decade we will be among the top five," he said in May at Fourth International Book Fair in Bogota.
Indeed, Colombia exported $79 million worth of books last year, up from $41 million in 1986, the year that Colombia became a net exporting nation. The number of titles published a year in Colombia increased to 2,757 in 1990, from 587 in 1988.
American publishing giants like McGraw-Hill, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and the United Bible Societies have had books printed here by Imprelibros, a division of Carvajal S.A. Smaller American publishers have found it economical to print limited numbers of books in Colombia.
"Even with the air freight, we can print and deliver to the United States for 50 percent of the cost of printing in the United States," said Luis Fernando Santos, a director of Intermedios, the publishing subsidiary of the Bogata newspaper El Tiempo.
 
Confluence of Factors
 The sudden and, to some, unexpected emergence of Colombia as a leading book-printing center is a result of a confluence of factors.
Despite its well-publicized drug wars and guerrilla violence, Colombia had Latin America's fastest-growing economy during the 1980's. Inflation was low, foreign debt manageable and growth high.
"Mexico and Argentina were in crisis during most of the 1980's, and they let their printing plants deteriorate," said Fernando Gomez, senior general manager of Grupo Editorial Norma, Carvajal's book subsidiary here, referring to Latin America's traditional publishing centers. "Colombia had a stable economy and was able to import modern machinery."
In addition, Spain, the mother nation for Spanish-language publishing, phased out subsidies on its book exports in the mid-1980's. And the Spanish peseta rose sharply against Latin American currencies. Suddenly, Latin Americans could no longer afford books imported from Spain.
"Until 1982, we depended almost exclusively on books imported from Spain," recalled Juan Luis Mejia Arango, distribution manager for Planeta Colombiana Editorial, the Bogota subsidiary of a Barcelona-based publishing house. "Now, eight of the top 10 Spanish publishers print books here. A book printed in Colombia costs 40 percent of the cost of a book imported from Spain."
To illustrate his point, Mr. Mejia ran his finger down the weekly best-seller list compiled by El Tiempo. Of the 10 fiction and 10 nonfiction titles listed, only one book was an import, from Argentina. Of that list, 11 were by Colombian authors.
But Colombia needs a market for its books, since its internal market is limited by a functional illiteracy rate of about 25 percent. So Colombia's publishing industry is oriented to printing books for export.
Publishers in the United States seem pleased with the work they get from Colombia.
"Colombia is now competitive with Hong Kong and Singapore," said Francis J. Crane, editor in chief of the international books division of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, referring to two other leading book-printing centers. "They have state-of-the-art equipment and the end quality is quite good," he said in a telephone interview from Florida.
In 1988, Mr. Crane supervised Carvajal's printing of 90,000 textbooks.
 
Problem of Geography
 One drawback to Colombia's book-printing industry is geography. The nation's two paper makers, Propal and Smurfit Carton de Colombia, are here in western Colombia, while most publishers are 12 hours away in Bogota. In turn, books must travel 25 hours by truck to the Caribbean port of Barranquilla for shipping.
But Colombia's wage scales allow for labor intensive-work at low cost.
For example, a Carvajal factory near here employs 2,000 people cutting, pasting and folding animated "pop up" books, which feature three-dimensional centerfolds. Printing them in 20 different languages, Carvajal now accounts for 60 percent of the world production of these books.

HEADLINE: In Canada, the Tempo Picks Up

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL, July 2

 BODY:
The Canadian economy is stirring again after a recession, far longer and deeper than the one in the United States, cut output by billions of dollars and sent unemployment to the highest levels since the early 1980's.
Like the United States, Canada has benefited from cuts in interest rates, which appear to be helping the housing and auto markets. Canada's economy is only a tenth the size of the United States' and Americans buy three-quarters of everything Canada exports, so it remains highly dependent on what happens south of the border. 
 Government indexes of leading indicators, used on both sides of the border to predict activity, are now pointing up. The Canadian index has just posted its first gain in 14 months, and most forecasting services expect further advances.
 
'At a Turning Pint'
 "I think we're at a turning point, though we may be bouncing along the bottom for the next three or four months," said Warren Jestin, chief economist in Toronto for the Bank of Nova Scotia.
His feelings were echoed by Purdy Crawford, chief executive of Imasco Ltd., a consumer goods and services holding company that owns drug stores, variety stores, tobacco companies and the Canada Trust bank, as well as the Hardee's fast-food chain in the United States.
Mr. Crawford said he had noticed a "quickening of the tempo of business" in the various company operations in Canada, especially in the last few weeks.
But serious problems and questions do remain, including the federal debt, high unemployment, and the direction of long-term interest rates. And while economic concerns have for now brushed aside the burning issues linked to Quebec's drive for greater sovereignty or independence, they are still lurking.
Prominent economists say there are solid signs that the ice may finally be cracking. They point to strength in exports, rising investment in the energy industry and a surge in provincial government spending in Ontario. That province accounts for nearly half of the nation's economic output.
As might be expected, the national government in Ottawa waxes even more enthusiastic. "I'm very encouraged," said Finance Minister Donald Mazankowski, adding that the Canadian recovery "looks pretty solid."
Especially heartening for the Government are the upward revisions in economic growth rates earlier this year, signaling that the economy was not as weak as first indicated.
Yet the severity of the recession has spurred great popular discontent against the Progressive Conservative Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who has led the country for seven years.
Poll results show an overwhelming number of Canadians want Mr. Mulroney to resign, even though his mandate, renewed in 1988 elections, runs until 1993.
Last summer, before interest rates started falling here, the polls showed the Prime Minister's popularity, in terms of his percentage of supporters, had fallen below the prime rate.
The prime was about 15 percent then. It is now around 9.75 percent, compared with 8.5 percent in the United States.
"At least for now there is a fury in the land against the Prime Minister," said Keith Spicer, a former political science professor and broadcaster. Mr. Spicer, the chairman of the Citizens' Forum on Canada's Future, appointed and financed by the Government, made the statement in his preface to the forum's report, published in late June.
While economic prospects have improved, the recovery here, as in the United States, still seems a bit anemic and fitful. As a result, in neither country does business or consumer confidence yet correspond with the more promising statistics.
"The momentum for new growth is already here in Canada, but it could run out of steam if the U.S. doesn't really move," cautioned Patrick Grady, a partner in Global Economics, an Ottawa consulting firm.
In both the United States and Canada, debt burdens weigh heavily on governments and consumers. The Bank of Montreal could have spoken for both countries when it noted in its recent Business Review that debt "will not only inhibit further expenditures but keep long-term interest rates higher than would otherwise be the case, further slowing activity."
Unemployment is far higher here than in the United States and is a source of deep anxiety. The unemployment rate for June was 10.5 percent, matching a six-year high, and 3.5 percentage points above the American rate.
Taxes are also much higher, causing thousands of Canadian shoppers to bolt across the border for bargains in the northern United States.
 
High Interest Rates
 The cost of money is another preoccupation. Real interest rates after adjustment for inflation are still considered lofty in the United States, even after steep declines in the last 12 months. But they are even higher in Canada, a result of deliberate Government policy.
"The Bank of Canada has been given a free rein to squeeze inflation out of the system here," said Ernie Stokes, director of Canadian services for the WEFA Group, a research and consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "The whole direction of policies here is much tougher against inflation."
Mr. Stokes, whose office is in Toronto, and others note that the health of the banking and credit system has not been a factor in the monetary equation here, as in the United States, allowing the Canadian authorities greater freedom to tighten credit.
To some, the Government's high interest-rate policy is a problem because it has raised the Canadian dollar from 70 American cents in the mid-1980's to about 87 cents now. Many economists and exporters say that appreciation is damaging this country's competitiveness.
 
Currency May Decline
 With growing expectations that Government inflation targets of 5 percent by the end of this year and 3 percent by the end of 1992 will be met, the Canadian dollar could move lower, some economists say.
Then there is the cloud over Quebec's future. If the French-speaking province makes foreign investors nervous. they might pull their money out of Canada. That could endanger the recovery.
The Mulroney Government expects to introduce new constitutional proposals this fall to try to keep Quebec in the federation while meeting the province's demand for recognition as a "distinct society."
All sides agree it will be a delicate balancing act.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
TV Networks, in a Crisis, Talk of Sweeping Changes

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 2

 BODY:
Searching for solutions to the worst economic crisis they have ever faced, the three big television networks are sailing in uncharted water --
and often in opposite directions.
The networks would still rather have the business adapt to their changed circumstances than be forced to adapt themselves. But they have mapped out somewhat different strategies, some of which would radically alter the television landscape. 
 Several events that signaled the networks' differing approaches took place last week:
*An ABC executive predicted that all three networks would not survive and that the hours of prime time would soon be scaled back.
*NBC announced a risky experiment that could leave some network programs, especially the evening newscasts, more vulnerable to losing their audiences.
*And a CBS executive decried the mood of "defeatism" and suggested that more aggressive control of costs could bring back prosperity.
Behind these moves and comments is the troubled financial outlook for all of network television, fueled by a depressed advertising market and rising program costs.
But at least some of the initial steps being taken appear to be carefully considered feints.
The financial squeeze is forcing network executives into a schizophrenic dance of mixed messages. To advertisers, from whom they still seek billions of dollars, and to viewers, from whom they still seek affection and loyalty, the networks still want to present themselves as the most powerful and entertaining way to reach mass audiences.
To others -- mainly Washington lawmakers from whom they seek regulatory relief; affiliated station managers, from whom they seek new and less costly relationships, and Hollywood producers, from whom they seek programs at lower costs -- the networks want to portray themselves as gravely wounded, essential all-American institutions.
NBC seems to be taking the lead in the regulatory end of the story. The network's corporate counsel, Richard Cotton, said today that without some fundamental changes, like requiring cable operators to pay a fee to carry the networks, the network economy was about to go into a free fall.
 
Leverage of Vulnerability
 All three networks are now marketing their vulnerability, because that vulnerability is providing some surprising leverage in the move to reduce costs. Two network executives said in separate interviews last week that the threat of diminished networks had made negotiations for fees to carry prime-time series much easier this year, with some producers actually accepting lower fees than they had received for the same programs the year before.
ABC is likely to be the only network to make money this year. Yet Robert A. Iger, the president of ABC Entertainment, offered the most pessimistic assessment at a press conference last week.
"We're just not going to exist in the same fashion in the years ahead," Mr. Iger said. He suggested that one network would probably go out of business and that the survivors would be putting on fewer hours of prime-time programs, dropping, if possible, the lowest-rated hours on the schedule.
Though he did not specify which hours the network would drop, Saturday night has clearly become the most endangered night.
Mr. Iger's comments were followed by NBC's decision to allow KCRA, its affiliated station in Sacramento, Calif., to experiment with moving prime time one hour earlier. The move would force NBC programs like "The Cosby Show" to 7 P.M., and its evening newscast back to 6 P.M. or even 5:30, an hour when it is likely to be seen by many fewer viewers.
Pierson Mapes, president of the NBC television network, said he recognized that if the KCRA experiment was successful, all NBC stations in the West -- and perhaps those in the East -- would press the network to change the prime-time hours.
"We're breaking all-new ground here," Mr. Mapes said.
An earlier prime time could help NBC's late-night lineup by giving it a bigger audience. The "Tonight" show, for example, would be broadcast at 10:35 P.M. But whether that would make up for the loss of viewers in the early evening is a serious question.
If only the station benefits from this experiment, NBC would probably seek to renegotiate its affiliate compensation deal, under which it pays a station to carry its programs.
John Kueneke, the general manager of KCRA, said the experiment at his station was a signal that radical change is inevitable in the network-affiliate relationship. "I think you're going to see the whole television landscape change," he said. "Nobody believes in the old rules anymore."
 
Disagreement by CBS
 But CBS certainly does. "If one of us goes out of business, it's not because there isn't a demand for quality network programming," said Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group. "If a network goes out of business, it's because the network messed it up."
Indeed, CBS painted a blistering portrait of an altered or reduced network in prime time. "Those open hours would be filled with junk," Mr. Stringer said.
The junk in question would consist of the kind of syndicated programs now in wide use at most local stations: usually game shows and tabloid magazine programs.
The networks clearly will score some points by comparing their more vulnerable programs -- like the ones on Saturday nights -- with such new syndicated fare as "Studs," which throws young people together for dates and then quizzes them on what happened in questions laden with sexual innuendo.
 
Disguised Commercials
 The networks can also make a strong case that "info-mercials" -- paid commercials disguised as half-hour programs, now in wide use in later hours at many stations -- would make their way into prime time.
Mr. Stringer said the answer for the networks was to "find ways to get the costs down." One way he cited: getting producers to reduce their fees, which he said CBS did successfully this year.
Though their comments seemed to be at odds, Mr. Iger and Mr. Stringer essentially made the same point that cost-cutting was at the heart of the grim talk.
In an interview after his press conference, Mr. Iger emphasized that he had not intended to drop a bombshell about the networks vanishing so much as he had wanted to send a message.
"I wasn't really espousing a corporate philosophy," he said, "as much as I was sending a signal to the program suppliers that we have to look at new ways of doing business."
ABC has been sending that signal in other ways. For the first time, the network has made deals with cable companies to supply programs, one of which, a comedy called "Hi, Honey, I'm Home," has been running on ABC this summer.
"Nickelodeon is supplying that show to us for less than half the cost of our next-least-expensive comedy," Mr. Iger said. "This is a way to tell the studios we want to be in business with them, but we can do it cheaper elsewhere."
The effort is working already. Mr. Iger said ABC had also been able to bring programs back to its schedule at lower prices next season.
"I didn't mean to say the world was absolutely coming to an end," Mr. Iger said. "I mean to say it will, unless we get a lot of things in line."
